889331_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	Littelfuse, Inc. and its subsidiaries (the company or Littelfuse or we or our ) is the world s leading supplier of circuit protection products for the electronics industry, providing the broadest line of circuit protection solutions to worldwide customers.
889331_11_ITEM1_P0_S1	In the electronics market, the company supplies leading manufacturers such as Alcatel-Lucent, Apple, Cisco, Celestica, Delta, Flextronics, Foxconn, Hewlett-Packard, Huawei, IBM, Intel, Jabil, LG, Motorola, Nokia, Panasonic, Quanta, Samsung, Sanmina-SCI, Seagate, Siemens and Sony.
889331_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	The company is also the leading provider of circuit protection for the automotive industry and the third largest producer of electrical fuses in North America.
889331_11_ITEM1_P1_S1	In the automotive market, the company s end customers include major automotive manufacturers in North America, Europe and Asia such as BMW, Chrysler, Ford Motor Company, General Motors, Hyundai Group, and Volkswagen.
889331_11_ITEM1_P1_S2	The company also supplies wiring harness manufacturers and auto parts suppliers worldwide, including Advance Auto Parts, Continental, Delphi, Lear, Leoni, O Reilly Auto Parts, Pep Boys, Sumitomo, Valeo, and Yazaki.
889331_11_ITEM1_P1_S3	In the electrical market, the company supplies representative customers such as Abbott, Acuity Brands, Dow Chemical, DuPont, GE, General Motors, Heinz, International Paper, John Deere, SMA, First Solar, Samsung, Merck, Polan d Springs, Procter Gamble, Rockwell, United Technologies and 3M. Through the company s Electrical business, the company supplies industrial ground fault circuit protection in mining and other large industrial operations to customers such as Potash Corporation, Mosaic, Agrium, and Cameco.
889331_11_ITEM1_P1_S4	See Business Environment: Circuit Protection Market.
889331_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	The company reports its operations by three business unit segments: Electronics, Automotive, and Electrical.
889331_11_ITEM1_P2_S1	For segment and geographical information and consolidated net sales and operating earnings see Item 7.
889331_11_ITEM1_P2_S2	Management s Discussion And Analysis Of Financial Condition And Results Of Operations and Note 15 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statments included in this report.
889331_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	Net sales by business unit segment for the periods indicated are as follows (in thousands):
889331_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	The company operates in three geographic territories: the Americas, Europe, and Asia-Pacific.
889331_11_ITEM1_P4_S1	The company manufactures products and sells to customers in all three territories.
889331_11_ITEM1_P4_S2	There has been and continues to be a shift in the company s revenues, and consequently manufacturing, to the Asia-Pacific region.
889331_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	Net sales in the company s three geographic territories, based upon the shipped to destination, are as follows (in thousands):
889331_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	The company s products are sold worldwide through a direct sales force and manufacturers representatives.
889331_11_ITEM1_P6_S1	For the year ended January 1, 2011, approximately 69.1% of the company s net sales were to customers outside the United States (exports and foreign operations), including 18.9% in Hong Kong.
889331_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	The company manufactures many of its products on fully integrated manufacturing and assembly equipment.
889331_11_ITEM1_P7_S1	The company maintains product quality through a Global Quality Management System with most manufacturing sites certified under ISO 9001:2000.
889331_11_ITEM1_P7_S2	In addition, several of the Littelfuse manufacturing sites are also certified under TS 16949 and ISO 14001.
889331_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	References herein to 2010 or fiscal 2010 refer to the fiscal year ended January 1, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	References herein to 2009 or fiscal 2009 refer to the fiscal year ended January 2, 2010.
889331_11_ITEM1_P8_S2	References herein to 2008 or fiscal 2008 refer to the fiscal year ended December 27, 2008.
889331_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	The company operates on a 4-4-5 fiscal calendar that normally keeps the number of weeks constant during the quarter.
889331_11_ITEM1_P9_S1	As a result of using this convention, fiscal year 2009 contained 53 weeks whereas each of fiscal 2010 and fiscal 2008 contained 52 weeks.
889331_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	The company s annual report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and all amendments to those reports are available free of charge through the Investors section of the company s Internet web site (http://www.littelfuse.com), as soon as practicable after such material is electronically filed with, or furnished to, the Securities and Exchange Commission (the SEC ), accessible via a link to the web site maintained by the SEC.
889331_11_ITEM1_P10_S1	Except as otherwise provided herein, such information is not incorporated by reference into this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
889331_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	Electronic circuit protection products are used to protect circuits in a multitude of electronic systems.
889331_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	The company s product offering includes a complete line of overcurrent and overvoltage solutions, including (i) fuses and protectors, (ii) positive temperature coefficient ( PTC ) resettable fuses, (iii) varistors, (iv) polymer electrostatic discharge ( ESD ) suppressors, (v) discrete transient voltage suppression ( TVS ) diodes, TVS diode arrays and protection thyristors, (vi) gas discharge tubes, (vii) power switching components and (viii) fuseholders, blocks and related accessories.
889331_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	Electronic fuses and protectors are devices that contain an element that melts in an overcurrent condition.
889331_11_ITEM1_P13_S1	Electronic miniature and subminiature fuses are designed to provide circuit protection in the limited space requirements of electronic equipment.
889331_11_ITEM1_P13_S2	The company s fuses are used in a wide variety of electronic products, including wireless telephones, consumer electronics, computers, modems and telecommunications equipment.
889331_11_ITEM1_P13_S3	The company markets these products under the trademarked brand names PICO II and NANO2 SMF.
889331_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	Resettable fuses are PTC polymer devices that limit the current when an overcurrent condition exists and then reset themselves once the overcurrent condition has cleared.
889331_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	The company s product line offers both radial leaded and surface mount products.
889331_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	Varistors are ceramic-based, high-energy absorption devices that provide transient overvoltage and surge suppression for automotive, telecommunication, consumer electronics and industrial applications.
889331_11_ITEM1_P16_S1	The company s product line offers both radial leaded and multilayer surface mount products.
889331_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	Polymer ESD suppressors are polymer-based devices that protect an electronic system from failure due to rapid transfer of electrostatic charge to the circuit.
889331_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	The company s PulseGuard line of ESD suppressors is used in PC and PC peripherals, digital consumer electronics and wireless applications.
889331_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	Discrete diodes, diode arrays and protection thyristors are fast switching silicon semiconductor structures.
889331_11_ITEM1_P18_S1	Discrete diodes protect a wide variety of applications from overvoltage transients such as ESD, inductive load switching or lightning, while diode arrays are used primarily as ESD suppressors.
889331_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	Protection thyristors are commonly used to protect telecommunications circuits from overvoltage transients such as those resulting from lightning.
889331_11_ITEM1_P19_S1	Applications include telephones, modems, data transmission lines and alarm systems.
889331_11_ITEM1_P19_S2	The company markets these products under the following trademarked brand names: TECCOR , SIDACtor and Battrax .
889331_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	Gas discharge tubes are very low capacitance devices designed to suppress any transient voltage event that is greater than the breakover voltage of the device.
889331_11_ITEM1_P20_S1	These devices are primarily used in telecommunication interface and conversion equipment applications as protection from overvoltage transients such as lightning.
889331_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	Power switching components are used to regulate energy to various type loads most commonly found in industrial and home equipment.
889331_11_ITEM1_P21_S1	These components are easily activated from simple control circuits or interfaced to computers for more complex load control.
889331_11_ITEM1_P21_S2	Typical applications include heating, cooling, battery chargers and lighting.
889331_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	In addition to the above products, the company is also a supplier of fuse holders (including OMNI-BLOK ), fuse blocks and fuse clips primarily to customers that purchase circuit protection devices from the company.
889331_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	Fuses are extensively used in automobiles, trucks, buses and off-road equipment to protect electrical circuits and the wires that supply electrical power to operate lights, heating, air conditioning, radios, windows and other controls.
889331_11_ITEM1_P23_S1	Currently, a typical automobile contains 30 to 100 fuses, depending upon the options installed.
889331_11_ITEM1_P23_S2	The fuse content per vehicle is expected to continue to grow as more electronic features are included in automobiles.
889331_11_ITEM1_P23_S3	The company also supplies fuses for the protection of electric and hybrid vehicles.
889331_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	The company is a primary supplier of automotive fuses to United States, Asian and European automotive original equipment manufacturers ( OEM ), automotive component parts manufacturers and automotive parts distributors.
889331_11_ITEM1_P24_S1	The company also sells its fuses in the replacement parts market, with its products being sold through merchandisers, discount stores and service stations, as well as under private label by national firms.
889331_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	The company invented and owns most of the U.S. patents related to the blade-type fuse, which is the standard and most commonly used fuse in the automotive industry.
889331_11_ITEM1_P25_S1	The company s automotive fuse products are marketed under trademarked brand names, including ATO , MINI , MAXI , MIDI , MEGA , MasterFuse , JCASE and CablePro .
889331_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	A majority of the company s automotive fuse sales are made to main-fuse box and wire harness manufacturers that incorporate the fuses into their products.
889331_11_ITEM1_P26_S1	The remaining automotive fuse sales are made directly to automotive manufacturers, retailers who sell automotive parts and accessories, and distributors who in turn sell most of their products to wholesalers, service stations and non-automotive OEMs.
889331_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	The company entered the electrical market in 1983 and manufactures and sells a broad range of low-voltage and medium-voltage circuit protection products as well as protection relays to electrical distributors and their customers in the construction, OEM and industrial maintenance, repair and operating supplies ( MRO ) markets.
889331_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	Power fuses are used to protect circuits in various types of industrial equipment and in industrial and commercial buildings.
889331_11_ITEM1_P28_S1	They are rated and listed under one of many Underwriters Laboratories fuse classifications.
889331_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	Major applications for power fuses include protection from over-load and short-circuit currents in motor branch circuits, heating and cooling systems, control systems, lighting circuits and electrical distribution networks.
889331_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	The company s POWR-GARD product line features the Indicator series power fuse used in both the OEM and MRO markets.
889331_11_ITEM1_P30_S1	The Indicator technology provides visual blown-fuse indication at a glance, reducing maintenance and downtime on production equipment.
889331_11_ITEM1_P30_S2	The Indicator product offering is widely used in motor protection and industrial control panel applications.
889331_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	Protection relays are used to protect personnel and equipment in industrial environments and commercial buildings from excessive currents, over voltages and electrical shock hazards called ground-faults.
889331_11_ITEM1_P31_S1	Major applications for protection relays include protection of motor, transformer and power-line distribution circuits.
889331_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	Ground-fault relays are used to protect personnel and equipment in wet environments such as underground mining or water treatment applications where there is a greater risk for electricity to come in contact with water and create a shock hazard.
889331_11_ITEM1_P33_S0	The company employs scientific, engineering and other personnel to continually improve its existing product lines and to develop new products at its research and engineering facilities in Champaign and Chicago, Illinois, Boston, Massachusetts, Canada, China, Germany, the Philippines and Mexico.
889331_11_ITEM1_P33_S1	The Product Development Technology departments maintain a staff of engineers, chemists, material scientists and technicians whose primary responsibility is to design and develop new products.
889331_11_ITEM1_P34_S0	Proposals for the development of new products are initiated primarily by sales and marketing personnel with input from customers.
889331_11_ITEM1_P34_S1	The entire product development process usually ranges from a few months to 18 months based on the complexity of development, with continuous efforts to reduce the development cycle.
889331_11_ITEM1_P34_S2	During fiscal years 2010, 2009 and 2008, the company expended $17.6 million, $18.1 million and $24.1 million, respectively, on research, product design and development ( R D ).
889331_11_ITEM1_P34_S3	During 2010, the company completed moving R D operations to lower cost locations closer to its customers.
889331_11_ITEM1_P34_S4	R D operations are now in Canada, China, Germany, the Philippines and Mexico as well as the United States.
889331_11_ITEM1_P35_S0	The company generally relies on patent and trademark laws and license and nondisclosure agreements to protect intellectual property and proprietary products.
889331_11_ITEM1_P35_S1	In cases where it is deemed necessary by management, key employees are required to sign an agreement that they will maintain the confidentiality of the company s proprietary information and trade secrets.
889331_11_ITEM1_P36_S0	As of January 1, 2011, the company owned 223 patents in North America, 105 patents in the European Union and 135 patents in other foreign countries.
889331_11_ITEM1_P36_S1	The company also has registered trademark protection for certain of its brand names and logos.
889331_11_ITEM1_P36_S2	The 223 North American patents are in the following product categories: 138 electronics, 57 automotive and 28 electrical.
889331_11_ITEM1_P36_S3	Patents and licenses are amortized over a period of 4-12 years, with a weighted average life of 11.9 years.
889331_11_ITEM1_P36_S4	Distribution networks are amortized over a period of 4-20 years, with a weighted average life of 14.7 years.
889331_11_ITEM1_P36_S5	Trademarks and tradenames are amortized over a period of 5-20 years, with a weighted average life of 14.9 years.
889331_11_ITEM1_P36_S6	The company recorded amortization expense of $5.0 million, $5.0 million and $3.9 million in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively, relat ed to intangible assets.
889331_11_ITEM1_P37_S0	New products are continually being developed to replace older products.
889331_11_ITEM1_P37_S1	The company regularly applies for patent protection on such new products.
889331_11_ITEM1_P37_S2	Although, in the aggregate, the company s patents are important in the operation of its businesses, the company believes that the loss by expiration or otherwise of any one patent or group of patents would not materially affect its business.
889331_11_ITEM1_P38_S0	License royalties amounted to $0.2 million, $0.1 million and $0.2 million for fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively, and are included in other expense (income), net on the Consolidated Statements of Income.
889331_11_ITEM1_P39_S0	The company performs the majority of its own fabrication, stamps some of the metal components used in its fuses, holders and switches from raw metal stock and makes its own contacts and springs.
889331_11_ITEM1_P39_S1	In addition, the company fabricates silicon wafers for certain applications and performs its own plating (silver, nickel, zinc, tin and oxides).
889331_11_ITEM1_P39_S2	All thermoplastic molded component requirements used for such products as the ATO , MINI and MAXI fuse product lines are met through the company s in-house molding capabilities.
889331_11_ITEM1_P40_S0	After components are stamped, molded, plated and readied for assembly, final assembly is accomplished on fully automatic and semi-automatic assembly machines.
889331_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	Quality assurance and operations personnel, using techniques such as statistical process control, perform tests, checks and mea surements during the production process to maintain the highest levels of product quality and customer satisfaction.
889331_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	The principal raw materials for the company s products include copper and copper alloys, heat-resistant plastics, zinc, melamine, glass, silver, raw silicon, solder and various gases.
889331_11_ITEM1_P42_S1	The company uses a sole source for several heat-resistant plastics and for zinc, but believes that suitable alternative heat-resistant plastics and zinc are available from other sources at comparable prices.
889331_11_ITEM1_P42_S2	All of the other raw materials are purchased from a number of readily available outside sources.
889331_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	A computer-aided design and manufacturing system (CAD/CAM) expedites product development and machine design and the company s laboratories test new products, prototype concepts and production run samples.
889331_11_ITEM1_P43_S1	The company participates in just-in-time delivery programs with many of its major suppliers and actively promotes the building of strong cooperative relationships with its suppliers by utilizing early supplier involvement techniques and engaging them in pre-engineering product and process development.
889331_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	The company s domestic sales and marketing staff of over 35 people maintains relationships with major OEMs and distributors.
889331_11_ITEM1_P44_S1	The company s sales, marketing and engineering personnel interact directly with OEM engineers to ensure appropriate circuit protection and reliability within the parameters of the OEM s circuit design.
889331_11_ITEM1_P44_S2	Internationally, the company maintains a sales and marketing staff of over 100 people with sales offices in the U.K., Germany, Spain, Italy, Singapore, Taiwan, Japan, Brazil, Hong Kong, Korea, China and India.
889331_11_ITEM1_P44_S3	The company also markets its products indirectly through a worldwide organization of over 60 manufacturers representatives and distributes through an extensive network of electronics, automotive and electr ical distributors.
889331_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	The company uses manufacturers representatives to sell its electronics products domestically and to call on major domestic and international OEMs and distributors.
889331_11_ITEM1_P45_S1	The company sells approximately 15% of its domestic products directly to OEMs, with the remainder sold through distributors nationwide.
889331_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	In the Asia-Pacific region, the company maintains a direct sales staff and utilizes distributors in Japan, Singapore, Korea, Taiwan, China, Malaysia, Thailand, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Philippines, New Zealand and Australia.
889331_11_ITEM1_P46_S1	In Europe, the company maintains a direct sales force and utilizes manufacturers representatives and distributors to support a wide array of customers.
889331_11_ITEM1_P47_S0	The company maintains a direct sales force to service all the major automotive OEMs and system suppliers domestically.
889331_11_ITEM1_P47_S1	Approximately 23 manufacturers representatives sell the company s products to aftermarket fuse retailers such as O Reilly Auto Parts and Pep Boys.
889331_11_ITEM1_P47_S2	In Europe, the company uses both a direct sales force and manufacturers representatives to distribute its products to OEMs, major system suppliers and aftermarket distributors.
889331_11_ITEM1_P47_S3	In the Asia-Pacific region, the company uses both a direct sales force and distributors to supply to major OEMs and system suppliers.
889331_11_ITEM1_P48_S0	The company markets and sells its power fuses and protection relays through approximately 38 manufacturers representatives across North America.
889331_11_ITEM1_P48_S1	These representatives sell power fuse products through an electrical and industrial distribution network comprised of approximately 2,000 distributor buying locations.
889331_11_ITEM1_P48_S2	These distributors have customers that include electrical contractors, municipalities, utilities and factories (including both MRO and OEM).
889331_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	The company s field sales force (including regional sales managers and application engineers) and manufacturers representatives call on both distributors and end-users (consulting engineers, municipalities, utilities and OEMs) in an effort to educate these customers on the capabilities and characteristics of the company s products.
889331_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	The company has three operating business unit segments: Electronics, Automotive and Electrical.
889331_11_ITEM1_P50_S1	For information with respect to the company s operations in its three reportable business unit segments for the fiscal year ended January 1, 2011, see Business Unit Segment Information included as part of Item 8.
889331_11_ITEM1_P50_S2	Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, which is incorporated herein by reference.
889331_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	The company sells to approximately 4,000 direct customers worldwide.
889331_11_ITEM1_P51_S1	Sales to Arrow Pemco were 10.4% in 2010 but less than 10% for 2009 and 2008.
889331_11_ITEM1_P51_S2	No other single customer accounted for more than 10% of net sales during the last three years.
889331_11_ITEM1_P51_S3	During fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008, net sales to customers outside the United States (exports and foreign operations) accounted for approximately 69.1%, 67.5% and 62.0%, respectively, of the company s total net sales.
889331_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	The company s products compete with similar products of other manufacturers, some of which have substantially greater financial resources than the company.
889331_11_ITEM1_P52_S1	In the electronics market, the company s competitors include AVX, Bel Fuse, Bourns, Cooper Industries, EPCOS, On Semiconductor, STMicroelectronics and Tyco Electronics.
889331_11_ITEM1_P52_S2	In the automotive market, the company s competitors include Cooper Industries, Pacific Engineering (a private company in Japan) and MTA (a private company in Italy).
889331_11_ITEM1_P52_S3	In the electrical market, the company s major competitors include Cooper Industries and Ferraz Shawmut.
889331_11_ITEM1_P52_S4	The company believes that it competes on the basis of innovative products, the breadth of its product line, the quality and design of its products and the responsiveness of its customer service, in addition to price.
889331_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	The backlog of unfilled orders at January 1, 2011, was approximately $107.5 million, compared to $59.0 million at January 2, 2010.
889331_11_ITEM1_P53_S1	Substantially all of the orders currently in backlog are scheduled for delivery in 2011.
889331_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	As of January 1, 2011, the company employed approximately 6,000 employees worldwide.
889331_11_ITEM1_P54_S1	Approximately 750 employees in Mexico and 28 employees in Germany are covered by collective bargaining agreements.
889331_11_ITEM1_P54_S2	The Mexico collective bargaining agreement, covering employees in Piedras Negras, expires January 31, 2012.
889331_11_ITEM1_P54_S3	During 2010, a collective bargaining agreement covering approximately 160 employees at the company s Matamoros, Mexico facility was terminated as a result of plant closure.
889331_11_ITEM1_P55_S0	In Germany the company has two separate collective bargaining agreements, one for 24 employees in D nsen, expiring June 30, 2011, and the second for 4 employees in Essen, expiring March 31, 2012.
889331_11_ITEM1_P56_S0	Previously in 2009 a collective bargaining agreement covered approximately 30 employees at the company s Des Plaines, Illinois facility.
889331_11_ITEM1_P56_S1	This agreement expired on March 31, 2009 and currently no U.S.-based employees are subject to a collective bargaining agreement.
889331_11_ITEM1_P57_S0	Approximately 13% of the company's total workforce are employed under collective bargaining agreements at January 1, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM1_P57_S1	Those employees covered by a collective bargaining agreement that will expire within one year of January 1, 2011 approximate less than 1% of the company's total workforce.
889331_11_ITEM1_P58_S0	Overall, the company has historically maintained satisfactory employee relations, and many of its employees have long service with the company.
889331_11_ITEM1_P59_S0	The company is subject to numerous foreign, federal, state and local regulations relating to air and water quality, the disposal of hazardous waste materials, safety and health.
889331_11_ITEM1_P59_S1	Compliance with applicable environmental regulations has not significantly changed the company s competitive position, capital spending or earnings in the past and the company does not presently anticipate that compliance with such regulations will change its competitive position, capital spending or earnings for the foreseeable future.
889331_11_ITEM1_P60_S0	The company employs an environmental engineer to monitor regulatory matters and believes that it is currently in compliance in all material respects with applicable environmental laws and regulations, except with respect to its facilities located in Ireland.
889331_11_ITEM1_P61_S0	The Ireland facility was acquired in October 1999 in connection with the acquisition from Harris Corporation of its suppression products division.
889331_11_ITEM1_P61_S1	Certain containment actions have been ongoing and full disclosure with appropriate agencies in Ireland has been initiated.
889331_11_ITEM1_P61_S2	The company received an indemnity from Harris Corporation with respect to these matters.
889331_11_ITEM1_P62_S0	Littelfuse GmbH, which was acquired by the company in May 2004, is responsible for maintaining closed coal mines from legacy acquisitions.
889331_11_ITEM1_P62_S1	The company is compliant with German regulations pertaining to the maintenance of the mines and has an accrual related to certain of these coal mine shafts based on an engineering study estimating the cost of remediating the dangers (such as a shaft collapse) of certain of these closed coal mine shafts in Germany.
889331_11_ITEM1_P62_S2	The reserve is reviewed annually and calculated based upon the cost of remediating the shafts that the study deems most risky.
889331_11_ITEM1_P62_S3	Further information regarding the coal mine liability reserve is provided in Note 10 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Our business, financial condition and results of operations are subject to various risks and uncertainties, including the risk factors we have identified below.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	These factors are not necessarily listed in order of importance.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P0_S2	We may amend or supplement the risk factors from time to time by other reports that we file with the SEC in the future.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Our industry is subject to intense competitive pressures.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We operate in markets that are highly competitive.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	We compete on the basis of price, quality, service and/or brand name across the industries and markets we serve.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Competitive pressures could affect the prices we are able to charge our customers or the demand for our products.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We may not always be able to compete on price, particularly when compared to manufacturers with lower cost structures.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Some of our competitors have substantially greater sales, financial and manufacturing resources and may have greater access to capital than Littelfuse.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P3_S2	As other companies enter our markets or develop new products, competition may intensify further.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Our failure to compete effectively could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	We may be unable to manufacture and deliver products in a manner that is responsive to our customers needs.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	The end markets for our products are characterized by technological change, frequent new product introductions and enhancements, changes in customer requirements and emerging industry standards.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P5_S1	The introduction of products embodying new technologies and the emergence of new industry standards could render our existing products obsolete and unmarketable before we can recover any or all of our research, development and commercialization expenses on capital investments.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Furthermore, the life cycles of our products may change and are difficult to estimate.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our future success will depend upon our ability to manufacture and deliver products in a manner that is responsive to our customers needs.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	We will need to develop and introduce new products and product enhancements on a timely basis that keep pace with technological developments and emerging industry standards and address increasingly sophisticated requirements of our customers.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P6_S2	We invest heavily in research and development without knowing that we will recover these costs.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Our competitors may develop products or technologies that will render our products non-competitive or obsolete.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P6_S4	If we cannot develop and market new products or product enhancements in a timely and cost-effective manner, our business, financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Our business may be interrupted by labor disputes or other interruptions of supplies.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	A work stoppage could occur at certain of our facilities, most likely as a result of disputes under collective bargaining agreements or in connection with negotiations of new collective bargaining agreements.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P8_S1	In addition, we may experience a shortage of supplies for various reasons, such as financial distress, work stoppages, natural disasters or production difficulties that may affect one of our suppliers.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P8_S2	A significant work stoppage, or an interruption or shortage of supplies for any reason, if protracted, could substantially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P8_S3	The transfer of our manufacturing operations and changes in our distribution model could disrupt operations for a limited time.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Our revenues may vary significantly from period to period.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our revenues may vary significantly from one accounting period to another due to a variety of factors including:
889331_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The bankruptcy or insolvency of a major customer could adversely affect us.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	The bankruptcy or insolvency of a major customer could result in lower sales revenue and cause a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P12_S1	In addition, the bankruptcy or insolvency of a major U.S. auto manufacturer or significant supplier likely could lead to substantial disruptions in the automotive supply base, resulting in lower demand for our products, which likely would cause a decrease in sales revenue and have a substantial adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Our ability to manage currency or commodity price fluctuations or shortages is limited.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	As a resource-intensive manufacturing operation, we are exposed to a variety of market and asset risks, including the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates, commodity prices and interest rates.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P14_S1	We have multiple sources of supply for the majority of our commodity requirements.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P14_S2	However, significant shortages that disrupt the supply of raw materials or result in price increases could affect prices we charge our customers, our product costs, and the competitive position of our products and services.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P14_S3	We monitor and manage these exposures as an integral part of our overall risk management program, which recognizes the unpredictability of markets and seeks to reduce the potentially adverse effects on our results.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P14_S4	Nevertheless, changes in currency exchange rates, commodity prices and interest rates cannot alw ays be predicted.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P14_S5	In addition, because of intense price competition and our high level of fixed costs, we may not be able to address such changes even if they are foreseeable.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P14_S6	Substantial changes in these rates and prices could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P14_S7	For additional discussion of interest rate, currency or commodity price risk, see "Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Operations and supply sources located outside the United States, particularly in emerging markets, are subject to greater risks.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Our operating activities outside the United States contribute significantly to our revenues and earnings.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P16_S1	Serving a global customer base and remaining competitive in the global marketplace requires the company to place our production in countries outside the United States, including emerging markets, to capitalize on market opportunities and maintain a cost-efficient structure.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P16_S2	In addition, we source a significant amount of raw materials and other components from third-party suppliers in low-cost countries.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Our international operating activities are subject to a number of risks generally associated with international operations, including risks relating to the following:
889331_11_ITEM1A_P18_S0	limitations on our ability to enforce legal rights and remedies.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Any of these factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We are in the process of relocating our manufacturing operations and changing our distribution and customer service model.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P21_S0	We are a company that, from time to time, seeks to optimize its manufacturing capabilities and efficiencies through restructurings, consolidations, plant closings or asset sales.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P21_S1	We may make further specific determinations to consolidate, close or sell additional facilities.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P21_S2	Possible adverse consequences related to such actions may include various charges for such items as idle capacity, disposition costs, severance costs, impairments of goodwill and possibly an immediate loss of revenues, in addition to normal or attendant risks and uncertainties.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P21_S3	We may be unsuccessful in any of our current or future efforts to restructure or consolidate our business.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P21_S4	Our plans to minimize or eliminate any loss of revenues during restructuring or consolidation may not be achieved.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P21_S5	These activities may have a material adverse effect upon our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P22_S0	We engage in acquisitions and may encounter difficulties in integrating these businesses.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P23_S0	We are a company that, from time to time, seeks to grow through strategic acquisitions.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P23_S1	We have in the past acquired a number of businesses or companies and additional product lines and assets.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P23_S2	We intend to continue to expand and diversify our operations with additional acquisitions.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P23_S3	The success of these transactions depends on our ability to integrate the assets and personnel acquired in these acquisitions.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P23_S4	We may encounter difficulties in integrating acquisitions with our operations and may not realize the degree or timing of the benefits that we anticipated from an acquisition.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Environmental liabilities could adversely impact our financial position.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Federal, state and local laws and regulations impose various restrictions and controls on the discharge of materials, chemicals and gases used in our manufacturing processes or in our finished goods.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P25_S1	These environmental regulations have required us to expend a portion of our resources and capital on relevant compliance programs.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Under these laws and regulations, we could be held financially responsible for remedial measures if our current or former properties are contaminated or if we send waste to a landfill or recycling facility that becomes contaminated, even if we did not cause the contamination.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P25_S3	We may be subject to additional common law claims if we release substances that damage or harm third parties.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P25_S4	In addition, future changes in environmental laws or regulations may require additional investments in capital equipment or the implementation of additional compliance programs.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P25_S5	Any failure to comply with new or existing environmental laws or regulations could subject us to significant liabilities and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P26_S0	In the conduct of our manufacturing operations, we have handled and do handle materials that are considered hazardous, toxic or volatile under federal, state and local laws.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P26_S1	The risk of accidental release of such materials cannot be completely eliminated.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P27_S0	In addition, we operate or own facilities located on or near real property that was formerly owned and operated by others.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P27_S1	Certain of these properties were used in ways that involved hazardous materials.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Contaminants may migrate from, within or through these properties.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P27_S3	These releases or migrations may give rise to claims.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Where third parties are responsible for contamination, the third parties may not have funds, or not make funds available when needed, to pay remediation costs imposed upon us under environmental laws and regulations.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P29_S0	The company is responsible for the maintenance of discontinued coal mining operations in Germany.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P29_S1	To date there have been no claims by any regulatory agency that would require the company to incur regulatory environmental remediation.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P29_S2	The risk of environmental remediation exists and the company is in the process of remediating the mines considered to be the most at risk.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P30_S0	We derive a substantial portion of our revenues from customers in the automotive, consumer electronics and communications industries, and we are susceptible to trends and factors affecting those industries as well as the success of our customers products.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Net sales to the automotive, consumer electronics and communications industries represent a substantial portion of our revenues.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P31_S1	Factors negatively affecting these industries and the demand for products also negatively affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P31_S2	Any adverse occurrence, including industry slowdown, recession, political instability, costly or constraining regulations, armed hostilities, terrorism, excessive inflation, prolonged disruptions in one or more of our customers production schedules or labor disturbances, that results in significant decline in the volume of sales in these industries, or in an overall downturn in the business and operations of our customers in these industries, could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operat ions.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P31_S3	For example, the automotive industry as well as the consumer electronics market is highly cyclical in nature and sensitive to changes in general economic conditions, consumer preferences and interest rates.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P31_S4	In addition, the global automotive and electronic industries have overall manufacturing capacity far exceeding demand.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P31_S5	To the extent that demand for certain of our customers products declines, the demand for our products may decline.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P31_S6	Reduced demand relating to general economic conditions, consumer preferences, interest rates or industry over-capacity may have a material adverse effect upon our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P32_S0	The inability to maintain access to capital markets may adversely affect our business and financial results.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Our ability to invest in our businesses, make strategic acquisitions and refinance maturing debt obligations may require access to the capital markets and sufficient bank credit lines to support short-term borrowings.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P33_S1	If we are unable to access the capital markets or bank credit facilities, we could experience a material adverse affect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Fixed costs may reduce operating results if our sales fall below expectations.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P35_S0	Our expense levels are based, in part, on our expectations for future sales.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P35_S1	Many of our expenses, particularly those relating to capital equipment and manufacturing overhead, are relatively fixed.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P35_S2	We might be unable to reduce spending quickly enough to compensate for reductions in sales.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P35_S3	Accordingly, shortfalls in sales could materially and adversely affect our operating results.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P36_S0	The volatility of our stock price could affect the value of an investment in our stock and our future financial position.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P37_S0	The market price of our stock has fluctuated widely.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P37_S1	Between January 2, 2010 and January 1, 2011, the closing sale price of our common stock ranged between a low of $28.96 and a high of $48.75, experiencing greater volatility over that time than the broader markets.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P37_S2	The volatility of our stock price may be related to any number of factors, such as general economic conditions, industry conditions, analysts expectations concerning our results of operations, or the volatility of our revenues as discussed above under Our Revenues May Vary Significantly from Period to Period.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P37_S3	The historic market price of our common stock may not be indicative of future market prices.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P37_S4	We may not be able to sustain or increase the value of our common stock.
889331_11_ITEM1A_P37_S5	Declines in the market price of our stock could adversely affec t our ability to retain personnel with stock incentives, to acquire businesses or assets in exchange for stock and/or to conduct future financing activities with or involving our common stock.
889331_11_ITEM2_P0_S0	The company s operations are located in 39 owned or leased facilities worldwide, representing an aggregate of 1,420,338 square feet.
889331_11_ITEM2_P0_S1	The company s corporate headquarters is located in the U.S. in Chicago, Illinois.
889331_11_ITEM2_P0_S2	The company has North American manufacturing facilities in Saskatoon, Canada, Piedras Negras, Mexico and Melchor Muzquiz, Mexico.
889331_11_ITEM2_P0_S3	The manufacturing facilities previously located in Irving, Texas and Matamoros, Mexico were closed in 2010.
889331_11_ITEM2_P0_S4	During 2010, the European headquarters and the primary European distribution center, previously located in Utrecht, the Netherlands, until the property was sold in 2010, were relocated to D nsen, Germany.
889331_11_ITEM2_P0_S5	A manufacturing plant currently located in D nsen, Germany is expected to close in 2011.
889331_11_ITEM2_P0_S6	The company is currently marketing for sale its Des Plaines, Illinois, property and Dundalk, Ireland, facility, both of which closed during fiscal year 2009.
889331_11_ITEM2_P0_S7	The Des Plaines building was demolished in 2010 to facilitate the sale of the underlying property.
889331_11_ITEM2_P1_S0	Asia-Pacific operations include sales and distribution centers located in Singapore, Taiwan, Japan, China and Korea, with manufacturing plants in China, Taiwan and the Philippines.
889331_11_ITEM2_P1_S1	The manufacturing plant in Taiwan is expected to close in 2011.
889331_11_ITEM2_P1_S2	The company does not believe that it will encounter any difficulty in renewing its existing leases upon the expiration of their current terms.
889331_11_ITEM2_P1_S3	Management believes that the company s facilities are adequate to meet its requirements for the foreseeable future.

889331_11_ITEM6_P0_S0	The information presented below provides selected financial data of the company during the past five fiscal years and should be read in conjunction with Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and the Consolidated Financial Statements and Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Item 7 and Item 8, respectively, for the respective years presented (amounts in thousands, except per share data):

889331_11_ITEM7_P0_S0	Littelfuse, Inc. and its subsidiaries (the company or Littelfuse ) design, manufacture, and sell circuit protection devices for use in the electronics, automotive and electrical markets throughout the world.
889331_11_ITEM7_P1_S0	The following Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations ( MD A ) is designed to provide the reader with information that will assist in understanding the company s Consolidated Financial Statements, the changes in certain key items in those financial statements from year to year, and the primary factors that accounted for those changes, as well as how certain accounting principles affect the Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM7_P1_S1	The discussion also provides information about the financial results of the various busines s segments to provide a better understanding of how those segments and their results affect the financial condition and results of operations of Littelfuse as a whole.
889331_11_ITEM7_P2_S0	U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) dictates annual and interim reporting standards for an enterprise's operating segments and related disclosures about its products, services, geographic areas and major customers.
889331_11_ITEM7_P2_S1	Within U.S. GAAP, an operating segment is defined as a component of an enterprise that engages in business activities from which it may earn revenues and incur expenses, and about which separate financial information is regularly evaluated by the Chief Operating Decision Maker ( CODM ) in deciding how to allocate resources.
889331_11_ITEM7_P2_S2	The CODM is the company s President and Chief Executive Officer.
889331_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	The company reports its operations by three business unit segments: Electronics, Automotive and Electrical.
889331_11_ITEM7_P3_S1	The following table is a summary of the company s operating segments net sales by business unit and geography (in thousands):
889331_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	Business unit segment information is described more fully in Note 15 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	The following discussion provides an analysis of the information contained in the Consolidated Financial Statements and accompanying notes beginning on page 40 at January 1, 2011 and January 2, 2010, and for the three fiscal years ended January 1, 2011, January 2, 2010 and December 27, 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	Net sales increased in the current year to $608.0 million compared to $430.1 million in 2009 reflecting strong growth in all market segments and geographies.
889331_11_ITEM7_P6_S1	The Automotive business segment sales increased $31.8 million or 32% to $130.3 million.
889331_11_ITEM7_P6_S2	The Electronics business segment sales increased $126.9 million or 48% to $389.9 million, and the Electrical business segment sales increased $19.2 million or 28% to $87.8 million.
889331_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	Sales levels were negatively impacted in 2009 due to the sharp downturn in the global economy and credit crisis.
889331_11_ITEM7_P7_S1	The strong revenue growth in 2010 was the result of the global economic recovery, distributor inventory replenishment and effective execution of the company s strategic growth plans.
889331_11_ITEM7_P7_S2	The company experienced $1.4 million in favorable currency effects in 2010 as compared to 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P7_S3	Thi s favorable impact resulted primarily from sales denominated in the Canadian dollar, Japanese yen and Korean won and were offset by the unfavorable impact of sales denominated in euros.
889331_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	The increase in Automotive sales was due to continued growth in Asian demand for passenger vehicles and recovery in the North American and European passenger vehicle and off-road truck and bus markets.
889331_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	The positive impact from increases in sales volume in 2010 was partially offset by unfavorable currency effects of $1.9 million mainly due to the weaker euro.
889331_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	The increase in Electronics sales reflected stronger demand and distributor inventory replenishment in all three geographic regions as well as successful new product introductions and other market share gains.
889331_11_ITEM7_P9_S1	The positive impact from an increase in volume was offset by net unfavorable currency effects of $0.3 million largely due to the weakness of the euro, partially offset by the favorable impact of a stronger Japanese yen and Korean won.
889331_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	The increase in Electrical sales was due to continued strong growth for protection relays and custom products driven primarily by strength in the potash mining market.
889331_11_ITEM7_P10_S1	Additionally, electrical fuse products realized steady improvement in demand as the industrial market continued to recover in 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P10_S2	The Electrical segment experienced net favorable currency effects of $3.6 million primarily from sales denominated in the Canadian dollar.
889331_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	On a geographic basis, sales in the Americas increased $61.6 million or 37% in 2010 compared to 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P11_S1	This increase resulted from increases at all three of the company s business segments.
889331_11_ITEM7_P11_S2	Automotive sales increased $8.1 million or 23% primarily reflecting recovery in the passenger vehicle market.
889331_11_ITEM7_P11_S3	Electronics sales increased $35.3 million or 55% reflecting strong end market demand and distributor restocking.
889331_11_ITEM7_P11_S4	Electrical sales increased $18.2 million or 27% resulting from an increase in demand for protection relays, custom products and power fuses.
889331_11_ITEM7_P11_S5	The Americas region also experienced $3.6 million in favorable currency effects resulting from sales denominated in the Canadian dollar.
889331_11_ITEM7_P12_S0	Europe sales increased $31.7 million or 38% in 2010 compared to 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P12_S1	This increase resulted from increases at all three of the company s business segments.
889331_11_ITEM7_P12_S2	Automotive sales increased $13.4 million or 29% reflecting strong end market demand and increased production resulting from the economic recovery in Europe during 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P12_S3	Electronics sales increased $18.0 million or 48% reflecting strong end market demand and distributor inventory replenishment.
889331_11_ITEM7_P12_S4	Current year results included unfavorable currency effects of $5.6 million, reflecting a weaker euro in 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P13_S0	Asia-Pacific sales increased $84.6 million or 47% in 2010 compared to 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P13_S1	This increase resulted from increases at all three of the company s business segments.
889331_11_ITEM7_P13_S2	Automotive sales increased $10.4 million or 59% reflecting continued increased demand for passenger vehicles in the developing Asian markets as well as gains in market share.
889331_11_ITEM7_P13_S3	Electronics sales increased $73.6 million or 46% primarily reflecting growth in demand for consumer products and restocking by distributors.
889331_11_ITEM7_P13_S4	Electrical sales increased $0.6 million or 41%.
889331_11_ITEM7_P13_S5	Current year results included favorable currency translation effects of $3.2 million primarily due to the impact of a stronger Japanese yen and Korean won.
889331_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	Gross profit was $233.9 million or 38.5% of sales in 2010, compared to $125.4 million or 29.1% of sales in 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P14_S1	The increase in gross profit margin percentage in 2010 resulted from operating leverage on higher sales, an improved cost structure due to consolidation of manufacturing facilities and the impact of restructuring activities in 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P14_S2	The company recorded approximately $4.2 million of restructuring charges in cost of sales in 2009 due primarily to the reorganization of the company s European and Asian operations.
889331_11_ITEM7_P14_S3	The European restructuring charges included the transfer of its manufacturing operations from D nsen, Germany, to Piedras Negras, Mexico.
889331_11_ITEM7_P14_S4	The Asian restructuring included the planned closure of a manufacturing facility in Taiwan.
889331_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	The company continues to focus heavily on research and development (R D) to develop new solutions for customers and expand product offerings.
889331_11_ITEM7_P15_S1	During 2010, the company continued moving R D operations to lower cost locations closer to its customers.
889331_11_ITEM7_P15_S2	R D operations are now in Canada, China, Germany, the Philippines and Mexico, as well as the United States.
889331_11_ITEM7_P16_S0	Total operating expense was $126.3 million or 20.8% of net sales for 2010 compared to $111.7 million or 26.0% of net sales for 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P16_S1	The increase in operating expenses primarily reflects the increased cost of company incentive programs driven by significantly improved financial performance in 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P16_S2	Higher transportation costs driven by higher sales volumes also contributed to the increase in operating expenses.
889331_11_ITEM7_P16_S3	Operating expenses as a percentage of sales improved in 2010 as compared to 2009 as a result of cost reduction plans initiated in 2009 resulting in improved operating efficiencies across the company.
889331_11_ITEM7_P17_S0	Operating income was $107.6 million or 17.7% of net sales in 2010 compared to $13.7 million or 3.2% of net sales in the prior year.
889331_11_ITEM7_P17_S1	The increase in operating income in the current year was due primarily to the increase in sales and reduction in costs as described above.
889331_11_ITEM7_P18_S0	Interest expense, net, decreased to $1.4 million in 2010 compared to $2.4 million for 2009 primarily due to lower borrowing in 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P19_S0	Other expense (income), net, consisting of interest income, royalties, non-operating income and foreign currency items, was $1.5 million of income in 2010 compared to $0.5 million of expense in 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P19_S1	The increase reflected a favorable net change of approximately $1.3 million in foreign currency translation effects primarily due to the strengthening of the Philippine peso and Mexican peso against the U.S. dollar.
889331_11_ITEM7_P20_S0	Income before income taxes was $107.7 million in 2010 compared to $10.8 million in 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P20_S1	Income tax expense was $29.0 million in 2010 compared to $1.4 million in 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P20_S2	The 2010 effective income tax rate was 27.0% compared to 13.2% in 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P20_S3	The increase in the 2010 effective tax rate reflects more income earned in high tax jurisdictions in 2010 (primarily the U.S.) as well as the favorable effects of one-time tax adjustments in 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P21_S0	Net sales decreased in 2009 to $430.1 million compared to $530.9 million in 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P21_S1	These results reflected sales declines in the Automotive segment of $28.4 million or 22% to $98.5 million, along with a decrease in sales in the Electronics segment of $79.5 million or 23% to $263.0 million, partially offset by an increase in sales in the Electrical segment of $7.1 million or 12% to $68.6 million.
889331_11_ITEM7_P21_S2	The Electrical segment sales included a full year of sales ($23.7 million) in 2009 from the acquisition of Startco Engineering Ltd. ( Startco ), which was acquired in the fourth quarter of 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P22_S0	The decrease in Automotive sales was due primarily to the continued weak passenger car and truck markets across all geographies, resulting in sharp declines in global vehicle production, as OEMs had extended plant shutdowns.
889331_11_ITEM7_P22_S1	The negative impact from declines in volume was further impacted by unfavorable currency effects of $2.6 million in 2009, mainly due to the weaker euro.
889331_11_ITEM7_P23_S0	The decrease in Electronics sales primarily reflected continued weak demand as consumers continued to lose confidence in the economy and cut back on spending, particularly in the consumer electronics market.
889331_11_ITEM7_P23_S1	In addition, many customers in Asia, particularly contract manufacturers and original design manufacturers, had extensive plant shutdowns, and electronics distributors reduced inventories in response to weak demand.
889331_11_ITEM7_P24_S0	During the second half of 2009, demand for some consumer electronic items began to improve resulting in increased demand for the company s products.
889331_11_ITEM7_P24_S1	The negative impact from declines in volume was further impacted by net unfavorable currency effects of $1.5 million largely due to the weakness of the euro and Korean won, partially offset by the favorable impact of a stronger Japanese yen.
889331_11_ITEM7_P25_S0	The increase in Electrical sales was due to incremental sales recorded in 2009 of $23.7 million from Startco, acquired at the beginning of the fourth quarter of 2008, as compared to $3.9 million in sales recorded in 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P25_S1	The base electrical business, which excludes Startco, declined 22% in 2009 as compared to 2008 due primarily to weakness in the non-residential construction and MRO markets.
889331_11_ITEM7_P26_S0	On a geographic basis, sales in the Americas decreased $35.7 million or 18% in 2009 compared to 2008 due to decreased Automotive sales of $15.9 million and lower Electronics sales of $25.9 million, partially offset by increased Electrical sales of $6.1 million, which included Startco.
889331_11_ITEM7_P26_S1	Automotive and Electronics sales declined due to the impact of the global recession and inventory de-stocking throughout the supply chain.
889331_11_ITEM7_P26_S2	The Electrical sales increase was due to incremental sales from the company s Startco acquisition.
889331_11_ITEM7_P27_S0	Europe sales decreased $35.2 million or 30% in 2009 compared to 2008 due to decreased Automotive sales of $17.5 million and lower Electronics sales of $17.7 million due to the impact of the global recession and inventory de-stocking throughout the supply chain.
889331_11_ITEM7_P27_S1	Current year results included unfavorable currency effects of $3.4 million, reflecting a weaker euro in 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P28_S0	Asia-Pacific sales decreased $29.9 million or 14% in 2009 compared to the prior year mainly due to lower Electronics sales of $36.0 million, which was partially offset by higher Automotive sales of $5.1 million and Electrical sales $1.0 million.
889331_11_ITEM7_P28_S1	The weaker Electronics sales reflected the impact of the global recession and inventory de-stocking throughout the supply chain.
889331_11_ITEM7_P28_S2	The increase in Automotive sales reflected strong growth in the China market and gains in market share.
889331_11_ITEM7_P28_S3	Current year results included unfavorable currency translation effects of $0.7 million primarily due to a sharp decline in the Korean won partially offset by a favorable impact of a stronger Japanese yen.
889331_11_ITEM7_P29_S0	Gross profit was $125.4 million or 29.1% of sales in 2009, compared to $143.7 million or 27.1% of sales in 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P29_S1	The increase in gross profit margin percentage in 2009 primarily resulted from cost savings related to manufacturing plant consolidations and reductions in operating expenses.
889331_11_ITEM7_P29_S2	Higher restructuring and other costs related to plant transfer activities and a pension settlement charge of $5.7 million during 2008 also contributed to the margin improvement change in 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P30_S0	The company recorded approximately $4.2 million of restructuring charges in cost of sales in 2009 due primarily to the reorganization of the company s European and Asian operations.
889331_11_ITEM7_P30_S1	The European restructuring charges included the transfer of its manufacturing operations from D nsen, Germany, to Piedras Negras, Mexico.
889331_11_ITEM7_P30_S2	The Asian restructuring included the planned closure of a manufacturing facility in Taiwan.
889331_11_ITEM7_P30_S3	The 2009 restructuring charges to cost of sales were approximately $4.6 million lower than restructuring charges to cost of sales for 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P31_S0	Total operating expense was $111.7 million or 26.0% of net sales for 2009 compared to $135.2 million or 25.5% of net sales for 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P31_S1	The reduction in operating expenses primarily reflects cost savings initiatives implemented in late 2008 and early 2009 including headcount reductions, consolidation of Asian and European sites and transfer of certain activities to low-cost Asian locations.
889331_11_ITEM7_P32_S0	Operating income was $13.7 million or 3.2% of net sales in 2009 compared to $8.5 million or 1.6% of net sales in the prior year.
889331_11_ITEM7_P32_S1	The increase in operating income in the current year was due primarily to the cost reductions and lower restructuring charges described above partially offset by lower sales.
889331_11_ITEM7_P33_S0	Interest expense, net, decreased to $2.4 million in 2009 compared to $3.4 million for 2008 primarily due to a $1.1 million loss on an interest rate swap transaction recognized in 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P34_S0	Other expense (income), net, consisting of interest income, royalties, non-operating income and foreign currency items, was $0.5 million of expense in 2009 compared to $5.6 million of income in 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P34_S1	The decrease primarily reflected an unfavorable net change of approximately $3.8 million in foreign currency translation effects (primarily due to the weakening of the Korean won against the U.S. dollar) and a $1.1 million refund received in 2008 related to a recovery of Japanese output taxes paid in 2007.
889331_11_ITEM7_P35_S0	Income before income taxes was $10.8 million in 2009 compared to $10.6 million in 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P35_S1	Income tax expense was $1.4 million in 2009 compared to $2.6 million in 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P35_S2	The 2009 effective income tax rate was 13.2% compared to 24.5% in 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P35_S3	The decrease in the 2009 effective tax rate reflects the mix of income earned in lower tax jurisdictions in 2009 as well as the release of $2.6 million of contingent income tax reserves due to the lapsing of statute of limitations and the close-out of open audit years by local tax authorities.
889331_11_ITEM7_P36_S0	The company historically has financed capital expenditures through cash flows from operations.
889331_11_ITEM7_P36_S1	Management expects that cash flows from operations and available lines of credit will be sufficient to support both the company s operations and its debt obligations for the foreseeable future.
889331_11_ITEM7_P37_S0	On September 29, 2008, the company entered into a Loan Agreement with various lenders that provides the company with a five-year term loan facility of up to $80.0 million for the purposes of (i) refinancing certain existing indebtedness; (ii) funding working capital needs; and (iii) funding capital expenditures and other lawful corporate purposes, including permitted acquisitions.
889331_11_ITEM7_P37_S1	The Loan Agreement also contains an expansion feature, pursuant to which the company may from time to time request incremental loans in an aggregate principal amount not to exceed $40.0 million.
889331_11_ITEM7_P37_S2	The company had $49.0 million outstanding at January 1, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM7_P37_S3	Further information regarding this arrangement is provided in Note 6 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_11_ITEM7_P38_S0	The Loan Agreement requires the company to meet certain financial tests, including a consolidated leverage ratio and a consolidated interest coverage ratio.
889331_11_ITEM7_P38_S1	The Loan Agreement also contains additional affirmative and negative covenants which, among other things, impose certain limitations on the company s ability to merge with other companies, create liens on its property, incur additional indebtedness, enter into transactions with affiliates except on an arm s length basis, dispose of property, or issue dividends or make distributions.
889331_11_ITEM7_P38_S2	At January 1, 2011, and for the year then ended, the company was in compliance with these covenants.
889331_11_ITEM7_P38_S3	The Loan Agreement does not impact the existing debt covenants in the revolving credit facility described below.
889331_11_ITEM7_P39_S0	On January 28, 2009, the company entered into an unsecured financing arrangement with a Canadian bank that provided a CAD 10.0 million (equivalent to approximately $10.0 million at January 1, 2011) revolving credit facility, for capital expenditures and general working capital, which expires on July 21, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM7_P39_S1	This facility consists of prime-based loans and overdrafts, bankers acceptances and U.S. base rate loans and overdrafts, and is guaranteed by the company.
889331_11_ITEM7_P39_S2	As of January 1, 2011, the company had approximately CAD 10.0 million (equivalent to approximately $10.0 million) available under the revolving credit.
889331_11_ITEM7_P40_S0	This agreement contains covenants that, among other matters, impose limitations on future mergers, sales of assets, and changes in control, as defined in the agreement.
889331_11_ITEM7_P40_S1	In addition, the company is required to satisfy certain financial covenants and tests relating to, among other matters, interest coverage, working capital, leverage and net worth.
889331_11_ITEM7_P40_S2	As of the fiscal year ended 2010, the company was in compliance with all covenants.
889331_11_ITEM7_P41_S0	The company has an unsecured domestic financing arrangement consisting of a credit agreement with banks that provides a $75.0 million revolving credit facility, with a potential increase of up to $125.0 million upon request of the company and agreement with the lenders, which expires on July 21, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM7_P41_S1	At January 2, 2010, the company had available $50.0 million of borrowing capacity under the revolving credit facility at an interest rate of LIBOR plus 0.500% (0.76% as of January 1, 2011).
889331_11_ITEM7_P42_S0	The domestic bank credit agreement contains covenants that, among other matters, impose limitations on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, future mergers, sales of assets, payment of dividends, and changes in control, as defined in the agreement.
889331_11_ITEM7_P42_S1	In addition, the company is required to satisfy certain financial covenants and tests relating to, among other matters, interest coverage, working capital, leverage and net worth.
889331_11_ITEM7_P42_S2	At January 1, 2011, and for the year then ended, the company was in compliance with these covenants.
889331_11_ITEM7_P43_S0	The company had $2.3 million available in letters of credit at January 1, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM7_P43_S1	No amounts were drawn under these letters of credit at January 1, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM7_P44_S0	The company started 2010 with $70.4 million of cash.
889331_11_ITEM7_P44_S1	Net cash provided by operating activities in 2010 was approximately $104.1 million in the year and included $78.7 million in net income and $46.1 million in non-cash adjustments (primarily $32.0 million in depreciation and amortization), partially offset by $20.7 million of changes in operating assets and liabilities.
889331_11_ITEM7_P45_S0	Changes in various operating assets and liabilities (including short-term and long-term items) that negatively impacted cash flows in 2010 consisted of increases in accounts receivable ($12.8 million) and inventories ($15.1 million), a decrease in accounts payable ($1.8 million) and accrued expenses (including post-retirement) ($13.6 million).
889331_11_ITEM7_P45_S1	The increase in accounts receivable result from increased sales activity.
889331_11_ITEM7_P45_S2	The increase in inventory results from increased sales activity and production rates in addition to higher prices for raw materials.
889331_11_ITEM7_P45_S3	Additionally, the company made contributions to its domestic and foreign pension plans of $16.2 million in 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P45_S4	Positively impacting cash flows were increases in accrued payroll and severance ($2.4 million), accrued taxes ($14.9 million), and a decrease in p repaid expenses and other current assets ($5.4 million).
889331_11_ITEM7_P46_S0	Net cash used in investing activities in 2010 was approximately $65.7 million and included $22.4 million in purchases of property, plant and equipment (primarily related to the company s plant expansion and new facilities in the Asia-Pacific region), and a net $48.3 million for the acquisition of Cole Hersee during the fourth quarter of 2010, partially offset by $5.0 million in cash receipts from the sale of property, plant and equipment.
889331_11_ITEM7_P46_S1	The majority of the receipts from asset sales resulted from the sale of the company s land and building at its Utrecht, Netherlands location.
889331_11_ITEM7_P47_S0	Net cash provided by financing activities in 2010 was approximately $2.2 million, which included $10.7 million in net proceeds from borrowing and $18.5 million in cash proceeds from the exercise of stock options.
889331_11_ITEM7_P47_S1	Additionally the company repurchased $25.4 million of its common stock during 2010 and paid a cash dividend of $3.3 million during the fourth quarter of 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P47_S2	The net payments from debt include $21.0 million in gross payments under the company s term loan discussed above.
889331_11_ITEM7_P47_S3	Further information regarding the company s debt is provided in Note 6 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_11_ITEM7_P48_S0	The effect of exchange rate changes decreased cash by $1.2 million in 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P48_S1	The net cash provided by operating activities less net cash used in financing and investing activities plus the effect of exchange rate changes, resulted in a $39.4 million increase in cash and cash equivalents in 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P48_S2	This left the company with a cash balance of $109.7 million at the end of 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P49_S0	Days sales outstanding (DSO) in accounts receivable decreased to 58 days at year-end 2010 (excluding the year-end Cole Hersee balance), compared to 61 days at year-end 2009 and 53 days at year-end 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P49_S1	DSO in 2008 was unusually low due to the sharp drop-off in sales at the end of the year.
889331_11_ITEM7_P49_S2	The DSO levels for 2010 and 2009 of 58 and 61 days respectively, are more typical of what is expected going forward.
889331_11_ITEM7_P49_S3	inventory outstanding was 70 days at year-end 2010 (excluding the year-end Cole Hersee balance), compared to 62 days at year-end 2009 and 72 days at year-end 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P50_S0	The ratio of current assets to current liabilities was 2.9 to 1 at year-end 2010, compared to 3.2 to 1 at year-end 2009 and 3.1 to 1 at year-end 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P50_S1	The change in the current ratio at the end of the 2010 compared to the prior year reflected increased current liabilities in 2010, primarily related to higher current portion of long term debt balances as well as higher accrued payroll and accrued income tax balances offset by lower accrued severance balances.
889331_11_ITEM7_P50_S2	The carrying amounts of total debt increased $10.8 million in 2010, compared to a decrease of $16.8 million in 2009 and an increase of $66.7 million in 2008, due to an increase in the amount borrowed under the revolving credit facility in 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P50_S3	The ratio of long-term debt to equity was 0.09 to 1 at year-end 2010, compared to 0.13 to 1 at year-end 2009 and 0.22 to 1 at year-end 2008.
889331_11_ITEM7_P50_S4	Further information regarding the company s debt is provided in Note 6 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.

889331_11_ITEM7_P52_S0	Changes in various operating assets and liabilities (including short-term and long-term items) that negatively impacted cash flows in 2009 consisted of decreases in accrued payroll and severance ($9.0 million), net decreases in accounts payable and accrued expenses ($7.9 million), increases in accounts receivable ($15.6 million), decreases in accrued taxes ($3.3 million), and increases in prepaid expenses and other current assets ($0.6 million), partially offset by decreases in inventory ($15.5 million).

889331_11_ITEM7_P53_S3	The company expects to fund 2011 capital investments from operating cash flows.

889331_11_ITEM7_P56_S0	As of January 1, 2011, the company did not have any off-balance sheet arrangements, as defined under the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission rules.
889331_11_ITEM7_P56_S1	Specifically, the company was not liable for guarantees of indebtedness owed by third parties; the company was not directly liable for the debt of any unconsolidated entity, and the company did not have any retained or contingent interest in assets; and the company does not participate in transactions that generate relationships with unconsolidated entities or financial partnerships, such as entities often referred to as structured finance or special purpose entities.
