889331_11_ITEM7_P58_S0	In June 2009, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued authoritative guidance that eliminates the qualifying special purpose entity concept, changes the requirements for derecognizing financial assets and requires enhanced disclosures about transfers of financial assets.
889331_11_ITEM7_P58_S1	The guidance also revises earlier guidance for determining whether an entity is a variable interest entity, requires a new approach for determining who should consolidate a variable interest entity, changes when it is necessary to reassess who should consolidate a variable interest entity, and requires enhanced disclosures related to an enterprise s involvement in variable interest entities.
889331_11_ITEM7_P58_S2	The guidance is effective for the first annual reporting period that begins after November 15, 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P58_S3	The company adop ted the new accounting guidance on January 3, 2010, which did not have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM7_P59_S0	In October 2009, the FASB issued authoritative guidance that amends earlier guidance addressing the accounting for contractual arrangements in which an entity provides multiple products or services (deliverables) to a customer.
889331_11_ITEM7_P59_S1	The amendments address the unit of accounting for arrangements involving multiple deliverables and how arrangement consideration should be allocated to the separate units of accounting, when applicable, by establishing a selling price hierarchy for determining the selling price of a deliverable.
889331_11_ITEM7_P59_S2	The selling price used for each deliverable will be based on vendor-specific objective evidence if available, third-party evidence if vendor-specific objective evidence is not available, or estimated selling price if neither vendor-specific nor third-party evidence is available.
889331_11_ITEM7_P59_S3	The amendments also req uire that arrangement consideration be allocated at the inception of an arrangement to all deliverables using the relative selling price method.
889331_11_ITEM7_P59_S4	The guidance is effective for fiscal years beginning on or after June 15, 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P59_S5	The company adopted the new accounting guidance on January 3, 2010, which did not have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM7_P60_S0	In October 2009, the FASB issued authoritative guidance that amends earlier guidance for revenue arrangements that include both tangible products and software elements.
889331_11_ITEM7_P60_S1	Tangible products containing software components and non-software components that function together to deliver the tangible product s essential functionality are no longer within the scope of guidance for recognizing revenue from the sale of software, but would be accounted for in accordance with other authoritative guidance.
889331_11_ITEM7_P60_S2	The guidance is effective for fiscal years beginning on or after June 15, 2010, with earlier application permitted.
889331_11_ITEM7_P60_S3	The company does not believe that the adoption of this accounting guidance will have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM7_P61_S0	In January 2010, the FASB issued additional guidance to improve fair value disclosures and increase the transparency in financial reporting.
889331_11_ITEM7_P61_S1	These enhancements include: (1) a reporting entity should disclose separately the amounts of significant transfers in and out of Level 1 and Level 2 fair value measurements and describe the reasons for the transfers; and (2) in the reconciliation for fair value measurements using significant unobservable inputs, a reporting entity should present separately information about purchases, sales, issuances, and settlements.
889331_11_ITEM7_P61_S2	This new guidance is effective for interim and annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P61_S3	The company adopted the new accounting guidance on January 3, 2010, which did not have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM7_P62_S0	In February 2010, the SEC issued a statement that reaffirms its support for the potential use of IFRS in the preparation of financial statements by U.S. registrants.
889331_11_ITEM7_P62_S1	It announced a work plan by which it is expected to make a determination in 2011 whether or not it will mandate the conversion to IFRS.
889331_11_ITEM7_P62_S2	As of October 2010, the SEC continues to anticipate making the determination in 2011 of whether, when, and how to incorporate IFRS into the U.S. domestic financial reporting system.
889331_11_ITEM7_P62_S3	The company is currently assessing the potential impact of IFRS on its Consolidated Financial Statements and will continue to review progress of the work plan.
889331_11_ITEM7_P63_S0	In December 2010, the FASB issued authoritative guidance related to disclosure of supplementary pro forma information for business combinations.
889331_11_ITEM7_P63_S1	The guidance specified that if a public entity presents comparative financial statements, the entity should disclose revenue and earnings of the combined entity as though the business combination(s) that occurred during the current year had occurred as of the beginning of the comparable prior annual reporting period only.
889331_11_ITEM7_P63_S2	The amendments also expand the supplemental pro forma disclosures to include a description of the nature and amount of material, nonrecurring pro forma adjustments directly attributable to the business combination included in the reported pro forma revenue and earnings.
889331_11_ITEM7_P63_S3	The guidance is effective prospectively for business combinations for which the acquisit ion date is on or after the beginning of the first annual reporting period beginning on or after December 15, 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P63_S4	The company does not believe that the adoption of this new guidance will have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM7_P64_S0	In December 2010, the FASB issued an authoritative guidance describing when to perform step 2 of the goodwill impairment test for reporting units with zero or negative carrying amounts.
889331_11_ITEM7_P64_S1	The amendments in this guidance modify Step 1 of the goodwill impairment test for reporting units with zero or negative carrying amounts.
889331_11_ITEM7_P64_S2	For those reporting units, an entity is required to perform Step 2 of the goodwill impairment test if it is more likely than not that a goodwill impairment exists.
889331_11_ITEM7_P65_S0	In determining whether it is more likely than not that goodwill impairment exists, an entity should consider whether there are any adverse qualitative factors indicating that impairment may exist.
889331_11_ITEM7_P65_S1	The qualitative factors are consistent with the existing guidance and examples, which require that goodwill of a reporting unit be tested for i mpairment between annual tests if an event occurs or circumstances change that would more likely than not reduce the fair value of a reporting unit below its carrying amount.
889331_11_ITEM7_P65_S2	For public entities, the amendments in this guidance are effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P65_S3	The company expects to adopt this new guidance effective the beginning of fiscal year 2011, and does not expect it to have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM7_P66_S0	Certain of the accounting policies as discussed below require the application of significant judgment by management in selecting the appropriate estimates and assumptions for calculating amounts to record in the financial statements.
889331_11_ITEM7_P66_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates and assumptions, impacting the reported results of operations and financial position.
889331_11_ITEM7_P66_S2	Significant accounting policies are more fully described in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report.
889331_11_ITEM7_P66_S3	Certain accounting policies, however, are considered to be critical in that they are most important to the depiction of the company s financial condition and results of operations and their application requires management s subjective judgment in making estimates about the effect of matters that a re inherently uncertain.
889331_11_ITEM7_P66_S4	The company believes the following accounting policies are the most critical to aid in fully understanding and evaluating its reported financial results, as they require management s most difficult, subjective or complex judgments, resulting from the need to make estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain.
889331_11_ITEM7_P66_S5	The company has reviewed these critical accounting policies and related disclosures with the Audit Committee of its Board of Directors.
889331_11_ITEM7_P67_S0	The company recognizes revenue on product sales in the period in which the sales process is complete.
889331_11_ITEM7_P67_S1	This generally occurs when products are shipped (FOB origin) to the customer in accordance with the terms of the sale, the risk of loss has been transferred, collectability is reasonably assured and the pricing is fixed and determinable.
889331_11_ITEM7_P67_S2	At the end of each period, for those shipments where title to the products and the risk of loss and rewards of ownership do not transfer until the product has been received by the customer, the company adjusts revenues and cost of sales for the delay between the time that the products are shipped and when they are received by the customer.
889331_11_ITEM7_P68_S0	The company s distribution channels are primarily through dire ct sales and independent third party distributors.
889331_11_ITEM7_P69_S0	The company accepts orders from customers based on long term purchasing contracts and written sales agreements.
889331_11_ITEM7_P69_S1	Contract pricing and selling agreement terms are based on market factors, costs and competition.
889331_11_ITEM7_P69_S2	Pricing normally is negotiated as an adjustment (premium or discount) from the company s published price lists.
889331_11_ITEM7_P69_S3	The customer is invoiced when the company s products are shipped to them in accordance with the terms of the sales agreement.
889331_11_ITEM7_P70_S0	the ability to receive price adjustments on products previously shipped and invoiced.
889331_11_ITEM7_P70_S1	This practice is common in the industry and is referred to as a ship and debit program.
889331_11_ITEM7_P70_S2	This program allows the distributor to debit the company for the difference between the distributors contracted price and a lower price for specific transactions.
889331_11_ITEM7_P71_S0	Under certain circumstances (usually in a competitive situation or large volume opportunity), a distributor will request authorization to reduce its price to its buyer.
889331_11_ITEM7_P71_S1	If the company approves such a reduction, the distributor is authorized to debit its ac count for the difference between the contracted price and the lower approved price.
889331_11_ITEM7_P71_S2	The company establishes reserves for this program based on historic activity and actual authorizations for the debit and recognizes these debits as a reduction of revenue.
889331_11_ITEM7_P72_S0	The company has a return to stock policy whereby a customer with previous authorization from Littelfuse management can return previously purchased goods for full or partial credit.
889331_11_ITEM7_P72_S1	The company establishes an estimated allowance for these returns based on historic activity.
889331_11_ITEM7_P72_S2	Sales revenue and cost of sales are reduced to anticipate estimated returns.
889331_11_ITEM7_P73_S0	The company properly meets all of the criteria for recognizing revenue when the right of return exists.
889331_11_ITEM7_P73_S1	Specifically, the company meets those requirements because:
889331_11_ITEM7_P74_S0	The company s selling price is fixed or determinable at the date of the sale.
889331_11_ITEM7_P75_S0	The company has policies and procedures to accept only credit worthy customers with the ability to pay the company.
889331_11_ITEM7_P76_S0	The company s customers are obligated to pay the company under the contract and the obligation is not contingent on the resale of the product.
889331_11_ITEM7_P77_S0	The risk ownership transfers to the company s customers upon shipment and is not changed in the event of theft, physical destruction or damage of the product.
889331_11_ITEM7_P78_S0	The company bills at the ship date and establishes a reserve to reduce revenue from the in-transit time until the product is delivered for FOB destination sales.
889331_11_ITEM7_P79_S0	The company s customers acquiring the product for resale have economic substance apart from that provided by Littelfuse.
889331_11_ITEM7_P79_S1	All distributors are independent of the company.
889331_11_ITEM7_P80_S0	The company does not have any obligations for future performance to bring about resale of the product by its customers.
889331_11_ITEM7_P81_S0	The company can reasonably estimate the amount of future returns.
889331_11_ITEM7_P82_S0	Volume Rebates : The company offers incentives to certain customers to achieve specific quarterly or annual sales targets.
889331_11_ITEM7_P82_S1	If customers achieve their sales targets, they are entitled to rebates.
889331_11_ITEM7_P82_S2	The company estimates the future cost of these rebates and recognizes this estimated cost as a reduction to revenue as products are sold.
889331_11_ITEM7_P83_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts : The company evaluates the collectability of its trade receivables based on a combination of factors.
889331_11_ITEM7_P83_S1	The company regularly analyzes its significant customer accounts and, when the company becomes aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the company records a specific reserve for bad debt to reduce the related receivable to the amount the company reasonably believes is collectible.
889331_11_ITEM7_P83_S2	The company also records allowances for all other customers based on a variety of factors including the length of time the receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, macroeconomic considerations and past experience.
889331_11_ITEM7_P84_S0	Historically, the allowance for doubtful accounts has been adequate to cover bad debts.
889331_11_ITEM7_P84_S1	If circumstances related to specific customers change, the estimates of the recoverability of receivables could be further adjusted.
889331_11_ITEM7_P85_S0	The company performs regular detailed assessments of inventory, which include a review of, among other factors, demand requirements, product life cycle and development plans, component cost trends, product pricing, shelf life and quality issues.
889331_11_ITEM7_P85_S1	Based on the analysis, the company records adjustments to inventory for excess quantities, obsolescence or impairment when appropriate to reflect inventory at net realizable value.
889331_11_ITEM7_P86_S0	Historically, inventory reserves have been adequate to reflect inventory at net realizable values.
889331_11_ITEM7_P87_S0	The company annually tests goodwill for impairment on the first day of its fiscal fourth quarter or at an interim date if there is an event or change in circumstances that indicates the asset may be impaired.
889331_11_ITEM7_P87_S1	The company has four reporting units for goodwill testing purposes.
889331_11_ITEM7_P87_S2	Management determines the fair value of each of its reporting units by using a discounted cash flow model (which includes forecasted five-year income statement and working capital projections, a market-based weighted average cost of capital and terminal values after five years) to estimate market value.
889331_11_ITEM7_P87_S3	In addition, the company compares its derived enterprise value on a consolidated basis to the company s market capitalization as of its test date to ensure its derived value approximates the market value of the company when taken as a whole.
889331_11_ITEM7_P88_S0	As of the most recent annual test conducted on October 2, 2010, the company concluded the fair value of each of the reporting units exceeded its carrying value of invested capital and therefore, no goodwill impairment existed.
889331_11_ITEM7_P88_S1	Specifically, the company noted that its headroom, defined as the excess of fair value over the carrying value of invested capital, was 85%, 64%, 253% and 141% for its electronics, automotive, base electrical, and protection relay and custom products reporting units, respectively, at October 2, 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P88_S2	Certain key assumptions used in the annual test included a discount rate of 14% and a long-term growth rate of 3% for all four reporting units.
889331_11_ITEM7_P89_S0	In addition, the company performed a sensitivity test at October 2, 2010 that showed a 100 basis point increase in its discount rate or a 100 basis point decrease in the long-term growth rate for each reporting unit would not have changed the company s conclusion that no goodwill impairment existed at October 2, 2010.
889331_11_ITEM7_P90_S0	The company will continue to perform a goodwill impairment test as required on an annual basis and on an interim basis, if certain conditions exist.
889331_11_ITEM7_P90_S1	Factors the company considers important, which could result in changes to its estimates, include underperformance relative to historical or projected future operating results and declines in acquisitions and trading multiples.
889331_11_ITEM7_P90_S2	Due to the diverse end user base and non-discretionary product demand, the company does not believe its future operating results will vary significantly relative to its historical and projected future operating results.
889331_11_ITEM7_P91_S0	The company evaluates long-lived asset groups on an ongoing basis.
889331_11_ITEM7_P91_S1	Long-lived asset groups are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the related asset may not be recoverable.
889331_11_ITEM7_P92_S0	Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of the asset to future undiscounted cash flows expected to be generated by the asset group.
889331_11_ITEM7_P92_S1	If it is determined to be impaired, the impairment recognized is measured by the amount by which the carrying value of the asset exceeds its fair value.
889331_11_ITEM7_P92_S2	The company s estimates of future cash flows from such assets could be impacted if it underperforms relative to historical or projected future operating results.
889331_11_ITEM7_P92_S3	The company recorded asset impairment charges of $3.0 million, $0.8 million a nd $3.2 million for the fiscal years ended 2010, 2009 and 2008 respectively.
889331_11_ITEM7_P92_S4	Further information regarding asset impairments is provided in Note 11 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_11_ITEM7_P93_S0	Environmental liabilities are accrued based on estimates of the probability of potential future environmental exposure.
889331_11_ITEM7_P93_S1	Expenses related to on-going maintenance of environmental sites are expensed as incurred.
889331_11_ITEM7_P93_S2	If actual or estimated probable future losses exceed the company s recorded liability for such claims, it would record additional charges as other expense during the period in which the actual loss or change in estimate occurred.
889331_11_ITEM7_P94_S0	Littelfuse has a number of company-sponsored defined benefit plans primarily in North America, Europe and the Asia-Pacific region.
889331_11_ITEM7_P94_S1	The company recognizes the full unfunded status of the plan on the balance sheet.
889331_11_ITEM7_P94_S2	Actuarial gains and losses and prior service costs and credits are recognized as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income.
889331_11_ITEM7_P95_S0	Accounting for pensions requires estimating the future benefit cost and recognizing the cost over the employee s expected period of employment with the company.
889331_11_ITEM7_P95_S1	Certain assumptions are required in the calculation of pension costs and obligations.
889331_11_ITEM7_P95_S2	These assumptions include the discount rate, salary scales and the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
889331_11_ITEM7_P96_S0	The discount rate is intended to represent the rate at which pension benefit obligations could be settled by purchase of an annuity contract.
889331_11_ITEM7_P96_S1	These assumptions are subject to change based on stock and bond market returns and other economic factors.
889331_11_ITEM7_P96_S2	Actual results that differ from the company s assumptions are accumulated and amortized over future periods and, therefore, generally affect its recognized expense and accrued liability in such future periods.
889331_11_ITEM7_P96_S3	While the company believes that its assumptions are appropriate given current economic conditions and its actual experience, significant differences in results or significant changes in the company s assumptions may materially affect its pension obligations and related future expense.
889331_11_ITEM7_P96_S4	Further information regarding these plans is provided in Note 12 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_11_ITEM7_P97_S0	Stock-based compensation expense is recorded for stock-option grants, restricted stock and performance-based restricted stock awards based upon the fair values of the awards.
889331_11_ITEM7_P97_S1	The fair value of stock option awards is estimated at the grant date using the Black-Scholes option pricing model, which includes assumptions for volatility, expected term, risk-free interest rate and dividend yield.
889331_11_ITEM7_P97_S2	Expected volatility is based on implied volatilities from traded options on Littelfuse stock, historical volatility of Littelfuse stock and other factors.
889331_11_ITEM7_P97_S3	Historical data is used to estimate employee termination experience and the expected term of the options.
889331_11_ITEM7_P98_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect at the time of grant.
889331_11_ITEM7_P98_S1	The company initiated a quarterly cash dividend in 2010 and expects to co ntinue making cash dividend payments in the foreseeable future.
889331_11_ITEM7_P99_S0	The performance-based restricted stock awards granted in 2008 vest after a three-year performance period and are paid completely in the company s common stock at the end of the performance period.
889331_11_ITEM7_P99_S1	The fair value of performance-based restricted stock awards that are paid in common stock is measured at the market price on the grant date, and the fair value of the portion paid in cash is measured at the current market price of a share.
889331_11_ITEM7_P100_S0	The number of shares issued is based on the company attaining certain financial performance goals relating to return on net tangible assets ( RONTA ) for performance-based restricted stock awards granted prior to 2008, or return on net assets ( RONA ) for performance-based restricted stock granted in 2008, as well as earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization ( EBITDA ) during the three-year performance period after the grant date.
889331_11_ITEM7_P100_S1	Stock-based compensation expense for performance-based restricted stock awards is based on the fair values and the company s current estimate of the probable number of shares to be issued (based on the probable outcome at the end of the performance period).
889331_11_ITEM7_P100_S2	As the company s estimate of the probable outcome changes in futur e periods, stock-based compensation expense is adjusted accordingly.
889331_11_ITEM7_P101_S0	Total stock-based compensation expense was $5.2 million, $5.5 million and $5.1 million in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
889331_11_ITEM7_P101_S1	Further information regarding this expense is provided in Note 13 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_11_ITEM7_P102_S0	The company accounts for income taxes using the liability method.
889331_11_ITEM7_P103_S0	Deferred taxes are recognized for the future effects of temporary differences between financial and income tax reporting using tax rates in effect for the years in which the differences are expected to reverse.
889331_11_ITEM7_P103_S1	The company recognizes deferred taxes for temporary differences, operating loss carryforwards and tax credit carryforwards.
889331_11_ITEM7_P103_S2	Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if it is more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
889331_11_ITEM7_P104_S0	Federal and state income taxes are provided on the portion of foreign income that is expected to be remitted to the U.S. and be taxable.
889331_11_ITEM7_P105_S0	The company recognizes the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical merits of the position.
889331_11_ITEM7_P105_S1	The tax benefits recognized in the financial statements from such a position are measured based on the largest benefit that has a greater than fifty percent likelihood of being realized upon ultimate settlement.
889331_11_ITEM7_P106_S0	Further information regarding income taxes, including a detailed reconciliation of current year activity, is provided in Note 14 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_11_ITEM7_P107_S0	The company s 2010 performance significantly rebounded from 2009 across all sectors.
889331_11_ITEM7_P107_S1	Sales for 2010 were $608.0 million compared to $430.1 million for 2009.
889331_11_ITEM7_P107_S2	Sales for 2011 are expected to be in the range of $670.0 to $690.0 million.
889331_11_ITEM7_P107_S3	Earnings for 2011 are expected to be in the range of $3.75 to $4.05 per diluted share.
889331_11_ITEM7_P107_S4	Capital expenditures for 2011 are expected to be in the range of $29.0 to $32.0 million.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The company is exposed to market risk from changes in interest rates, foreign exchange rates and commodities.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The company had $74.0 million in debt outstanding at January 1, 2011, primarily related to the term loan, which is described above in Item 7 under Liquidity and Capital Resources .
889331_11_ITEM7A_P1_S1	While the remaining portion of this debt has a variable interest rate, the company s interest expense is not materially sensitive to changes in interest rate levels since debt levels and potential interest expense increases are insignificant relative to earnings.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The majority of the company s operations consist of manufacturing and sales activities in foreign countries.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The company has manufacturing facilities in Mexico, Canada, Germany, China, Taiwan and the Philippines.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P2_S2	During 2010, sales to customers outside the U.S. were 69.1% of total net sales.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Substantially all sales in Europe are denominated in euros and substantially all sales in the Asia-Pacific region are denominated in U.S. dollars, Japanese yen, Korean won, Chinese yuan and Taiwanese dollars.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P3_S0	The company s foreign exchange exposures result primarily from sale of products in foreign currencies, foreign currency denominated purchases, employee-related and other costs of running operations in foreign countries and translation of balance sheet accounts denominated in foreign currencies.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P3_S1	The company s most significant long exposure is to the euro, with lesser long exposures to the Canadian dollar, Japanese yen and Korean won.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P3_S2	The company s most significant short exposures are to the Mexican peso, Philippine peso and Chinese yuan.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P3_S3	Changes in foreign exchange rates could affect the company s sales, costs, balance sheet values and earnings.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P3_S4	The company uses netting and offsetting intercompany account management techniques to reduce known foreign currency exposures where possible and also, from time to time, utilizes derivative instruments to hedge certain foreign currency exposures deemed to be material.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The company uses various metals in the manufacturing of its products, including copper, zinc, tin, gold and silver.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P4_S1	Prices of these commodities can and do fluctuate significantly, which can impact the company s earnings.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P4_S2	The most significant of these exposures is to copper and zinc, where at current prices and volumes, a 10% price change in copper would affect pretax profit by approximately $2.6 million.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P4_S3	A 10% change in zinc would affect pretax profit by approximately $0.8 million.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The cost of oil fluctuated dramatically over the past several years.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P5_S1	Consequently, there is a risk that a return to high prices for oil and electricity in 2011 could have a significant impact on the company s transportation and utility expenses.
889331_11_ITEM7A_P6_S0	While the company is exposed to significant changes in certain commodity prices and foreign currency exchange rates, the company actively monitors these exposures and takes various actions to mitigate any negative impacts of these exposures.
889331_11_ITEM8_P0_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders of Littelfuse, Inc.
889331_11_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Littelfuse, Inc. and subsidiaries (Company) as of January 1, 2011 and January 2, 2010, and the related consolidated statements of income, equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended January 1, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM8_P1_S1	Our audits also included the financial statement schedule listed in the Index at Item 15(a).
889331_11_ITEM8_P1_S2	These financial statements and schedule are the responsibility of the Company's management.
889331_11_ITEM8_P1_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements and schedule based on our audits.
889331_11_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
889331_11_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
889331_11_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
889331_11_ITEM8_P3_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
889331_11_ITEM8_P3_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
889331_11_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of Littelfuse, Inc. and subsidiaries at January 1, 2011 and January 2, 2010, and the consolidated results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended January 1, 2011, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
889331_11_ITEM8_P4_S1	Also, in our opinion, the related financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic financial statements taken as a whole, presents fairly in all material respects the information set forth therein.
889331_11_ITEM8_P5_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Littelfuse, Inc. and subsidiaries internal control over financial reporting as of January 1, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission and our report dated February 25, 2011, expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
889331_11_ITEM8_P6_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders of Littelfuse, Inc.
889331_11_ITEM8_P7_S0	We have audited Littelfuse, Inc. s internal control over financial reporting as of January 1, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (the COSO criteria).
889331_11_ITEM8_P7_S1	Littelfuse, Inc. s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Form 10-K. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
889331_11_ITEM8_P8_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
889331_11_ITEM8_P8_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
889331_11_ITEM8_P8_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
889331_11_ITEM8_P8_S3	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
889331_11_ITEM8_P9_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
889331_11_ITEM8_P9_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance wi th authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
889331_11_ITEM8_P10_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
889331_11_ITEM8_P10_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
889331_11_ITEM8_P11_S0	In our opinion, Littelfuse, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of January 1, 2011, based on the COSO criteria .
889331_11_ITEM8_P12_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Littelfuse, Inc. and subsidiaries as of January 1, 2011 and January 2, 2010, and the related consolidated statements of income, equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended January 1, 2011, and our report dated February 25, 2011 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
889331_11_ITEM8_P13_S0	Nature of Operations : Littelfuse, Inc. and its subsidiaries (the company ) design, manufacture, and sell circuit protection devices for use in the automotive, electronic and electrical markets throughout the world.
889331_11_ITEM8_P14_S0	Fiscal Year : The company s fiscal year ended January 1, 2011 contained 52 weeks.
889331_11_ITEM8_P14_S1	The fiscal year ended January 2, 2010 contained 53 weeks and the fiscal year ended December 27, 2008 contained 52 weeks.
889331_11_ITEM8_P15_S0	Basis of Presentation : The Consolidated Financial Statements include the accounts of Littelfuse, Inc. and its subsidiaries.
889331_11_ITEM8_P15_S1	All significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
889331_11_ITEM8_P16_S0	The company s Consolidated Financial Statements were prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America and include the assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses of all wholly-owned subsidiaries and majority-owned subsidiaries over which the company exercises control.
889331_11_ITEM8_P17_S0	Use of Estimates : The process of preparing financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the Consolidated Financial Statements, and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses and the accompanying notes.
889331_11_ITEM8_P17_S1	The company evaluates and updates its assumptions and estimates on an ongoing basis and may employ outside experts to assist in its evaluation, as considered necessary.
889331_11_ITEM8_P17_S2	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
889331_11_ITEM8_P18_S0	Cash Equivalents : All highly liquid investments, with a maturity of three months or less when purchased, are considered to be cash equivalents.
889331_11_ITEM8_P19_S0	Investments : The company has determined that all of its investment securities are to be classified as available-for-sale.
889331_11_ITEM8_P19_S1	Available-for-sale securities are carried at fair value with the unrealized gains and losses reported as a component of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income (Loss).
889331_11_ITEM8_P20_S0	Realized gains and losses and declines in unrealized value judged to be other-than-temporary on available-for-sale securities are included in other expense (income), net.
889331_11_ITEM8_P21_S0	The cost of securities sold is based on the specific identification method.
889331_11_ITEM8_P21_S1	Interest and dividends on securities classified as available-for-sale are included in interest income.
889331_11_ITEM8_P22_S0	Fair Value of Financial Instruments : The company s financial instruments include cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, investments, derivative instruments and long-term debt.
889331_11_ITEM8_P22_S1	The carrying values of such financial instruments approximate their estimated fair values.
889331_11_ITEM8_P23_S0	Accounts Receivable : The company performs credit evaluations of customers financial condition and generally does not require collateral.
889331_11_ITEM8_P24_S0	Credit losses are provided for in the financial statements based upon specific knowledge of a customer s inability to meet its financial obligations to the company.
889331_11_ITEM8_P25_S0	Historically, credit losses have consistently been within management s expectations and have not been a material amount.
889331_11_ITEM8_P25_S1	A receivable is considered past due if payments have not been received within agreed upon invoice terms.
889331_11_ITEM8_P25_S2	Write-offs are recorded at the time a customer receivable is deemed uncollectible.
889331_11_ITEM8_P26_S0	The company also maintains allowances against accounts receivable for the settlement of rebates and sales discounts to customers.
889331_11_ITEM8_P26_S1	These allowances are based upon specific customer sales and sales discounts as well as actual historical experience.
889331_11_ITEM8_P27_S0	Inventories : Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market (first in, first out method), which approximates current replacement cost.
889331_11_ITEM8_P28_S0	The company maintains excess and obsolete allowances against inventory to reduce the carrying value to the expected net realizable value.
889331_11_ITEM8_P28_S1	These allowances are based upon a combination of factors including historical sales volume, market conditions, lower of cost or market analysis and expected realizable value of the inventory.
889331_11_ITEM8_P29_S0	Property, Plant and Equipment : Land, buildings, and equipment are carried at cost.
889331_11_ITEM8_P29_S1	Depreciation is calculated using the straight-line method with useful lives of 21 years for buildings, seven to nine years for equipment, seven years for furniture and fixtures, five years for tooling and three years for computer equipment.
889331_11_ITEM8_P30_S0	Goodwill: The company annually tests goodwill and indefinite lived intangible assets for impairment on the first day of its fiscal fourth quarter or at an interim date if there is an event or change in circumstances that indicates the asset may be impaired.
889331_11_ITEM8_P30_S1	The company has four reporting units for testing purposes.
889331_11_ITEM8_P30_S2	Management determines the fair value of each of its reporting units by using a discounted cash flow model (which includes forecasted five-year income statement and working capital projections, a market-based weighted average cost of capital and terminal values after five years) to estimate market value.
889331_11_ITEM8_P30_S3	In addition, the company compares its derived enterprise value on a consolidated basis to the company s market capitalization a s of its test date to ensure its derived value approximates the market value of the company when taken as a whole.
889331_11_ITEM8_P31_S0	As of the most recent annual test conducted on October 2, 2010, the company concluded the fair value of each of the reporting units exceeded its carrying value of invested capital and therefore, no goodwill impairment existed.
889331_11_ITEM8_P31_S1	Specifically, the company noted that its headroom, defined as the excess of fair value over the carrying value of invested capital, was 85%, 64%, 253% and 141% for its electronics, automotive, base electrical, and protection relay and custom products reporting units, respectively, at October 2, 2010.
889331_11_ITEM8_P31_S2	Certain key assumptions used in the annual test included a discount rate of 14.0% and a long-term growth rate of 3% for all four reporting units.
889331_11_ITEM8_P32_S0	In addition, the company performed a sensitivity test at October 2, 2010 that showed a 100 basis point increase in its discount rate or a 100 basis point decrease in the long-term growth rate for each reporting unit would not have changed the company s conclusion that no goodwill impairment existed at October 2, 2010.
889331_11_ITEM8_P33_S0	The company will continue to perform a goodwill impairment test as required on an annual basis and on an interim basis, if certain conditions exist.
889331_11_ITEM8_P33_S1	Factors the company considers important, which could result in changes to its estimates, include underperformance relative to historical or projected future operating results and declines in acquisitions and trading multiples.
889331_11_ITEM8_P33_S2	Due to the diverse end user base and non-discretionary product demand, the company does not believe its future operating results will vary significantly relative to its historical and projected future operating results.
889331_11_ITEM8_P34_S0	Other Intangible Assets : Trademarks and tradenames are amortized using the straight-line method over estimated useful lives that have a range of five to 20 years.
889331_11_ITEM8_P34_S1	Patents, licenses and software are amortized using the straight-line method or an accelerated method over estimated useful lives that have a range of four to 12 years.
889331_11_ITEM8_P34_S2	The distribution networks are amortized on either a straight-line or accelerated basis over estimated useful lives that have a range of four to 20 years.
889331_11_ITEM8_P34_S3	Other intangible assets are also tested for impairment when there is a significant event that may cause the asset to be impaired.
889331_11_ITEM8_P35_S0	Environmental Liabilities : Environmental liabilities are accrued based on engineering studies estimating the cost of remediating sites.
889331_11_ITEM8_P35_S1	Expenses related to on-going maintenance of environmental sites are expensed as incurred.
889331_11_ITEM8_P35_S2	If actual or estimated probable future losses exceed the company s recorded liability for such claims, the company would record additional charges during the period in which the actual loss or change in estimate occurred.
889331_11_ITEM8_P36_S0	Pension and Other Post-retirement Benefits : Accounting for pensions requires estimating the future benefit cost and recognizing the cost over the employee s expected period of employment with the company.
889331_11_ITEM8_P36_S1	Certain assumptions are required in the calculation of pension costs and obligations.
889331_11_ITEM8_P36_S2	These assumptions include the discount rate, salary scales and the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
889331_11_ITEM8_P37_S0	The discount rate is intended to represent the rate at which pension benefit obligations could be settled by purchase of an annuity contract.
889331_11_ITEM8_P37_S1	These assumptions are subject to change based on stock and bond market returns and other economic factors.
889331_11_ITEM8_P37_S2	Actual results that differ from the company s assumptions are accumulated and amortized over future pe riods and therefore generally affect its recognized expense and accrued liability in such future periods.
889331_11_ITEM8_P37_S3	While the company believes that its assumptions are appropriate given current economic conditions and its actual experience, significant differences in results or significant changes in the company s assumptions may materially affect its pension obligations and related future expense.
889331_11_ITEM8_P38_S0	On April 1, 2009, the company elected to freeze its U.S. benefit plan.
889331_11_ITEM8_P38_S1	As a result of the freeze decision, the company remeasured its pension plan assets and obligations which resulted in a decrease in the net obligation at that date.
889331_11_ITEM8_P38_S2	See Note 12 for additional information.
889331_11_ITEM8_P39_S0	Reclassifications : Certain items in the 2009 and 2008 financial statements have been reclassified to conform to the 2010 presentation.
889331_11_ITEM8_P40_S0	The company recognizes revenue on product sales in the period in which the sales process is complete.
889331_11_ITEM8_P40_S1	This generally occurs when products are shipped (FOB origin) to the customer in accordance with the terms of the sale, the risk of loss has been transferred, collectability is reasonably assured and the pricing is fixed and determinable.
889331_11_ITEM8_P40_S2	At the end of each period, for those shipments where title to the products and the risk of loss and rewards of ownership do not transfer until the product has been received by the customer, the company adjusts revenues and cost of sales for the delay between the time that the products are shipped and when they are received by the customer.
889331_11_ITEM8_P41_S0	The company s distribution channels are primarily through dire ct sales and independent third party distributors.
889331_11_ITEM8_P42_S0	The company accepts orders from customers based on long term purchasing contracts and written sales agreements.
889331_11_ITEM8_P42_S1	Contract pricing and selling agreement terms are based on market factors, costs, and competition.
889331_11_ITEM8_P42_S2	Pricing normally is negotiated as an adjustment (premium or discount) from the company s published price lists.
889331_11_ITEM8_P42_S3	The customer is invoiced when the company s products are shipped to them in accordance with the terms of the sales agreement.
889331_11_ITEM8_P43_S0	the ability to receive price adjustments on products previously shipped and invoiced.
889331_11_ITEM8_P43_S1	This practice is common in the industry and is referred to as a ship and debit program.
889331_11_ITEM8_P43_S2	This program allows the distributor to debit the company for the difference between the distributors contracted price and a lower price for specific transactions.
889331_11_ITEM8_P44_S0	Under certain circumstances (usually in a competitive situation or large volume opportunity), a distributor will request authorization to reduce its price to its buyer.
889331_11_ITEM8_P44_S1	If the company approves such a reduction, the distributor is authorized to debit its ac count for the difference between the contracted price and the lower approved price.
889331_11_ITEM8_P44_S2	The company establishes reserves for this program based on historic activity and actual authorizations for the debit and recognizes these debits as a reduction of revenue.
889331_11_ITEM8_P45_S0	The company has a return to stock policy whereby a customer with prior authorization from Littelfuse management can return previously purchased goods for full or partial credit.
889331_11_ITEM8_P45_S1	The company establishes an estimated allowance for these returns based on historic activity.
889331_11_ITEM8_P45_S2	Sales revenue and cost of sales are reduced to anticipate estimated returns.
889331_11_ITEM8_P46_S0	The company properly meets all of the criteria for recognizing revenue when the right of return exists.
889331_11_ITEM8_P46_S1	Specifically, the company meets those requirements because:
889331_11_ITEM8_P47_S0	The company s selling price is fixed or determinable at the date of the sale.
889331_11_ITEM8_P48_S0	The company has policies and procedures to accept only credit worthy customers with the ability to pay the company.
889331_11_ITEM8_P49_S0	The company s customers are obligated to pay the company under the contract and the obligation is not contingent on the resale of the product.
889331_11_ITEM8_P50_S0	The risk ownership transfers to the company s customers upon shipment and is not changed in the event of theft, physical destruction or damage of the product.
889331_11_ITEM8_P51_S0	The company bills at the ship date and establishes a reserve to reduce revenue from the in transit time until the product is delivered for FOB destination sales.
889331_11_ITEM8_P52_S0	The company s customers acquiring the product for resale have economic substance apart from that provided by Littelfuse, and all distributors are independent of the company.
889331_11_ITEM8_P53_S0	The company does not have any obligations for future performance to bring about resale of the product by its customers.
889331_11_ITEM8_P54_S0	The company can reasonably estimate the amount of future returns.
889331_11_ITEM8_P55_S0	Volume Rebates : The company offers incentives to certain customers to achieve specific quarterly or annual sales targets.
889331_11_ITEM8_P55_S1	If customers achieve their sales targets, they are entitled to rebates.
889331_11_ITEM8_P55_S2	The company estimates the future cost of these rebates and recognizes this estimated cost as a reduction to revenue as products are sold.
889331_11_ITEM8_P56_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts : The company evaluates the collectability of its trade receivables based on a combination of factors.
889331_11_ITEM8_P56_S1	The company regularly analyzes its significant customer accounts and, when the company becomes aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the company records a specific reserve for bad debt to reduce the related receivable to the amount the company reasonably believes is collectible.
889331_11_ITEM8_P56_S2	The company also records allowances for all other customers based on a variety of factors including the length of time the receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, macroeconomic considerations and past experience.
889331_11_ITEM8_P57_S0	Historically, the allowance for doubtful accounts has been adequate to cover bad debts.
889331_11_ITEM8_P57_S1	If circumstances related to specific customers change, the estimates of the recoverability of receivables could be further adjusted.
889331_11_ITEM8_P57_S2	However, due to the company s diverse customer base and lack of credit concentration, the company does not believe its estimates would be materially impacted by changes in its assumptions.
889331_11_ITEM8_P58_S0	Advertising Costs : The company expenses advertising costs as incurred, which amounted to $1.2 million in 2010, $1.1 million in 2009 and $2.3 million in 2008, and are included as a component of selling, general and administrative expenses.
889331_11_ITEM8_P59_S0	Shipping and Handling Fees and Costs : Amounts billed to customers related to shipping and handling are classified as revenue.
889331_11_ITEM8_P59_S1	Costs incurred for shipping and handling of $10.9 million, $5.0 million, and $6.5 million in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively, are classified in selling, general and administrative expenses.
889331_11_ITEM8_P60_S0	Restructuring Costs : The company incurred severance charges and plant closure expenses as part of the company s on-going cost reduction efforts.
889331_11_ITEM8_P60_S1	These charges are included in cost of sales, selling, general and administrative expenses, or research and development expenses depending on the personnel being included in the charge.
889331_11_ITEM8_P60_S2	See Note 9 for additional information on restructuring costs.
889331_11_ITEM8_P61_S0	Foreign Currency Translation : The company s foreign subsidiaries use the local currency or the U.S. dollar as their functional currency, as appropriate.
889331_11_ITEM8_P61_S1	Assets and liabilities are translated using exchange rates at the balance sheet date, and revenues and expenses are translated at weighted average rates.
889331_11_ITEM8_P61_S2	The amount of foreign currency conversion recognized in the income statement related to currency translation were losses of $3.3 million and $0.4 million in 2010 and 2009, respectively and a gain of $2.3 million in 2008 and is included as a component of other expense (income), net.
889331_11_ITEM8_P61_S3	Adjustments from the translation process are recognized in Shareholders Equity as a component of Accumulated other comprehensive income .
889331_11_ITEM8_P62_S0	Stock-based Compensation : The company recognizes compensation expense for the cost of awards of equity compensation using a fair value method.
889331_11_ITEM8_P62_S1	Benefits of tax deductions in excess of recognized compensation expense are reported both in operating and financing cash flows.
889331_11_ITEM8_P63_S0	On certain occasions, the company has granted stock options for a fixed number of shares with an exercise price below that of the underlying stock on the date of the grant and recognizes compensation expense accordingly.
889331_11_ITEM8_P63_S1	This compensation expense has historically not been significant.
889331_11_ITEM8_P63_S2	See Note 13 for additional information on stock-based compensation.
889331_11_ITEM8_P64_S0	Income Taxes: The company accounts for income taxes using the liability method.
889331_11_ITEM8_P64_S1	Deferred taxes are recognized for the future effects of temporary differences between financial and income tax reporting using enacted tax rates in effect for the years in which the differences are expected to reverse.
889331_11_ITEM8_P64_S2	The company recognizes deferred taxes for temporary differences, operating loss carryforwards and tax credit carryforwards.
889331_11_ITEM8_P64_S3	Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if it is more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
889331_11_ITEM8_P65_S0	Federal and state income taxes are provided on the portion of foreign income that is expected to be remitted to the U.S. and be taxable.
889331_11_ITEM8_P66_S0	Subsequent Events: The company has evaluated subsequent events through February 25, 2011, the date the financial statements were issued.
889331_11_ITEM8_P67_S0	Accounting Pronouncements : In June 2009, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued authoritative guidance that eliminates the qualifying special purpose entity concept, changes the requirements for derecognizing financial assets and requires enhanced disclosures about transfers of financial assets.
889331_11_ITEM8_P67_S1	The guidance also revises earlier guidance for determining whether an entity is a variable interest entity, requires a new approach for determining who should consolidate a variable interest entity, changes when it is necessary to reassess who should consolidate a variable interest entity, and requires enhanced disclosures related to an enterprise s involvement in variable interest entities.
889331_11_ITEM8_P68_S0	The guid ance is effective for the first annual reporting period that begins after November 15, 2009.
889331_11_ITEM8_P68_S1	The company adopted the new accounting guidance on January 3, 2010, which did not have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM8_P69_S0	In October 2009, the FASB issued authoritative guidance that amends earlier guidance addressing the accounting for contractual arrangements in which an entity provides multiple products or services (deliverables) to a customer.
889331_11_ITEM8_P69_S1	The amendments address the unit of accounting for arrangements involving multiple deliverables and how arrangement consideration should be allocated to the separate units of accounting, when applicable, by establishing a selling price hierarchy for determining the selling price of a deliverable.
889331_11_ITEM8_P69_S2	The selling price used for each deliverable will be based on vendor-specific objective evidence if available, third-party evidence if vendor-specific objective evidence is not available, or estimated selling price if neither vendor-specific nor third-party evidence is available.
889331_11_ITEM8_P69_S3	The amendments also req uire that arrangement consideration be allocated at the inception of an arrangement to all deliverables using the relative selling price method.
889331_11_ITEM8_P69_S4	The guidance is effective for fiscal years beginning on or after June 15, 2010 with early adoption allowed.
889331_11_ITEM8_P69_S5	The company adopted the new accounting guidance on January 3, 2010, which did not have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM8_P70_S0	In October 2009, the FASB issued authoritative guidance that amends earlier guidance for revenue arrangements that include both tangible products and software elements.
889331_11_ITEM8_P70_S1	Tangible products containing software components and non-software components that function together to deliver the tangible product s essential functionality are no longer within the scope of guidance for recognizing revenue from the sale of software, but would be accounted for in accordance with other authoritative guidance.
889331_11_ITEM8_P70_S2	The guidance is effective for fiscal years beginning on or after June 15, 2010, with earlier application permitted.
889331_11_ITEM8_P70_S3	The company does not believe the accounting guidance will have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM8_P71_S0	In January 2010, the FASB issued additional guidance to improve fair value disclosures and increase the transparency in financial reporting.
889331_11_ITEM8_P71_S1	These enhancements include: (1) a reporting entity should disclose separately the amounts of significant transfers in and out of Level 1 and Level 2 fair value measurements and describe the reasons for the transfers; and (2) in the reconciliation for fair value measurements using significant unobservable inputs, a reporting entity should present separately information about purchases, sales, issuances, and settlements.
889331_11_ITEM8_P71_S2	This new guidance is effective for interim and annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2009.
889331_11_ITEM8_P71_S3	The company adopted the new accounting guidance on January 3, 2010, which did no t have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM8_P72_S0	In February 2010, the SEC issued a statement that reaffirms its support for the potential use of IFRS in the preparation of financial statements by U.S. registrants.
889331_11_ITEM8_P72_S1	It announced a work plan by which it is expected to make a determination in 2011 whether or not it will mandate the conversion to IFRS.
889331_11_ITEM8_P72_S2	As of October 2010, the SEC continues to anticipate making the determination in 2011 of whether, when, and how to incorporate IFRS into the U.S. domestic financial reporting system.
889331_11_ITEM8_P72_S3	The company is currently assessing the potential impact of IFRS on its Consolidated Financial Statements and will continue to review progress of the work plan.
889331_11_ITEM8_P73_S0	In December 2010, the FASB issued authoritative guidance related to disclosure of supplementary pro forma information for business combinations.
889331_11_ITEM8_P73_S1	The guidance specified that if a public entity presents comparative financial statements, the entity should disclose revenue and earnings of the combined entity as though the business combination(s) that occurred during the current year had occurred as of the beginning of the comparable prior annual reporting period only.
889331_11_ITEM8_P73_S2	The amendments also expand the supplemental pro forma disclosures to include a description of the nature and amount of material, nonrecurring pro forma adjustments directly attributable to the business combination included in the reported pro forma revenue and earnings.
889331_11_ITEM8_P73_S3	The guidance is effective prospectively for business combinations for which the acquisit ion date is on or after the beginning of the first annual reporting period beginning on or after December 15, 2010.
889331_11_ITEM8_P73_S4	The company does not believe that the adoption of this guidance will have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM8_P74_S0	In December 2010, the FASB issued an authoritative guidance describing when to perform step 2 of the goodwill impairment test for reporting units with zero or negative carrying amounts.
889331_11_ITEM8_P74_S1	The amendments in this guidance modify Step 1 of the goodwill impairment test for reporting units with zero or negative carrying amounts.
889331_11_ITEM8_P74_S2	For those reporting units, an entity is required to perform Step 2 of the goodwill impairment test if it is more likely than not that a goodwill impairment exists.
889331_11_ITEM8_P75_S0	In determining whether it is more likely than not that goodwill impairment exists, an entity should consider whether there are any adverse qualitative factors indicating that impairment may exist.
889331_11_ITEM8_P75_S1	The qualitative factors are consistent with the existing guidance and examples, which require that goodwill of a reporting unit be tested for i mpairment between annual tests if an event occurs or circumstances change that would more likely than not reduce the fair value of a reporting unit below its carrying amount.
889331_11_ITEM8_P75_S2	For public entities, the amendments in this guidance are effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2010.
889331_11_ITEM8_P75_S3	The company expects to adopt this guidance effective the beginning of fiscal year 2011, and does not expect it to have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_11_ITEM8_P76_S0	On February 29, 2008, the company acquired Shock Block Corporation ( Shock Block ), a leading manufacturer in ground fault technology located in Dallas, Texas, for $9.2 million less a holdback of $0.9 million subject to the fulfillment of certain contractual obligations by the seller.
889331_11_ITEM8_P76_S1	From February 29, 2008 and thereafter, the results of operations of Shock Block are included in the company s Consolidated Statements of Income.
889331_11_ITEM8_P77_S0	The company primarily acquired customer lists and intellectual property rights, including trademarks and tradenames.
889331_11_ITEM8_P77_S1	The customer lists were assigned a useful life of seven years.
889331_11_ITEM8_P77_S2	The company funded the acquisition with cash and has continued to operate Shock Block s electrical business subseque nt to the acquisition.
889331_11_ITEM8_P77_S3	The Shock Block acquisition expands the company s portfolio of protection products for commercial and industrial applications and strengthens the company s position in the circuit protection industry.
889331_11_ITEM8_P78_S0	The acquisition was accounted for using the purchase method of accounting and the operations of Shock Block are included in the company s consolidated results from the date of the acquisition.
889331_11_ITEM8_P79_S0	The following table sets forth the preliminary purchase price allocations for Shock Block s net assets in accordance with the purchase method of accounting with adjustments to record the acquired net assets at their estimated fair market or net realizable values.
889331_11_ITEM8_P80_S0	All Shock Block goodwill and other assets are recorded in the Electrical business unit segment and reflected in the Americas geographical area.
889331_11_ITEM8_P80_S1	Goodwill for the above acquisition is not expected to be deductible for tax purposes.
889331_11_ITEM8_P81_S0	On September 17, 2008, the company announced that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the stock of Startco Engineering Ltd. ( Startco ), a leading manufacturer in ground-fault protection products and custom-power distribution centers located in Saskatchewan, Canada.
889331_11_ITEM8_P81_S1	On September 30, 2008, the company completed the purchase of Startco for approximately $37.7 million.
889331_11_ITEM8_P81_S2	From September 30, 2008 and thereafter, the results of operations of Startco are included in the company s Consolidated Statements of Income.
889331_11_ITEM8_P81_S3	The company funded the acquisition with proceeds from the Loan Agreement discussed in Note 6.
889331_11_ITEM8_P82_S0	The Startco acquisition strengthens the company s position in the industrial ground-fault protection business and provides industrial power distribution design and manufacturing capabilities that strengthen the company s position within the growing mining industry.
889331_11_ITEM8_P82_S1	The acquisition was accounted for using the purchase method of accounting and the operations of Startco are included in the company s consolidated results from the date of the acquisition.
889331_11_ITEM8_P83_S0	The following table sets forth the purchase price allocation for Startco s net assets in accordance with the purchase method of accounting with adjustments to record the acquired net assets at their estimated fair market or net realizable values.

889331_11_ITEM8_P84_S1	The patents and product designs are both being amortized over 12 years.
889331_11_ITEM8_P84_S2	Customer lists are being amortized over 15 years.
889331_11_ITEM8_P84_S3	Backlog is being amortized over 3 years.
889331_11_ITEM8_P84_S4	Trademarks and tradenames have indefinite lives and are not being amortized.
889331_11_ITEM8_P84_S5	Goodwill for the above acquisition is not expected to be deductible for tax purposes.
889331_11_ITEM8_P85_S0	On December 17, 2010, the company acquired the Cole Hersee Company ( Cole Hersee ), a leading manufacturer of power management products and heavy duty electromechanical and solid-state switches, for $50.0 million.
889331_11_ITEM8_P85_S1	The acquisition allows the company to further expand its off-road, truck and bus business.

889331_11_ITEM8_P99_S0	Included in investments are shares of Polytronics Technology Corporation Ltd. ( Polytronics ), a Taiwanese company.
889331_11_ITEM8_P99_S1	In addition, the company had an immaterial investment in Sumi Motherson, an Indian company, which was sold during the quarter ended September 26, 2009 for 0.1 million (approximately $0.2 million).
889331_11_ITEM8_P99_S2	Both of these investments were acquired as part of the Littelfuse GmbH (formerly known as Heinrich Industries, AG) acquisition.
889331_11_ITEM8_P99_S3	The company s Polytronics shares held at the end of fiscal 2010 and 2009 represent approximately 8.0% of total Polytronics shares outstanding for both years.
889331_11_ITEM8_P99_S4	The fair value of the Polytronics investment was 8.8 million (approximately $11.7 million) at January 1, 2011 and 8.2 million (approximately $11.7 million) a t January 2, 2010.

889331_11_ITEM8_P99_S6	The remaining movement year over year was due to the impact of changes in exchange rates.
889331_11_ITEM8_P100_S0	The investment in Polytronics stock had traded significantly below its acquisition cost of 4.1 million (approximately $4.3 million) from June 2008 through December 27, 2008 and had not traded above cost during that time period.
889331_11_ITEM8_P100_S1	As such, management concluded as of December 27, 2008 that it was more likely than not the loss was other than temporary .
889331_11_ITEM8_P100_S2	The cost basis of the security was adjusted down to the fair value as of the measurement date with a resulting charge to earnings.
889331_11_ITEM8_P100_S3	Consequently, the company recorded a realized loss on investment of 2.0 million (approximately $2.8 million) to other expense (income), net for the fiscal year ended December 27, 2008.
889331_11_ITEM8_P101_S0	The carrying amounts of long-term debt at January 1, 2011 and January 2, 2010 are as follows:
889331_11_ITEM8_P102_S0	On September 29, 2008, the company entered into a Loan Agreement with various lenders that provides the company with a five-year term loan facility of up to $80.0 million for the purposes of (i) refinancing certain existing indebtedness; (ii) funding working capital needs; and (iii) funding capital expenditures and other lawful corporate purposes, including permitted acquisitions.
889331_11_ITEM8_P102_S1	The Loan Agreement also contains an expansion feature, pursuant to which the company may from time to time request incremental loans in an aggregate principal amount not to exceed $40.0 million.
889331_11_ITEM8_P102_S2	The company had $49.0 million outstanding on the term loan at January 1, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM8_P103_S0	At the company s option, any loan under the Loan Agreement bears interest at a rate equal to the applicable rate, as determined in accordance with the pricing grid set forth in the Loan Agreement, plus one of the following indexes: (i) LIBOR or (ii) the Base Rate (defined as the higher of (a) the prime rate publicly announced from time to time by the Agent under the Loan Agreement and (b) the federal funds rate plus 0.50%).
889331_11_ITEM8_P103_S1	Overdue amounts bear a fee of 2.0% per annum above the applicable rate.
889331_11_ITEM8_P103_S2	The actual interest rate paid on the term loan was approximately 1.8% for the year ended January 1, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM8_P104_S0	The Loan Agreement requires the company to meet certain financial tests, including a consolidated leverage ratio and a consolidated interest coverage ratio.
889331_11_ITEM8_P104_S1	The Loan Agreement also contains additional affirmative and negative covenants which, among other things, impose certain limitations on the company s ability to merge with other companies, create liens on its property, incur additional indebtedness, enter into transactions with affiliates except on an arm s length basis, or dispose of property.
889331_11_ITEM8_P104_S2	At January 1, 2011, and January 2, 2010, and for the years then ended, the company was in compliance with these covenants.
889331_11_ITEM8_P104_S3	This Loan Agreement does not impact the existing debt covenants in the revolving credit facility described below.
889331_11_ITEM8_P105_S0	On January 28, 2009, the company entered into an unsecured financing arrangement with a Canadian bank that provided a CAD 10.0 million (equivalent to approximately $10.0 million at January 1, 2011) revolving credit facility, for capital expenditures and general working capital, which expires on July 21, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM8_P105_S1	This facility consists of prime-based loans and overdrafts, bankers acceptances and U.S. base rate loans and overdrafts, and is guaranteed by the company.
889331_11_ITEM8_P105_S2	At January 1, 2011, the company had approximately CAD 10.0 million (equivalent to approximately $10.0 million) available under the revolving credit facility.
889331_11_ITEM8_P106_S0	This agreement contains covenants that, among other matters, impose limitations on future mergers, sales of assets, and changes in control, as defined in the agreement.
889331_11_ITEM8_P106_S1	In add ition, the company is required to satisfy certain financial covenants and tests relating to, among other matters, interest coverage, working capital, leverage and net worth.
889331_11_ITEM8_P106_S2	At January 1, 2011, the company was in compliance with all covenants.
889331_11_ITEM8_P107_S0	The company has an unsecured domestic financing arrangement consisting of a credit agreement with banks that provides a $75.0 million revolving credit facility, with a potential increase of up to $125.0 million upon request of the company and agreement with the lenders, which expires on July 21, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM8_P107_S1	At January 1, 2011, the company had available $50.0 million of borrowing capacity under the revolving credit facility at an interest rate of LIBOR plus 0.500% (0.76% as of January 1, 2011).
889331_11_ITEM8_P107_S2	The company also had $2.3 million available in letters of credit at January 1, 2011, and January 2, 2010, respectively.
889331_11_ITEM8_P107_S3	No amounts were outstanding under these letters of credit at fiscal year-end 2010 and 2009.
889331_11_ITEM8_P108_S0	The domestic bank credit agreement contains covenants that, among other matters, impose limitations on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, future mergers, sales of assets, and changes in control, as defined in the agreement.
889331_11_ITEM8_P108_S1	In addition, the company is required to satisfy certain financial covenants and tests relating to, among other matters, interest coverage, working capital, leverage and net worth.
889331_11_ITEM8_P108_S2	At January 1, 2011, and January 2, 2010, and for the years then ended, the company was in compliance with these covenants.

889331_11_ITEM8_P110_S0	Occasionally, the company uses financial instruments to manage its exposures to movements in commodity prices, foreign exchange and interest rates.
889331_11_ITEM8_P110_S1	The use of these financial instruments modifies the company s exposure to these risks with the goal of reducing the risk or cost to the company.
889331_11_ITEM8_P110_S2	The company does not use derivatives for trading purposes and is not a party to leveraged derivative contracts.
889331_11_ITEM8_P111_S0	The company recognizes all derivative instruments as either assets or liabilities at fair value in the Consolidated Balance Sheets.
889331_11_ITEM8_P111_S1	The fair value is based upon either market quotes for actively traded instruments or independent bids for non-exchange traded instruments.
889331_11_ITEM8_P111_S2	The company formally documents its hedge relationships, including identifying the hedging instruments and the hedged items, as well as its risk management objectives and strategies for undertaking the hedge transaction.
889331_11_ITEM8_P112_S0	This process includes linking derivatives that are designated as hedges of specific assets, liabilities, firm commitments or forecasted transactions to the hedged risk.
889331_11_ITEM8_P112_S1	On the date the derivative is entered into, the company designates the derivative as a fair value hedge, cash flow hedge or a net investment hedge, and accounts for the derivative in accordance with its designation.
889331_11_ITEM8_P112_S2	The company also formally assesses, both at inception and at least quarterly thereafter, whether the derivatives are highly effective in offsetting changes in either the fair value or cash flows of the hedged item.
889331_11_ITEM8_P112_S3	If it is determined that a derivative ceases to be a highly effective hedge, or if the anticipated transaction is no longer likely to occur, the company discontinues hedge accounting, and any deferred gains or losses are recorded in the respective measurement period.
889331_11_ITEM8_P113_S0	The company currently does not have any outstanding hedge instruments.
889331_11_ITEM8_P114_S0	A hedge of a forecasted transaction or of the variability of cash flows to be received or paid related to a recognized asset or liability is designated as a cash flow hedge.
889331_11_ITEM8_P114_S1	The effective portion of the change in the fair value of a derivative that is designated as a cash flow hedge is recorded in other comprehensive income (loss).
889331_11_ITEM8_P114_S2	When the impact of the hedged item is recognized in the income statement, the gain or loss included in other comprehensive income (loss) is reported on the same line in the Consolidated Statements of Income as the hedged item.
889331_11_ITEM8_P115_S0	In January 2009, the company entered into a series of weekly forward contracts to buy Mexican pesos to manage its exposure to fluctuations in the cost of this currency through December 28, 2009.
889331_11_ITEM8_P115_S1	The company uses Mexican pesos to fund payroll and operating expenses at one of the company s Mexico manufacturing facilities.
889331_11_ITEM8_P115_S2	The operations of the Mexico facility are accounted for within an entity where the U.S. dollar is the functional currency.
889331_11_ITEM8_P115_S3	In September 2009, the company extended the arrangement through June 28, 2010.
889331_11_ITEM8_P116_S0	Amounts included in other comprehensive income (loss) are reclassified into cost of sales in the period in which the hedged transaction is recognized in earnings.
889331_11_ITEM8_P117_S0	As of July 3, 2010, the company s Mexican peso forward contracts expired.
