889331_11_ITEM8_P121_S0	In determining fair value, the company uses various valuation approaches within the fair value measurement framework.
889331_11_ITEM8_P121_S1	Fair value measurements are determined based on the assumptions that market participants would use in pricing an asset or liability.
889331_11_ITEM8_P122_S0	Applicable accounting literature establishes a hierarchy for inputs used in measuring fair value that maximizes the use of observable inputs and minimizes the use of unobservable inputs by requiring that the most observable inputs be used when available.
889331_11_ITEM8_P122_S1	Applicable accounting literature defines levels within the hierarchy based on the reliability of inputs as follows:
889331_11_ITEM8_P123_S0	Level 3 Valuations derived from valuation techniques in which one or more significant inputs or significant value drivers are unobservable, such as pricing models, discounted cash flow models and similar techniques not based on market, exchange, dealer or broker-traded transactions.
889331_11_ITEM8_P124_S0	Following is a description of the valuation methodologies used for instruments measured at fair value and their classification in the valuation hierarchy.
889331_11_ITEM8_P125_S0	Equity securities listed on a national market or exchange are valued at the last sales price.
889331_11_ITEM8_P125_S1	Such securities are classified within Level 1 of the valuation hierarchy.
889331_11_ITEM8_P126_S0	The fair values of commodity derivatives are valued based on quoted futures prices for the underlying commodity and are categorized as Level 2.
889331_11_ITEM8_P126_S1	The fair values of interest rate and foreign exchange rate derivatives are determined based on inputs that are readily available in public markets or can be derived from information available in publicly quoted markets and are categorized as Level 2.
889331_11_ITEM8_P127_S0	The company does not have any financial assets or liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis categorized as Level 3, and there were no transfers in or out of Level 3 during 2010 or 2009.
889331_11_ITEM8_P127_S1	There were no changes during the year ended January 1, 2011, to the company s valuation techniques used to measure asset and liability fair values on a recurring basis.
889331_11_ITEM8_P127_S2	As of January 1, 2011 and January 2, 2010, the company held no non-financial assets or liabilities that are required to be measured at fair value on a recurring basis.
889331_11_ITEM8_P128_S0	The following table presents assets measured at fair value by classification within the fair value hierarchy as of January 1, 2011 (in thousands):
889331_11_ITEM8_P129_S0	The following table presents assets measured at fair value by classification within the fair value hierarchy as of January 2, 2010 (in thousands):
889331_11_ITEM8_P130_S0	The company s other financial instruments include cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable and long-term debt.
889331_11_ITEM8_P130_S1	Due to their short-term maturity, the carrying amounts of cash and cash equivalents and accounts receivable approximate their fair values.
889331_11_ITEM8_P130_S2	The company s long-term debt fair value approximates book value at January 1, 2011 and January 2, 2010, respectively, as the long-term debt variable interest rates fluctuate along with market interest rates.

889331_11_ITEM8_P145_S0	Included in other long-term liabilities is an accrual related to former coal mining operations at Littelfuse GmbH (formerly known as Heinrich Industries, AG) for the amounts of 3.3 million ($4.4 million) and 3.8 million ($5.4 million) at January 1, 2011, and January 2, 2010, respectively.
889331_11_ITEM8_P146_S0	Management accrues for losses associated with litigation and environmental claims based on management's best estimate of future costs when such losses are probable and reasonably able to be estimated.
889331_11_ITEM8_P146_S1	Management uses, in conjunction with an independent third-party to prepare an annual engineering study, performs an annual evaluation of the former coal mining operations in order to develop its estimate of their probable future obligations in regard to remediating the dangers (such as a shaft collapse) of aba ndoned coal mine shafts in the former coal mining operations.
889331_11_ITEM8_P146_S2	The ultimate determination can only be done after respective investigations because the concrete conditions are mostly unknown at this time.
889331_11_ITEM8_P147_S0	The accrual recorded represents the lower end of management s estimated range of potential future costs, which ranges from 3.36 million ($4.4 million) to 6.3 million ($7.6 million) at January 1, 2011 as management does not have reason to believe that any amount in the above range is a better estimate than another.
889331_11_ITEM8_P147_S1	The accrual is not discounted as management cannot reasonably estimate when such remediation efforts will take place.
889331_11_ITEM8_P147_S2	While the ultimate exposure at these former coal mining operations continues to be evaluated, the company does not anticipate a material effect on its consolidated financial position or results of operations.

889331_11_ITEM8_P168_S0	Equity Plans : The company has equity-based compensation plans authorizing the granting of stock options, restricted shares, restricted share units, performance shares, and other stock rights of up to 5,925,000 shares of common stock to employees and directors.
889331_11_ITEM8_P169_S0	Stock options granted prior to 2002 vest over a five-year period and are exercisable over a ten-year period commencing from the date of vesting.
889331_11_ITEM8_P169_S1	The stock options granted in 2002 through February 2005, vest over a five-year period and are exercisable over a ten-year period commencing from the date of the grant.
889331_11_ITEM8_P169_S2	Stock options granted after February 2005, vest over a three, four or five-year period and are exercisable over either a seven or ten-year period commencing from the date of the grant.
889331_11_ITEM8_P169_S3	Restricted shares and share units granted by the company vest over three to four years.
889331_11_ITEM8_P170_S0	The company also has performance share agreements under its equity-based compensation plans pursuant to which a target amount of performance share awards have been granted based on the company attaining certain financial performance goals relating to return on net tangible assets (for performance shares granted prior to 2008) or return on net assets (for performance shares granted in 2008 and 2009) and earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization over a three-year performance period.
889331_11_ITEM8_P170_S1	The performance-based restricted stock awards granted prior to 2008 vest in thirds over a three-year period (following the three-year performance period).
889331_11_ITEM8_P170_S2	When vested, half of the stock awards are paid in cash and half will be settled through the issuance of the company s common stock.
889331_11_ITEM8_P170_S3	The performance-based restri cted stock awards granted in 2008 and 2009 vest after a three-year performance period and are satisfied completely by the issuance of the company s common stock at the end of the performance period.
889331_11_ITEM8_P170_S4	The fair value of the performance-based restricted stock awards that are settled in common stock is measured at the market price on the grant date, and the fair value of the portion paid in cash is measured at the current market price of a share.

889331_11_ITEM8_P193_S0	An operating segment is defined as a component of an enterprise that engages in business activities from which it may earn revenues and incur expenses, and about which separate financial information is regularly evaluated by the Chief Operating Decision Maker ( CODM ) in deciding how to allocate resources.
889331_11_ITEM8_P193_S1	The CODM is the company s President and Chief Executive Officer ( CEO ).
889331_11_ITEM8_P194_S0	The company reports its operations by the following business unit segments: Electronics, Automotive and Electrical.
889331_11_ITEM8_P195_S0	Provides circuit protection components and expertise to leading global manufacturers of a wide range of electronic products including mobile phones, computers, LCD TVs, telecommunications equipment, medical devices, lighting products and white goods.
889331_11_ITEM8_P195_S1	The Electronics business segment has the broadest product offering in the industry including fuses and protectors, positive temperature coefficient ( PTC ) resettable fuses, varistors, polymer electrostatic discharge ( ESD ) suppressors, discrete transient voltage suppression ( TVS ) diodes, TVS diode arrays and protection thyristors, gas discharge tubes, power switching components and fuseholders, blocks and related accessories.
889331_11_ITEM8_P196_S0	Provides circuit protection products to the worldwide automotive original equipment manufacturers ( OEM ) and parts distributors of passenger automobiles, trucks, buses and off-road equipment.
889331_11_ITEM8_P196_S1	The company also sells its fuses in the automotive replacement parts market.
889331_11_ITEM8_P196_S2	Products include blade fuses, high current fuses, battery cable protectors and varistors.
889331_11_ITEM8_P197_S0	Provides circuit protection products and hazard assessments for industrial and commercial customers.
889331_11_ITEM8_P197_S1	Products include power fuses and other circuit protection devices that are used in commercial and industrial buildings and large equipment such as HVAC systems, elevators and machine tools.
889331_11_ITEM8_P198_S0	Each of the operating segments is directly responsible for sales, marketing and research and development.
889331_11_ITEM8_P198_S1	Manufacturing, purchasing, logistics, customer service, finance, information technology and human resources are shared functions that are allocated back to the three operating segments.
889331_11_ITEM8_P198_S2	The CEO allocates resources to and assesses the performance of each operating segment using information about its revenue and operating income (loss), but does not evaluate the operating segments using discrete asset information.
889331_11_ITEM8_P199_S0	Sales, marketing and research and development expenses are charged directly into each operating segment.
889331_11_ITEM8_P199_S1	All other functions are shared by the operating segments and expenses for these shared functions are allocated to the operating segments and included in the operating results reported below.
889331_11_ITEM8_P199_S2	The company does not report inter-segment revenue because the operating segments do not record it.
889331_11_ITEM8_P199_S3	The company does not allocate interest and other income, interest expense, or taxes to operating segments.
889331_11_ITEM8_P199_S4	Although the CEO uses operating income to evaluate the segments, operating costs included in one segment may benefit other segments.
889331_11_ITEM8_P200_S0	Except as discussed above, the accounting policies for segment reporting are the same as for the company as a whole.
889331_11_ITEM8_P201_S0	The company has provided this business unit segment information for all comparable prior periods.
889331_11_ITEM8_P201_S1	Segment information is summarized as follows (in thousands):

889331_11_ITEM8_P202_S1	Included in Other Operating income (loss) for 2009 are severance and asset impairment charges related to restructuring activities in the U.S. ($1.6 million), Europe ($5.5 million) and Asia-Pacific ($1.5 million) locations (see Note 9).

889331_11_ITEM8_P206_S1	The difference between straight-line basis rent and the amount paid has been recorded as accrued lease obligations.
889331_11_ITEM8_P206_S2	The company also has leases that have lease renewal provisions.
889331_11_ITEM8_P206_S3	As of January 1, 2011, all operating leases outstanding were with third parties.
889331_11_ITEM8_P206_S4	The company did not have any capital leases as of January 1, 2011.

889331_11_ITEM8_P207_S1	The lease, with a stated commencement date of January 1, 2009, expires December 31, 2024, and contains two five-year renewal options.
889331_11_ITEM8_P207_S2	In addition, the lease contains leasehold improvement incentives and rent abatement for the first year of the lease.
889331_11_ITEM8_P207_S3	The company recognizes rental expense for this lease on a straight-line basis over the term of the lease, including base rent and all considerations received.

889331_11_ITEM8_P210_S0	In June 2008, the FASB issued authoritative guidance titled Determining Whether Instruments Granted in Share-Based Payment Transactions Are Participating Securities.
889331_11_ITEM8_P210_S1	The guidance states that unvested share-based payment awards that contain nonforfeitable rights to dividends or dividend equivalents (whether paid or unpaid) are participating securities and shall be included in the computation of earnings per share pursuant to the two-class method.
889331_11_ITEM8_P210_S2	Upon adoption, a company is required to retrospectively adjust its earnings per share data presentation to conform with the guidance provisions.
889331_11_ITEM8_P210_S3	The guidance is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2008.
889331_11_ITEM8_P210_S4	The company adopted the new guidance on December 28, 2008.
889331_11_ITEM8_P211_S0	criteria of a participating security as defined by the guidance.
889331_11_ITEM8_P211_S1	The adoption has changed the methodology of computing the company s earnings per share to the two-class method from the treasury stock method.
889331_11_ITEM8_P211_S2	This change has not affected previously reported earnings per share, consolidated net earnings or net cash flows from operations.
889331_11_ITEM8_P212_S0	Under the two-class method, earnings are allocated between common stock and participating securities.
889331_11_ITEM8_P212_S1	The guidance provides that the presentation of basic and diluted earnings per share is required only for each class of common stock and not for participating securities.
889331_11_ITEM8_P212_S2	As such, the company will present basic and diluted earnings per share for its one class of common stock.
889331_11_ITEM8_P213_S0	The two-class method includes an earnings allocation formula that determines earnings per share for each class of common stock according to dividends declared and undistributed earnings for the period.
889331_11_ITEM8_P213_S1	The company s reported net earnings is reduced by the amount allocated to participating securities to arrive at the earnings allocated to common stock shareholders for purposes of calculating earnings per share.
889331_11_ITEM8_P214_S0	The dilutive effect of participating securities is calculated using the more dilutive of the treasury stock or the two-class method.
889331_11_ITEM8_P214_S1	The company has determined the two-class method to be the more dilutive.
889331_11_ITEM8_P214_S2	As such, the earnings allocated to common stock shareholders in the basic earnings per share calculation is adjusted for the reallocation of undistributed earnings to participating securities as prescribed by the guidance to arrive at the earnings allocated to common stock shareholders for calculating the diluted earnings per share.
889331_11_ITEM8_P215_S0	The following table sets forth the computation of basic and diluted earnings per share under the two-class method:
889331_11_ITEM8_P216_S0	The following potential shares of common stock attributable to stock options were excluded from the earnings per share calculation because their effect would be anti-dilutive: 77,729 in 2010; 1,812,414 in 2009; and 1,322,540 in 2008.
889331_11_ITEM8_P217_S0	The quarterly periods for 2010 are for the 13-weeks ending January 1, 2011, October 2, 2010, July 3, 2010 and April 3, 2010, respectively.
889331_11_ITEM8_P217_S1	The quarterly periods listed in the table below for 2009 are for the 14-weeks ending January 2, 2010 and the 13-weeks ending September 26, 2009, June 27, 2009 and March 28, 2009, respectively.
889331_11_ITEM8_P218_S0	In the third quarter of 2010, the company recorded a $3.0 million charge related to asset impairments in the U.S. and Europe.
889331_11_ITEM8_P219_S0	In the third quarter of 2009, the company recorded a $1.7 million charge related to severance and asset impairments in Europe and Asia.
889331_11_ITEM8_P219_S1	In addition, the company realized an income tax benefit from the release of $2.6 million in contingent income tax reserves due to the lapsing of statutes of limitations.
889331_11_ITEM8_P220_S0	In the second quarter of 2009, the company recorded a $7.3 million charge related to severance charges and asset write-offs for the U.S., Europe and Asia.
889331_11_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 requires management to include in this Annual Report on Form 10-K a report on management s assessment of the effectiveness of the company s internal control over financial reporting, as well as an attestation report from the company s independent registered accounting firm on the effectiveness of the company s internal control over financial reporting.
889331_11_ITEM9A_P1_S0	The management of Littelfuse is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as such term is defined in Exchange Act Rule 13a-15(f).
889331_11_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Littelfuse s internal control system was designed to provide reasonable assurance to its management and the Board of Directors regarding the preparation and fair presentation of published financial statements.
889331_11_ITEM9A_P2_S0	All internal control systems, no matter how well designed, have inherent limitations.
889331_11_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Therefore, even those systems determined effective can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation.
889331_11_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Littelfuse s management assessed the effectiveness of the company s internal control over financial reporting as of January 1, 2011, based upon the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ).
889331_11_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Based on this assessment, the company s management concluded that, as of January 1, 2011, the company s internal control over financial reporting is effective.
889331_11_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Littelfuse s independent registered public accounting firm, Ernst Young LLP, has audited the effectiveness of the company s internal control over financial reporting as of January 1, 2011.
889331_11_ITEM9A_P4_S1	Their report appears on page 39 hereof.
889331_11_ITEM9A_P5_S0	There was no change in the company s internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the company s most recent fiscal quarter that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the company s internal control over financial reporting.
889331_11_ITEM9A_P6_S0	The company maintains disclosure controls and procedures that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in the company s Exchange Act reports is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the Securities and Exchange Commission s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to the company s management, including the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
889331_11_ITEM9A_P7_S0	As of January 1, 2011, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer of the company evaluated the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures of the company and concluded that these disclosure controls and procedures were effective.
889331_11_ITEM10_P0_S0	The executive officers of the company are as follows:
889331_11_ITEM10_P1_S0	Officers of Littelfuse are elected by the Board of Directors and serve at the discretion of the Board.
889331_11_ITEM10_P2_S0	Gordon Hunter was elected as the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the company and President and Chief Executive Officer effective January 1, 2005.
889331_11_ITEM10_P2_S1	Mr. Hunter served as Chief Operating Officer of the company from November 2003 to January 2005.
889331_11_ITEM10_P2_S2	Mr. Hunter has been a member of the Board of Directors of the company since June 2002, where he has served as Chairman of the Technology Committee.
889331_11_ITEM10_P2_S3	Prior to joining Littelfuse, Mr. Hunter was employed with Intel Corporation, where he was Vice President, Intel Communications Group, and General Manager, Optical Products Group, responsible for managing the access and optical communications business segments, from 2002 to 2003.
889331_11_ITEM10_P2_S4	Mr. Hunter was CEO for Calmar Optcom during 2001.
889331_11_ITEM10_P2_S5	From 1997 to 2002, he also served as a Vice President for Raychem Corporation.
889331_11_ITEM10_P2_S6	His experience includes 20 years with Raychem Corporation in the United States and Europe, with responsibilities in sales, marketing, engineering and general management.
889331_11_ITEM10_P3_S0	Philip G. Franklin, Vice President, Operations Support, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer, joined the company in 1998 and is responsible for finance and accounting, investor relations, mergers and acquisitions, and information systems.
889331_11_ITEM10_P3_S1	Prior to joining Littelfuse, Mr. Franklin was Vice President and Chief Financial Officer for OmniQuip International, a private equity sponsored roll-up in the construction equipment industry, which he helped take public.
889331_11_ITEM10_P3_S2	Before that, Mr. Franklin served as Chief Financial Officer for both Monarch Marking Systems, a subsidiary of Pitney Bowes, and Hill Refrigeration, a company controlled by Sam Zell.
889331_11_ITEM10_P3_S3	Earlier in his career, he worked in a variety of finance and general management positions at FMC Corporation.
889331_11_ITEM10_P4_S0	Dal Ferbert, Vice President and General Manager, Electrical Business Unit, is responsible for the management of daily operations, sales, marketing and strategic planning efforts of the Electrical Business Unit (POWR-GARD ) products.
889331_11_ITEM10_P4_S1	Mr. Ferbert joined the company in 1976 as a member of the electronic distributor sales team.
889331_11_ITEM10_P4_S2	From 1980 to 1989 he served in the Materials Management Department as a buyer and then Purchasing Manager.
889331_11_ITEM10_P4_S3	In 1990, he was promoted to National Sales Manager of the Electrical Business Unit and then promoted to his current position in 2004.
889331_11_ITEM10_P5_S0	Dieter Roeder, Vice President and General Manager, Automotive Business Unit, is responsible for marketing, sales, product development and customer relationships for all automotive business units.
889331_11_ITEM10_P5_S1	Mr. Roeder joined the company in 2005 leading the Automotive Business Unit s European sales team, based in Germany, before he was promoted to his current position in August 2007.
889331_11_ITEM10_P5_S2	Prior to joining the company, Mr. Roeder served as Director of Business Development Europe for TDS Automotive from 2002 to 2005.
889331_11_ITEM10_P5_S3	Before that, Mr. Roeder spent ten years with Raychem GmbH (later Tyco Electronics) where he had various sales and marketing responsibilities within the European automotive industry.
889331_11_ITEM10_P6_S0	Chen-Ming Wang, Vice President and General Manager, Electronics Business Unit, is responsible for marketing, sales, product development and customer relationships of the Electronic Business Unit.
889331_11_ITEM10_P6_S1	He is also responsible for leading the company s overall operations, strategy and new business development in Asia.
889331_11_ITEM10_P6_S2	Mr. Wang has multinational experience in the electronics business, including the U.S., Mexico, Malaysia, China and Taiwan.
889331_11_ITEM10_P6_S3	Mr. Wang joined the management team in November 2009, prior to which he was vice president of Lite-On Technology Corporation.
889331_11_ITEM10_P6_S4	Lite-On Technology Corporation, a Taiwanese provider of consumer electrical products, is where Mr. Wang started his career in 1991, holding operation, sales and business development responsibilities.
889331_11_ITEM10_P7_S0	David W. Heinzmann, Vice President, Global Operations, is responsible for Littelfuse s manufacturing and supply chain groups for all three of the company s business units.
889331_11_ITEM10_P7_S1	Mr. Heinzmann began his career at the company in 1985 and possesses a broad range of experience within the organization.
889331_11_ITEM10_P7_S2	He has held positions as a Manufacturing Manager, Quality Manager, Plant Manager and Product Development Manager.
889331_11_ITEM10_P7_S3	Mr. Heinzmann also served as Director of Global Operations of the Electronics Business Unit from early 2000 through 2003.
889331_11_ITEM10_P7_S4	He served as Vice President and General Manager, Automotive Business Unit, from 2004 through August 2007 and then was promoted to his current position.
889331_11_ITEM10_P8_S0	Ryan K. Stafford, General Counsel and Vice President, Human Resources, is responsible for the company s legal, compliance, internal audit and human resources functions.
889331_11_ITEM10_P8_S1	Mr. Stafford joined the company s management team in January 2007.
889331_11_ITEM10_P8_S2	Prior to joining the company, Mr. Stafford served as Vice President of China Operations for Tyco Engineered Products Services from 2005 to 2006 and Vice President and General Counsel from 2001 to 2005.
889331_11_ITEM10_P8_S3	He served as Associate General Counsel for Grinnell Corporation from 1998 to 2001.
889331_11_ITEM10_P8_S4	Prior to that he was with the law firm Sulloway Hollis P.L.L.C.
889331_11_ITEM10_P9_S0	Paul Dickinson, Vice President and General Manager, Semiconductor Products, is responsible for the marketing, sales, product development and strategic planning efforts of the company s semiconductor products.
889331_11_ITEM10_P9_S1	Mr. Dickinson joined the company in 1993 and has held a broad range of positions with responsibility for corporate and international accounting and finance.
889331_11_ITEM10_P9_S2	Most recently, Mr. Dickinson served as Vice President, Corporate Development and Treasurer from 2005 through 2008, with responsibility for corporate acquisition, strategy, treasury, tax and finance functions.
889331_11_ITEM10_P9_S3	Mr. Dickinson was promoted to his current position in August 2008.
889331_11_ITEM10_P10_S0	Mary S. Muchoney has served as Corporate Secretary since 1991, after joining Littelfuse in 1977.
889331_11_ITEM10_P10_S1	She is responsible for providing all secretarial and administrative functions for the President and Littelfuse Board of Directors.
889331_11_ITEM10_P10_S2	Ms. Muchoney is a member of the Society of Corporate Secretaries Governance Professionals, as well as honorary member of the Society s Silver Quill Society.

889331_11_ITEM15_P44_S0	Pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 (subsections (a) and (b) of Section 1350, Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code), each of the undersigned officers of Littelfuse, Inc. ( the Company ) does hereby certify that to his knowledge:
889331_11_ITEM15_P45_S0	The Annual Report of the Company on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended January 1, 2011 ( the Report ) fully complies with the requirements of section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and the information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
889331_12_ITEM1_P0_S0	Littelfuse, Inc. and its subsidiaries (the company or Littelfuse or we or our ) is the world s leading supplier of circuit protection products for the electronics industry, providing a broad line of circuit protection solutions to worldwide customers.
889331_12_ITEM1_P1_S0	In the electronics market, the company supplies leading manufacturers such as Alcatel-Lucent, Apple, Cisco, Celestica, Delta, Flextronics, Foxconn, Hewlett-Packard, HTC, Huawei, IBM, Intel, Jabil, LG, Motorola, Nokia, Panasonic, Quanta, Samsung, Sanmina-SCI, Seagate, Siemens and Sony.
889331_12_ITEM1_P1_S1	The company is also the leading provider of circuit protection for the automotive industry and the third largest producer of electrical fuses in North America.
889331_12_ITEM1_P1_S2	In the automotive market, the company s end customers include major automotive manufacturers in North America, Europe and Asia such as BMW, Caterpillar, Chrysler, Ford Motor Company, General Motors, Hyundai Group, and Volkswagen.
889331_12_ITEM1_P1_S3	The company also supplies wiring harness manufacturers and auto parts suppliers worldwide, including Advance Auto Parts, Continental, Delphi, Lear, Leoni, O Reilly Auto Parts, Pep Boys, Sumitomo, Valeo, and Yazaki.
889331_12_ITEM1_P1_S4	In the electrical market, the company supplies representative customers such as Abbott, Acuity Brands, Dow Chemical, DuPont, GE, General Motors, Heinz, International Paper, John Deere, SMA, First Solar, Samsung, Merck, Poland Springs, Procter Gamble, Rockwell, United Technologies and 3M. Through the company s Electrical business, the company supplies industrial ground fault protection in mining and other large industrial operations to customers such as Potash Corporation, Mosaic, Agrium, and Cameco.
889331_12_ITEM1_P1_S5	See Business Environment: Circuit Protection Market.
889331_12_ITEM1_P2_S0	The company reports its operations by three business unit segments: Electronics, Automotive, and Electrical.
889331_12_ITEM1_P2_S1	For segment and geographical information and consolidated net sales and operating earnings see Item 7.
889331_12_ITEM1_P2_S2	Management s Discussion And Analysis Of Financial Condition And Results Of Operations and Note 15 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_12_ITEM1_P3_S0	During 2011, the company invested $6.0 million in certain preferred stock of Shocking Technologies, Inc., a research and development company in the electronics industry located in San Jose, California.
889331_12_ITEM1_P3_S1	Shocking Technologies, Inc. is a developer of circuit protection products for the computer and telecommunication markets.
889331_12_ITEM1_P4_S0	On August 3, 2011, the company acquired 100% of Selco A/S, a manufacturer of relays and generator controls for the marine industry, for approximately $11.1 million.
889331_12_ITEM1_P4_S1	The acquisition allows the company to further expand its global relay business within its Electrical business unit segment.
889331_12_ITEM1_P5_S0	Selco A/S is located in Roskilde, Denmark with a sales office located in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.
889331_12_ITEM1_P5_S1	The company funded the acquisition with available cash.
889331_12_ITEM1_P6_S0	Net sales by business unit segment for the periods indicated are as follows (in thousands):
889331_12_ITEM1_P7_S0	During 2011, the company adjusted its business segment reporting methodology to report results by product line rather than by sales organization.
889331_12_ITEM1_P7_S1	Accordingly, results for 2010 and 2009 have been restated to reflect this change.
889331_12_ITEM1_P7_S2	The company s total consolidated revenues and operating income did not change.
889331_12_ITEM1_P8_S0	The company operates in three geographic regions: the Americas, Europe, and Asia-Pacific.
889331_12_ITEM1_P8_S1	The company manufactures products and sells to customers in all three regions.
889331_12_ITEM1_P9_S0	Net sales in the company s three geographic regions, based upon the shipped to destination, are as follows (in thousands):
889331_12_ITEM1_P10_S0	The company s products are sold worldwide through distributors, a direct sales force and manufacturers representatives.
889331_12_ITEM1_P10_S1	For the year ended December 31, 2011, approximately 66% of the company s net sales were to customers outside the United States, including approximately 22% to China.
889331_12_ITEM1_P11_S0	The company manufactures many of its products on fully integrated manufacturing and assembly equipment.
889331_12_ITEM1_P11_S1	The company maintains product quality through a Global Quality Management System with most manufacturing sites certified under ISO 9001:2000.
889331_12_ITEM1_P11_S2	In addition, several of the Littelfuse manufacturing sites are also certified under TS 16949 and ISO 14001.
889331_12_ITEM1_P12_S0	References herein to 2011 or fiscal 2011 refer to the fiscal year ended December 31, 2011.
889331_12_ITEM1_P12_S1	References herein to 2010 or fiscal 2010 refer to the fiscal year ended January 1, 2011.
889331_12_ITEM1_P12_S2	References herein to 2009 or fiscal 2009 refer to the fiscal year ended January 2, 2010.
889331_12_ITEM1_P13_S0	The company operates on a 4-4-5 fiscal calendar that normally keeps the number of weeks constant during each quarter.
889331_12_ITEM1_P13_S1	As a result of using this convention, each of fiscal 2011 and fiscal 2010 contained 52 weeks whereas fiscal 2009 contained 53 weeks.
889331_12_ITEM1_P14_S0	The company s annual report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and all amendments to those reports are available free of charge through the Investors section of the company s Internet web site (http://www.littelfuse.com), as soon as practicable after such material is electronically filed with, or furnished to, the Securities and Exchange Commission (the SEC ), accessible via a link to the web site maintained by the SEC.
889331_12_ITEM1_P14_S1	Except as otherwise provided herein, such information is not incorporated by reference into this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
889331_12_ITEM1_P15_S0	Electronic circuit protection products are used to protect circuits in a multitude of electronic systems.
889331_12_ITEM1_P16_S0	The company s product offering includes a complete line of overcurrent and overvoltage solutions, including (i) fuses and protectors, (ii) positive temperature coefficient ( PTC ) resettable fuses, (iii) varistors, (iv) polymer electrostatic discharge ( ESD ) suppressors, (v) discrete transient voltage suppression ( TVS ) diodes, TVS diode arrays and protection thyristors, (vi) gas discharge tubes, (vii) power switching components and (viii) fuseholders, blocks and related accessories.
889331_12_ITEM1_P17_S0	Electronic fuses and protectors are devices that contain an element that melts in an overcurrent condition.
889331_12_ITEM1_P17_S1	Electronic miniature and subminiature fuses are designed to provide circuit protection in the limited space requirements of electronic equipment.
889331_12_ITEM1_P17_S2	The company s fuses are used in a wide variety of electronic products, including mobile phones, flat-screen TVs, computers, and telecommunications equipment.
889331_12_ITEM1_P17_S3	The company markets these products under trademarked brand names including PICO II and NANO2 SMF.
889331_12_ITEM1_P18_S0	Resettable fuses are PTC polymer devices that limit the current when an overcurrent condition exists and then reset themselves once the overcurrent condition has cleared.
889331_12_ITEM1_P19_S0	The company s product line offers both radial leaded and surface mount products.
889331_12_ITEM1_P20_S0	Varistors are ceramic-based, high-energy absorption devices that provide transient overvoltage and surge suppression for automotive, telecommunication, consumer electronics and industrial applications.
889331_12_ITEM1_P20_S1	The company s product line offers both radial leaded and multilayer surface mount products.
889331_12_ITEM1_P21_S0	Polymer ESD suppressors are polymer-based devices that protect an electronic system from failure due to rapid transfer of electrostatic charge to the circuit.
889331_12_ITEM1_P21_S1	The company s PulseGuard line of ESD suppressors is used in PC and PC peripherals, digital consumer electronics and wireless applications.
889331_12_ITEM1_P22_S0	Discrete diodes, diode arrays and protection thyristors are fast switching silicon semiconductor structures.
889331_12_ITEM1_P22_S1	Discrete diodes protect a wide variety of applications from overvoltage transients such as ESD, inductive load switching or lightning, while diode arrays are used primarily as ESD suppressors.
889331_12_ITEM1_P23_S0	Protection thyristors are commonly used to protect telecommunications circuits from overvoltage transients such as those resulting from lightning.
889331_12_ITEM1_P23_S1	Applications include telephones, modems, data transmission lines and alarm systems.
889331_12_ITEM1_P23_S2	The company markets these products under trademarked brand names including TECCOR , SIDACtor , Battrax and SPA .
889331_12_ITEM1_P24_S0	Gas discharge tubes are very low capacitance devices designed to suppress any transient voltage event that is greater than the breakover voltage of the device.
889331_12_ITEM1_P24_S1	These devices are primarily used in telecommunication interface and conversion equipment applications as protection from overvoltage transients such as lightning.
889331_12_ITEM1_P25_S0	Power switching components are used to regulate energy to various types of loads most commonly found in industrial and home applications.
889331_12_ITEM1_P25_S1	These components are easily activated from simple control circuits or interfaced to computers for more complex load control.
889331_12_ITEM1_P25_S2	Typical applications include heating, cooling, battery chargers and lighting.
889331_12_ITEM1_P26_S0	In addition to the above products, the company is also a supplier of fuse holders (including OMNI-BLOK ), fuse blocks and fuse clips primarily to customers that purchase circuit protection devices from the company.
889331_12_ITEM1_P27_S0	Fuses are extensively used in automobiles, trucks, buses and off-road equipment to protect electrical circuits and the wires that supply electrical power to operate lights, heating, air conditioning, radios, windows and other controls.
889331_12_ITEM1_P27_S1	Currently, a typical automobile contains 30 to 100 fuses, depending upon the options installed.
889331_12_ITEM1_P27_S2	The fuse content per vehicle is expected to continue to grow as more electronic features are included in automobiles.
889331_12_ITEM1_P27_S3	The company also supplies fuses for the protection of electric and hybrid vehicles.
889331_12_ITEM1_P28_S0	The company is a primary supplier of automotive fuses to United States, Asian and European automotive original equipment manufacturers ( OEM ), automotive component parts manufacturers and automotive parts distributors.
889331_12_ITEM1_P28_S1	The company also sells its fuses in the replacement parts market, with its products being sold through merchandisers, discount stores and service stations, as well as under private label by national firms.
889331_12_ITEM1_P29_S0	The company invented and owns U.S. and foreign patents related to blade-type fuses, which is the standard and most commonly used fuse in the automotive industry.
889331_12_ITEM1_P29_S1	The company s automotive fuse products are marketed under trademarked brand names, including ATO , MINI , MAXI, MIDI , MEGA , MasterFuse, JCASE and CablePro .
889331_12_ITEM1_P30_S0	A majority of the company s automotive fuse sales are made to main-fuse box and wire harness manufacturers that incorporate the fuses into their products.
889331_12_ITEM1_P30_S1	The remaining automotive fuse sales are made directly to automotive manufacturers, retailers who sell automotive parts and accessories, and distributors who in turn sell most of their products to wholesalers, service stations and non-automotive OEMs.
889331_12_ITEM1_P31_S0	The company has expanded the Automotive Business Segment into the commercial vehicle market with the acquisition of Cole Hersee.
889331_12_ITEM1_P31_S1	Additional products in this market include: power distribution modules, low current switches, high current switches, solenoids and relays, electronic switches, battery management products and ignition key switches.
889331_12_ITEM1_P32_S0	The company entered the electrical market in 1983 and manufactures and sells a broad range of low-voltage and medium-voltage circuit protection products to electrical distributors and their customers in the construction, OEM and industrial maintenance, repair and operating supplies ( MRO ) markets.
889331_12_ITEM1_P32_S1	The company also designs and manufactures portable custom electrical equipment for the mining industry in Canada as well as protection relays for the global mining, oil and gas, industrial and marine markets.
889331_12_ITEM1_P33_S0	Power fuses are used to protect circuits in various types of industrial equipment and in industrial and commercial buildings.
889331_12_ITEM1_P33_S1	They are rated and listed under one of many Underwriters Laboratories fuse classifications.
889331_12_ITEM1_P34_S0	Major applications for power fuses include protection from over-load and short-circuit currents in motor branch circuits, heating and cooling systems, control systems, lighting circuits and electrical distribution networks.
889331_12_ITEM1_P35_S0	The company s POWR-GARD product line features the Indicator series power fuse used in both the OEM and MRO markets.
889331_12_ITEM1_P35_S1	The Indicator technology provides visual blown-fuse indication at a glance, reducing maintenance and downtime on production equipment.
889331_12_ITEM1_P35_S2	The Indicator product offering is widely used in motor protection and industrial control panel applications.
889331_12_ITEM1_P36_S0	Protection relays are used to protect personnel and equipment in industrial environments and commercial buildings from excessive currents, over voltages and electrical shock hazards called ground-faults.
889331_12_ITEM1_P36_S1	Major applications for protection relays include protection of motor, transformer and power-line distribution circuits.
889331_12_ITEM1_P37_S0	Ground-fault relays are used to protect personnel and equipment in wet environments such as underground mining or water treatment applications where there is a greater risk for electricity to come in contact with water and create a shock hazard.
889331_12_ITEM1_P38_S0	Custom electrical equipment is used in harsh environments such as underground mining where standard electrical gear will not meet customer needs for reliability and durability.
889331_12_ITEM1_P39_S0	Portable power substations are used to transform and distribute electrical power to mobile equipment such as mining cutting machines and other electrical machinery.
889331_12_ITEM1_P40_S0	Miner control units provide power management for critical electrically operated underground production equipment.
889331_12_ITEM1_P41_S0	The company employs scientific, engineering and other personnel to continually improve its existing product lines and to develop new products at its research and engineering facilities in Champaign and Chicago, Illinois, Boston, Massachusetts, Canada, China, Germany, the Philippines and Mexico.
889331_12_ITEM1_P41_S1	The Product Development Technology departments maintain a staff of engineers, chemists, material scientists and technicians whose primary responsibility is to design and develop new products.
889331_12_ITEM1_P42_S0	Proposals for the development of new products are initiated primarily by sales and marketing personnel with input from customers.
889331_12_ITEM1_P42_S1	The entire product development process usually ranges from a few months to 18 months based on the complexity of development, with continuous efforts to reduce the development cycle.
889331_12_ITEM1_P43_S0	During fiscal years 2011, 2010 and 2009, the company expended $19.4 million, $17.6 million and $18.1 million, respectively, on research, product design and development ( R D ).
889331_12_ITEM1_P43_S1	During 2010, the company completed moving R D operations to lower cost locations closer to its customers.
889331_12_ITEM1_P43_S2	R D operations are now in Canada, China, Germany, the Philippines and Mexico as well as the United States.
889331_12_ITEM1_P44_S0	The company generally relies on patent and trademark laws and license and nondisclosure agreements to protect intellectual property and proprietary products.
889331_12_ITEM1_P44_S1	In cases where it is deemed necessary by management, key employees are required to sign an agreement that they will maintain the confidentiality of the company s proprietary information and trade secrets.
889331_12_ITEM1_P45_S0	As of December 31, 2011, the company owned 197 patents in North America, 85 patents in the European Union and 63 patents in other foreign countries.
889331_12_ITEM1_P45_S1	The company also has registered trademark protection for certain of its brand names and logos.
889331_12_ITEM1_P45_S2	The 197 North American patents are in the following product categories: 124 electronics, 44 automotive and 29 electrical.
889331_12_ITEM1_P45_S3	Patents and licenses are amortized over a period of 7-12 years, with a weighted average life of 11.9 years.
889331_12_ITEM1_P45_S4	Distribution networks are amortized over a period of 3-20 years, with a weighted average life of 13.8 years.
889331_12_ITEM1_P45_S5	Trademarks and tradenames are amortized over a period of 5-20 years, with a weighted average life of 13.8 years.
889331_12_ITEM1_P45_S6	The company recorded amortization expense of $6.6 million, $5.0 million and $5.0 million in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively, related to amortizable intangible assets.
889331_12_ITEM1_P46_S0	New products are continually being developed to replace older products.
889331_12_ITEM1_P46_S1	The company regularly applies for patent protection on such new products.
889331_12_ITEM1_P46_S2	Although, in the aggregate, the company s patents are important in the operation of its businesses, the company believes that the loss by expiration or otherwise of any one patent or group of patents would not materially affect its business.
889331_12_ITEM1_P47_S0	License royalties amounted to $1.0 million, $0.2 million and $0.1 million for fiscal 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively, and are included in other expense (income), net on the Consolidated Statements of Income.
889331_12_ITEM1_P48_S0	The company performs the majority of its own fabrication, stamps some of the metal components used in its fuses, holders and switches from raw metal stock and makes its own contacts and springs.
889331_12_ITEM1_P48_S1	In addition, the company fabricates silicon wafers for certain applications and performs its own plating (silver, nickel, zinc, tin and oxides).
889331_12_ITEM1_P48_S2	All thermoplastic molded component requirements used for such products as the ATO , MINI and MAXI fuse product lines are met through the company s in-house molding capabilities.
889331_12_ITEM1_P49_S0	After components are stamped, molded, plated and readied for assembly, final assembly is accomplished on fully automatic and semi-automatic assembly machines.
889331_12_ITEM1_P50_S0	Quality assurance and operations personnel, using techniques such as statistical process control, perform tests, checks and measurements during the production process to maintain the highest levels of product quality and customer satisfaction.
889331_12_ITEM1_P51_S0	The principal raw materials for the company s products include copper and copper alloys, heat-resistant plastics, zinc, melamine, glass, silver, gold, raw silicon, solder and various gases.
889331_12_ITEM1_P51_S1	The company uses a sole source for several heat-resistant plastics and for zinc, but believes that suitable alternative heat-resistant plastics and zinc are available from other sources at comparable prices.
889331_12_ITEM1_P51_S2	All other raw materials are purchased from a number of readily available outside sources.
889331_12_ITEM1_P52_S0	A computer-aided design and manufacturing system (CAD/CAM) expedites product development and machine design and the company s laboratories test new products, prototype concepts and production run samples.
889331_12_ITEM1_P52_S1	The company participates in just-in-time delivery programs with many of its major suppliers and actively promotes the building of strong cooperative relationships with its suppliers by utilizing early supplier involvement techniques and engaging them in pre-engineering product and process development.
889331_12_ITEM1_P53_S0	The company s domestic sales and marketing staff of over 35 people maintains relationships with major OEMs and distributors.
889331_12_ITEM1_P53_S1	The company s sales, marketing and engineering personnel interact directly with OEM engineers to ensure appropriate circuit protection and reliability within the parameters of the OEM s circuit design.
889331_12_ITEM1_P53_S2	Internationally, the company maintains a sales and marketing staff of over 100 people with sales offices in the U.K., Germany, Spain, Italy, Singapore, Taiwan, Japan, Brazil, Hong Kong, Korea, China and India.
889331_12_ITEM1_P53_S3	The company also markets its products indirectly through a worldwide organization of over 60 manufacturers representatives and distributes through an extensive network of electronics, automotive and electrical distributors.
889331_12_ITEM1_P54_S0	The company uses manufacturers representatives to sell its electronics products domestically and to call on major domestic and international OEMs and distributors.
889331_12_ITEM1_P54_S1	The company sells approximately 15% of its domestic products directly to OEMs, with the remainder sold through distributors nationwide.
889331_12_ITEM1_P55_S0	In the Asia-Pacific region, the company maintains a direct sales staff and utilizes distributors in Japan, Singapore, Korea, Taiwan, China, Malaysia, Thailand, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, the Philippines, New Zealand and Australia.
889331_12_ITEM1_P55_S1	In the Americas, the company maintains a direct sales staff in Brazil and utilizes manufacturers representatives and distributors in Canada.
889331_12_ITEM1_P55_S2	In Europe, the company maintains a direct sales force and utilizes manufacturers representatives and distributors to support a wide array of customers.
889331_12_ITEM1_P56_S0	The company maintains a direct sales force to service all the major automotive and commercial vehicle OEMs and system suppliers domestically.
889331_12_ITEM1_P56_S1	Approximately 23 manufacturers representatives sell the company s products to aftermarket fuse retailers such as O Reilly Auto Parts and Pep Boys.
889331_12_ITEM1_P56_S2	The company also uses about 15 manufacturers' representatives to sell to the commercial vehicle aftermarket.
889331_12_ITEM1_P56_S3	In Europe, the company uses both a direct sales force and manufacturers representatives to distribute its products to OEMs, major system suppliers and aftermarket distributors.
889331_12_ITEM1_P56_S4	In the Asia-Pacific region, the company uses both a direct sales force and distributors to supply to major OEMs and system suppliers.
889331_12_ITEM1_P57_S0	The company markets and sells its power fuses and protection relays through approximately 38 manufacturers representatives across North America.
889331_12_ITEM1_P57_S1	These representatives sell power fuse products through an electrical and industrial distribution network comprised of approximately 2,000 distributor buying locations.
889331_12_ITEM1_P57_S2	These distributors have customers that include electrical contractors, municipalities, utilities and factories (including both MRO and OEM).
889331_12_ITEM1_P58_S0	The company s field sales force (including regional sales managers and application engineers) and manufacturers representatives call on both distributors and end-users (consulting engineers, municipalities, utilities and OEMs) in an effort to educate these customers on the capabilities and characteristics of the company s products.
889331_12_ITEM1_P59_S0	The company sells to over 5,000 customers and distributors worldwide.
889331_12_ITEM1_P59_S1	Sales to Arrow Electronics (an Electronics distributor) were less than 10% of net sales for 2011 and 2009, respectively, but were 10.4% for 2010.
889331_12_ITEM1_P59_S2	No other single customer accounted for more than 10% of net sales during any of the last three years.
889331_12_ITEM1_P59_S3	During fiscal 2011, 2010 and 2009, net sales to customers outside the United States accounted for approximately 66%, 69% and 68%, respectively, of the company s total net sales.
889331_12_ITEM1_P60_S0	The company s products compete with similar products of other manufacturers, some of which have substantially greater financial resources than the company.
889331_12_ITEM1_P60_S1	In the electronics market, the company s competitors include Cooper Industries, Bel Fuse, Bourns, EPCOS, On Semiconductor, STMicroelectronics, Semtech, Vishay and TE Connectivity.
889331_12_ITEM1_P60_S2	In the automotive market, the company s competitors include Cooper Industries, Pacific Engineering (a private company in Japan) and MTA (a private company in Italy).
889331_12_ITEM1_P60_S3	In the electrical market, the company s major competitors include Cooper Industries and Mersen.
889331_12_ITEM1_P60_S4	The company believes that it competes on the basis of innovative products, the breadth of its product line, the quality and design of its products and the responsiveness of its customer service, in addition to price.
889331_12_ITEM1_P61_S0	The backlog of unfilled orders at December 31, 2011, was approximately $92.4 million, compared to $107.5 million at January 1, 2011.
889331_12_ITEM1_P61_S1	Substantially all of the orders currently in backlog are scheduled for delivery in 2012.
889331_12_ITEM1_P62_S0	As of December 31, 2011, the company employed approximately 6,000 employees worldwide.
889331_12_ITEM1_P62_S1	Approximately 750 employees in Mexico and 3 employees in Germany are covered by collective bargaining agreements.
889331_12_ITEM1_P62_S2	The Mexico collective bargaining agreement, covering employees in Piedras Negras, expires January 31, 2014.
889331_12_ITEM1_P62_S3	During 2010, a collective bargaining agreement covering approximately 160 employees at the company s Matamoros, Mexico facility was terminated as a result of the plant s closure.
889331_12_ITEM1_P63_S0	The Germany collective bargaining agreement, covering 3 employees in Essen, expires March 31, 2012.
889331_12_ITEM1_P64_S0	During 2011, a collective bargaining agreement covering 28 employees at the company s D nsen, Germany facility was terminated as a result of plant closure.
889331_12_ITEM1_P65_S0	Approximately 13% of the company's total workforce was employed under collective bargaining agreements at December 31, 2011.
889331_12_ITEM1_P65_S1	The employees covered by a collective bargaining agreement that will expire within one year of December 31, 2011 represent approximately less than 1% of the company's total workforce.
889331_12_ITEM1_P66_S0	Overall, the company has historically maintained satisfactory employee relations and considers employee relations to be good.
889331_12_ITEM1_P67_S0	The company is subject to numerous foreign, federal, state and local regulations relating to air and water quality, the disposal of hazardous waste materials, safety and health.
889331_12_ITEM1_P67_S1	Compliance with applicable environmental regulations has not significantly changed the company s competitive position, capital spending or earnings in the past and the company does not presently anticipate that compliance with such regulations will change its competitive position, capital spending or earnings for the foreseeable future.
889331_12_ITEM1_P68_S0	The company employs an environmental engineer to monitor regulatory matters and believes that it is currently in compliance in all material respects with applicable environmental laws and regulations, except with respect to its facilities located in Ireland.
889331_12_ITEM1_P69_S0	The Ireland facility was acquired in October 1999 in connection with the acquisition from Harris Corporation of its suppression products division.
889331_12_ITEM1_P69_S1	Certain containment actions have been ongoing and full disclosure with appropriate agencies in Ireland has been initiated.
889331_12_ITEM1_P69_S2	The company received an indemnity from Harris Corporation with respect to these matters.
889331_12_ITEM1_P70_S0	Littelfuse GmbH, which was acquired by the company in May 2004, is responsible for maintaining closed coal mines from legacy acquisitions.
889331_12_ITEM1_P70_S1	The company is compliant with German regulations pertaining to the maintenance of the mines and has an accrual related to certain of these coal mine shafts based on an engineering study estimating the cost of remediating the dangers (such as a shaft collapse) of certain of these closed coal mine shafts in Germany.
889331_12_ITEM1_P70_S2	The reserve is reviewed annually and calculated based upon the cost of remediating the shafts that the study deems most risky.
889331_12_ITEM1_P70_S3	Further information regarding the coal mine liability reserve is provided in Note 10 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Our business, financial condition and results of operations are subject to various risks and uncertainties, including the risk factors we have identified below.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P0_S1	These factors are not necessarily listed in order of importance.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P0_S2	We may amend or supplement the risk factors from time to time by other reports that we file with the SEC in the future.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Our industry is subject to intense competitive pressures.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We operate in markets that are highly competitive.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P2_S1	We compete on the basis of price, quality, service and/or brand name across the industries and markets we serve.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Competitive pressures could affect the prices we are able to charge our customers or the demand for our products.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We may not always be able to compete on price, particularly when compared to manufacturers with lower cost structures.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Some of our competitors have substantially greater sales, financial and manufacturing resources and may have greater access to capital than Littelfuse.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P3_S2	As other companies enter our markets or develop new products, competition may further intensify.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Our failure to compete effectively could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P4_S0	We may be unable to manufacture and deliver products in a manner that is responsive to our customers needs.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P5_S0	The end markets for our products are characterized by technological change, frequent new product introductions and enhancements, changes in customer requirements and emerging industry standards.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P5_S1	The introduction of products embodying new technologies and the emergence of new industry standards could render our existing products obsolete and unmarketable before we can recover any or all of our research, development and commercialization expenses on capital investments.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Furthermore, the life cycles of our products may change and are difficult to estimate.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our future success will depend upon our ability to manufacture and deliver products in a manner that is responsive to our customers needs.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P6_S1	We will need to develop and introduce new products and product enhancements on a timely basis that keep pace with technological developments and emerging industry standards and address increasingly sophisticated requirements of our customers.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P6_S2	We invest heavily in research and development without knowing that we will recover these costs.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Our competitors may develop products or technologies that will render our products non-competitive or obsolete.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P6_S4	If we cannot develop and market new products or product enhancements in a timely and cost-effective manner, our business, financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Our business may be interrupted by labor disputes or other interruptions of supplies.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P8_S0	A work stoppage could occur at certain of our facilities, most likely as a result of disputes under collective bargaining agreements or in connection with negotiations of new collective bargaining agreements.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P8_S1	In addition, we may experience a shortage of supplies for various reasons, such as financial distress, work stoppages, natural disasters or production difficulties that may affect one of our suppliers.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P8_S2	A significant work stoppage, or an interruption or shortage of supplies for any reason, if protracted, could substantially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P8_S3	The transfer of our manufacturing operations and changes in our distribution model could disrupt operations for a limited time.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Our revenues may vary significantly from period to period.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our revenues may vary significantly from one accounting period to another due to a variety of factors including:
889331_12_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The bankruptcy or insolvency of a major customer could adversely affect us.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P12_S0	The bankruptcy or insolvency of a major customer could result in lower sales revenue and cause a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P12_S1	In addition, the bankruptcy or insolvency of a major U.S. auto manufacturer or significant supplier likely could lead to substantial disruptions in the automotive supply base, resulting in lower demand for our products, which likely would cause a decrease in sales revenue and have a substantial adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Our ability to manage currency or commodity price fluctuations or shortages is limited.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P14_S0	As a resource-intensive manufacturing operation, we are exposed to a variety of market and asset risks, including the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates, commodity prices and interest rates.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P14_S1	We have multiple sources of supply for the majority of our commodity requirements.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P14_S2	However, significant shortages that disrupt the supply of raw materials or result in price increases could affect prices we charge our customers, our product costs, and the competitive position of our products and services.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P14_S3	We monitor and manage these exposures as an integral part of our overall risk management program, which recognizes the unpredictability of markets and seeks to reduce the potentially adverse effects on our results.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P14_S4	Nevertheless, changes in currency exchange rates, commodity prices and interest rates cannot always be predicted.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P14_S5	In addition, because of intense price competition and our high level of fixed costs, we may not be able to address such changes even if they are foreseeable.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P14_S6	Substantial changes in these rates and prices could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P14_S7	For additional discussion of interest rate, currency or commodity price risk, see "Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Operations and supply sources located outside the United States, particularly in emerging markets, are subject to greater risks.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Our operating activities outside the United States contribute significantly to our revenues and earnings.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P16_S1	Serving a global customer base and remaining competitive in the global marketplace requires the company to place our production in countries outside the United States, including emerging markets, to capitalize on market opportunities and maintain a cost-efficient structure.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P16_S2	In addition, we source a significant amount of raw materials and other components from third-party suppliers in low-cost countries.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Our international operating activities are subject to a number of risks generally associated with international operations, including risks relating to the following:
889331_12_ITEM1A_P18_S0	limitations on our ability to enforce legal rights and remedies.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Any of these factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We are in the process of relocating our manufacturing operations and changing our distribution and customer service model.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P21_S0	We are a company that, from time to time, seeks to optimize its manufacturing capabilities and efficiencies through restructurings, consolidations, plant closings or asset sales.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P21_S1	We may make further specific determinations to consolidate, close or sell additional facilities.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P21_S2	Possible adverse consequences related to such actions may include various charges for such items as idle capacity, disposition costs, severance costs, impairments of goodwill and possibly an immediate loss of revenues, in addition to normal or attendant risks and uncertainties.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P21_S3	We may be unsuccessful in any of our current or future efforts to restructure or consolidate our business.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P21_S4	Our plans to minimize or eliminate any loss of revenues during restructuring or consolidation may not be achieved.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P21_S5	These activities may have a material adverse effect upon our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P22_S0	We engage in acquisitions and may encounter difficulties in integrating these businesses.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P23_S0	We are a company that, from time to time, seeks to grow through strategic acquisitions.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P23_S1	We have in the past acquired a number of businesses or companies and additional product lines and assets.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P23_S2	We intend to continue to expand and diversify our operations with additional acquisitions.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P23_S3	The success of these transactions depends on our ability to integrate the assets and personnel acquired in these acquisitions.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P23_S4	We may encounter difficulties in integrating acquisitions with our operations and may not realize the degree or timing of the benefits that we anticipated from an acquisition.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Environmental liabilities could adversely impact our financial position.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Federal, state and local laws and regulations impose various restrictions and controls on the discharge of materials, chemicals and gases used in our manufacturing processes or in our finished goods.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P25_S1	These environmental regulations have required us to expend a portion of our resources and capital on relevant compliance programs.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Under these laws and regulations, we could be held financially responsible for remedial measures if our current or former properties are contaminated or if we send waste to a landfill or recycling facility that becomes contaminated, even if we did not cause the contamination.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P25_S3	We may be subject to additional common law claims if we release substances that damage or harm third parties.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P25_S4	In addition, future changes in environmental laws or regulations may require additional investments in capital equipment or the implementation of additional compliance programs.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P25_S5	Any failure to comply with new or existing environmental laws or regulations could subject us to significant liabilities and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P26_S0	In the conduct of our manufacturing operations, we have handled and do handle materials that are considered hazardous, toxic or volatile under federal, state and local laws.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P26_S1	The risk of accidental release of such materials cannot be completely eliminated.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P27_S0	In addition, we operate or own facilities located on or near real property that was formerly owned and operated by others.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P27_S1	Certain of these properties were used in ways that involved hazardous materials.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Contaminants may migrate from, within or through these properties.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P27_S3	These releases or migrations may give rise to claims.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Where third parties are responsible for contamination, the third parties may not have funds, or not make funds available when needed, to pay remediation costs imposed upon us under environmental laws and regulations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P29_S0	The company is responsible for the maintenance of discontinued coal mining operations in Germany.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P29_S1	The risk of environmental remediation exists and the company is in the process of remediating the mines considered to be the most at risk.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P30_S0	We derive a substantial portion of our revenues from customers in the automotive, consumer electronics and communications industries, and we are susceptible to trends and factors affecting those industries as well as the success of our customers products.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Net sales to the automotive, consumer electronics and communications industries represent a substantial portion of our revenues.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P31_S1	Factors negatively affecting these industries and the demand for products also negatively affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P31_S2	Any adverse occurrence, including industry slowdown, recession, political instability, costly or constraining regulations, armed hostilities, terrorism, excessive inflation, prolonged disruptions in one or more of our customers production schedules or labor disturbances, that results in significant decline in the volume of sales in these industries, or in an overall downturn in the business and operations of our customers in these industries, could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P31_S3	For example, the automotive industry as well as the consumer electronics market is highly cyclical in nature and sensitive to changes in general economic conditions, consumer preferences and interest rates.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P31_S4	In addition, the global automotive and electronic industries have overall manufacturing capacity far exceeding demand.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P31_S5	To the extent that demand for certain of our customers products declines, the demand for our products may decline.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P31_S6	Reduced demand relating to general economic conditions, consumer preferences, interest rates or industry over-capacity may have a material adverse effect upon our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P32_S0	The inability to maintain access to capital markets may adversely affect our business and financial results.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Our ability to invest in our businesses, make strategic acquisitions and refinance maturing debt obligations may require access to the capital markets and sufficient bank credit lines to support short-term borrowings.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P33_S1	If we are unable to access the capital markets or bank credit facilities, we could experience a material adverse affect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Fixed costs may reduce operating results if our sales fall below expectations.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P35_S0	Our expense levels are based, in part, on our expectations for future sales.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P35_S1	Many of our expenses, particularly those relating to capital equipment and manufacturing overhead, are relatively fixed.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P35_S2	We might be unable to reduce spending quickly enough to compensate for reductions in sales.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P35_S3	Accordingly, shortfalls in sales could materially and adversely affect our operating results.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P36_S0	The volatility of our stock price could affect the value of an investment in our stock and our future financial position.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P37_S0	The market price of our stock has fluctuated widely.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P37_S1	Between January 2, 2011 and December 31, 2011, the closing sale price of our common stock ranged between a low of $38.56 and a high of $64.82, experiencing greater volatility over that time than the broader markets.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P37_S2	The volatility of our stock price may be related to any number of factors, such as general economic conditions, industry conditions, analysts expectations concerning our results of operations, or the volatility of our revenues as discussed above under Our Revenues May Vary Significantly from Period to Period.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P37_S3	The historic market price of our common stock may not be indicative of future market prices.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P37_S4	We may not be able to sustain or increase the value of our common stock.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P37_S5	Declines in the market price of our stock could adversely affect our ability to retain personnel with stock incentives, to acquire businesses or assets in exchange for stock and/or to conduct future financing activities with or involving our common stock.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Customer demands and new regulations related to conflict-free minerals may force us to incur additional expenses.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P39_S0	The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act requires disclosure of use of conflict minerals mined from the Democratic Republic of Congo and adjoining countries and efforts to prevent the use of such minerals.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P40_S0	In the semiconductor industry, these minerals are most commonly found in metals.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P41_S0	As there may be only a limited number of suppliers offering conflict free metals, we cannot be sure that we will be able to obtain necessary metals in sufficient quantities or at competitive prices.
889331_12_ITEM1A_P41_S1	Also, we may face challenges with our customers and suppliers if we are unable to sufficiently verify that the metals used in our products are conflict free.
889331_12_ITEM2_P0_S0	The company s operations are located in 44 owned or leased facilities worldwide, representing an aggregate of 1,458,374 square feet.
889331_12_ITEM2_P0_S1	The company s corporate headquarters is located in the U.S. in Chicago, Illinois.
889331_12_ITEM2_P0_S2	The company has North American manufacturing facilities in Saskatoon, Canada, Piedras Negras, Mexico and Melchor Muzquiz, Mexico.
889331_12_ITEM2_P0_S3	The manufacturing facilities previously located in Irving, Texas and Matamoros, Mexico were closed in 2010.
889331_12_ITEM2_P0_S4	During 2010, the European headquarters and the primary European distribution center, previously located in Utrecht, the Netherlands, until the property was sold in 2010, were relocated to D nsen, Germany.
889331_12_ITEM2_P0_S5	The D nsen facility was closed during 2011.
889331_12_ITEM2_P0_S6	Manufacturing operations were transferred to Piedras Negras, Mexico.
889331_12_ITEM2_P0_S7	The office and European headquarters were subsequently transferred to Bremen, Germany.
889331_12_ITEM2_P0_S8	In addition to the D nsen, Germany, facility, the company is currently marketing for sale its Des Plaines, Illinois, property and Dundalk, Ireland, facility, both of which closed during fiscal year 2009.
889331_12_ITEM2_P0_S9	The Des Plaines building was demolished in 2010 to facilitate the sale of the underlying property.
889331_12_ITEM2_P1_S0	Asia-Pacific operations include sales and distribution centers located in Singapore, Taiwan, Japan, China and Korea, with manufacturing plants in China, Taiwan and the Philippines.
889331_12_ITEM2_P1_S1	The manufacturing plant in Taiwan is expected to close in 2012.
889331_12_ITEM2_P1_S2	The company does not believe that it will encounter any difficulty in renewing its existing leases upon the expiration of their current terms.
889331_12_ITEM2_P1_S3	Management believes that the company s facilities are adequate to meet its requirements for the foreseeable future.

889331_12_ITEM5_P6_S0	The company initiated cash dividends in the fourth quarter of 2010.
889331_12_ITEM5_P6_S1	The company previously had not paid any cash dividends prior to fiscal 2010.
889331_12_ITEM5_P6_S2	Future dividend policy will be determined by the Board of Directors based upon its evaluation of earnings, cash availability and general business prospects.
889331_12_ITEM5_P7_S0	Currently, there are restrictions on the payment of dividends contained in the company s credit agreements that relate to the maintenance of a minimum net worth and certain financial ratios.
889331_12_ITEM5_P7_S1	However, the company expects to continue paying cash dividends on a quarterly basis for the foreseeable future.
889331_12_ITEM5_P8_S0	The Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of up to 1,000,000 shares of the company s common stock under a program for the period May 1, 2011 to April 30, 2012, of which 859,029 shares were purchased, at an average price of $43.18, through December 31, 2011, and 140,971 shares remain available for purchase under the initial program as of December 31, 2011.

889331_12_ITEM5_P9_S1	This provides authority to purchase up to 640,971 additional shares between October 28, 2011 and the April 30, 2012 expiration date.
889331_12_ITEM5_P10_S0	The company withheld 20,537 shares of stock in lieu of withholding taxes on behalf of employees who became vested in restricted share units during fiscal 2011.
889331_12_ITEM5_P10_S1	Shares withheld were 16,512 during the period March 2, 2011 to April 30, 2011 and 4,025 during the period July 2, 2011 to July 30, 2011.
889331_12_ITEM5_P10_S2	Shares withheld are classified as Treasury stock on the Consolidated Balance Sheet.
