889331_12_ITEM15_P361_S4	Notwithstanding any provision in this Agreement to the contrary, if at the time of separation from service the Executive is a "specified employee" within the meaning of Section 409A, any cash or in-kind payments which constitute a "deferral of compensation" under Section 409A and which would otherwise become due under this Agreement during the first 6 months (or such longer period as required by Section 409A) after separation from service shall be delayed and all such delayed payments shall be paid in full in the 7th month after the separation from service, and all subsequent payments shall be paid in accordance with their original payment schedule.
889331_12_ITEM15_P361_S5	To the extent that any insurance premiums or other benefit contributions constituting a "deferral of compensation" become subject to the above delay, the Executive shall be responsible for paying such amounts directly to the insurer or other third party and shall receive reimbursement from the Company for such amounts in the 7th month as described above.
889331_12_ITEM15_P361_S6	The above specified employee delay shall not apply to any payments that are excepted from coverage by Section 409A, such as those payments covered by the short-term deferral exception described in Treasury Regulations Section 1.409A-1(b)(4).
889331_12_ITEM15_P362_S0	Nothing in this Agreement shall prevent or limit the Executive s continuing or future participation in any plan, program, policy or practice provided by the Company or any of its affiliated companies and for which the Executive may qualify, nor, subject to Subsection 13(f) hereof, shall anything herein limit or otherwise affect such rights as the Executive may have under any contract or agreement with the Company or any of its affiliated companies.
889331_12_ITEM15_P362_S1	Amounts which are vested benefits or which the Executive is otherwise entitled to receive under any plan, policy, practice or program of or any contract or agreement with the Company or any of its affiliated companies at or subsequent to his or her separation from service shall be payable in accordance with such plan, policy, practice or program or contract or agreement, except as explicitly modified by this Agreement.
889331_12_ITEM15_P363_S0	The Company s obligation to make the payments provided for in this Agreement and otherwise to perform its obligations hereunder shall not be affected by any set-off, counterclaim, recoupment, defense or other claim, right or action which the Company may have against the Executive or others.
889331_12_ITEM15_P363_S1	In no event shall the Executive be obligated to seek another position or take any other action by way of mitigation of the amounts payable to the Executive under any of the provisions of this Agreement and such amounts shall not be reduced whether or not the Executive obtains another position.
889331_12_ITEM15_P363_S2	To the extent that any amount due hereunder has become subject to a bona fide dispute, payment of such amount may be delayed until no later than the end of the first taxable year of the Executive in which the Company and the Executive enter into a legally binding settlement of such dispute, the Company concedes that the amount is payable, or the Company is required to make such payment pursuant to a final and nonappealable judgment or other binding decision, as set forth in Treasury Regulation Section 1.409A-3(g), and any such payment shall include interest on such delayed amount from the original due date thereof until paid at the prime rate from time to time reported in The Wall Street Journal during said period, plus, to the fullest extent permitted by law, the amount of all legal fees and expenses which the Executive reasonably incurs as a result of any contest by the Company, the Executive or others in which the Executive is the prevailing party.
889331_12_ITEM15_P364_S0	The Executive shall hold in a fiduciary capacity for the benefit of the Company all secret or confidential information, knowledge or data relating to the Company or any of its affiliated companies, and their respective businesses, which shall have been obtained by the Executive during the Executive s service with the Company or any of its affiliated companies and which shall not be or become public knowledge (other than by acts by the Executive or representatives of the Executive in violation of this Agreement).
889331_12_ITEM15_P364_S1	After Executive s separation from service with the Company, the Executive shall not, without the prior written consent of the Company or as may otherwise be required by law or legal process, communicate or divulge any such information, knowledge or data to anyone other than the Company and those designated by it.
889331_12_ITEM15_P364_S2	In no event shall an asserted violation of the provisions of this Section 10 constitute a basis for deferring or withholding any amounts otherwise payable to the Executive under this Agreement.
889331_12_ITEM15_P364_S3	The provisions of this Section 10 shall survive any termination of this Agreement or the Executive s separation of service with the Company.
889331_12_ITEM15_P365_S0	Excise Tax on Parachute Payments .
889331_12_ITEM15_P365_S1	(a) Anything in this Agreement to the contrary notwithstanding and except as set forth below, in the event it shall be determined that any payment or distribution by the Company to or for the benefit of the Executive (whether paid or payable or distributed or distributable pursuant to the terms of this Agreement or otherwise, but determined without regard to any additional payments required under this Section, except as otherwise provided in this Section) (hereinafter referred to collectively as a Payment ) would be subject to the excise tax imposed by Section 4999 of the Code or any interest or penalties are incurred by the Executive with respect to such excise tax (such excise tax, together with any such interest and penalties, are hereinafter collectively referred to as the Excise Tax ), then the Payments shall be reduced to the extent necessary so that no portion thereof shall be subject to the Excise Tax, but only if, by reason of such reduction, the net after-tax benefit received by the Executive shall exceed the net after-tax benefit that would be received by the Executive if no such reduction was made.
889331_12_ITEM15_P366_S0	(b) For purposes of paragraph (a), net after-tax benefit shall mean (i) the total of all Payments which the Executive receives or is then entitled to receive from the Company that would constitute excess parachute payments within the meaning of Section 280G of the Code, less (ii) the amount of all foreign, federal, state and local income and employment taxes payable by the Executive with respect to the foregoing calculated at the maximum marginal income tax rate for each year in which such payments shall be made to the Executive (based on the rate in effect for such year as set forth in the Code as in effect at the time of the first such payment), less (iii) the amount of Excise Tax imposed with respect to the Payments described in (i) above.
889331_12_ITEM15_P367_S0	(c) If a reduction is to occur pursuant to paragraph (a), the payments and benefits under this Agreement shall be reduced in the following order: any cash severance (in reverse order of payment), then outplacement services (in reverse order), then any other amount that is a parachute payment within the meaning of Section 280G of the Code in such order as determined in the sole discretion of the Company and not the Executive.
889331_12_ITEM15_P368_S0	This Agreement is personal to the Executive and without the prior written consent of the Company shall not be assignable by the Executive otherwise than by will or the laws of descent and distribution.
889331_12_ITEM15_P369_S0	This Agreement shall inure to the benefit of and be enforceable by the Executive s legal representatives.
889331_12_ITEM15_P370_S0	(b) This Agreement shall inure to the benefit of and be binding upon the Company and its successors and assigns.
889331_12_ITEM15_P371_S0	(c) The Company will require any successor (whether direct or indirect, by purchase, merger, consolidation or otherwise) to all or substantially all of the business and/or assets of the Company to assume expressly and agree to perform this Agreement in the same manner and to the same extent that the Company would be required to perform it if no such succession had taken place.
889331_12_ITEM15_P371_S1	As used in this Agreement, the term Company shall mean the Company as hereinbefore defined and any successor to its business and/or assets as aforesaid which assumes and agrees to perform this Agreement by operation of law or otherwise.
889331_12_ITEM15_P372_S0	This Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Illinois, without reference to principles of conflict of laws.
889331_12_ITEM15_P372_S1	This Agreement may not be amended or modified otherwise than by a written agreement executed by the parties hereto or their respective successors and legal representatives.
889331_12_ITEM15_P373_S0	(b) Each notice, request, demand, approval or other communication which may be or is required to be given under this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been properly given when delivered personally at the address set forth below for the intended party during normal business hours at such address, when sent by facsimile or other electronic transmission to the respective facsimile transmission numbers of the parties set forth below with telephone confirmation of receipt, or when sent by recognized overnight courier or by the United States registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid, addressed as follows:
889331_12_ITEM15_P374_S0	Notices shall be given to such other addressee or address, or both, or by way of such other facsimile transmission number, as a particular party may from time to time designate by written notice to the other party hereto.
889331_12_ITEM15_P374_S1	Each notice, request, demand, approval or other communication which is sent in accordance with this Section shall be deemed given and received for all purposes of this Agreement as of two business days after the date of deposit thereof for mailing in a duly constituted United States post office or branch thereof, one business day after deposit with a recognized overnight courier service or upon confirmation of receipt of any facsimile transmission.
889331_12_ITEM15_P374_S2	Notice given to a party hereto by any other method shall only be deemed to be given and received when actually received in writing by such party.
889331_12_ITEM15_P375_S0	(c) The invalidity or unenforceability of any provision of this Agreement shall not affect the validity or enforceability of any other provision of this Agreement.
889331_12_ITEM15_P376_S0	(d) The Company may withhold from any amounts payable under this Agreement such Federal, state, local or foreign taxes as shall be required to be withheld pursuant to any applicable law or regulation.
889331_12_ITEM15_P377_S0	(e) The Executive s or the Company s failure to insist upon strict compliance with any provision of this Agreement or the failure to promptly assert any right the Executive or the Company may have hereunder, including, without limitation, the right of the Executive to separate from service for Good Reason pursuant to Subsection 5(c)(i)-(v) hereof, shall not be deemed to be a waiver of such provision or right or any other provision or right of this Agreement.
889331_12_ITEM15_P378_S0	(f) The Executive and the Company acknowledge that, except as may otherwise be provided under any other written agreement between the Executive and the Company, the employment or other service of the Executive by or with the Company is at will and, subject to Subsection 1(a) hereof and/or any other written agreement between the Executive and the Company, prior to the Effective Date, the Executive s employment and/or service and/or this Agreement may be terminated by either the Executive or the Company at any time prior to the Effective Date upon written notice to the other party, in which case the Executive shall have no further rights under this Agreement.
889331_12_ITEM15_P378_S1	From and after the Effective Date, this Agreement shall supersede any other agreement between the parties with respect to the subject matter hereof.

889331_12_ITEM15_P389_S0	Pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 (subsections (a) and (b) of Section 1350, Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code), each of the undersigned officers of Littelfuse, Inc. ( the Company ) does hereby certify that to his knowledge:
889331_12_ITEM15_P390_S0	The Annual Report of the Company on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2011 ( the Report ) fully complies with the requirements of section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and the information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
889331_13_ITEM1_P0_S0	Littelfuse, Inc. and its subsidiaries (the company or Littelfuse or we or our ) is the world s leading supplier of circuit protection products for the electronics, automotive and electrical industries.
889331_13_ITEM1_P0_S1	In addition to the broadest and deepest portfolio of circuit protection products and solutions, the company offers a comprehensive line of highly reliable electromechanical and electronic switch and control devices for commercial and specialty vehicles and sensors for automobile safety systems, as well as protection relays and power distribution centers for the safe control and distribution of electricity.
889331_13_ITEM1_P0_S2	The company has a network of global labs that develop new products and product enhancements, provide customer application support and test products for safety, reliability and regulatory compliance.
889331_13_ITEM1_P1_S0	In the electronics market, the company supplies leading manufacturers such as Alcatel-Lucent, Cisco, Celestica, Delta, Flextronics, Foxconn, Hewlett-Packard, HTC, Huawei, IBM, Intel, Jabil, LG, Motorola, Nokia, Panasonic, Quanta, Samsung, Sanmina-SCI, Seagate, Siemens and Sony.
889331_13_ITEM1_P1_S1	The company is also the leading provider of circuit protection for the automotive industry and the third largest producer of electrical fuses in North America.
889331_13_ITEM1_P1_S2	In the automotive market, the company s end customers include major automotive manufacturers in North America, Europe and Asia such as BMW, Caterpillar, Chrysler, Daimler Trucks NA, Ford Motor Company, General Motors, Hyundai Group and Volkswagen.
889331_13_ITEM1_P1_S3	The company also supplies wiring harness manufacturers and auto parts suppliers worldwide, including Advance Auto Parts, Continental, Delphi, Lear, Leoni, O Reilly Auto Parts, Pep Boys, Sumitomo, Valeo and Yazaki.
889331_13_ITEM1_P1_S4	In the electrical market, the company supplies representative customers such as Abbott, Acuity Brands, Dow Chemical, DuPont, GE, General Motors, Heinz, International Paper, John Deere, SMA, First Solar, Samsung, Merck, Poland Springs, Procter Gamble, Rockwell, United Technologies and 3M. Through the company s Electrical business, the company supplies industrial ground fault protection in mining and other large industrial operations to customers such as Potash Corporation, Mosaic, Agrium and Cameco.
889331_13_ITEM1_P1_S5	See Business Environment: Circuit Protection Market.
889331_13_ITEM1_P2_S0	The company reports its operations by three business unit segments: Electronics, Automotive, and Electrical.
889331_13_ITEM1_P2_S1	For segment and geographical information and consolidated net sales and operating earnings see Item 7.
889331_13_ITEM1_P2_S2	Management s Discussion And Analysis Of Financial Condition And Results Of Operations and Note 16 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_13_ITEM1_P3_S0	On May 31, 2012, the company acquired 100% of ACCEL AB ( Accel ), a manufacturer of advanced electromechanical products, including sensors and switches primarily for the automotive industry, for approximately $23.9 million.
889331_13_ITEM1_P3_S1	The acquisition allows the company to expand its automotive product offering and establish a presence in the growing automotive sensor market within its Automotive business unit segment.
889331_13_ITEM1_P4_S0	Accel is based in V nersborg, Sweden with a manufacturing facility located in Kaunas, Lithuania.
889331_13_ITEM1_P4_S1	The company funded the acquisition with available cash.
889331_13_ITEM1_P5_S0	On September 26, 2012, the company acquired 100% of Terra Power Systems, LLC ("Terra Power") , a U.S. manufacturer of electromechanical components including power distribution modules and fuse holders for commercial vehicle products in the automotive industry for $10.6 million.
889331_13_ITEM1_P5_S1	The acquisition allows the company to strengthen its position in the commercial vehicle products market by adding new products and new customers within its Automotive business unit segment.
889331_13_ITEM1_P6_S0	Terra Power is based in Bellingham, Washington.
889331_13_ITEM1_P6_S1	The company funded the acquisition with available cash.
889331_13_ITEM1_P7_S0	Net sales by business unit segment for the periods indicated are as follows (in thousands):
889331_13_ITEM1_P8_S0	The company operates in three geographic regions: the Americas, Europe and Asia-Pacific.
889331_13_ITEM1_P8_S1	The company manufactures products and sells to customers in all three regions.
889331_13_ITEM1_P9_S0	Net sales in the company s three geographic regions, based upon the shipped to destination, are as follows (in thousands):
889331_13_ITEM1_P10_S0	The company s products are sold worldwide through distributors, a direct sales force and manufacturers representatives.
889331_13_ITEM1_P10_S1	For the fiscal year ended December 29, 2012, approximately 67% of the company s net sales were to customers outside the United States, including approximately 21% to China.
889331_13_ITEM1_P11_S0	The company manufactures many of its products on fully integrated manufacturing and assembly equipment.
889331_13_ITEM1_P11_S1	The company maintains product quality through a Global Quality Management System with most manufacturing sites certified under ISO 9001:2000.
889331_13_ITEM1_P11_S2	In addition, several of the Littelfuse manufacturing sites are also certified under TS 16949 and ISO 14001.
889331_13_ITEM1_P12_S0	References herein to 2012 or fiscal 2012 refer to the fiscal year ended December 29, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM1_P12_S1	References herein to 2011 or fiscal 2011 refer to the fiscal year ended December 31, 2011.
889331_13_ITEM1_P12_S2	References herein to 2010 or fiscal 2010 refer to the fiscal year ended January 1, 2011.
889331_13_ITEM1_P13_S0	The company s annual report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and all amendments to those reports are available free of charge through the Investor Relations section of the company s Internet website (http://www.littelfuse.com), as soon as practicable after such material is electronically filed with, or furnished to, the Securities and Exchange Commission (the SEC ), accessible via a link to the website maintained by the SEC.
889331_13_ITEM1_P13_S1	Except as otherwise provided herein, such information is not incorporated by reference into this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
889331_13_ITEM1_P14_S0	Electronic circuit protection products are used to protect circuits in a multitude of electronic systems.
889331_13_ITEM1_P15_S0	The company s product offering includes a complete line of overcurrent and overvoltage solutions, including (i) fuses and protectors, (ii) positive temperature coefficient ( PTC ) resettable fuses, (iii) varistors, (iv) polymer electrostatic discharge ( ESD ) suppressors, (v) discrete transient voltage suppression ( TVS ) diodes, TVS diode arrays and protection thyristors, (vi) gas discharge tubes, (vii) power switching components and (viii) fuseholders, blocks and related accessories.
889331_13_ITEM1_P16_S0	Electronic fuses and protectors are devices that contain an element that melts in an overcurrent condition.
889331_13_ITEM1_P16_S1	Electronic miniature and subminiature fuses are designed to provide circuit protection in the limited space requirements of electronic equipment.
889331_13_ITEM1_P16_S2	The company s fuses are used in a wide variety of electronic products, including mobile phones, flat-screen TVs, computers and telecommunications equipment.
889331_13_ITEM1_P16_S3	The company markets these products under trademarked brand names including PICO II and NANO2 SMF.
889331_13_ITEM1_P17_S0	Resettable fuses are PTC polymer devices that limit the current when an overcurrent condition exists and then reset themselves once the overcurrent condition has cleared.
889331_13_ITEM1_P18_S0	The company s product line offers both radial leaded and surface mount products.
889331_13_ITEM1_P19_S0	Varistors are ceramic-based, high-energy absorption devices that provide transient overvoltage and surge suppression for automotive, telecommunication, consumer electronics and industrial applications.
889331_13_ITEM1_P19_S1	The company s product line offers both radial leaded and multilayer surface mount products.
889331_13_ITEM1_P20_S0	Polymer ESD suppressors are polymer-based devices that protect an electronic system from failure due to rapid transfer of electrostatic charge to the circuit.
889331_13_ITEM1_P20_S1	The company s PulseGuard line of ESD suppressors is used in PC and PC peripherals, digital consumer electronics and wireless applications.
889331_13_ITEM1_P21_S0	Discrete diodes, diode arrays and protection thyristors are fast switching silicon semiconductor structures.
889331_13_ITEM1_P21_S1	Discrete diodes protect a wide variety of applications from overvoltage transients such as ESD, inductive load switching or lightning, while diode arrays are used primarily as ESD suppressors.
889331_13_ITEM1_P22_S0	Protection thyristors are commonly used to protect telecommunications circuits from overvoltage transients such as those resulting from lightning.
889331_13_ITEM1_P22_S1	Applications include telephones, modems, data transmission lines and alarm systems.
889331_13_ITEM1_P22_S2	The company markets these products under trademarked brand names including TECCOR , SIDACtor , Battrax and SPA .
889331_13_ITEM1_P23_S0	Gas discharge tubes are very low capacitance devices designed to suppress any transient voltage event that is greater than the breakover voltage of the device.
889331_13_ITEM1_P23_S1	These devices are primarily used in telecommunication interface and conversion equipment applications as protection from overvoltage transients such as lightning.
889331_13_ITEM1_P24_S0	Power switching components are used to regulate energy to various types of loads most commonly found in industrial and home applications.
889331_13_ITEM1_P24_S1	These components are easily activated from simple control circuits or interfaced to computers for more complex load control.
889331_13_ITEM1_P24_S2	Typical applications include heating, cooling, battery chargers and lighting.
889331_13_ITEM1_P25_S0	In addition to the above products, the company is also a supplier of fuse holders (including OMNI-BLOK ), fuse blocks and fuse clips primarily to customers that purchase circuit protection devices from the company.
889331_13_ITEM1_P26_S0	Fuses are extensively used in automobiles, trucks, buses and off-road equipment to protect electrical circuits and the wires that supply electrical power to operate lights, heating, air conditioning, radios, windows and other controls.
889331_13_ITEM1_P26_S1	Currently, a typical automobile contains 30 to 100 fuses, depending upon the options installed.
889331_13_ITEM1_P26_S2	The fuse content per vehicle is expected to continue to grow as more electronic features are included in automobiles.
889331_13_ITEM1_P26_S3	The company also supplies fuses for the protection of electric and hybrid vehicles.
889331_13_ITEM1_P27_S0	The company is a primary supplier of automotive fuses to United States, Asian and European automotive original equipment manufacturers ( OEM ), automotive component parts manufacturers and automotive parts distributors.
889331_13_ITEM1_P27_S1	The company also sells its fuses in the replacement parts market, with its products being sold through merchandisers, discount stores and service stations, as well as under private label by national firms.
889331_13_ITEM1_P28_S0	The company invented and owns U.S. and foreign patents related to blade-type fuses, which is the standard and most commonly used fuse in the automotive industry.
889331_13_ITEM1_P28_S1	The company s automotive fuse products are marketed under trademarked brand names, including ATO , MINI , MAXI, MIDI , MEGA , MasterFuse, JCASE and CablePro .
889331_13_ITEM1_P29_S0	A majority of the company s automotive fuse sales are made to main-fuse box and wire harness manufacturers that incorporate the fuses into their products.
889331_13_ITEM1_P29_S1	The remaining automotive fuse sales are made directly to automotive manufacturers, retailers who sell automotive parts and accessories, and distributors who in turn sell most of their products to wholesalers, service stations and non-automotive OEMs.
889331_13_ITEM1_P30_S0	The company has expanded the Automotive Business Segment into the commercial vehicle market with the acquisition of Cole Hersee and Terra Power.
889331_13_ITEM1_P30_S1	Additional products in this market include: power distribution modules, low current switches, high current switches, solenoids and relays, electronic switches, battery management products and ignition key switches.
889331_13_ITEM1_P31_S0	The company has expanded into the automotive sensor market with the acquisition of Accel AB.
889331_13_ITEM1_P31_S1	Additional products in this market include advanced electromechanical sensors and switches.
889331_13_ITEM1_P32_S0	The company entered the electrical market in 1983 and manufactures and sells a broad range of low-voltage and medium-voltage circuit protection products to electrical distributors and their customers in the construction, OEM and industrial maintenance, repair and operating supplies ( MRO ) markets.
889331_13_ITEM1_P32_S1	The company also designs and manufactures portable custom electrical equipment for the mining industry in Canada as well as protection relays for the global mining, oil and gas, industrial and marine markets.
889331_13_ITEM1_P33_S0	Power fuses are used to protect circuits in various types of industrial equipment and in industrial and commercial buildings.
889331_13_ITEM1_P33_S1	They are rated and listed under one of many Underwriters Laboratories fuse classifications.
889331_13_ITEM1_P34_S0	Major applications for power fuses include protection from over-load and short-circuit currents in motor branch circuits, heating and cooling systems, control systems, lighting circuits, solar and electrical distribution networks.
889331_13_ITEM1_P35_S0	The company s POWR-GARD product line features the Indicator series power fuse used in both the OEM and MRO markets.
889331_13_ITEM1_P35_S1	The Indicator technology provides visual blown-fuse indication at a glance, reducing maintenance and downtime on production equipment.
889331_13_ITEM1_P35_S2	The Indicator product offering is widely used in motor protection and industrial control panel applications.
889331_13_ITEM1_P36_S0	Protection relays are used to protect personnel and equipment in mining, oil gas and industrial environments from excessive currents, over voltages and electrical shock hazards called ground-faults.
889331_13_ITEM1_P36_S1	Major applications for protection relays include protection of motor, transformer and power-line distribution circuits.
889331_13_ITEM1_P37_S0	Ground-fault relays are used to protect personnel and equipment in wet environments such as underground mining or water treatment applications where there is a greater risk for electricity to come in contact with water and create a shock hazard.
889331_13_ITEM1_P38_S0	Custom electrical equipment is used in harsh environments such as underground mining where standard electrical gear will not meet customer needs for reliability and durability.
889331_13_ITEM1_P39_S0	Portable power substations are used to transform and distribute electrical power to mobile equipment such as mining cutting machines and other electrical machinery.
889331_13_ITEM1_P40_S0	Miner control units provide power management for critical electrically operated underground production equipment.
889331_13_ITEM1_P41_S0	The company employs scientific, engineering and other personnel to continually improve its existing product lines and to develop new products at its research and engineering facilities in Champaign and Chicago, Illinois, Boston, Massachusetts, Canada, China, Germany, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Mexico.
889331_13_ITEM1_P41_S1	The Product Development Technology departments maintain a staff of engineers, chemists, material scientists and technicians whose primary responsibility is to design and develop new products.
889331_13_ITEM1_P42_S0	Proposals for the development of new products are initiated primarily by sales and marketing personnel with input from customers.
889331_13_ITEM1_P42_S1	The entire product development process usually ranges from a few months to 18 months based on the complexity of development, with continuous efforts to reduce the development cycle.
889331_13_ITEM1_P43_S0	During fiscal years 2012, 2011 and 2010, the company expended $21.2 million, $19.4 million and $17.6 million, respectively, on research, product design and development ( R D ).
889331_13_ITEM1_P43_S1	During 2010, the company completed moving R D operations to lower cost locations closer to its customers.
889331_13_ITEM1_P43_S2	R D operations are now in Canada, China, Germany, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Mexico, as well as the United States.
889331_13_ITEM1_P44_S0	The company generally relies on patent and trademark laws and license and nondisclosure agreements to protect intellectual property and proprietary products.
889331_13_ITEM1_P44_S1	In cases where it is deemed necessary by management, key employees are required to sign an agreement that they will maintain the confidentiality of the company s proprietary information and trade secrets.
889331_13_ITEM1_P45_S0	As of December 29, 2012, the company owned 219 patents in North America, 100 patents in the European Union and 149 patents in other foreign countries.
889331_13_ITEM1_P45_S1	The company also has registered trademark protection for certain of its brand names and logos.
889331_13_ITEM1_P45_S2	The 219 North American patents are in the following product categories: 135 electronics, 49 automotive and 35 electrical.
889331_13_ITEM1_P46_S0	Patents and licenses are amortized over a period of 7-12 years, with a weighted average life of 11.8 years.
889331_13_ITEM1_P46_S1	Distribution networks are amortized over a period of 3-20 years, with a weighted average life of 13.6 years.
889331_13_ITEM1_P46_S2	Trademarks and tradenames are amortized over a period of 5-20 years, with a weighted average life of 13.5 years.
889331_13_ITEM1_P46_S3	The company recorded amortization expense of $6.1 million, $6.6 million and $5.0 million in 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively, related to amortizable intangible assets.
889331_13_ITEM1_P47_S0	New products are continually being developed to replace older products.
889331_13_ITEM1_P47_S1	The company regularly applies for patent protection on such new products.
889331_13_ITEM1_P47_S2	Although, in the aggregate, the company s patents are important in the operation of its businesses, the company believes that the loss by expiration or otherwise of any one patent or group of patents would not materially affect its business.
889331_13_ITEM1_P48_S0	License royalties amounted to $0.7 million, $1.0 million and $0.2 million for fiscal 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively, and are included in other expense (income), net on the Consolidated Statements of Net Income.
889331_13_ITEM1_P49_S0	The company performs the majority of its own fabrication, stamps some of the metal components used in its fuses, holders and switches from raw metal stock and makes its own contacts and springs.
889331_13_ITEM1_P49_S1	In addition, the company fabricates silicon wafers for certain applications and performs its own plating (silver, nickel, zinc, tin and oxides).
889331_13_ITEM1_P49_S2	All thermoplastic molded component requirements used for such products as the ATO , MINI and MAXI fuse product lines are met through the company s in-house molding capabilities.
889331_13_ITEM1_P50_S0	After components are stamped, molded, plated and readied for assembly, final assembly is accomplished on fully automatic and semi-automatic assembly machines.
889331_13_ITEM1_P51_S0	Quality assurance and operations personnel, using techniques such as statistical process control, perform tests, checks and measurements during the production process to maintain the highest levels of product quality and customer satisfaction.
889331_13_ITEM1_P52_S0	The principal raw materials for the company s products include copper and copper alloys, heat-resistant plastics, zinc, melamine, glass, silver, gold, raw silicon, solder and various gases.
889331_13_ITEM1_P52_S1	The company uses a sole source for several heat-resistant plastics and for zinc, but believes that suitable alternative heat-resistant plastics and zinc are available from other sources at comparable prices.
889331_13_ITEM1_P52_S2	All other raw materials are purchased from a number of readily available outside sources.
889331_13_ITEM1_P53_S0	A computer-aided design and manufacturing system (CAD/CAM) expedites product development and machine design and the company s laboratories test new products, prototype concepts and production run samples.
889331_13_ITEM1_P53_S1	The company participates in just-in-time delivery programs with many of its major suppliers and actively promotes the building of strong cooperative relationships with its suppliers by utilizing early supplier involvement techniques and engaging them in pre-engineering product and process development.
889331_13_ITEM1_P54_S0	The company s domestic sales and marketing staff of over 35 people maintains relationships with major OEMs and distributors.
889331_13_ITEM1_P54_S1	The company s sales, marketing and engineering personnel interact directly with OEM engineers to ensure appropriate circuit protection and reliability within the parameters of the OEM s circuit design.
889331_13_ITEM1_P54_S2	Internationally, the company maintains a sales and marketing staff of over 100 people with sales offices in the U.K., Germany, Spain, Italy, Singapore, Taiwan, Japan, Brazil, Hong Kong, Korea, China and India.
889331_13_ITEM1_P54_S3	The company also markets its products indirectly through a worldwide organization of over 60 manufacturers representatives and distributes through an extensive network of electronics, automotive and electrical distributors.
889331_13_ITEM1_P55_S0	The company uses manufacturers representatives to sell its electronics products domestically and to call on major domestic and international OEMs and distributors.
889331_13_ITEM1_P55_S1	The company sells approximately 15% of its domestic products directly to OEMs, with the remainder sold through distributors nationwide.
889331_13_ITEM1_P56_S0	In the Asia-Pacific region, the company maintains a direct sales staff and utilizes distributors in Japan, Singapore, Korea, Taiwan, China, Malaysia, Hong Kong, India and the Philippines.
889331_13_ITEM1_P56_S1	In the Americas, the company maintains a direct sales staff in the U.S. and Brazil and utilizes manufacturers representatives and distributors in Canada.
889331_13_ITEM1_P56_S2	In Europe, the company maintains a direct sales force and utilizes manufacturers representatives and distributors to support a wide array of customers.
889331_13_ITEM1_P57_S0	The company maintains a direct sales force to service all the major automotive and commercial vehicle OEMs and system suppliers domestically.
889331_13_ITEM1_P57_S1	Over 20 manufacturers representatives sell the company s products to aftermarket fuse retailers such as O Reilly Auto Parts and Pep Boys.
889331_13_ITEM1_P57_S2	The company also uses about 15 manufacturers representatives to sell to the commercial vehicle aftermarket.
889331_13_ITEM1_P57_S3	In Europe, the company uses both a direct sales force and manufacturers representatives to distribute its products to OEMs, major system suppliers and aftermarket distributors.
889331_13_ITEM1_P57_S4	In the Asia-Pacific region, the company uses both a direct sales force and distributors to supply to major OEMs and system suppliers.
889331_13_ITEM1_P58_S0	The company markets and sells its power fuses and protection relays through over 35 manufacturers representatives across North America.
889331_13_ITEM1_P58_S1	These representatives sell power fuse products through an electrical and industrial distribution network comprised of approximately 2,000 distributor buying locations.
889331_13_ITEM1_P58_S2	These distributors have customers that include electrical contractors, municipalities, utilities and factories (including both MRO and OEM).
889331_13_ITEM1_P59_S0	The company s field sales force (including regional sales managers and application engineers) and manufacturers representatives call on both distributors and end-users (consulting engineers, municipalities, utilities and OEMs) in an effort to educate these customers on the capabilities and characteristics of the company s products.
889331_13_ITEM1_P60_S0	The company sells to over 5,000 customers and distributors worldwide.
889331_13_ITEM1_P60_S1	Sales to Arrow Electronics (an Electronics distributor) were less than 10% of net sales for 2012 and 2011, respectively, but were 10.4% for 2010.
889331_13_ITEM1_P60_S2	No other single customer accounted for more than 10% of net sales during any of the last three years.
889331_13_ITEM1_P60_S3	During fiscal 2012, 2011 and 2010, net sales to customers outside the United States accounted for approximately 67%, 66% and 69%, respectively, of the company s total net sales.
889331_13_ITEM1_P61_S0	The company s products compete with similar products of other manufacturers, some of which have substantially greater financial resources than the company.
889331_13_ITEM1_P61_S1	In the electronics market, the company s competitors include Cooper Industries, Bel Fuse, Bourns, EPCOS, On Semiconductor, STMicroelectronics, Semtech, Vishay and TE Connectivity.
889331_13_ITEM1_P61_S2	In the automotive market, the company s competitors include Cooper Industries, Pacific Engineering (a private company in Japan) and MTA (a private company in Italy).
889331_13_ITEM1_P61_S3	In the electrical market, the company s major competitors include Cooper Industries and Mersen.
889331_13_ITEM1_P61_S4	The company believes that it competes on the basis of innovative products, the breadth of its product line, the quality and design of its products and the responsiveness of its customer service, in addition to price.
889331_13_ITEM1_P62_S0	The backlog of unfilled orders at December 29, 2012 was approximately $79.2 million, compared to $92.4 million at December 31, 2011.
889331_13_ITEM1_P62_S1	Substantially all of the orders currently in backlog are scheduled for delivery in 2013.
889331_13_ITEM1_P63_S0	As of December 29, 2012, the company employed approximately 6,000 employees worldwide.
889331_13_ITEM1_P63_S1	Approximately 730 employees in Mexico and three employees in Germany are covered by collective bargaining agreements.
889331_13_ITEM1_P63_S2	The Mexico collective bargaining agreement, covering employees in Piedras Negras, expires January 31, 2014.
889331_13_ITEM1_P64_S0	The Germany collective bargaining agreement, covering three employees in Essen, expires March 31, 2013.
889331_13_ITEM1_P65_S0	During 2011, a collective bargaining agreement covering 28 employees at the company s D nsen, Germany facility was terminated as a result of plant closure.
889331_13_ITEM1_P66_S0	Approximately 12% of the company's total workforce was employed under collective bargaining agreements at December 29, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM1_P66_S1	The employees covered by a collective bargaining agreement that will expire within one year of December 29, 2012 represent less than 1% of the company's total workforce.
889331_13_ITEM1_P67_S0	Overall, the company has historically maintained satisfactory employee relations and considers employee relations to be good.
889331_13_ITEM1_P68_S0	The company is subject to numerous foreign, federal, state and local regulations relating to air and water quality, the disposal of hazardous waste materials, safety and health.
889331_13_ITEM1_P68_S1	Compliance with applicable environmental regulations has not significantly changed the company s competitive position, capital spending or earnings in the past and the company does not presently anticipate that compliance with such regulations will change its competitive position, capital spending or earnings for the foreseeable future.
889331_13_ITEM1_P69_S0	The company employs an environmental engineer to monitor regulatory matters and believes that it is currently in compliance in all material respects with applicable environmental laws and regulations.
889331_13_ITEM1_P70_S0	Littelfuse GmbH, which was acquired by the company in May 2004, is responsible for maintaining closed coal mines from legacy acquisitions.
889331_13_ITEM1_P70_S1	The company is compliant with German regulations pertaining to the maintenance of the mines and has an accrual related to certain of these coal mine shafts based on an engineering study estimating the cost of remediating the dangers (such as a shaft collapse) of certain of these closed coal mine shafts in Germany.
889331_13_ITEM1_P70_S2	The reserve is reviewed annually and calculated based upon the cost of remediating the shafts that the study deems most risky.
889331_13_ITEM1_P70_S3	Further information regarding the coal mine liability reserve is provided in Note 11 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Our business, financial condition and results of operations are subject to various risks and uncertainties, including the risk factors we have identified below.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P0_S1	These factors are not necessarily listed in order of importance.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P0_S2	We may amend or supplement the risk factors from time to time by other reports that we file with the SEC in the future.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Our industry is subject to intense competitive pressures.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We operate in markets that are highly competitive.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P2_S1	We compete on the basis of price, quality, service and/or brand name across the industries and markets we serve.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Competitive pressures could affect the prices we are able to charge our customers or the demand for our products.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We may not always be able to compete on price, particularly when compared to manufacturers with lower cost structures.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Some of our competitors have substantially greater sales, financial and manufacturing resources and may have greater access to capital than Littelfuse.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P3_S2	As other companies enter our markets or develop new products, competition may further intensify.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Our failure to compete effectively could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P4_S0	We may be unable to manufacture and deliver products in a manner that is responsive to our customers needs.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P5_S0	The end markets for our products are characterized by technological change, frequent new product introductions and enhancements, changes in customer requirements and emerging industry standards.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P5_S1	The introduction of products embodying new technologies and the emergence of new industry standards could render our existing products obsolete and unmarketable before we can recover any or all of our research, development and commercialization expenses on capital investments.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Furthermore, the life cycles of our products may change and are difficult to estimate.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our future success will depend upon our ability to manufacture and deliver products in a manner that is responsive to our customers needs.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P6_S1	We will need to develop and introduce new products and product enhancements on a timely basis that keep pace with technological developments and emerging industry standards and address increasingly sophisticated requirements of our customers.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P6_S2	We invest heavily in research and development without knowing that we will recover these costs.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Our competitors may develop products or technologies that will render our products non-competitive or obsolete.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P6_S4	If we cannot develop and market new products or product enhancements in a timely and cost-effective manner, our business, financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Our business may be interrupted by labor disputes or other interruptions of supplies.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P8_S0	A work stoppage could occur at certain of our facilities, most likely as a result of disputes under collective bargaining agreements or in connection with negotiations of new collective bargaining agreements.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P8_S1	In addition, we may experience a shortage of supplies for various reasons, such as financial distress, work stoppages, natural disasters or production difficulties that may affect one of our suppliers.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P8_S2	A significant work stoppage, or an interruption or shortage of supplies for any reason, if protracted, could substantially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P8_S3	The transfer of our manufacturing operations and changes in our distribution model could disrupt operations for a limited time.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Our revenues may vary significantly from period to period.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our revenues may vary significantly from one accounting period to another due to a variety of factors including:
889331_13_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The bankruptcy or insolvency of a major customer could adversely affect us.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P12_S0	The bankruptcy or insolvency of a major customer could result in lower sales revenue and cause a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P12_S1	In addition, the bankruptcy or insolvency of a major U.S. auto manufacturer or significant supplier likely could lead to substantial disruptions in the automotive supply base, resulting in lower demand for our products, which likely would cause a decrease in sales revenue and have a substantial adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Our ability to manage currency or commodity price fluctuations or shortages is limited.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P14_S0	As a resource-intensive manufacturing operation, we are exposed to a variety of market and asset risks, including the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates, commodity prices and interest rates.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P14_S1	We have multiple sources of supply for the majority of our commodity requirements.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P14_S2	However, significant shortages that disrupt the supply of raw materials or result in price increases could affect prices we charge our customers, our product costs and the competitive position of our products and services.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P14_S3	We monitor and manage these exposures as an integral part of our overall risk management program, which recognizes the unpredictability of markets and seeks to reduce the potentially adverse effects on our results.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P14_S4	Nevertheless, changes in currency exchange rates, commodity prices and interest rates cannot always be predicted.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P14_S5	In addition, because of intense price competition and our high level of fixed costs, we may not be able to address such changes even if they are foreseeable.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P14_S6	Substantial changes in these rates and prices could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P14_S7	For additional discussion of interest rate, currency or commodity price risk, see "Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Operations and supply sources located outside the United States, particularly in emerging markets, are subject to greater risks.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Our operating activities outside the United States contribute significantly to our revenues and earnings.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P16_S1	Serving a global customer base and remaining competitive in the global marketplace requires the company to place our production in countries outside the United States, including emerging markets, to capitalize on market opportunities and maintain a cost-efficient structure.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P16_S2	In addition, we source a significant amount of raw materials and other components from third-party suppliers in low-cost countries.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Our international operating activities are subject to a number of risks generally associated with international operations, including risks relating to the following:
889331_13_ITEM1A_P18_S0	limitations on our ability to enforce legal rights and remedies.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Any of these factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We engage in acquisitions and may encounter difficulties in integrating these businesses.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P21_S0	We are a company that, from time to time, seeks to grow through strategic acquisitions.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P21_S1	We have in the past acquired a number of businesses or companies and additional product lines and assets.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P21_S2	We intend to continue to expand and diversify our operations with additional acquisitions.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P21_S3	The success of these transactions depends on our ability to integrate the assets and personnel acquired in these acquisitions.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P21_S4	We may encounter difficulties in integrating acquisitions with our operations and may not realize the degree or timing of the benefits that we anticipated from an acquisition.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Environmental liabilities could adversely impact our financial position.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Federal, state and local laws and regulations impose various restrictions and controls on the discharge of materials, chemicals and gases used in our manufacturing processes or in our finished goods.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P23_S1	These environmental regulations have required us to expend a portion of our resources and capital on relevant compliance programs.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P23_S2	Under these laws and regulations, we could be held financially responsible for remedial measures if our current or former properties are contaminated or if we send waste to a landfill or recycling facility that becomes contaminated, even if we did not cause the contamination.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P23_S3	We may be subject to additional common law claims if we release substances that damage or harm third parties.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P23_S4	In addition, future changes in environmental laws or regulations may require additional investments in capital equipment or the implementation of additional compliance programs.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P23_S5	Any failure to comply with new or existing environmental laws or regulations could subject us to significant liabilities and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P24_S0	In the conduct of our manufacturing operations, we have handled and do handle materials that are considered hazardous, toxic or volatile under federal, state and local laws.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P24_S1	The risk of accidental release of such materials cannot be completely eliminated.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P25_S0	In addition, we operate or own facilities located on or near real property that was formerly owned and operated by others.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Certain of these properties were used in ways that involved hazardous materials.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Contaminants may migrate from, within or through these properties.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P25_S3	These releases or migrations may give rise to claims.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Where third parties are responsible for contamination, the third parties may not have funds, or not make funds available when needed, to pay remediation costs imposed upon us under environmental laws and regulations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P27_S0	The company is responsible for the maintenance of discontinued coal mining operations in Germany.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P27_S1	The risk of environmental remediation exists and the company is in the process of remediating the mines considered to be the most at risk.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P28_S0	We derive a substantial portion of our revenues from customers in the automotive, consumer electronics and communications industries, and we are susceptible to trends and factors affecting those industries as well as the success of our customers products.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Net sales to the automotive, consumer electronics and communications industries represent a substantial portion of our revenues.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P29_S1	Factors negatively affecting these industries and the demand for products also negatively affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P29_S2	Any adverse occurrence, including industry slowdown, recession, political instability, costly or constraining regulations, armed hostilities, terrorism, excessive inflation, prolonged disruptions in one or more of our customers production schedules or labor disturbances, that results in significant decline in the volume of sales in these industries, or in an overall downturn in the business and operations of our customers in these industries, could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P29_S3	For example, the automotive industry as well as the consumer electronics market is highly cyclical in nature and sensitive to changes in general economic conditions, consumer preferences and interest rates.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P29_S4	In addition, the global automotive and electronic industries have overall manufacturing capacity far exceeding demand.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P29_S5	To the extent that demand for certain of our customers products declines, the demand for our products may decline.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P29_S6	Reduced demand relating to general economic conditions, consumer preferences, interest rates or industry over-capacity may have a material adverse effect upon our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P30_S0	The inability to maintain access to capital markets may adversely affect our business and financial results.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Our ability to invest in our businesses, make strategic acquisitions and refinance maturing debt obligations may require access to the capital markets and sufficient bank credit lines to support short-term borrowings.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P31_S1	If we are unable to access the capital markets or bank credit facilities, we could experience a material adverse affect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Fixed costs may reduce operating results if our sales fall below expectations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Our expense levels are based, in part, on our expectations for future sales.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P33_S1	Many of our expenses, particularly those relating to capital equipment and manufacturing overhead, are relatively fixed.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P33_S2	We might be unable to reduce spending quickly enough to compensate for reductions in sales.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P33_S3	Accordingly, shortfalls in sales could materially and adversely affect our operating results.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P34_S0	The volatility of our stock price could affect the value of an investment in our stock and our future financial position.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P35_S0	The market price of our stock has fluctuated widely.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P35_S1	Between January 1, 2012 and December 29, 2012, the closing sale price of our common stock ranged between a low of $43.81 and a high of $64.86, experiencing greater volatility over that time than the broader markets.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P35_S2	The volatility of our stock price may be related to any number of factors, such as general economic conditions, industry conditions, analysts expectations concerning our results of operations, or the volatility of our revenues as discussed above under Our Revenues May Vary Significantly from Period to Period.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P35_S3	The historic market price of our common stock may not be indicative of future market prices.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P35_S4	We may not be able to sustain or increase the value of our common stock.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P35_S5	Declines in the market price of our stock could adversely affect our ability to retain personnel with stock incentives, to acquire businesses or assets in exchange for stock and/or to conduct future financing activities with or involving our common stock.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P36_S0	Customer demands and new regulations related to conflict-free minerals may force us to incur additional expenses.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P37_S0	The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act requires disclosure of use of conflict minerals mined from the Democratic Republic of Congo and adjoining countries and efforts to prevent the use of such minerals.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P38_S0	In the semiconductor industry, these minerals are most commonly found in metals.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P39_S0	As there may be only a limited number of suppliers offering conflict free metals, we cannot be sure that we will be able to obtain necessary metals in sufficient quantities or at competitive prices.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P39_S1	Also, we may face challenges with our customers and suppliers if we are unable to sufficiently verify that the metals used in our products are conflict free.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P40_S0	Our Information Technology ( IT ) systems could be breached.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P41_S0	We face certain security threats relating to the confidentiality and integrity of our IT systems.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P41_S1	Despite implementation of security measures, our IT systems may be vulnerable to damage from computer viruses, cyber attacks and other unauthorized access and these security breaches could result in a disruption to our operations.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P41_S2	A material network breach of our IT systems could involve the theft of intellectual property or customer data which may be used by competitors.
889331_13_ITEM1A_P41_S3	To the extent that any security breach results in a loss or damage to data, or inappropriate disclosure of confidential or proprietary information, it could cause damage to our reputation, affect our customer relations, lead to claims against us, increase our costs to protect against future damage and could result in a material adverse effect on our business and financial position.
889331_13_ITEM2_P0_S0	The company s operations are located in 44 owned or leased facilities worldwide, totaling approximately 1.6 million square feet.
889331_13_ITEM2_P0_S1	The company s corporate headquarters is located in the U.S. in Chicago, Illinois.
889331_13_ITEM2_P0_S2	The company has North American manufacturing facilities in Saskatoon, Canada, Piedras Negras, Mexico, Melchor Muzquiz, Mexico and Bellingham, Washington.
889331_13_ITEM2_P0_S3	During 2010, the European headquarters and the primary European distribution center, previously located in Utrecht, the Netherlands, until the property was sold in 2010, were relocated to D nsen, Germany.
889331_13_ITEM2_P0_S4	The D nsen facility was closed during 2011 and sold in 2012.
889331_13_ITEM2_P0_S5	Manufacturing operations were transferred from D nsen to Piedras Negras, Mexico.
889331_13_ITEM2_P0_S6	The office and European headquarters were subsequently transferred to Bremen, Germany.
889331_13_ITEM2_P0_S7	The company has added manufacturing facilities in Roskilde, Denmark and Kaunas, Lithuania through acquisitions completed in 2011 and 2012, respectively.
889331_13_ITEM2_P0_S8	The company has entered into a binding agreement for the future sale of its Des Plaines, Illinois, property which was closed in 2009.
889331_13_ITEM2_P0_S9	The Des Plaines building was demolished in 2010 to facilitate the sale of the underlying property.
889331_13_ITEM2_P0_S10	The Dundalk, Ireland facility, which was also closed in 2009, was sold in 2012.

889331_13_ITEM2_P1_S1	The manufacturing plant previously located in Taiwan was closed and sold during 2012.
889331_13_ITEM2_P1_S2	The company does not believe that it will encounter any difficulty in renewing its existing leases upon the expiration of their current terms.
889331_13_ITEM2_P1_S3	Management believes that the company s facilities are adequate to meet its requirements for the foreseeable future.

889331_13_ITEM6_P0_S0	The information presented below provides selected financial data of the company during the past five fiscal years and should be read in conjunction with Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and the Consolidated Financial Statements and Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Item 7 and Item 8, respectively, for the respective years presented (amounts in thousands, except per share data):
889331_13_ITEM7_P0_S0	Littelfuse, Inc. and its subsidiaries (the company or Littelfuse ) design, manufacture and sell circuit protection devices for use in the electronics, automotive and electrical markets throughout the world.
889331_13_ITEM7_P1_S0	The following Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations ( MD A ) is designed to provide the reader with information that will assist in understanding the company s Consolidated Financial Statements, the changes in certain key items in those financial statements from year to year, and the primary factors that accounted for those changes, as well as how certain accounting principles affect the Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_13_ITEM7_P1_S1	The discussion also provides information about the financial results of the various business unit segments to provide a better understanding of how those segments and their results affect the financial condition and results of operations of Littelfuse as a whole.
889331_13_ITEM7_P2_S0	U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ) dictates annual and interim reporting standards for an enterprise's operating segments and related disclosures about its products, services, geographic areas and major customers.
889331_13_ITEM7_P2_S1	Within U.S. GAAP, an operating segment is defined as a component of an enterprise that engages in business activities from which it may earn revenues and incur expenses, and about which separate financial information is regularly evaluated by the Chief Operating Decision Maker ( CODM ) in deciding how to allocate resources.
889331_13_ITEM7_P2_S2	The CODM is the company s President and Chief Executive Officer.
889331_13_ITEM7_P3_S0	The company reports its operations by three business unit segments: Electronics, Automotive and Electrical.
889331_13_ITEM7_P3_S1	The following table is a summary of the company s operating segments net sales by business unit and geography (in millions):
889331_13_ITEM7_P4_S0	Sales by geography represent sales to customer or distributor locations.
889331_13_ITEM7_P5_S0	Business unit segment information is described more fully in Note 16 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_13_ITEM7_P6_S0	The following discussion provides an analysis of the information contained in the Consolidated Financial Statements and accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements at December 29, 2012 and December 31, 2011, and for the three fiscal years ended December 29, 2012, December 31, 2011 and January 1, 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P7_S0	Net sales increased $2.9 million or less than 1% to $667.9 million for fiscal year 2012 compared to $665.0 million in fiscal year 2011 due primarily to an incremental $16.6 million from business acquisitions and growth in protection relays, custom mining products and automotive products, offset by lower electronics sales.
889331_13_ITEM7_P7_S1	The company also experienced $9.4 million in unfavorable foreign currency effects in 2012 as compared to 2011 primarily resulting from sales denominated in euros and, to a lesser extent, Canadian dollars and Korean won.
889331_13_ITEM7_P7_S2	Excluding acquisitions and currency effects, net sales decreased $4.3 million or less than 1% year over year.
889331_13_ITEM7_P7_S3	The Automotive business segment sales increased $8.6 million or 4% to $206.2 million.
889331_13_ITEM7_P7_S4	The Electronics business segment sales decreased $25.0 million or 7% to $329.5 million, and the Electrical business segment sales increased $19.3 million or 17% to $132.2 million.
889331_13_ITEM7_P8_S0	Sales levels in 2012, excluding acquisitions and currency effects, were negatively impacted by slowing demand for the company s electronics products coupled with channel inventory de-stocking.
889331_13_ITEM7_P8_S1	Sales levels in 2011, excluding acquisitions and currency effects, were negatively impacted by slowing demand for the company s electronics products coupled with inventory de-stocking in the supply chain.
889331_13_ITEM7_P9_S0	The increase in Automotive sales was primarily due to an incremental $12.9 million in sales related to the Accel and Terra Power acquisitions in 2012 and organic growth in the passenger vehicle market.
889331_13_ITEM7_P9_S1	This was offset by a decline in commercial vehicle sales and unfavorable currency effects.
889331_13_ITEM7_P10_S0	Lower commercial vehicle sales reflected weakness in the construction and heavy truck markets.
889331_13_ITEM7_P10_S1	Currency effects reduced sales by $5.0 million in 2012 compared to 2011 primarily due to the weaker euro.
889331_13_ITEM7_P10_S2	Excluding incremental sales from acquisitions and currency effects, Automotive sales increased $0.7 million or less than 1% year over year.
889331_13_ITEM7_P11_S0	The decrease in Electronics sales reflected slowing demand across all geographies.
889331_13_ITEM7_P11_S1	There was weakness in the telecom, PC and TV end markets in addition to distributor channel inventory de-stocking.
889331_13_ITEM7_P11_S2	In addition, sales were negatively impacted by net unfavorable currency effects of $3.2 million, primarily from sales denominated in euros and Korean won.
889331_13_ITEM7_P12_S0	The increase in Electrical sales was due to continued strong growth for protection relays and custom mining products, an upturn in solar sales reflecting the success of new products, and improvement in the industrial fuse market.
889331_13_ITEM7_P12_S1	The Electrical business segment also had $3.7 million in incremental sales from the Selco acquisition in 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P12_S2	The Electrical segment experienced net unfavorable currency effects of $1.2 million primarily from sales denominated in Canadian dollars.
889331_13_ITEM7_P12_S3	Excluding incremental sales from acquisitions and currency effects, Electrical sales increased $16.8 million or 15% year over year.
889331_13_ITEM7_P13_S0	On a geographic basis, sales in the Americas increased $15.0 million or 5% in 2012 as compared to 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P13_S1	This increase resulted from an increase in the company s Automotive and Electrical business segments offset by a decline in the Electronics business segment.
889331_13_ITEM7_P13_S2	Automotive sales increased $1.7 million or 2% primarily reflecting incremental sales from Terra Power.
889331_13_ITEM7_P13_S3	Excluding the acquisition, Automotive sales were essentially flat year-over-year as growth in the passenger vehicle market was offset by declines in the commercial vehicle market.
889331_13_ITEM7_P13_S4	Electrical sales increased $15.5 million or 15% resulting from increases in demand for protection relays, custom products and industrial power fuses.
889331_13_ITEM7_P13_S5	Electronics sales decreased $2.2 million or 2% primarily reflecting inventory de-stocking.
889331_13_ITEM7_P13_S6	The Americas region also experienced $0.9 million in unfavorable currency effects resulting from sales denominated in Canadian dollars.
889331_13_ITEM7_P14_S0	European sales decreased $7.4 million or 6% in 2012 compared to 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P14_S1	This resulted from decreases in the company s Electronics and Automotive business segments offset by an increase in the Electrical business segment.
889331_13_ITEM7_P14_S2	Automotive sales decreased $0.4 million or less than 1% in 2012 primarily reflecting lower demand in the passenger vehicle markets.
889331_13_ITEM7_P14_S3	Excluding the impact of incremental sales from acquisitions and unfavorable currency effects, primarily from a weaker euro, Automotive sales declined $6.5 million or 10%.
889331_13_ITEM7_P14_S4	Electronics sales decreased $10.3 million or 24% reflecting lower demand resulting from a weaker economy during 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P14_S5	Electrical sales increased $3.3 million or 63% primarily from the incremental sales of Selco.
889331_13_ITEM7_P14_S6	Excluding incremental sales and currency effects, Electrical sales increased $0.1 million or 2% year-over-year.
889331_13_ITEM7_P14_S7	Overall European sales in 2012 included unfavorable currency effects of $8.6 million, resulting primarily from sales denominated in euros.
889331_13_ITEM7_P15_S0	Asia-Pacific sales decreased $4.7 million or 2% in 2012 compared to 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P15_S1	This decrease resulted from a decrease in the Electronics business segment offset by increases at the company s Automotive and Electrical business segments.
889331_13_ITEM7_P15_S2	Electronics sales decreased $12.5 million or 6% reflecting slowing end-market demand and inventory de-stocking.
889331_13_ITEM7_P15_S3	Automotive sales increased $7.4 million or 20% reflecting continued increased demand for passenger vehicles in the developing Asian markets as well as gains in market share.
889331_13_ITEM7_P15_S4	Electrical sales increased $0.5 million or 9%.
889331_13_ITEM7_P15_S5	Current year results included favorable currency effects of $0.1 million resulting from sales denominated in Chinese yuan partially offset by sales denominated in Korean won and Japanese yen.
889331_13_ITEM7_P16_S0	Gross profit was $258.5 million or 38.7% of sales in 2012, compared to $256.7 million or 38.6% of sales in 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P16_S1	Gross profit in both 2012 and 2011 were negatively impacted by purchase accounting adjustments in cost of sales of $0.6 million and $4.1 million, respectively.
889331_13_ITEM7_P16_S2	These charges were the additional cost of goods sold for Accel and Selco inventory which had been stepped-up to fair value at the acquisition dates as required by purchase accounting rules.
889331_13_ITEM7_P16_S3	Excluding the impact of these charges, gross profit was $259.1 million or 38.8% of sales for 2012 as compared to $260.8 million or 39.2% of sales in 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P16_S4	The decline in gross margin was primarily attributable to the unfavorable impact of currency effects on sales as described above.
889331_13_ITEM7_P17_S0	Total operating expense was $151.6 million or 22.7% of net sales for 2012 compared to $142.8 million or 21.5% of net sales for 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P17_S1	The increase in operating expenses primarily reflects incremental operating expenses of $6.5 million from business acquisitions and $5.1 million in charges related to the settlement of pension liabilities for certain former employees.
889331_13_ITEM7_P17_S2	Further information regarding the company s pension settlement charge is provided in Note 13 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_13_ITEM7_P18_S0	Operating income was $106.9 million or 16.0% of net sales in 2012 compared to $113.9 million or 17.1% of net sales in the prior year.
889331_13_ITEM7_P18_S1	The decrease in operating income in the current year was due primarily to the limited sales growth and an increase in costs as described above.
889331_13_ITEM7_P19_S0	Interest expense was unchanged at $1.7 million in both 2012 and 2011 and is primarily related to the company s revolving credit facility.
889331_13_ITEM7_P20_S0	Impairment and equity in net loss of unconsolidated affiliate was $7.3 million in 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P21_S0	During the fourth quarter, the company determined that it had the ability to exert significant influence over Shocking Technologies, Inc. ( Shocking ) and as a result began accounting for the investment using the equity method.
889331_13_ITEM7_P21_S1	In accordance with Accounting Standards Codification ( ASC ) 323, the company retroactively recorded its proportional share of Shocking s operating losses, which amounted to approximately $4.0 million in 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P21_S2	The proportional amount of operating losses in 2011 was not material.
889331_13_ITEM7_P21_S3	In addition, the company concluded that there was an other-than-temporary impairment which existed for its remaining investment in Shocking.
889331_13_ITEM7_P21_S4	The company engaged a third-party valuation firm to assist in developing the fair value of the investment in Shocking.
889331_13_ITEM7_P21_S5	Based on the then fair value, the company determined that there was an impairment of approximately $3.3 million which was recorded as a non-operating impairment and equity loss of unconsolidated affiliate in the Consolidated Statements of Net Income.
889331_13_ITEM7_P21_S6	See Note 6 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_13_ITEM7_P22_S0	Other expense (income), net, consisting of interest income, royalties, non-operating income and foreign currency items was $2.2 million of income in 2012 compared to $2.9 million of income in 2011.The year-over-year decrease in income primarily reflects the impact of unfavorable currency translation effects (primarily due to the weakening of the euro against the U.S. dollar) in 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P23_S0	Income before income taxes was $100.1 million in 2012 compared to $115.1 million in 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P23_S1	Income tax expense was $24.7 million in 2012 compared to $28.1 million in 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P23_S2	The 2012 effective income tax rate was 24.7% compared to 24.4% in 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P23_S3	The 2012 effective tax rate is lower than the statutory tax rate primarily due to the result of more income earned in low tax jurisdictions.
889331_13_ITEM7_P24_S0	Net sales increased $57.0 million or 9% to $665.0 million for fiscal year 2011 compared to $608.0 million in fiscal year 2010 due primarily to an incremental $50.1 million from business acquisitions and growth in protection relays, custom mining products and automotive products, offset by lower electronics sales.
889331_13_ITEM7_P24_S1	The company also experienced $10.4 million in favorable foreign currency effects in 2011 as compared to 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P24_S2	The favorable foreign currency impact primarily resulted from sales denominated in euros and, to a lesser extent, Canadian dollars and Japanese yen.
889331_13_ITEM7_P24_S3	Excluding acquisitions and currency effects, net sales decreased $3.5 million or 1% year over year.
889331_13_ITEM7_P24_S4	The Automotive business segment sales increased $58.5 million or 42% to $197.6 million.
889331_13_ITEM7_P24_S5	The Electronics business segment sales decreased $18.9 million or 5% to $354.5 million, and the Electrical business segment sales increased $17.4 million or 18% to $112.9 million.
889331_13_ITEM7_P25_S0	Sales levels in 2011, excluding acquisitions and currency effects, were negatively impacted by slowing demand for the company s electronics products coupled with inventory de-stocking in the supply chain.
889331_13_ITEM7_P25_S1	Sales levels in 2010 were positively impacted by the global economic recovery, distributor inventory replenishment and effective execution of the company s strategic growth plans.
889331_13_ITEM7_P26_S0	The increase in Automotive sales was primarily due to an incremental $46.9 million in sales related to Cole Hersee, organic growth in all regions and favorable currency effects.
889331_13_ITEM7_P26_S1	Excluding Cole Hersee, automotive sales increased $11.6 million or 8.4% year over year.
889331_13_ITEM7_P26_S2	Currency effects added $4.3 million to sales in 2011 compared to 2010 primarily due to the stronger euro.
889331_13_ITEM7_P27_S0	The decrease in Electronics sales reflected slowing demand across all geographies coupled with inventory de-stocking in the supply chain.
889331_13_ITEM7_P27_S1	In addition, the effects of the Japan disaster in March 2011 negatively impacted sales by approximately $3 to $4 million in 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P27_S2	The negative impact from a decrease in volume was partially offset by net favorable currency effects of $4.0 million primarily from sales denominated in euros and Japanese yen.
889331_13_ITEM7_P28_S0	The increase in Electrical sales was due to continued strong growth for protection relays and custom mining products and steady improvement in the industrial fuse market.
889331_13_ITEM7_P28_S1	This was partially offset by a slowdown in the solar market.
889331_13_ITEM7_P28_S2	The Electrical segment experienced net favorable currency effects of $2.0 million primarily from sales denominated in Canadian dollars.
889331_13_ITEM7_P29_S0	On a geographic basis, sales in the Americas increased $60.8 million or 27% in 2011 compared to 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P29_S1	This increase resulted from increases in the company s Automotive and Electrical business segments offset by a decline in the Electronics business segment.
889331_13_ITEM7_P29_S2	Automotive sales increased $46.8 million or 100% primarily reflecting incremental sales from Cole Hersee.
889331_13_ITEM7_P29_S3	Excluding Cole Hersee, Automotive sales increased $2.7 million or 6% reflecting increased demand in the passenger and commercial vehicle markets.
889331_13_ITEM7_P29_S4	Electrical sales increased $17.5 million or 21% resulting from increases in demand for protection relays, custom products and industrial power fuses partially offset by a decline in solar fuse sales.
889331_13_ITEM7_P29_S5	Electronics sales decreased $3.5 million or 4% reflecting slowing end-market demand and inventory de-stocking.
889331_13_ITEM7_P29_S6	The Americas region also experienced $1.9 million in favorable currency effects resulting from sales denominated in Canadian dollars.
889331_13_ITEM7_P30_S0	European sales decreased $0.2 million for fiscal year 2011 compared to 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P30_S1	This resulted from decreases in the company s Electronics and Electrical business segments offset by an increase in the Automotive business segment.
