889331_13_ITEM7_P30_S2	Automotive sales increased $7.2 million or 12% in 2011 primarily reflecting increased end-market demand and favorable currency effects.
889331_13_ITEM7_P30_S3	Electronics sales decreased $6.9 million or 14% reflecting lower demand resulting from a weaker economy during 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P30_S4	Electrical sales decreased $0.5 million or 9%.
889331_13_ITEM7_P30_S5	Overall European sales in 2011 included favorable currency effects of $5.3 million, resulting from sales denominated in euros.
889331_13_ITEM7_P31_S0	Asia-Pacific sales decreased $3.7 million or 1% in 2011 compared to 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P31_S1	This decrease resulted from a decrease in the Electronics business segment offset by increases at the company s Automotive and Electrical business segments.
889331_13_ITEM7_P31_S2	Electronics sales decreased $8.5 million or 4% reflecting slowing end-market demand and inventory de-stocking.
889331_13_ITEM7_P31_S3	Automotive sales increased $4.4 million or 14% reflecting continued increased demand for passenger vehicles in the developing Asian markets as well as gains in market share.
889331_13_ITEM7_P31_S4	Also contributing to the increase in Automotive sales was incremental sales from Cole Hersee.
889331_13_ITEM7_P31_S5	Excluding Cole Hersee, Automotive sales increased $2.3 million or 7%.
889331_13_ITEM7_P31_S6	Electrical sales increased $0.4 million or 7%.
889331_13_ITEM7_P31_S7	Current year results included favorable currency effects of $3.2 million resulting from sales denominated in Japanese yen, Korean won and Chinese yuan.
889331_13_ITEM7_P32_S0	Gross profit was $256.7 million or 38.6% of sales in 2011, compared to $233.9 million or 38.5% of sales in 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P32_S1	Gross profit in 2011 was negatively impacted by $4.1 million of purchase accounting adjustments recorded in cost of sales.
889331_13_ITEM7_P32_S2	These charges were the additional cost of goods sold for Cole Hersee and Selco inventory which had been stepped-up to fair value at the acquisition dates as required by purchase accounting rules.
889331_13_ITEM7_P32_S3	Excluding the impact of these charges, gross profit was $260.8 million or 39.2% of sales for 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P32_S4	The improvement in gross margin was attributable to improved operating leverage resulting from higher production volumes in 2011 as well as cost reductions related to manufacturing transfers.
889331_13_ITEM7_P33_S0	Total operating expense was $142.8 million or 21.5% of net sales for 2011 compared to $126.3 million or 20.8% of net sales for 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P33_S1	The increase in operating expenses primarily reflects incremental operating expenses of $12.8 million from business acquisitions.
889331_13_ITEM7_P34_S0	Operating income was $113.9 million or 17.1% of net sales in 2011 compared to $107.6 million or 17.7% of net sales in the prior year.
889331_13_ITEM7_P34_S1	The increase in operating income in the current year was due primarily to the increase in sales and reduction in costs as described above.
889331_13_ITEM7_P35_S0	Interest expense, net, increased to $1.7 million in 2011 compared to $1.4 million for 2010 primarily due to amortization of debt issuance costs incurred related to the new credit agreement in 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P36_S0	Other expense (income), net, consisting of interest income, royalties, non-operating income and foreign currency items, was $2.9 million of income in 2011 compared to $1.5 million of income in 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P36_S1	The year over year increase resulted primarily from dividend and royalty income.
889331_13_ITEM7_P37_S0	Income before income taxes was $115.1 million in 2011 compared to $107.7 million in 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P37_S1	Income tax expense was $28.1 million in 2011 compared to $29.0 million in 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P37_S2	The 2011 effective income tax rate was 24.4% compared to 27.0% in 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P37_S3	The 2011 effective tax rate is lower than the statuatory tax rate primarily due to the result of more income earned in low tax jurisdictions and a large tax benefit from revaluation of a deferred tax asset.
889331_13_ITEM7_P38_S0	As of December 29, 2012, $227.3 million of the $235.4 million of the company s cash and cash equivalents was held by foreign subsidiaries.
889331_13_ITEM7_P38_S1	Of the $227.3 million held by foreign subsidiaries, approximately $28.1 million could be repatriated with minimal tax consequences.
889331_13_ITEM7_P38_S2	The company expects to maintain its foreign cash balances (other than the aforementioned $28.1 million) for local operating requirements, to provide funds for future capital expenditures and for potential acquisitions.
889331_13_ITEM7_P38_S3	The company does not expect to repatriate these funds to the U.S.
889331_13_ITEM7_P39_S0	The company historically has financed capital expenditures through cash flows from operations.
889331_13_ITEM7_P39_S1	Management expects that cash flows from operations and available lines of credit will be sufficient to support both the company s operations and its debt obligations for the foreseeable future.
889331_13_ITEM7_P40_S0	On September 29, 2008, the company entered into a Loan Agreement with various lenders that provided the company with a five-year term loan facility of up to $80.0 million for the purposes of (i) refinancing certain existing indebtedness; (ii) funding working capital needs; and (iii) funding capital expenditures and other lawful corporate purposes, including permitted acquisitions.
889331_13_ITEM7_P40_S1	The company terminated this loan agreement on June 13, 2011 at which time any outstanding amounts were refinanced under the company s new revolving credit facility effective June 13, 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P41_S0	The company had an unsecured domestic financing arrangement, which expired on July 21, 2011, consisting of a credit agreement with banks that provided a $75.0 million revolving credit facility, with a potential to increase up to $125.0 million upon request of the company and agreement with the lenders.
889331_13_ITEM7_P41_S1	The company refinanced this loan agreement with proceeds from a new revolving credit facility on June 13, 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P42_S0	The company s revolving credit facility is an uncommitted and discretionary facility, subject to withdrawal at any time by the lender upon due notice to the company.
889331_13_ITEM7_P43_S0	On June 13, 2011, the company entered into a new credit agreement with certain commercial banks that provides an unsecured revolving credit facility in an amount of up to $150.0 million, with a potential to increase up to $225.0 million.
889331_13_ITEM7_P43_S1	At December 29, 2012, the company had available approximately $65.0 million of borrowing capacity under the revolving credit agreement at an interest rate of LIBOR plus 1.25% (1.46% as of December 29, 2012).
889331_13_ITEM7_P43_S2	The credit agreement replaces the company s previous credit agreement dated July 21, 2006 and term loan agreement dated September 29, 2008, and, unless terminated earlier, will terminate on June 13, 2016.
889331_13_ITEM7_P43_S3	During the second quarter of 2011, $0.2 million of previously capitalized debt issuance costs were written off as a non-cash charge and $0.7 million of new debt issuance costs incurred was capitalized and will be amortized over the life of the new credit agreement.
889331_13_ITEM7_P44_S0	This arrangement contains covenants that, among other matters, impose limitations on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, future mergers, sales of assets, payment of dividends, and changes in control, as defined in the agreement.
889331_13_ITEM7_P44_S1	In addition, the company is required to satisfy certain financial covenants and tests relating to, among other matters, interest coverage and leverage.
889331_13_ITEM7_P44_S2	At December 29, 2012, the company was in compliance with all covenants under the revolving credit facility.
889331_13_ITEM7_P45_S0	During the second quarter of 2011, as part of the new refinancing arrangement discussed above, $47.0 million of indebtedness that was due on the previous term loan was settled and rolled-over into the revolving credit facility by the lender.
889331_13_ITEM7_P46_S0	For the fiscal year ended December 29, 2012, the company had $0.8 million outstanding in letters of credit.
889331_13_ITEM7_P46_S1	No amounts were drawn under these letters of credit at December 29, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P46_S2	For the fiscal year ended December 31, 2011, the company had $2.3 million available in letters of credit.
889331_13_ITEM7_P46_S3	No amounts were drawn under these letters of credit at December 31, 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P47_S0	The company started 2012 with $164.0 million of cash.
889331_13_ITEM7_P47_S1	Net cash provided by operating activities in 2012 was approximately $116.2 million and included $75.3 million in net income and $46.0 million in non-cash adjustments (primarily $31.4 million in depreciation and amortization), partially offset by $5.2 million of changes in operating assets and liabilities.
889331_13_ITEM7_P48_S0	Changes in operating assets and liabilities in 2012 (including short-term and long-term items) that negatively impacted cash flows in 2012 consisted of changes in accounts receivable ($1.6 million), accrued expenses including post-retirement ($9.6 million), accrued payroll and severance ($4.4 million), accrued taxes ($0.4 million), and prepaid expenses and other (less than $0.1 million).
889331_13_ITEM7_P48_S1	Accrued expenses including post-retirement included $10.0 million in pension contributions in 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P48_S2	Positively impacting cash flows were changes in inventory ($5.4 million) and accounts payable ($5.4 million).
889331_13_ITEM7_P49_S0	Net cash used in investing activities in 2012 was approximately $51.7 million and included $22.5 million in purchases of property, plant and equipment (primarily production equipment for capacity expansion and new products at the company s facilities in Mexico, China and the Philippines), $4.6 million for purchases of short-term investments, $34.0 million for the acquisitions of Accel and Terra Power, a $2.0 million secured loan to and $10.0 million of additional investment in Shocking Technologies.
889331_13_ITEM7_P49_S1	Offsetting the cash used in investing activities was $3.7 million in proceeds from sales of property, plant and equipment and $17.8 million in proceeds from maturities of short-term investments.
889331_13_ITEM7_P50_S0	Net cash provided by financing activities in 2012 was approximately $0.8 million, which included $1.8 million in net payments from borrowing, $2.7 million in excess tax benefits on share-based compensation and $16.4 million in cash proceeds from the exercise of stock options.
889331_13_ITEM7_P50_S1	Additionally the company paid cash dividends of $16.6 million during the year.
889331_13_ITEM7_P50_S2	Information regarding the company s debt is provided in Note 7 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_13_ITEM7_P51_S0	The effect of exchange rate changes increased cash by $6.2 million in 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P51_S1	The net cash provided by operating activities less net cash used in financing and provided by investing activities plus the effect of exchange rate changes, resulted in a $71.4 million increase in cash and cash equivalents in 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P51_S2	This left the company with a cash balance of $235.4 million at December 29, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P52_S0	Days sales outstanding (DSO) in accounts receivable was 58 days at year-end 2012 compared to 57 days at year-end 2011 and 58 days at year-end 2010 (excluding the year-end Cole Hersee balance).
889331_13_ITEM7_P52_S1	inventory outstanding was 69 days at year-end 2012, compared to 73 days at year-end 2011 and 70 days at year-end 2010 (excluding the year-end Cole Hersee balance).
889331_13_ITEM7_P53_S0	The ratio of current assets to current liabilities was 2.9 to 1 at year-end 2012, compared to 2.5 to 1 at year-end 2011 and 2.9 to 1 at year-end 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P53_S1	The change in the current ratio at the end of 2012 compared to the prior year reflected increased current assets in 2012, primarily related to higher cash and cash equivalents balances.
889331_13_ITEM7_P53_S2	The carrying amounts of total debt decreased $1.0 million in 2012, compared to an increase of $11.0 million in 2011 and an increase of $10.8 million in 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P53_S3	The decrease in 2012 is due to lower net amounts borrowed under the revolving credit facility in 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P53_S4	The ratio of long-term debt to equity was 0.00 to 1 at year-end 2012 and 2011 and 0.09 to 1 at year-end 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P53_S5	Further information regarding the company s debt is provided in Note 7 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_13_ITEM7_P54_S0	The company started 2011 with $109.7 million of cash.
889331_13_ITEM7_P54_S1	Net cash provided by operating activities in 2011 was approximately $120.8 million and included $87.0 million in net income and $39.6 million in non-cash adjustments (primarily $32.3 million in depreciation and amortization), partially offset by $5.8 million of changes in operating assets and liabilities.
889331_13_ITEM7_P55_S0	Changes in operating assets and liabilities in 2011 (including short-term and long-term items) that negatively impacted cash flows in 2011 consisted of decreases in accounts payable ($5.3 million), accrued expenses including post-retirement ($0.4 million), accrued payroll and severance ($3.2 million) and accrued taxes ($6.1 million).
889331_13_ITEM7_P55_S1	The decrease in accounts payable resulted from decreased purchases related to low production levels at the end of 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P55_S2	The decrease in accrued payroll and severance resulted from lower severance accruals in 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P55_S3	Positively impacting cash flows were decreases in accounts receivable ($4.8 million), a decrease in inventory ($2.6 million) and a decrease in prepaid expenses and other current assets ($1.8 million).
889331_13_ITEM7_P56_S0	The company s capital expenditures were $22.5 million in 2012, $17.6 million in 2011 and $22.4 million in 2010.
889331_13_ITEM7_P56_S1	The company expects capital expenditures in 2013 to increase to between $25 and $30 million primarily related to building expansion in Mexico to support the company s growth initiatives.
889331_13_ITEM7_P56_S2	The company expects to fund 2013 capital expenditures from operating cash flows.
889331_13_ITEM7_P57_S0	The company s Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of up to 1,000,000 shares of the company s common stock under a program for the period May 1, 2012 to April 30, 2013.
889331_13_ITEM7_P57_S1	The company did not repurchase any shares of its common stock during 2012 under this program.
889331_13_ITEM7_P58_S0	The company withheld 27,417 shares of stock in lieu of withholding taxes on behalf of employees who became vested in restricted stock option grants during 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P59_S0	The following table summarizes contractual obligations and commitments as of December 29, 2012:
889331_13_ITEM7_P60_S0	As of December 29, 2012, the company did not have any off-balance sheet arrangements, as defined under SEC rules.
889331_13_ITEM7_P60_S1	Specifically, the company was not liable for guarantees of indebtedness owed by third parties; the company was not directly liable for the debt of any unconsolidated entity, and the company did not have any retained or contingent interest in assets; and the company does not participate in transactions that generate relationships with unconsolidated entities or financial partnerships, such as entities often referred to as structured finance or special purpose entities.
889331_13_ITEM7_P61_S0	In May 2011, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued authoritative guidance that provides a consistent definition of fair value and ensures that the fair value measurement and disclosure requirements are similar between U.S. GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards.
889331_13_ITEM7_P61_S1	The new guidance changes certain fair value measurement principles and enhances the disclosure requirements particularly for Level 3 fair value measurements.
889331_13_ITEM7_P61_S2	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P61_S3	There was no significant impact on its consolidated financial statements upon adoption.
889331_13_ITEM7_P62_S0	In June 2011, the FASB issued authoritative guidance that will require companies to present the components of net income and other comprehensive income either as one continuous statement or as two consecutive statements.
889331_13_ITEM7_P62_S1	It eliminates the option to present components of other comprehensive income as part of the statement of changes in equity.
889331_13_ITEM7_P62_S2	The guidance does not change the items which must be reported in other comprehensive income, how such items are measured or when they must be reclassified to net income.
889331_13_ITEM7_P62_S3	This guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P62_S4	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012, which resulted in a different presentation in its consolidated financial statements.
889331_13_ITEM7_P63_S0	In September 2011, the FASB issued authoritative guidance on testing goodwill for impairment.
889331_13_ITEM7_P63_S1	Under the revised guidance, entities testing goodwill for impairment have the option of performing a qualitative assessment before calculating the fair value of the reporting unit (i.e., step 1 of the goodwill impairment test).
889331_13_ITEM7_P63_S2	If entities determine, on the basis of qualitative factors, that the fair value of the reporting unit is more likely than not less than the carrying amount, the two-step impairment test would be required.
889331_13_ITEM7_P63_S3	The guidance does not change how goodwill is calculated or assigned to reporting units, nor does it revise the requirement to test goodwill annually for impairment.
889331_13_ITEM7_P63_S4	In addition, the guidance does not amend the requirement to test goodwill for impairment between annual tests if events or circumstances warrant; however, it does revise the examples of events and circumstances that an entity should consider.
889331_13_ITEM7_P63_S5	The amendments are effective for annual and interim goodwill impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
889331_13_ITEM7_P63_S6	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P63_S7	There was no significant impact on its consolidated financial statements upon adoption.
889331_13_ITEM7_P63_S8	Goodwill testing was completed in September 2012 using the previous methodology, as permitted.
889331_13_ITEM7_P64_S0	In July 2012, the FASB issued authoritative guidance on testing indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment.
889331_13_ITEM7_P64_S1	Under the revised guidance, entities testing indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment will have the option first to assess qualitative factors to determine whether the existence of events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that the indefinite-lived intangible asset is impaired.
889331_13_ITEM7_P64_S2	If, after assessing the totality of events and circumstances, an entity concludes that it is not more likely than not that the indefinite-lived intangible asset is not impaired, then the entity is not required to take further action.
889331_13_ITEM7_P64_S3	The amendment is effective for annual and interim indefinite-lived asset impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after September 15, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P64_S4	The company believes that adoption of the new guidance will have no effect on its consolidated financial statements.
889331_13_ITEM7_P65_S0	Certain of the accounting policies as discussed below require the application of significant judgment by management in selecting the appropriate estimates and assumptions for calculating amounts to record in the financial statements.
889331_13_ITEM7_P65_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates and assumptions, impacting the reported results of operations and financial position.
889331_13_ITEM7_P65_S2	Significant accounting policies are more fully described in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report.
889331_13_ITEM7_P65_S3	Certain accounting policies, however, are considered to be critical in that they are most important to the depiction of the company s financial condition and results of operations and their application requires management s subjective judgment in making estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain.
889331_13_ITEM7_P65_S4	The company believes the following accounting policies are the most critical to aid in fully understanding and evaluating its reported financial results, as they require management s most difficult, subjective or complex judgments, resulting from the need to make estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain.
889331_13_ITEM7_P65_S5	The company has reviewed these critical accounting policies and related disclosures with the Audit Committee of its Board of Directors.
889331_13_ITEM7_P66_S0	The company recognizes revenue on product sales in the period in which the sales process is complete.
889331_13_ITEM7_P66_S1	This generally occurs when products are shipped (FOB origin) to the customer in accordance with the terms of the sale, the risk of loss has been transferred, collectability is reasonably assured and the pricing is fixed and determinable.
889331_13_ITEM7_P66_S2	At the end of each period, for those shipments where title to the products and the risk of loss and rewards of ownership do not transfer until the product has been received by the customer, the company adjusts revenues and cost of sales for the delay between the time that the products are shipped and when they are received by the customer.
889331_13_ITEM7_P67_S0	The company s distribution channels are primarily through direct sales and independent third party distributors.
889331_13_ITEM7_P68_S0	The company accepts orders from customers based on long term purchasing contracts and written sales agreements.
889331_13_ITEM7_P68_S1	Contract pricing and selling agreement terms are based on market factors, costs and competition.
889331_13_ITEM7_P68_S2	Pricing normally is negotiated as an adjustment (premium or discount) from the company s published price lists.
889331_13_ITEM7_P68_S3	The customer is invoiced when the company s products are shipped to them in accordance with the terms of the sales agreement.
889331_13_ITEM7_P69_S0	the ability to receive price adjustments on products previously shipped and invoiced.
889331_13_ITEM7_P69_S1	This practice is common in the industry and is referred to as a ship and debit program.
889331_13_ITEM7_P69_S2	This program allows the distributor to debit the company for the difference between the distributors contracted price and a lower price for specific transactions.
889331_13_ITEM7_P70_S0	Under certain circumstances (usually in a competitive situation or large volume opportunity), a distributor will request authorization to reduce its price to its buyer.
889331_13_ITEM7_P70_S1	If the company approves such a reduction, the distributor is authorized to debit its account for the difference between the contracted price and the lower approved price.
889331_13_ITEM7_P70_S2	The company establishes reserves for this program based on historic activity and actual authorizations for the debit and recognizes these debits as a reduction of revenue.
889331_13_ITEM7_P71_S0	The company has a return to stock policy whereby a customer with previous authorization from Littelfuse management can return previously purchased goods for full or partial credit.
889331_13_ITEM7_P71_S1	The company establishes an estimated allowance for these returns based on historic activity.
889331_13_ITEM7_P71_S2	Sales revenue and cost of sales are reduced to anticipate estimated returns.
889331_13_ITEM7_P72_S0	The company properly meets all of the criteria for recognizing revenue when the right of return exists.
889331_13_ITEM7_P72_S1	Specifically, the company meets those requirements because:
889331_13_ITEM7_P73_S0	The company s selling price is fixed or determinable at the date of the sale.
889331_13_ITEM7_P74_S0	The company has policies and procedures to accept only credit worthy customers with the ability to pay the company.
889331_13_ITEM7_P75_S0	The company s customers are obligated to pay the company under the contract and the obligation is not contingent on the resale of the product.
889331_13_ITEM7_P76_S0	The risk ownership transfers to the company s customers upon shipment and is not changed in the event of theft, physical destruction or damage of the product.
889331_13_ITEM7_P77_S0	The company bills at the ship date and establishes a reserve to reduce revenue from the in-transit time until the product is delivered for FOB destination sales.
889331_13_ITEM7_P78_S0	The company s customers acquiring the product for resale have economic substance apart from that provided by Littelfuse.
889331_13_ITEM7_P78_S1	All distributors are independent of the company.
889331_13_ITEM7_P79_S0	The company does not have any obligations for future performance to bring about resale of the product by its customers.
889331_13_ITEM7_P80_S0	The company can reasonably estimate the amount of future returns.
889331_13_ITEM7_P81_S0	Volume Rebates: The company offers incentives to certain customers to achieve specific quarterly or annual sales targets.
889331_13_ITEM7_P81_S1	If customers achieve their sales targets, they are entitled to rebates.
889331_13_ITEM7_P81_S2	The company estimates the future cost of these rebates and recognizes this estimated cost as a reduction to revenue as products are sold.
889331_13_ITEM7_P82_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts: The company evaluates the collectability of its trade receivables based on a combination of factors.
889331_13_ITEM7_P82_S1	The company regularly analyzes its significant customer accounts and, when the company becomes aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the company records a specific reserve for bad debt to reduce the related receivable to the amount the company reasonably believes is collectible.
889331_13_ITEM7_P82_S2	The company also records allowances for all other customers based on a variety of factors including the length of time the receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, macroeconomic considerations and past experience.
889331_13_ITEM7_P83_S0	Historically, the allowance for doubtful accounts has been adequate to cover bad debts.
889331_13_ITEM7_P83_S1	If circumstances related to specific customers change, the estimates of the recoverability of receivables could be further adjusted.
889331_13_ITEM7_P84_S0	The company performs regular detailed assessments of inventory, which include a review of, among other factors, demand requirements, product life cycle and development plans, component cost trends, product pricing, shelf life and quality issues.
889331_13_ITEM7_P84_S1	Based on the analysis, the company records adjustments to inventory for excess quantities, obsolescence or impairment when appropriate to reflect inventory at net realizable value.
889331_13_ITEM7_P85_S0	Historically, inventory reserves have been adequate to reflect inventory at net realizable values.
889331_13_ITEM7_P85_S1	During 2012, 2011 and 2010, the company was required to step up the value of inventory acquired in business combinations to its selling prices less the cost to sell under business combination accounting.
889331_13_ITEM7_P85_S2	This was approximately $0.6 million in 2012 for Accel and Selco, $0.4 million in 2011 for Selco and $3.7 million in 2010 for Cole Hersee.
889331_13_ITEM7_P86_S0	The company annually tests goodwill for impairment on the first day of its fiscal fourth quarter or at an interim date if there is an event or change in circumstances that indicates the asset may be impaired.
889331_13_ITEM7_P86_S1	The company has seven reporting units for goodwill testing purposes.
889331_13_ITEM7_P86_S2	Management determines the fair value of each of its reporting units by using a discounted cash flow model (which includes forecasted five-year income statement and working capital projections, a market-based weighted average cost of capital and terminal values after five years) to estimate market value.
889331_13_ITEM7_P86_S3	In addition, the company compares its derived enterprise value on a consolidated basis to the company s market capitalization as of its test date to ensure its derived value approximates the market value of the company when taken as a whole.
889331_13_ITEM7_P87_S0	As of the most recent annual test conducted on September 30, 2012, the company concluded the fair value of each of the reporting units exceeded its carrying value of invested capital and therefore, no potential goodwill impairment existed.
889331_13_ITEM7_P87_S1	Specifically, the company noted that its headroom, defined as the excess of fair value over the carrying value of invested capital, was 66%, 113%, 59%, 99%, 96%, 247% and 119% for its electronics (non-silicon), electronics (silicon), automotive (excluding Cole Hersee), Cole Hersee, relay, custom products and fuse reporting units, respectively, at September 30, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P87_S2	Certain key assumptions used in the annual test included a discount rate of 12.7% for all reporting units.
889331_13_ITEM7_P87_S3	A long-term growth rate of 3.0% was used for all seven reporting units.
889331_13_ITEM7_P88_S0	In addition, the company performed a sensitivity test at September 30, 2012 that showed either a 100 basis point increase in its discount rate or a 100 basis point decrease in the long-term growth rate for each reporting unit would not have changed the company s conclusion that no potential goodwill impairment existed at September 30, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM7_P89_S0	The company will continue to perform a goodwill impairment test as required on an annual basis and on an interim basis, if certain conditions exist.
889331_13_ITEM7_P89_S1	Factors the company considers important, which could result in changes to its estimates, include underperformance relative to historical or projected future operating results and declines in acquisitions and trading multiples.
889331_13_ITEM7_P89_S2	Due to the diverse end user base and non-discretionary product demand, the company does not believe its future operating results will vary significantly relative to its historical and projected future operating results.
889331_13_ITEM7_P90_S0	The company evaluates long-lived asset groups on an ongoing basis.
889331_13_ITEM7_P90_S1	Long-lived asset groups are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the related asset may not be recoverable.
889331_13_ITEM7_P91_S0	Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of the asset to future undiscounted cash flows expected to be generated by the asset group.
889331_13_ITEM7_P91_S1	If it is determined to be impaired, the impairment recognized is measured by the amount by which the carrying value of the asset exceeds its fair value.
889331_13_ITEM7_P91_S2	The company s estimates of future cash flows from such assets could be impacted if it underperforms relative to historical or projected future operating results.
889331_13_ITEM7_P91_S3	The company recorded asset impairment charges of $0.5 million, $2.3 million and $3.0 million for the fiscal years ended 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
889331_13_ITEM7_P91_S4	Further information regarding asset impairments is provided in Note 12 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_13_ITEM7_P92_S0	The company evaluates its investments quarterly or when there is an indicator of a potential impairment.
889331_13_ITEM7_P92_S1	During the fourth quarter of 2012, company management determined that an indicator of impairment existed for the company s investment in Shocking Technologies, Inc.
889331_13_ITEM7_P92_S2	Subsequently, the company engaged a third party asset valuation firm to perform an analysis for purposes of assisting management in determining the amount of impairment.
889331_13_ITEM7_P92_S3	Further information regarding the impairment of the company s investment in Shocking Technologies, Inc. is provided in Note 6 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_13_ITEM7_P93_S0	Environmental liabilities are accrued based on estimates of the probability of potential future environmental exposure.
889331_13_ITEM7_P93_S1	Expenses related to on-going maintenance of environmental sites are expensed as incurred.
889331_13_ITEM7_P93_S2	If actual or estimated probable future losses exceed the company s recorded liability for such claims, it would record additional charges as other expense during the period in which the actual loss or change in estimate occurred.
889331_13_ITEM7_P94_S0	The company evaluates its reserve for coal mine remediation annually utilizing a third party expert.
889331_13_ITEM7_P95_S0	Littelfuse has a number of company-sponsored defined benefit plans primarily in North America, Europe and the Asia-Pacific region.
889331_13_ITEM7_P95_S1	The company recognizes the full unfunded status of these plans on the balance sheet.
889331_13_ITEM7_P95_S2	Actuarial gains and losses and prior service costs and credits are recognized as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income.
889331_13_ITEM7_P96_S0	Accounting for pensions requires estimating the future benefit cost and recognizing the cost over the employee s expected period of employment with the company.
889331_13_ITEM7_P96_S1	Certain assumptions are required in the calculation of pension costs and obligations.
889331_13_ITEM7_P96_S2	These assumptions include the discount rate, salary scales and the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
889331_13_ITEM7_P97_S0	The discount rate is intended to represent the rate at which pension benefit obligations could be settled by purchase of an annuity contract.
889331_13_ITEM7_P97_S1	These assumptions are subject to change based on stock and bond market returns and other economic factors.
889331_13_ITEM7_P97_S2	Actual results that differ from the company s assumptions are accumulated and amortized over future periods and, therefore, generally affect its recognized expense and accrued liability in such future periods.
889331_13_ITEM7_P97_S3	While the company believes that its assumptions are appropriate given current economic conditions and its actual experience, significant differences in results or significant changes in the company s assumptions may materially affect its pension obligations and related future expense.
889331_13_ITEM7_P97_S4	Further information regarding these plans is provided in Note 13 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_13_ITEM7_P98_S0	Stock-based compensation expense is recorded for stock-option grants and restricted share units based upon the fair values of the awards.
889331_13_ITEM7_P99_S0	The fair value of stock option awards is estimated at the grant date using the Black-Scholes option pricing model, which includes assumptions for volatility, expected term, risk-free interest rate and dividend yield.
889331_13_ITEM7_P99_S1	Expected volatility is based on implied volatilities from traded options on Littelfuse stock, historical volatility of Littelfuse stock and other factors.
889331_13_ITEM7_P99_S2	Historical data is used to estimate employee termination experience and the expected term of the options.
889331_13_ITEM7_P100_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect at the time of grant.
889331_13_ITEM7_P100_S1	The company initiated a quarterly cash dividend in 2010 and expects to continue making cash dividend payments in the foreseeable future.
889331_13_ITEM7_P101_S0	Total stock-based compensation expense was $7.3 million, $5.8 million and $5.2 million in 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
889331_13_ITEM7_P101_S1	Further information regarding this expense is provided in Note 14 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_13_ITEM7_P102_S0	The company accounts for income taxes using the liability method.
889331_13_ITEM7_P103_S0	Deferred taxes are recognized for the future effects of temporary differences between financial and income tax reporting using tax rates in effect for the years in which the differences are expected to reverse.
889331_13_ITEM7_P103_S1	The company recognizes deferred taxes for temporary differences, operating loss carryforwards and tax credit carryforwards.
889331_13_ITEM7_P103_S2	Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if it is more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
889331_13_ITEM7_P104_S0	Federal and state income taxes are provided on the portion of foreign income that is expected to be remitted to the U.S. and be taxable.
889331_13_ITEM7_P105_S0	The company recognizes the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical merits of the position.
889331_13_ITEM7_P105_S1	The tax benefits recognized in the financial statements from such a position are measured based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized upon ultimate settlement.
889331_13_ITEM7_P106_S0	Further information regarding income taxes, including a detailed reconciliation of current year activity, is provided in Note 15 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_13_ITEM7_P107_S0	The company s 2012 revenue, excluding acquisitions ($16.6 million) and unfavorable currency effects ($9.4 million), was essentially flat compared to 2011 ($660.7 million in 2012 versus $665.0 million in 2011).
889331_13_ITEM7_P108_S0	The outlook for 2013 is guarded due to global economic uncertainty.
889331_13_ITEM7_P108_S1	The electronics book-to-bill ratio is beginning to improve.
889331_13_ITEM7_P108_S2	Automotive passenger vehicle sales continue to be strong in Asia, solid in the U.S. and weak in Europe.
889331_13_ITEM7_P108_S3	The commercial vehicle market remains weak but has shown some early signs of improvement.
889331_13_ITEM7_P108_S4	Electrical continues to show solid performance in the powerfuse business.
889331_13_ITEM7_P109_S0	There is a world-wide slowdown in Potash mining which may impact the company s relay/custom business.
889331_13_ITEM7_P109_S1	Revenues for 2013 are expected to be in the range of $680.0 to $720.0 million.
889331_13_ITEM7_P109_S2	Capital expenditures are expected to be in the range of $25.0 to $30.0 million.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The company is exposed to market risk from changes in interest rates, foreign exchange rates and commodity prices.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The company had $84.0 million in debt outstanding at December 29, 2012 related to the unsecured revolving credit facility, which is described in Item 7 under Liquidity and Capital Resources .
889331_13_ITEM7A_P1_S1	While this debt has a variable interest rate of LIBOR plus 1.25%, the company s interest expense is not materially sensitive to changes in interest rate levels since debt levels and potential interest expense increases are insignificant relative to earnings.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The majority of the company s operations consist of manufacturing and sales activities in foreign countries.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The company has manufacturing facilities in the U.S., Mexico, Canada, Denmark, China, Lithuania, Taiwan and the Philippines.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P2_S2	During 2012, sales to customers outside the U.S. were approximately 67% of total net sales.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Substantially all sales in Europe are denominated in euros and substantially all sales in the Asia-Pacific region are denominated in U.S. dollars, Japanese yen, Korean won, Chinese yuan and Taiwanese dollars.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P3_S0	The company s foreign exchange exposures result primarily from sale of products in foreign currencies, foreign currency denominated purchases, employee-related and other costs of running operations in foreign countries and translation of balance sheet accounts denominated in foreign currencies.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P3_S1	The company s most significant long exposure is to the euro, with lesser long exposures to the Canadian dollar, Japanese yen and Korean won.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P3_S2	The company s most significant short exposures are to the Mexican peso, Philippine peso and Chinese renminbi.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P4_S0	Changes in foreign exchange rates could affect the company s sales, costs, balance sheet values and earnings.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P4_S1	The company uses netting and offsetting intercompany account management techniques to reduce known foreign currency exposures where possible and also, from time to time, utilizes derivative instruments to hedge certain foreign currency exposures deemed to be material.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The company uses various metals in the manufacturing of its products, including copper, zinc, tin, gold and silver.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P5_S1	Prices of these commodities can and do fluctuate significantly, which can impact the company s earnings.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P5_S2	The most significant of these exposures is to copper, zinc, gold and silver, where at current prices and volumes, a 10% price change would affect annual pre-tax profit by approximately $1.9 million for copper, $0.7 million for zinc, $0.6 million for gold and $1.0 million for silver.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P6_S0	The cost of oil fluctuated dramatically over the past several years.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P6_S1	Consequently, there is a risk that a return to high prices for oil and electricity in 2013 could have a significant impact on the company s transportation and utility expenses.
889331_13_ITEM7A_P7_S0	While the company is exposed to significant changes in certain commodity prices and foreign currency exchange rates, the company actively monitors these exposures and takes various actions to mitigate any negative impacts of these exposures.
889331_13_ITEM8_P0_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders of Littelfuse, Inc.
889331_13_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Littelfuse, Inc. as of December 29, 2012 and December 31, 2011, and the related consolidated statements of net income and comprehensive income, shareholders equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 29, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM8_P1_S1	Our audits also included the financial statement schedule listed in the Index at Item 15(a).
889331_13_ITEM8_P1_S2	These financial statements and schedule are the responsibility of the company's management.
889331_13_ITEM8_P1_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements and schedule based on our audits.
889331_13_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
889331_13_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
889331_13_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
889331_13_ITEM8_P3_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
889331_13_ITEM8_P3_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
889331_13_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of Littelfuse, Inc., and subsidiaries at December 29, 2012 and December 31, 2011, and the consolidated results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 29, 2012, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
889331_13_ITEM8_P4_S1	Also, in our opinion, the related financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic financial statements taken as a whole, presents fairly in all material respects the information set forth therein.
889331_13_ITEM8_P5_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Littelfuse, Inc.'s internal control over financial reporting as of December 29, 2012, based on criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission and our report dated February 27, 2013 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
889331_13_ITEM8_P6_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders of Littelfuse, Inc.
889331_13_ITEM8_P7_S0	We have audited Littelfuse, Inc.'s internal control over financial reporting as of December 29, 2012 , based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (the COSO criteria).
889331_13_ITEM8_P7_S1	Littelfuse, Inc. management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting.
889331_13_ITEM8_P7_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
889331_13_ITEM8_P8_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
889331_13_ITEM8_P8_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
889331_13_ITEM8_P8_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
889331_13_ITEM8_P8_S3	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
889331_13_ITEM8_P9_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
889331_13_ITEM8_P9_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
889331_13_ITEM8_P10_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
889331_13_ITEM8_P10_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
889331_13_ITEM8_P11_S0	In our opinion, Littelfuse, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 29, 2012, based on the COSO criteria.
889331_13_ITEM8_P12_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Littelfuse, Inc., as of December 29, 2012 and December 31, 2011, and the related consolidated statements of net income and comprehensive income, shareholders equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 29, 2012 of Littelfuse, Inc., and our report dated February 27, 2013 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
889331_13_ITEM8_P13_S0	See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_13_ITEM8_P14_S0	See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_13_ITEM8_P15_S0	See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_13_ITEM8_P16_S0	*Including related tax impact (see Note 15).
889331_13_ITEM8_P17_S0	See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_13_ITEM8_P18_S0	Nature of Operations : Littelfuse, Inc. and subsidiaries (the company ) design, manufacture, and sell circuit protection devices for use in the automotive, electronic and electrical markets throughout the world.
889331_13_ITEM8_P19_S0	Fiscal Year : The company s fiscal years ended on December 29, 2012, December 31, 2011 and January 1, 2011 and contained 52 weeks each.
889331_13_ITEM8_P20_S0	Basis of Presentation : The Consolidated Financial Statements include the accounts of Littelfuse, Inc. and its subsidiaries.
889331_13_ITEM8_P20_S1	All significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
889331_13_ITEM8_P21_S0	The company s Consolidated Financial Statements were prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America and include the assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses of all wholly-owned subsidiaries and majority-owned subsidiaries over which the company exercises control.
889331_13_ITEM8_P22_S0	Use of Estimates : The process of preparing financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the Consolidated Financial Statements, and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses and the accompanying notes.
889331_13_ITEM8_P22_S1	The company evaluates and updates its assumptions and estimates on an ongoing basis and may employ outside experts to assist in its evaluation, as considered necessary.
889331_13_ITEM8_P22_S2	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
889331_13_ITEM8_P23_S0	Cash Equivalents : All highly liquid investments, with an original maturity of three months or less when purchased, are considered to be cash equivalents.
889331_13_ITEM8_P24_S0	Short-Term and Long-Term Investments : The company has determined that certain of its investment securities are to be classified as available-for-sale.
889331_13_ITEM8_P24_S1	Available-for-sale securities are carried at fair value with the unrealized gains and losses reported as a component of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income (Loss).
889331_13_ITEM8_P25_S0	Realized gains and losses and declines in unrealized value judged to be other-than-temporary on available-for-sale securities are included in other expense (income), net.
889331_13_ITEM8_P26_S0	The cost of securities sold is based on the specific identification method.
889331_13_ITEM8_P26_S1	Interest and dividends on securities classified as available-for-sale are included in interest income.
889331_13_ITEM8_P27_S0	Fair Value of Financial Instruments : The company s financial instruments include cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, investments and long-term debt.
889331_13_ITEM8_P27_S1	The carrying values of such financial instruments approximate their estimated fair values.
889331_13_ITEM8_P28_S0	Accounts Receivable : The company performs credit evaluations of customers financial condition and generally does not require collateral.
889331_13_ITEM8_P29_S0	Credit losses are provided for in the financial statements based upon specific knowledge of a customer s inability to meet its financial obligations to the company.
889331_13_ITEM8_P30_S0	Historically, credit losses have consistently been within management s expectations and have not been a material amount.
889331_13_ITEM8_P30_S1	A receivable is considered past due if payments have not been received within agreed upon invoice terms.
889331_13_ITEM8_P30_S2	Write-offs are recorded at the time a customer receivable is deemed uncollectible.
889331_13_ITEM8_P31_S0	The company also maintains allowances against accounts receivable for the settlement of rebates and sales discounts to customers.
889331_13_ITEM8_P31_S1	These allowances are based upon specific customer sales and sales discounts as well as actual historical experience.
889331_13_ITEM8_P32_S0	Inventories : Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market (first in, first out method), which approximates current replacement cost.
889331_13_ITEM8_P33_S0	The company maintains excess and obsolete allowances against inventory to reduce the carrying value to the expected net realizable value.
889331_13_ITEM8_P33_S1	These allowances are based upon a combination of factors including historical sales volume, market conditions, lower of cost or market analysis and expected realizable value of the inventory.
889331_13_ITEM8_P34_S0	Cost and Equity Method Investments/Investment in unconsolidated affiliate: Investments in unconsolidated affiliates over which the company has significant influence over the investees operating and financing activities are accounted for under the equity method of accounting.
889331_13_ITEM8_P34_S1	Investments in affiliates over which the company does not have the ability to exert significant influence over the investees operating and financing activities are accounted for under the cost method.
889331_13_ITEM8_P35_S0	Property, Plant and Equipment : Land, buildings and equipment are carried at cost.
889331_13_ITEM8_P35_S1	Depreciation is calculated using the straight-line method with useful lives of 21 years for buildings, seven to nine years for equipment, seven years for furniture and fixtures, five years for tooling and three years for computer equipment.
889331_13_ITEM8_P36_S0	Goodwill and Indefinite-Lived Intangible Assets: The company annually tests goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment on the first day of its fiscal fourth quarter or at other dates if there is an event or change in circumstances that indicates the asset may be impaired.
889331_13_ITEM8_P36_S1	The company has seven reporting units for testing purposes.
889331_13_ITEM8_P36_S2	Management determines the fair value of each of its reporting units by using a discounted cash flow model (which includes forecasted five-year income statement and working capital projections, a market-based weighted average cost of capital and terminal values after five years) to estimate market value.
889331_13_ITEM8_P36_S3	In addition, the company compares its derived enterprise value on a consolidated basis to the company s market capitalization as of its test date to ensure its derived value approximates the market value of the company when taken as a whole.
889331_13_ITEM8_P37_S0	As of the most recent annual test conducted on September 30, 2012, the company concluded the fair value of each of the reporting units exceeded its carrying value of invested capital and therefore, no potential goodwill impairment existed.
889331_13_ITEM8_P37_S1	Specifically, the company noted that its headroom, defined as the excess of fair value over the carrying value of invested capital, was 66%, 113%, 59%, 99%, 96%, 247% and 119% for its electronics (non-silicon), electronics (silicon), automotive (excluding Cole Hersee), Cole Hersee, relay, custom products and fuse reporting units, respectively, at September 30, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM8_P37_S2	Certain key assumptions used in the annual test included a discount rate of 12.7% for all reporting units.
889331_13_ITEM8_P37_S3	A long-term growth rate of 3.0% was used for all seven reporting units.
889331_13_ITEM8_P38_S0	In addition, the company performed a sensitivity test at September 30, 2012 that showed a 100 basis point increase in its discount rate or a 100 basis point decrease in the long-term growth rate for each reporting unit would not have changed the company s conclusion that no potential goodwill impairment existed at September 30, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM8_P39_S0	The company will continue to perform a goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible asset impairment test as required on an annual basis and on an interim basis, if certain conditions exist.
889331_13_ITEM8_P39_S1	Factors the company considers important, which could result in changes to its estimates, include underperformance relative to historical or projected future operating results and declines in acquisitions and trading multiples.
889331_13_ITEM8_P39_S2	Due to the diverse end user base and non-discretionary product demand, the company does not believe its future operating results will vary significantly relative to its historical and projected future operating results.
889331_13_ITEM8_P40_S0	Other Intangible Assets : Trademarks and tradenames are amortized using the straight-line method over estimated useful lives that have a range of five to 20 years.
889331_13_ITEM8_P40_S1	Patents, licenses and software are amortized using the straight-line method or an accelerated method over estimated useful lives that have a range of seven to 12 years.
889331_13_ITEM8_P40_S2	The distribution networks are amortized on either a straight-line or accelerated basis over estimated useful lives that have a range of three to 20 years.
889331_13_ITEM8_P40_S3	Other intangible assets are also tested for impairment when there is a significant event that may cause the asset to be impaired.
889331_13_ITEM8_P41_S0	Environmental Liabilities : Environmental liabilities are accrued based on engineering studies estimating the cost of remediating sites.
889331_13_ITEM8_P41_S1	Expenses related to on-going maintenance of environmental sites are expensed as incurred.
889331_13_ITEM8_P41_S2	If actual or estimated probable future losses exceed the company s recorded liability for such claims, the company would record additional charges during the period in which the actual loss or change in estimate occurred.
889331_13_ITEM8_P42_S0	Pension and Other Post-retirement Benefits : Accounting for pensions requires estimating the future benefit cost and recognizing the cost over the employee s expected period of employment with the company.
889331_13_ITEM8_P42_S1	Certain assumptions are required in the calculation of pension costs and obligations.
889331_13_ITEM8_P42_S2	These assumptions include the discount rate, salary scales and the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
889331_13_ITEM8_P43_S0	The discount rate is intended to represent the rate at which pension benefit obligations could be settled by purchase of an annuity contract.
889331_13_ITEM8_P43_S1	These assumptions are subject to change based on stock and bond market returns and other economic factors.
889331_13_ITEM8_P43_S2	Actual results that differ from the company s assumptions are accumulated and amortized over future periods and therefore generally affect its recognized expense and accrued liability in such future periods.
889331_13_ITEM8_P43_S3	While the company believes that its assumptions are appropriate given current economic conditions and its actual experience, significant differences in results or significant changes in the company s assumptions may materially affect its pension obligations and related future expense.
889331_13_ITEM8_P44_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2012, the company amended the Littelfuse Inc., Retirement Plan to allow participants who met certain requirements to elect to receive their vested retirement benefits in a lump sum on (or for certain participants annuity payments, on and after) December 1, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM8_P44_S1	This amendment resulted in a settlement charge of $5.1 million in 2012.
889331_13_ITEM8_P44_S2	See Note 13 for additional information.
889331_13_ITEM8_P45_S0	Reclassifications: Certain items in the 2011 and 2010 financial statements have been reclassified to conform to the 2012 presentations specifically, the 2011 presentation of the Investment in unconsolidated affiliate of $6.0 million has been separately presented.
889331_13_ITEM8_P45_S1	It was previously included as part of Other investments.
889331_13_ITEM8_P45_S2	These reclassifications had no impact on net income or shareholders equity for any period.
889331_13_ITEM8_P46_S0	The company recognizes revenue on product sales in the period in which the sales process is complete.
889331_13_ITEM8_P46_S1	This generally occurs when products are shipped (FOB origin) to the customer in accordance with the terms of the sale, the risk of loss has been transferred, collectability is reasonably assured and the pricing is fixed and determinable.
889331_13_ITEM8_P46_S2	At the end of each period, for those shipments where title to the products and the risk of loss and rewards of ownership do not transfer until the product has been received by the customer, the company adjusts revenues and cost of sales for the delay between the time that the products are shipped and when they are received by the customer.
889331_13_ITEM8_P47_S0	The company s distribution channels are primarily through direct sales and independent third party distributors.
889331_13_ITEM8_P48_S0	The company accepts orders from customers based on long term purchasing contracts and written sales agreements.
889331_13_ITEM8_P48_S1	Contract pricing and selling agreement terms are based on market factors, costs, and competition.
889331_13_ITEM8_P48_S2	Pricing normally is negotiated as an adjustment (premium or discount) from the company s published price lists.
889331_13_ITEM8_P48_S3	The customer is invoiced when the company s products are shipped to them in accordance with the terms of the sales agreement.
889331_13_ITEM8_P49_S0	the ability to receive price adjustments on products previously shipped and invoiced.
889331_13_ITEM8_P49_S1	This practice is common in the industry and is referred to as a ship and debit program.
889331_13_ITEM8_P49_S2	This program allows the distributor to debit the company for the difference between the distributors contracted price and a lower price for specific transactions.
889331_13_ITEM8_P50_S0	Under certain circumstances (usually in a competitive situation or large volume opportunity), a distributor will request authorization to reduce its price to its buyer.
889331_13_ITEM8_P50_S1	If the company approves such a reduction, the distributor is authorized to debit its account for the difference between the contracted price and the lower approved price.
889331_13_ITEM8_P50_S2	The company establishes reserves for this program based on historic activity and actual authorizations for the debit and recognizes these debits as a reduction of revenue.
889331_13_ITEM8_P51_S0	The company has a return to stock policy whereby a customer with prior authorization from Littelfuse management can return previously purchased goods for full or partial credit.
889331_13_ITEM8_P51_S1	The company establishes an estimated allowance for these returns based on historic activity.
889331_13_ITEM8_P51_S2	Sales revenue and cost of sales are reduced to anticipate estimated returns.
889331_13_ITEM8_P52_S0	The company properly meets all of the criteria for recognizing revenue when the right of return exists.
889331_13_ITEM8_P52_S1	Specifically, the company meets those requirements because:
889331_13_ITEM8_P53_S0	The company s selling price is fixed or determinable at the date of the sale.
889331_13_ITEM8_P54_S0	The company has policies and procedures to accept only credit worthy customers with the ability to pay the company.
889331_13_ITEM8_P55_S0	The company s customers are obligated to pay the company under the contract and the obligation is not contingent on the resale of the product.
889331_13_ITEM8_P56_S0	The risk ownership transfers to the company s customers upon shipment and is not changed in the event of theft, physical destruction or damage of the product.
889331_13_ITEM8_P57_S0	The company bills at the ship date and establishes a reserve to reduce revenue from the in transit time until the product is delivered for FOB destination sales.
889331_13_ITEM8_P58_S0	The company s customers acquiring the product for resale have economic substance apart from that provided by Littelfuse, and all distributors are independent of the company.
889331_13_ITEM8_P59_S0	The company does not have any obligations for future performance to bring about resale of the product by its customers.
889331_13_ITEM8_P60_S0	The company can reasonably estimate the amount of future returns.
889331_13_ITEM8_P61_S0	Volume Rebates: The company offers incentives to certain customers to achieve specific quarterly or annual sales targets.
889331_13_ITEM8_P61_S1	If customers achieve their sales targets, they are entitled to rebates.
889331_13_ITEM8_P61_S2	The company estimates the future cost of these rebates and recognizes this estimated cost as a reduction to revenue as products are sold.
889331_13_ITEM8_P62_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts: The company evaluates the collectability of its trade receivables based on a combination of factors.
889331_13_ITEM8_P62_S1	The company regularly analyzes its significant customer accounts and, when the company becomes aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the company records a specific reserve for bad debt to reduce the related receivable to the amount the company reasonably believes is collectible.
889331_13_ITEM8_P62_S2	The company also records allowances for all other customers based on a variety of factors including the length of time the receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, macroeconomic considerations and past experience.
889331_13_ITEM8_P62_S3	Accounts receivable balances that are deemed to be uncollectible, are written off against the reserve on a case-by-case basis.
889331_13_ITEM8_P63_S0	Historically, the allowance for doubtful accounts has been adequate to cover bad debts.
889331_13_ITEM8_P63_S1	If circumstances related to specific customers change, the estimates of the recoverability of receivables could be further adjusted.
889331_13_ITEM8_P63_S2	However, due to the company s diverse customer base and lack of credit concentration, the company does not believe its estimates would be materially impacted by changes in its assumptions.
889331_13_ITEM8_P64_S0	Advertising Costs : The company expenses advertising costs as incurred, which amounted to $1.7 million in 2012, $1.9 million in 2011 and $1.2 million in 2010, and are included as a component of selling, general and administrative expenses.
889331_13_ITEM8_P65_S0	Shipping and Handling Fees and Costs : Amounts billed to customers related to shipping and handling are classified as revenue.
889331_13_ITEM8_P65_S1	Costs incurred for shipping and handling of $6.2 million, $5.9 million and $10.9 million in 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively, are classified in selling, general and administrative expenses.
889331_13_ITEM8_P66_S0	Restructuring Costs : The company incurred severance charges and plant closure expenses as part of the company s on-going cost reduction efforts.
889331_13_ITEM8_P66_S1	These charges are included in cost of sales, selling, general and administrative expenses, or research and development expenses depending on the personnel being included in the charge.
889331_13_ITEM8_P66_S2	See Note 10 for additional information on restructuring costs.
889331_13_ITEM8_P67_S0	Foreign Currency Translation : The company s foreign subsidiaries use the local currency or the U.S. dollar as their functional currency, as appropriate.
889331_13_ITEM8_P67_S1	Assets and liabilities are translated using exchange rates at the balance sheet date, and revenues and expenses are translated at weighted average rates.
889331_13_ITEM8_P67_S2	The amount of foreign currency conversion recognized in the income statement related to currency translation were losses of $8.5 million, $0.9 million and $3.3 million in 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively, and is included as a component of other expense (income), net.
889331_13_ITEM8_P67_S3	Adjustments from the translation process are recognized in Shareholders equity as a component of Accumulated other comprehensive income.
889331_13_ITEM8_P68_S0	Stock-based Compensation : The company recognizes compensation expense for the cost of awards of equity compensation using a fair value method.
889331_13_ITEM8_P68_S1	Benefits of tax deductions in excess of recognized compensation expense are reported as both operating and financing cash flows.
889331_13_ITEM8_P68_S2	See Note 14 for additional information on stock-based compensation.
889331_13_ITEM8_P69_S0	Other Expense (Income), Net: Other expense (income), net consisting of interest income, royalties, non-operating income and foreign currency items, was $2.2 million of income in 2012 compared to $2.9 million of income in 2011 and $1.5 million of income in 2010.
889331_13_ITEM8_P70_S0	Income Taxes: The company accounts for income taxes using the liability method.
889331_13_ITEM8_P70_S1	Deferred taxes are recognized for the future effects of temporary differences between financial and income tax reporting using enacted tax rates in effect for the years in which the differences are expected to reverse.
889331_13_ITEM8_P70_S2	The company recognizes deferred taxes for temporary differences, operating loss carryforwards and tax credit carryforwards.
889331_13_ITEM8_P70_S3	Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if it is more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
889331_13_ITEM8_P71_S0	Federal and state income taxes are provided on the portion of foreign income that is expected to be remitted to the U.S. and be taxable.
889331_13_ITEM8_P72_S0	Accounting Pronouncements : In May 2011, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued authoritative guidance that provides a consistent definition of fair value and ensures that the fair value measurement and disclosure requirements are similar between U.S. GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards.
889331_13_ITEM8_P72_S1	The new guidance changes certain fair value measurement principles and enhances the disclosure requirements particularly for Level 3 fair value measurements.
889331_13_ITEM8_P72_S2	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM8_P72_S3	There was no significant impact on its consolidated financial statements upon adoption.
889331_13_ITEM8_P73_S0	In June 2011, the FASB issued authoritative guidance that will require companies to present the components of net income and other comprehensive income either as one continuous statement or as two consecutive statements.
889331_13_ITEM8_P73_S1	It eliminates the option to present components of other comprehensive income as part of the statement of changes in equity.
889331_13_ITEM8_P73_S2	The guidance does not change the items which must be reported in other comprehensive income, how such items are measured or when they must be reclassified to net income.
889331_13_ITEM8_P73_S3	This guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2011.
889331_13_ITEM8_P73_S4	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012, which resulted in a different presentation in its consolidated financial statements.
889331_13_ITEM8_P74_S0	In September 2011, the FASB issued authoritative guidance on testing goodwill for impairment.
889331_13_ITEM8_P74_S1	Under the revised guidance, entities testing goodwill for impairment have the option of performing a qualitative assessment before calculating the fair value of the reporting unit (i.e., step 1 of the goodwill impairment test).
889331_13_ITEM8_P74_S2	If entities determine, on the basis of qualitative factors, that the fair value of the reporting unit is more likely than not less than the carrying amount, the two-step impairment test would be required.
889331_13_ITEM8_P74_S3	The guidance does not change how goodwill is calculated or assigned to reporting units, nor does it revise the requirement to test goodwill annually for impairment.
889331_13_ITEM8_P74_S4	In addition, the guidance does not amend the requirement to test goodwill for impairment between annual tests if events or circumstances warrant; however, it does revise the examples of events and circumstances that an entity should consider.
889331_13_ITEM8_P74_S5	The amendments are effective for annual and interim goodwill impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
889331_13_ITEM8_P74_S6	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM8_P74_S7	There was no significant impact on its consolidated financial statements upon adoption.
889331_13_ITEM8_P74_S8	Goodwill testing was completed as of September 30, 2012 using the previous methodology, as permitted.
889331_13_ITEM8_P75_S0	In July 2012, the FASB issued authoritative guidance on testing indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment.
889331_13_ITEM8_P75_S1	Under the revised guidance, entities testing indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment will have the option first to assess qualitative factors to determine whether the existence of events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that the indefinite-lived intangible asset is impaired.
889331_13_ITEM8_P75_S2	If, after assessing the totality of events and circumstances, an entity concludes that it is not more likely than not that the indefinite-lived intangible asset is not impaired, then the entity is not required to take further action.
889331_13_ITEM8_P75_S3	The amendment is effective for annual and interim indefinite-lived asset impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after September 15, 2012.
889331_13_ITEM8_P75_S4	The company believes that adoption of new guidance will have no effect on its consolidated financial statements.
889331_13_ITEM8_P76_S0	On December 17, 2010, the company acquired the Cole Hersee Company ( Cole Hersee ), a leading manufacturer of power management products and heavy duty electromechanical and solid-state switches, for approximately $50.0 million.
889331_13_ITEM8_P76_S1	The acquisition allows the company to further expand its off-road, truck and bus business.
889331_13_ITEM8_P77_S0	Cole Hersee is located in Boston, Massachusetts with manufacturing operations in Melchor Muzquiz, Mexico.
889331_13_ITEM8_P77_S1	The company funded the acquisition with available cash.
889331_13_ITEM8_P78_S0	The following table sets forth the final purchase price allocation for Cole Hersee s net assets in accordance with the purchase method of accounting with adjustments to record the acquired net assets at their estimated fair values.
889331_13_ITEM8_P79_S0	All Cole Hersee goodwill and other assets and liabilities were recorded in the Automotive business unit segment and reflected in the Americas geographical area.
889331_13_ITEM8_P79_S1	The customer list is being amortized over 13 years.
889331_13_ITEM8_P79_S2	The distribution network is being amortized over five years.
889331_13_ITEM8_P79_S3	The trademarks are being amortized over 10 years.
889331_13_ITEM8_P79_S4	Goodwill for the above acquisition is expected to be deductible for tax purposes.
889331_13_ITEM8_P80_S0	As required by purchase accounting rules, the company recorded a $3.7 million step-up of inventory to its fair value as of the acquisition date.
889331_13_ITEM8_P80_S1	During the first quarter of 2011, as this inventory was sold, cost of goods sold included $3.7 million of non-cash charges for this step-up.
889331_13_ITEM8_P81_S0	On August 3, 2011, the company acquired 100% of Selco A/S ( Selco ), a manufacturer of relays and generator controls for the marine industry, for approximately $11.1 million.
889331_13_ITEM8_P81_S1	The acquisition allows the company to further expand its global relay business within its Electrical business unit segment.
889331_13_ITEM8_P82_S0	Selco is located in Roskilde, Denmark with a sales office located in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.
889331_13_ITEM8_P82_S1	The company funded the acquisition with available cash.

889331_13_ITEM8_P84_S2	The distribution network is being amortized over three to 10 years.
889331_13_ITEM8_P84_S3	The trademarks are being amortized over five years.
889331_13_ITEM8_P84_S4	The patents and licenses are being amortized over 10 years.
889331_13_ITEM8_P84_S5	Goodwill for the above acquisition is not expected to be deductible for tax purposes.

889331_13_ITEM8_P85_S1	During the fourth quarter of 2011, as this inventory was sold, cost of goods sold included $0.5 million of non-cash charges for this step-up.
889331_13_ITEM8_P85_S2	The remaining $0.2 million was included in cost of goods sold for the three months ended March 31, 2012.
