889331_14_ITEM7_P74_S0	Changes in operating assets and liabilities in 2012 (including short-term and long-term items) that negatively impacted cash flows in 2012 consisted of changes in accounts receivable ($1.6 million), accrued expenses including post-retirement ($9.6 million), accrued payroll and severance ($4.4 million), accrued taxes ($0.4 million), and prepaid expenses and other (less than $0.1 million).
889331_14_ITEM7_P74_S1	Accrued expenses including post-retirement included $10.0 million in pension contributions in 2012.
889331_14_ITEM7_P74_S2	Positively impacting cash flows were changes in inventory ($5.4 million) and accounts payable ($5.4 million).
889331_14_ITEM7_P75_S0	The company s capital expenditures were $35.0 million in 2013, $22.5 million in 2012 and $17.6 million in 2011.
889331_14_ITEM7_P76_S0	The company s Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of up to 1,000,000 shares of the company s common stock under a program for the period May 1, 2013 to April 30, 2014.
889331_14_ITEM7_P76_S1	The company did not repurchase any shares of its common stock during 2013 under this program.
889331_14_ITEM7_P77_S0	The company withheld 32,671 shares of stock in lieu of withholding taxes on behalf of employees who became vested in restricted stock option grants during 2013.
889331_14_ITEM7_P78_S0	The following table summarizes contractual obligations and commitments as of December 28, 2013:
889331_14_ITEM7_P79_S0	As of December 28, 2013, the company did not have any off-balance sheet arrangements, as defined under SEC rules.
889331_14_ITEM7_P79_S1	Specifically, the company was not liable for guarantees of indebtedness owed by third parties; the company was not directly liable for the debt of any unconsolidated entity, and the company did not have any retained or contingent interest in assets; and the company does not participate in transactions that generate relationships with unconsolidated entities or financial partnerships, such as entities often referred to as structured finance or special purpose entities.
889331_14_ITEM7_P80_S0	In May 2011, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued authoritative guidance that provides a consistent definition of fair value and ensures that the fair value measurement and disclosure requirements are similar between U.S. GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards.
889331_14_ITEM7_P80_S1	The new guidance changes certain fair value measurement principles and enhances the disclosure requirements particularly for Level 3 fair value measurements.
889331_14_ITEM7_P80_S2	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012.
889331_14_ITEM7_P80_S3	There was no significant impact on its consolidated financial statements upon adoption.
889331_14_ITEM7_P81_S0	In June 2011, the FASB issued authoritative guidance that will require companies to present the components of net income and other comprehensive income either as one continuous statement or as two consecutive statements.
889331_14_ITEM7_P81_S1	It eliminates the option to present components of other comprehensive income as part of the statement of changes in equity.
889331_14_ITEM7_P81_S2	The guidance does not change the items which must be reported in other comprehensive income, how such items are measured or when they must be reclassified to net income.
889331_14_ITEM7_P81_S3	This guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2011.
889331_14_ITEM7_P81_S4	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012, which resulted in a different presentation in its consolidated financial statements.
889331_14_ITEM7_P82_S0	In September 2011, the FASB issued authoritative guidance on testing goodwill for impairment.
889331_14_ITEM7_P82_S1	Under the revised guidance, entities testing goodwill for impairment have the option of performing a qualitative assessment before calculating the fair value of the reporting unit (i.e., step 1 of the goodwill impairment test).
889331_14_ITEM7_P82_S2	If entities determine, on the basis of qualitative factors, that the fair value of the reporting unit is more likely than not less than the carrying amount, the two-step impairment test would be required.
889331_14_ITEM7_P82_S3	The guidance does not change how goodwill is calculated or assigned to reporting units, nor does it revise the requirement to test goodwill annually for impairment.
889331_14_ITEM7_P82_S4	In addition, the guidance does not amend the requirement to test goodwill for impairment between annual tests if events or circumstances warrant; however, it does revise the examples of events and circumstances that an entity should consider.
889331_14_ITEM7_P82_S5	The amendments are effective for annual and interim goodwill impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
889331_14_ITEM7_P82_S6	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012.
889331_14_ITEM7_P82_S7	There was no significant impact on its consolidated financial statements upon adoption.
889331_14_ITEM7_P82_S8	Goodwill testing was completed in September 2013 using the previous methodology, as permitted.
889331_14_ITEM7_P83_S0	In July 2012, the FASB issued authoritative guidance on testing indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment.
889331_14_ITEM7_P83_S1	Under the revised guidance, entities testing indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment will have the option first to assess qualitative factors to determine whether the existence of events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that the indefinite-lived intangible asset is impaired.
889331_14_ITEM7_P83_S2	If, after assessing the totality of events and circumstances, an entity concludes that it is not more likely than not that the indefinite-lived intangible asset is not impaired, then the entity is not required to take further action.
889331_14_ITEM7_P83_S3	The amendment is effective for annual and interim indefinite-lived asset impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after September 15, 2012.
889331_14_ITEM7_P83_S4	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2013.
889331_14_ITEM7_P83_S5	There was no significant impact on its consolidated financial statements upon adoption.
889331_14_ITEM7_P84_S0	In February 2013, the FASB issued authoritative guidance on the reporting of amounts reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income into net income or the balance sheet.
889331_14_ITEM7_P84_S1	Under the new guidance, in addition to the presentation of changes in accumulated balances, an entity shall present separately for each component of other comprehensive income, current period reclassifications out of accumulated other comprehensive income and other amounts of current-period other comprehensive income.
889331_14_ITEM7_P84_S2	Both before-tax and net-of-tax presentations are permitted.
889331_14_ITEM7_P84_S3	The guidance is effective for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2013.
889331_14_ITEM7_P84_S4	The company believes the adoption of the new guidance will require additional disclosures but will have no significant effect on its consolidated financial statements.
889331_14_ITEM7_P85_S0	Certain of the accounting policies as discussed below require the application of significant judgment by management in selecting the appropriate estimates and assumptions for calculating amounts to record in the financial statements.
889331_14_ITEM7_P85_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates and assumptions, impacting the reported results of operations and financial position.
889331_14_ITEM7_P85_S2	Significant accounting policies are more fully described in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report.
889331_14_ITEM7_P85_S3	Certain accounting policies, however, are considered to be critical in that they are most important to the depiction of the company s financial condition and results of operations and their application requires management s subjective judgment in making estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain.
889331_14_ITEM7_P85_S4	The company believes the following accounting policies are the most critical to aid in fully understanding and evaluating its reported financial results, as they require management s most difficult, subjective or complex judgments, resulting from the need to make estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain.
889331_14_ITEM7_P85_S5	The company has reviewed these critical accounting policies and related disclosures with the Audit Committee of its Board of Directors.
889331_14_ITEM7_P86_S0	The company recognizes revenue on product sales in the period in which the sales process is complete.
889331_14_ITEM7_P86_S1	This generally occurs when products are shipped (FOB origin) to the customer in accordance with the terms of the sale, the risk of loss has been transferred, collectability is reasonably assured and the pricing is fixed and determinable.
889331_14_ITEM7_P86_S2	At the end of each period, for those shipments where title to the products and the risk of loss and rewards of ownership do not transfer until the product has been received by the customer, the company adjusts revenues and cost of sales for the delay between the time that the products are shipped and when they are received by the customer.
889331_14_ITEM7_P87_S0	The company s distribution channels are primarily through direct sales and independent third party distributors.
889331_14_ITEM7_P88_S0	The company accepts orders from customers based on long term purchasing contracts and written sales agreements.
889331_14_ITEM7_P88_S1	Contract pricing and selling agreement terms are based on market factors, costs and competition.
889331_14_ITEM7_P88_S2	Pricing normally is negotiated as an adjustment (premium or discount) from the company s published price lists.
889331_14_ITEM7_P88_S3	The customer is invoiced when the company s products are shipped to them in accordance with the terms of the sales agreement.
889331_14_ITEM7_P89_S0	the ability to receive price adjustments on products previously shipped and invoiced.
889331_14_ITEM7_P89_S1	This practice is common in the industry and is referred to as a ship and debit program.
889331_14_ITEM7_P89_S2	This program allows the distributor to debit the company for the difference between the distributors contracted price and a lower price for specific transactions.
889331_14_ITEM7_P90_S0	Under certain circumstances (usually in a competitive situation or large volume opportunity), a distributor will request authorization to reduce its price to its buyer.
889331_14_ITEM7_P90_S1	If the company approves such a reduction, the distributor is authorized to debit its account for the difference between the contracted price and the lower approved price.
889331_14_ITEM7_P90_S2	The company establishes reserves for this program based on historic activity and actual authorizations for the debit and recognizes these debits as a reduction of revenue.
889331_14_ITEM7_P91_S0	The company has a return to stock policy whereby a customer with previous authorization from Littelfuse management can return previously purchased goods for full or partial credit.
889331_14_ITEM7_P91_S1	The company establishes an estimated allowance for these returns based on historic activity.
889331_14_ITEM7_P91_S2	Sales revenue and cost of sales are reduced to anticipate estimated returns.
889331_14_ITEM7_P92_S0	The company properly meets all of the criteria for recognizing revenue when the right of return exists.
889331_14_ITEM7_P92_S1	Specifically, the company meets those requirements because:
889331_14_ITEM7_P93_S0	The company s selling price is fixed or determinable at the date of the sale.
889331_14_ITEM7_P94_S0	The company has policies and procedures to accept only credit worthy customers with the ability to pay the company.
889331_14_ITEM7_P95_S0	The company s customers are obligated to pay the company under the contract and the obligation is not contingent on the resale of the product.
889331_14_ITEM7_P96_S0	The risk ownership transfers to the company s customers upon shipment and is not changed in the event of theft, physical destruction or damage of the product.
889331_14_ITEM7_P97_S0	The company bills at the ship date and establishes a reserve to reduce revenue from the in-transit time until the product is delivered for FOB destination sales.
889331_14_ITEM7_P98_S0	The company s customers acquiring the product for resale have economic substance apart from that provided by Littelfuse.
889331_14_ITEM7_P98_S1	All distributors are independent of the company.
889331_14_ITEM7_P99_S0	The company can reasonably estimate the amount of future returns.
889331_14_ITEM7_P100_S0	Volume Rebates: The company offers incentives to certain customers to achieve specific quarterly or annual sales targets.
889331_14_ITEM7_P100_S1	If customers achieve their sales targets, they are entitled to rebates.
889331_14_ITEM7_P100_S2	The company estimates the future cost of these rebates and recognizes this estimated cost as a reduction to revenue as products are sold.
889331_14_ITEM7_P101_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts: The company evaluates the collectability of its trade receivables based on a combination of factors.
889331_14_ITEM7_P101_S1	The company regularly analyzes its significant customer accounts and, when the company becomes aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the company records a specific reserve for bad debt to reduce the related receivable to the amount the company reasonably believes is collectible.
889331_14_ITEM7_P101_S2	The company also records allowances for all other customers based on a variety of factors including the length of time the receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, macroeconomic considerations and past experience.
889331_14_ITEM7_P102_S0	Historically, the allowance for doubtful accounts has been adequate to cover bad debts.
889331_14_ITEM7_P102_S1	If circumstances related to specific customers change, the estimates of the recoverability of receivables could be further adjusted.
889331_14_ITEM7_P103_S0	The company performs regular detailed assessments of inventory, which include a review of, among other factors, demand requirements, product life cycle and development plans, component cost trends, product pricing, shelf life and quality issues.
889331_14_ITEM7_P103_S1	Based on the analysis, the company records adjustments to inventory for excess quantities, obsolescence or impairment when appropriate to reflect inventory at net realizable value.
889331_14_ITEM7_P104_S0	Historically, inventory reserves have been adequate to reflect inventory at net realizable values.
889331_14_ITEM7_P104_S1	During 2013, 2012 and 2011, the company was required to step up the value of inventory acquired in business combinations to its selling prices less the cost to sell under business combination accounting.
889331_14_ITEM7_P104_S2	This was approximately $1.5 million for Hamlin in 2013, $0.6 million in 2012 for Accel and Selco and $0.4 million in 2011 for Selco.
889331_14_ITEM7_P105_S0	The company annually tests goodwill for impairment on the first day of its fiscal fourth quarter or at an interim date if there is an event or change in circumstances that indicates the asset may be impaired.
889331_14_ITEM7_P105_S1	The company has eight reporting units for goodwill testing purposes.
889331_14_ITEM7_P105_S2	Management determines the fair value of each of its reporting units by using a discounted cash flow model (which includes forecasted five-year income statement and working capital projections, a market-based weighted average cost of capital and terminal values after five years) to estimate market value.
889331_14_ITEM7_P105_S3	In addition, the company compares its derived enterprise value on a consolidated basis to the company s market capitalization as of its test date to ensure its derived value approximates the market value of the company when taken as a whole.
889331_14_ITEM7_P106_S0	As of the most recent annual test conducted on September 29, 2013, the company concluded the fair value of each of the reporting units exceeded its carrying value of invested capital and therefore, no potential goodwill impairment existed.
889331_14_ITEM7_P106_S1	Specifically, the company noted that its headroom, defined as the excess of fair value over the carrying value of invested capital, was 61%, 97%, 67%, 158%, 42%, 57%, 244% and 151% for its electronics (non-silicon), electronics (silicon), passenger car, commercial vehicle products, sensors, relay, custom products and fuse reporting units, respectively, at September 29, 2013.
889331_14_ITEM7_P106_S2	Certain key assumptions used in the annual test included a discount rate of 12.5% and a long-term growth rate of 3.0% used for all eight reporting units.
889331_14_ITEM7_P107_S0	In addition, the company performed a sensitivity test at September 29, 2013 that showed either a 100 basis point increase in its discount rate or a 100 basis point decrease in the long-term growth rate for each reporting unit would not have changed the company s conclusion that no potential goodwill impairment existed at September 29, 2013.
889331_14_ITEM7_P108_S0	The company will continue to perform a goodwill impairment test as required on an annual basis and on an interim basis, if certain conditions exist.
889331_14_ITEM7_P108_S1	Factors the company considers important, which could result in changes to its estimates, include underperformance relative to historical or projected future operating results and declines in acquisitions and trading multiples.
889331_14_ITEM7_P108_S2	Due to the diverse end user base and non-discretionary product demand, the company does not believe its future operating results will vary significantly relative to its historical and projected future operating results.
889331_14_ITEM7_P109_S0	The company evaluates long-lived asset groups on an ongoing basis.
889331_14_ITEM7_P109_S1	Long-lived asset groups are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the related asset may not be recoverable.
889331_14_ITEM7_P110_S0	Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of the asset to future undiscounted cash flows expected to be generated by the asset group.
889331_14_ITEM7_P110_S1	If it is determined to be impaired, the impairment recognized is measured by the amount by which the carrying value of the asset exceeds its fair value.
889331_14_ITEM7_P110_S2	The company s estimates of future cash flows from such assets could be impacted if it underperforms relative to historical or projected future operating results.
889331_14_ITEM7_P110_S3	The company recorded asset impairment charges of $0.0 million, $0.5 million and $2.3 million for the fiscal years ended 2013, 2012 and 2011, respectively.
889331_14_ITEM7_P110_S4	Further information regarding asset impairments is provided in Note 11 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_14_ITEM7_P111_S0	The company evaluates its investments quarterly or when there is an indicator of a potential impairment.
889331_14_ITEM7_P111_S1	During the fourth quarter of 2012, company management determined that an indicator of impairment existed for the company s investment in Shocking Technologies, Inc.
889331_14_ITEM7_P111_S2	Subsequently, the company engaged a third party asset valuation firm to perform an analysis for purposes of assisting management in determining the amount of impairment.
889331_14_ITEM7_P111_S3	Further information regarding the impairment of the company s investment in Shocking Technologies, Inc. is provided in Note 6 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_14_ITEM7_P112_S0	Environmental liabilities are accrued based on estimates of the probability of potential future environmental exposure.
889331_14_ITEM7_P112_S1	Expenses related to on-going maintenance of environmental sites are expensed as incurred.
889331_14_ITEM7_P112_S2	If actual or estimated probable future losses exceed the company s recorded liability for such claims, it would record additional charges as other expense during the period in which the actual loss or change in estimate occurred.
889331_14_ITEM7_P113_S0	The company evaluates its reserve for coal mine remediation annually utilizing a third party expert.
889331_14_ITEM7_P114_S0	Littelfuse has a number of company-sponsored defined benefit plans primarily in North America, Europe and the Asia-Pacific region.
889331_14_ITEM7_P114_S1	The company recognizes the full unfunded status of these plans on the balance sheet.
889331_14_ITEM7_P114_S2	Actuarial gains and losses and prior service costs and credits are recognized as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income.
889331_14_ITEM7_P115_S0	Accounting for pensions requires estimating the future benefit cost and recognizing the cost over the employee s expected period of employment with the company.
889331_14_ITEM7_P115_S1	Certain assumptions are required in the calculation of pension costs and obligations.
889331_14_ITEM7_P115_S2	These assumptions include the discount rate, salary scales and the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
889331_14_ITEM7_P116_S0	The discount rate is intended to represent the rate at which pension benefit obligations could be settled by purchase of an annuity contract.
889331_14_ITEM7_P116_S1	These assumptions are subject to change based on stock and bond market returns and other economic factors.
889331_14_ITEM7_P116_S2	Actual results that differ from the company s assumptions are accumulated and amortized over future periods and, therefore, generally affect its recognized expense and accrued liability in such future periods.
889331_14_ITEM7_P116_S3	While the company believes that its assumptions are appropriate given current economic conditions and its actual experience, significant differences in results or significant changes in the company s assumptions may materially affect its pension obligations and related future expense.
889331_14_ITEM7_P116_S4	Further information regarding these plans is provided in Note 12 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_14_ITEM7_P117_S0	Stock-based compensation expense is recorded for stock-option grants and restricted share units based upon the fair values of the awards.
889331_14_ITEM7_P118_S0	The fair value of stock option awards is estimated at the grant date using the Black-Scholes option pricing model, which includes assumptions for volatility, expected term, risk-free interest rate and dividend yield.
889331_14_ITEM7_P118_S1	Expected volatility is based on implied volatilities from traded options on Littelfuse stock, historical volatility of Littelfuse stock and other factors.
889331_14_ITEM7_P118_S2	Historical data is used to estimate employee termination experience and the expected term of the options.
889331_14_ITEM7_P119_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect at the time of grant.
889331_14_ITEM7_P119_S1	The company initiated a quarterly cash dividend in 2010 and expects to continue making cash dividend payments in the foreseeable future.
889331_14_ITEM7_P120_S0	Total stock-based compensation expense was $8.6 million, $7.3 million, and $5.8 million in 2013, 2012, and 2011, respectively.
889331_14_ITEM7_P120_S1	Further information regarding this expense is provided in Note 13 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_14_ITEM7_P121_S0	The company accounts for income taxes using the liability method.
889331_14_ITEM7_P122_S0	Deferred taxes are recognized for the future effects of temporary differences between financial and income tax reporting using tax rates in effect for the years in which the differences are expected to reverse.
889331_14_ITEM7_P122_S1	The company recognizes deferred taxes for temporary differences, operating loss carryforwards and tax credit carryforwards.
889331_14_ITEM7_P122_S2	Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if it is more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
889331_14_ITEM7_P123_S0	Federal and state income taxes are provided on the portion of foreign income that is expected to be remitted to the U.S. and be taxable.
889331_14_ITEM7_P124_S0	The company recognizes the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical merits of the position.
889331_14_ITEM7_P124_S1	The tax benefits recognized in the financial statements from such a position are measured based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized upon ultimate settlement.
889331_14_ITEM7_P125_S0	Further information regarding income taxes, including a detailed reconciliation of current year activity, is provided in Note 14 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_14_ITEM7_P126_S0	Overall, the company expects the first quarter of 2014 to look similar to the fourth quarter of 2013.
889331_14_ITEM7_P127_S0	SymCom is expected to contribute about $5.0 million in incremental sales in what for them is typically a seasonally weak quarter.
889331_14_ITEM7_P127_S1	However, the company expects the incremental sales from SymCom to be partially offset by lower custom sales reflecting continued weakness in the mining sector.
889331_14_ITEM7_P128_S0	Sales for the first quarter of 2014 are expected to be in the range of $195.0 to $205.0 million which, at the midpoint, represents 17% growth compared to the first quarter of 2013.
889331_14_ITEM7_P128_S1	Earnings for the first quarter of 2014 are expected to be in the range of $0.98 to $1.12 per diluted share.
889331_14_ITEM7_P129_S0	For the year 2014, the company expects moderate organic growth in both the Automotive and Electronics segments.
889331_14_ITEM7_P129_S1	In addition, a full year of sales for the recently-acquired Hamlin business will add to 2014 sales for both of these segments.
889331_14_ITEM7_P129_S2	The Electrical segment is expected to continue to be challenged by the global mining downturn and delays in the expansion plans of several major potash producers.
889331_14_ITEM7_P129_S3	This mining weakness is expected to be partially offset by moderate growth in the solar and industrial markets and the addition of SymCom.
889331_14_ITEM7_P130_S0	While typically the company s business model would enable earnings growth to exceed sales growth, the newly-acquired businesses, Hamlin and SymCom, are expected to operate below their margin potential for 2014.
889331_14_ITEM7_P130_S1	The company is making upfront investments to grow sales and to integrate these businesses, which it believes will contribute to earnings in 2015 and beyond.
889331_14_ITEM7_P130_S2	The company is also actively working on margin improvement plans for both these businesses.
889331_14_ITEM7_P131_S0	The company expects capital expenditures in 2014 to be in the range of $35 to $40 million primarily for capacity to support volume increases and new product introductions.
889331_14_ITEM7_P131_S1	The company expects to fund 2014 capital expansion from operating cash flows.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The company is exposed to market risk from changes in interest rates, foreign exchange rates and commodity prices.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The company had $219.8 million in debt outstanding at December 28, 2013 related to the unsecured revolving credit facility and term loan, which is described in Item 7 under Liquidity and Capital Resources .
889331_14_ITEM7A_P1_S1	While this debt has a variable interest rate of LIBOR plus 1.25%, the company s interest expense is not materially sensitive to changes in interest rate levels since debt levels and potential interest expense increases are insignificant relative to earnings.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The majority of the company s operations consist of manufacturing and sales activities in foreign countries.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The company has manufacturing facilities in the U.S., Mexico, Canada, Denmark, China, Lithuania, Taiwan and the Philippines.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P2_S2	During 2013, sales to customers outside the U.S. were approximately 64% of total net sales.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Substantially all sales in Europe are denominated in euros and substantially all sales in the Asia-Pacific region are denominated in U.S. dollars, Japanese yen, Korean won, Chinese yuan and Taiwanese dollars.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P3_S0	The company s foreign exchange exposures result primarily from sale of products in foreign currencies, foreign currency denominated purchases, employee-related and other costs of running operations in foreign countries and translation of balance sheet accounts denominated in foreign currencies.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P3_S1	The company s most significant long exposure is to the euro, with lesser long exposures to the Canadian dollar, Japanese yen and Korean won.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P3_S2	The company s most significant short exposures are to the Mexican peso, Philippine peso and Chinese yuan.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P3_S3	Changes in foreign exchange rates could affect the company s sales, costs, balance sheet values and earnings.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P3_S4	The company uses netting and offsetting intercompany account management techniques to reduce known foreign currency exposures where possible and also, from time to time, utilizes derivative instruments to hedge certain foreign currency exposures deemed to be material.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The company uses various metals in the manufacturing of its products, including copper, zinc, tin, gold and silver.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P4_S1	Prices of these commodities can and do fluctuate significantly, which can impact the company s earnings.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P4_S2	The most significant of these exposures is to copper, zinc, gold and silver, where at current prices and volumes, a 10% price change would affect annual pre-tax profit by approximately $2.0 million for copper, $0.6 million for zinc, $0.3 million for gold and $0.5 million for silver.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The cost of oil fluctuated dramatically over the past several years.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P5_S1	Consequently, there is a risk that a return to high prices for oil and electricity in 2014 could have a significant impact on the company s transportation and utility expenses.
889331_14_ITEM7A_P6_S0	While the company is exposed to significant changes in certain commodity prices and foreign currency exchange rates, the company actively monitors these exposures and takes various actions to mitigate any negative impacts of these exposures.
889331_14_ITEM8_P0_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders of Littelfuse, Inc.
889331_14_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Littelfuse, Inc., as of December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012, and the related consolidated statements of net income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 28, 2013.
889331_14_ITEM8_P1_S1	Our audits also included the financial statement schedule listed in the Index at Item 15(a).
889331_14_ITEM8_P1_S2	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company's management.
889331_14_ITEM8_P1_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
889331_14_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
889331_14_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
889331_14_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P3_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
889331_14_ITEM8_P3_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
889331_14_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of Littelfuse, Inc., as of December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012, and its results of operations and its cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 28, 2013, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
889331_14_ITEM8_P5_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Littelfuse, Inc.'s internal control over financial reporting as of December 28, 2013, based on criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (1992 framework) and our report dated February 25, 2014 expressed an adverse opinion thereon.
889331_14_ITEM8_P6_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders of Littelfuse, Inc.
889331_14_ITEM8_P7_S0	We have audited Littelfuse, Inc. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 28, 2013, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (1992 framework) (the COSO criteria).
889331_14_ITEM8_P7_S1	Littelfuse, Inc. s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting.
889331_14_ITEM8_P7_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
889331_14_ITEM8_P8_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
889331_14_ITEM8_P8_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
889331_14_ITEM8_P8_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
889331_14_ITEM8_P8_S3	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
889331_14_ITEM8_P9_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
889331_14_ITEM8_P9_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P10_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P10_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
889331_14_ITEM8_P11_S0	As indicated in the accompanying Management s Annual Report On Internal Control Over Financial Reporting, management s assessment of and conclusion on the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting did not include the internal controls of Hamlin, Inc., and subsidiaries, which are included in the 2013 consolidated financial statements of Littelfuse, Inc., and constituted approximately 18.3% of total assets as of December 28, 2013, approximately 6.7% of total revenue and approximately 1.9% of consolidated operating income for the year then ended.
889331_14_ITEM8_P11_S1	Our audit of internal control over financial reporting of Littelfuse, Inc. also did not include an evaluation of the internal control over financial reporting of Hamlin, Inc., and subsidiaries.
889331_14_ITEM8_P12_S0	A material weakness is a deficiency, or combination of deficiencies, in internal control over financial reporting, such that there is a reasonable possibility that a material misstatement of the company s annual or interim financial statements will not be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
889331_14_ITEM8_P12_S1	The following material weakness has been identified and included in management s assessment: A material weakness in internal control over financial reporting relating to the company s evaluation of the income tax considerations, including deferred tax valuation allowances, relating to the write-off of its investment in Shocking Technologies, Inc. during the first quarter of 2013.
889331_14_ITEM8_P13_S0	In our opinion, because of the effect of the material weakness described above on the achievement of the objectives of the control criteria, Littelfuse, Inc., has not maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 28, 2013, based on the COSO criteria.
889331_14_ITEM8_P14_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Littelfuse, Inc., as of December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012, and the related consolidated statements of net income and comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 28, 2013.
889331_14_ITEM8_P14_S1	This material weakness was considered in determining the nature, timing and extent of audit tests applied in our audit of the 2013 consolidated financial statements, and this report does not affect our report dated February 25, 2014, which expressed an unqualified opinion on those consolidated financial statements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P15_S0	See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P16_S0	See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P17_S0	See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P18_S0	*Including related tax impact (see Note 14).
889331_14_ITEM8_P19_S0	See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P20_S0	Nature of Operations : Littelfuse, Inc. and subsidiaries (the company ) design, manufacture, and sell circuit protection devices for use in the automotive, electronic and electrical markets throughout the world.
889331_14_ITEM8_P20_S1	In addition to the broadest and deepest portfolio of circuit protection products and solutions, the company offers a comprehensive line of highly reliable electromechanical and electronic switch and control devices for commercial and specialty vehicles and sensors for automobile safety systems, as well as protection relays and power distribution centers for the safe control and distribution of electricity.
889331_14_ITEM8_P21_S0	Fiscal Year : The company s fiscal years ended on December 28, 2013, December 29, 2012 and December 31, 2011 and contained 52 weeks each.
889331_14_ITEM8_P22_S0	Basis of Presentation : The Consolidated Financial Statements include the accounts of Littelfuse, Inc. and its subsidiaries.
889331_14_ITEM8_P22_S1	All significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
889331_14_ITEM8_P23_S0	The company s Consolidated Financial Statements were prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America and include the assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses of all wholly-owned subsidiaries and majority-owned subsidiaries over which the company exercises control.
889331_14_ITEM8_P24_S0	Use of Estimates : The process of preparing financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the Consolidated Financial Statements, and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses and the accompanying notes.
889331_14_ITEM8_P24_S1	The company evaluates and updates its assumptions and estimates on an ongoing basis and may employ outside experts to assist in its evaluation, as considered necessary.
889331_14_ITEM8_P24_S2	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
889331_14_ITEM8_P25_S0	Cash Equivalents : All highly liquid investments, with an original maturity of three months or less when purchased, are considered to be cash equivalents.
889331_14_ITEM8_P26_S0	Short-Term and Long-Term Investments : The company has determined that certain of its investment securities are to be classified as available-for-sale.
889331_14_ITEM8_P26_S1	Available-for-sale securities are carried at fair value with the unrealized gains and losses reported as a component of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income (Loss).
889331_14_ITEM8_P27_S0	Realized gains and losses and declines in unrealized value judged to be other-than-temporary on available-for-sale securities are included in other expense (income), net.
889331_14_ITEM8_P28_S0	The cost of securities sold is based on the specific identification method.
889331_14_ITEM8_P28_S1	Interest and dividends on securities classified as available-for-sale are included in interest income.
889331_14_ITEM8_P29_S0	Fair Value of Financial Instruments : The company s financial instruments include cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, investments and long-term debt.
889331_14_ITEM8_P29_S1	The carrying values of such financial instruments approximate their estimated fair values.
889331_14_ITEM8_P30_S0	Accounts Receivable : The company performs credit evaluations of customers financial condition and generally does not require collateral.
889331_14_ITEM8_P31_S0	Credit losses are provided for in the financial statements based upon specific knowledge of a customer s inability to meet its financial obligations to the company.
889331_14_ITEM8_P32_S0	Historically, credit losses have consistently been within management s expectations and have not been a material amount.
889331_14_ITEM8_P32_S1	A receivable is considered past due if payments have not been received within agreed upon invoice terms.
889331_14_ITEM8_P32_S2	Write-offs are recorded at the time a customer receivable is deemed uncollectible.
889331_14_ITEM8_P33_S0	The company also maintains allowances against accounts receivable for the settlement of rebates and sales discounts to customers.
889331_14_ITEM8_P33_S1	These allowances are based upon specific customer sales and sales discounts as well as actual historical experience.
889331_14_ITEM8_P34_S0	Inventories : Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market (first in, first out method), which approximates current replacement cost.
889331_14_ITEM8_P35_S0	The company maintains excess and obsolete allowances against inventory to reduce the carrying value to the expected net realizable value.
889331_14_ITEM8_P35_S1	These allowances are based upon a combination of factors including historical sales volume, market conditions, lower of cost or market analysis and expected realizable value of the inventory.
889331_14_ITEM8_P36_S0	Investment in Unconsolidated Affiliate: Investments in unconsolidated affiliates over which the company has significant influence over the investees operating and financing activities are accounted for under the equity method of accounting.
889331_14_ITEM8_P36_S1	Investments in affiliates over which the company does not have the ability to exert significant influence over the investees operating and financing activities are accounted for under the cost method.
889331_14_ITEM8_P37_S0	Property, Plant and Equipment : Land, buildings and equipment are carried at cost.
889331_14_ITEM8_P37_S1	Depreciation is calculated using the straight-line method with useful lives of 21 years for buildings, seven to nine years for equipment, seven years for furniture and fixtures, five years for tooling and three years for computer equipment.
889331_14_ITEM8_P38_S0	Goodwill and Indefinite-Lived Intangible Assets: The company annually tests goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment on the first day of its fiscal fourth quarter or at other dates if there is an event or change in circumstances that indicates the asset may be impaired.
889331_14_ITEM8_P38_S1	The company has eight reporting units for testing purposes.
889331_14_ITEM8_P38_S2	Management determines the fair value of each of its reporting units by using a discounted cash flow model (which includes forecasted five-year income statement and working capital projections, a market-based weighted average cost of capital and terminal values after five years) to estimate market value.
889331_14_ITEM8_P38_S3	In addition, the company compares its derived enterprise value on a consolidated basis to the company s market capitalization as of its test date to ensure its derived value approximates the market value of the company when taken as a whole.
889331_14_ITEM8_P39_S0	As of the most recent annual test, the company concluded the fair value of each of the reporting units exceeded its carrying value of invested capital and therefore, no potential goodwill impairment existed.
889331_14_ITEM8_P39_S1	Specifically, the company noted that its headroom, defined as the excess of fair value over the carrying value of invested capital, was 61%, 97%, 67%, 158%, 42%, 57%, 244% and 151% for its electronics (non-silicon), electronics (silicon), passenger car, commercial vehicle products, sensors, relay, custom products and fuse reporting units, respectively, at September 29, 2013.
889331_14_ITEM8_P39_S2	Certain key assumptions used in the annual test included a discount rate of 12.5% and a long-term growth rate of 3.0% was used for all eight reporting units.
889331_14_ITEM8_P40_S0	In addition, the company performed a sensitivity test that showed a 100 basis point increase in its discount rate or a 100 basis point decrease in the long-term growth rate for each reporting unit would not have changed the company s conclusion that no potential goodwill impairment existed.
889331_14_ITEM8_P41_S0	The company will continue to perform a goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible asset impairment test as required on an annual basis and on an interim basis, if certain conditions exist.
889331_14_ITEM8_P41_S1	Factors the company considers important, which could result in changes to its estimates, include underperformance relative to historical or projected future operating results and declines in acquisitions and trading multiples.
889331_14_ITEM8_P41_S2	Due to the diverse end user base and non-discretionary product demand, the company does not believe its future operating results will vary significantly relative to its historical and projected future operating results.
889331_14_ITEM8_P42_S0	Other Intangible Assets : Trademarks and tradenames are amortized using the straight-line method over estimated useful lives that have a range of five to 20 years.
889331_14_ITEM8_P42_S1	Patents, licenses and software are amortized using the straight-line method or an accelerated method over estimated useful lives that have a range of seven to 12 years.
889331_14_ITEM8_P42_S2	The distribution networks are amortized on either a straight-line or accelerated basis over estimated useful lives that have a range of three to 20 years.
889331_14_ITEM8_P42_S3	Other intangible assets are also tested for impairment when there is a significant event that may cause the asset to be impaired.
889331_14_ITEM8_P43_S0	Environmental Liabilities : Environmental liabilities are accrued based on engineering studies estimating the cost of remediating sites.
889331_14_ITEM8_P43_S1	Expenses related to on-going maintenance of environmental sites are expensed as incurred.
889331_14_ITEM8_P43_S2	If actual or estimated probable future losses exceed the company s recorded liability for such claims, the company would record additional charges during the period in which the actual loss or change in estimate occurred.
889331_14_ITEM8_P44_S0	Pension and Other Post-retirement Benefits : Accounting for pensions requires estimating the future benefit cost and recognizing the cost over the employee s expected period of employment with the company.
889331_14_ITEM8_P44_S1	Certain assumptions are required in the calculation of pension costs and obligations.
889331_14_ITEM8_P44_S2	These assumptions include the discount rate, salary scales and the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
889331_14_ITEM8_P45_S0	The discount rate is intended to represent the rate at which pension benefit obligations could be settled by purchase of an annuity contract.
889331_14_ITEM8_P45_S1	These assumptions are subject to change based on stock and bond market returns and other economic factors.
889331_14_ITEM8_P45_S2	Actual results that differ from the company s assumptions are accumulated and amortized over future periods and therefore generally affect its recognized expense and accrued liability in such future periods.
889331_14_ITEM8_P45_S3	While the company believes that its assumptions are appropriate given current economic conditions and its actual experience, significant differences in results or significant changes in the company s assumptions may materially affect its pension obligations and related future expense.
889331_14_ITEM8_P46_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2012, the company amended the Littelfuse Inc., Retirement Plan to allow participants who met certain requirements to elect to receive their vested retirement benefits in a lump sum on (or for certain participants annuity payments, on and after) December 1, 2012.
889331_14_ITEM8_P46_S1	This amendment resulted in a settlement charge of $5.1 million in 2012.
889331_14_ITEM8_P46_S2	See Note 12 for additional information.
889331_14_ITEM8_P47_S0	Reclassifications: Certain items in the 2012 and 2011 financial statements have been reclassified to conform to the 2013 presentations specifically, the 2012 and 2011 presentation of the Foreign exchange (gain) or loss of $3.2 million and $1.2 million, respectively has been separately presented.
889331_14_ITEM8_P47_S1	This was previously included as part of Other expense (income), net.
889331_14_ITEM8_P47_S2	These reclassifications had no impact on net income or shareholders equity for any period.
889331_14_ITEM8_P48_S0	The company recognizes revenue on product sales in the period in which the sales process is complete.
889331_14_ITEM8_P48_S1	This generally occurs when products are shipped (FOB origin) to the customer in accordance with the terms of the sale, the risk of loss has been transferred, collectability is reasonably assured and the pricing is fixed and determinable.
889331_14_ITEM8_P48_S2	At the end of each period, for those shipments where title to the products and the risk of loss and rewards of ownership do not transfer until the product has been received by the customer, the company adjusts revenues and cost of sales for the delay between the time that the products are shipped and when they are received by the customer.
889331_14_ITEM8_P49_S0	The company s distribution channels are primarily through direct sales and independent third party distributors.
889331_14_ITEM8_P50_S0	The company accepts orders from customers based on long term purchasing contracts and written sales agreements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P50_S1	Contract pricing and selling agreement terms are based on market factors, costs, and competition.
889331_14_ITEM8_P50_S2	Pricing normally is negotiated as an adjustment (premium or discount) from the company s published price lists.
889331_14_ITEM8_P50_S3	The customer is invoiced when the company s products are shipped to them in accordance with the terms of the sales agreement.
889331_14_ITEM8_P51_S0	the ability to receive price adjustments on products previously shipped and invoiced.
889331_14_ITEM8_P51_S1	This practice is common in the industry and is referred to as a ship and debit program.
889331_14_ITEM8_P51_S2	This program allows the distributor to debit the company for the difference between the distributors contracted price and a lower price for specific transactions.
889331_14_ITEM8_P52_S0	Under certain circumstances (usually in a competitive situation or large volume opportunity), a distributor will request authorization to reduce its price to its buyer.
889331_14_ITEM8_P52_S1	If the company approves such a reduction, the distributor is authorized to debit its account for the difference between the contracted price and the lower approved price.
889331_14_ITEM8_P52_S2	The company establishes reserves for this program based on historic activity and actual authorizations for the debit and recognizes these debits as a reduction of revenue.
889331_14_ITEM8_P53_S0	The company has a return to stock policy whereby a customer with prior authorization from Littelfuse management can return previously purchased goods for full or partial credit.
889331_14_ITEM8_P53_S1	The company establishes an estimated allowance for these returns based on historic activity.
889331_14_ITEM8_P53_S2	Sales revenue and cost of sales are reduced to anticipate estimated returns.
889331_14_ITEM8_P54_S0	The company properly meets all of the criteria for recognizing revenue when the right of return exists.
889331_14_ITEM8_P54_S1	Specifically, the company meets those requirements because:
889331_14_ITEM8_P55_S0	The company s selling price is fixed or determinable at the date of the sale.
889331_14_ITEM8_P56_S0	The company has policies and procedures to accept only credit worthy customers with the ability to pay the company.
889331_14_ITEM8_P57_S0	The company s customers are obligated to pay the company under the contract and the obligation is not contingent on the resale of the product.
889331_14_ITEM8_P58_S0	The risk ownership transfers to the company s customers upon shipment and is not changed in the event of theft, physical destruction or damage of the product.
889331_14_ITEM8_P59_S0	The company bills at the ship date and establishes a reserve to reduce revenue from the in transit time until the product is delivered for FOB destination sales.
889331_14_ITEM8_P60_S0	The company s customers acquiring the product for resale have economic substance apart from that provided by Littelfuse, and all distributors are independent of the company.
889331_14_ITEM8_P61_S0	The company does not have any obligations for future performance to bring about resale of the product by its customers.
889331_14_ITEM8_P62_S0	The company can reasonably estimate the amount of future returns.
889331_14_ITEM8_P63_S0	Volume Rebates: The company offers incentives to certain customers to achieve specific quarterly or annual sales targets.
889331_14_ITEM8_P63_S1	If customers achieve their sales targets, they are entitled to rebates.
889331_14_ITEM8_P63_S2	The company estimates the future cost of these rebates and recognizes this estimated cost as a reduction to revenue as products are sold.
889331_14_ITEM8_P64_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts: The company evaluates the collectability of its trade receivables based on a combination of factors.
889331_14_ITEM8_P64_S1	The company regularly analyzes its significant customer accounts and, when the company becomes aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the company records a specific reserve for bad debt to reduce the related receivable to the amount the company reasonably believes is collectible.
889331_14_ITEM8_P64_S2	The company also records allowances for all other customers based on a variety of factors including the length of time the receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, macroeconomic considerations and past experience.
889331_14_ITEM8_P64_S3	Accounts receivable balances that are deemed to be uncollectible, are written off against the reserve on a case-by-case basis.
889331_14_ITEM8_P65_S0	Historically, the allowance for doubtful accounts has been adequate to cover bad debts.
889331_14_ITEM8_P65_S1	If circumstances related to specific customers change, the estimates of the recoverability of receivables could be further adjusted.
889331_14_ITEM8_P65_S2	However, due to the company s diverse customer base and lack of credit concentration, the company does not believe its estimates would be materially impacted by changes in its assumptions.
889331_14_ITEM8_P66_S0	Advertising Costs : The company expenses advertising costs as incurred, which amounted to $1.6 million in 2013, $1.7 million in 2012 and $1.9 million in 2011, and are included as a component of selling, general and administrative expenses.
889331_14_ITEM8_P67_S0	Shipping and Handling Fees and Costs : Amounts billed to customers related to shipping and handling is classified as revenue.
889331_14_ITEM8_P67_S1	Costs incurred for shipping and handling of $6.5 million, $6.2 million and $5.9 million in 2013, 2012 and 2011, respectively, are classified in selling, general and administrative expenses.
889331_14_ITEM8_P68_S0	Foreign Currency Translation : The company s foreign subsidiaries use the local currency or the U.S. dollar as their functional currency, as appropriate.
889331_14_ITEM8_P68_S1	Assets and liabilities are translated using exchange rates at the balance sheet date, and revenues and expenses are translated at weighted average rates.
889331_14_ITEM8_P68_S2	The amount of foreign currency conversion recognized in the income statement related to currency translation was income of $5.2 million in 2013 and losses of $8.5 million and $0.9 million in 2012 and 2011, respectively.
889331_14_ITEM8_P68_S3	Adjustments from the translation process are recognized in Shareholders equity as a component of Accumulated other comprehensive income.
889331_14_ITEM8_P69_S0	Stock-based Compensation : The company recognizes compensation expense for the cost of awards of equity compensation using a fair value method.
889331_14_ITEM8_P69_S1	Benefits of tax deductions in excess of recognized compensation expense are reported as both operating and financing cash flows.
889331_14_ITEM8_P69_S2	See Note 13 for additional information on stock-based compensation.
889331_14_ITEM8_P70_S0	Other Expense (Income), Net: Other expense (income), net consisting of interest income, royalties and non-operating income , was $4.6 million of income in 2013 compared to $5.4 million of income in 2012 and $4.1 million of income in 2011.
889331_14_ITEM8_P71_S0	Income Taxes: The company accounts for income taxes using the liability method.
889331_14_ITEM8_P71_S1	Deferred taxes are recognized for the future effects of temporary differences between financial and income tax reporting using enacted tax rates in effect for the years in which the differences are expected to reverse.
889331_14_ITEM8_P71_S2	The company recognizes deferred taxes for temporary differences, operating loss carryforwards and tax credit carryforwards.
889331_14_ITEM8_P71_S3	Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if it is more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
889331_14_ITEM8_P72_S0	Federal and state income taxes are provided on the portion of foreign income that is expected to be remitted to the U.S. and be taxable.
889331_14_ITEM8_P73_S0	Accounting Pronouncements : In May 2011, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued authoritative guidance that provides a consistent definition of fair value and ensures that the fair value measurement and disclosure requirements are similar between U.S. GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards.
889331_14_ITEM8_P73_S1	The new guidance changes certain fair value measurement principles and enhances the disclosure requirements particularly for Level 3 fair value measurements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P73_S2	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012.
889331_14_ITEM8_P73_S3	There was no significant impact on its consolidated financial statements upon adoption.
889331_14_ITEM8_P74_S0	In June 2011, the FASB issued authoritative guidance that will require companies to present the components of net income and other comprehensive income either as one continuous statement or as two consecutive statements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P74_S1	It eliminates the option to present components of other comprehensive income as part of the statement of changes in equity.
889331_14_ITEM8_P74_S2	The guidance does not change the items which must be reported in other comprehensive income, how such items are measured or when they must be reclassified to net income.
889331_14_ITEM8_P74_S3	This guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2011.
889331_14_ITEM8_P74_S4	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012, which resulted in a different presentation in its consolidated financial statements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P75_S0	In September 2011, the FASB issued authoritative guidance on testing goodwill for impairment.
889331_14_ITEM8_P75_S1	Under the revised guidance, entities testing goodwill for impairment have the option of performing a qualitative assessment before calculating the fair value of the reporting unit (i.e., step 1 of the goodwill impairment test).
889331_14_ITEM8_P75_S2	If entities determine, on the basis of qualitative factors, that the fair value of the reporting unit is more likely than not less than the carrying amount, the two-step impairment test would be required.
889331_14_ITEM8_P75_S3	The guidance does not change how goodwill is calculated or assigned to reporting units, nor does it revise the requirement to test goodwill annually for impairment.
889331_14_ITEM8_P75_S4	In addition, the guidance does not amend the requirement to test goodwill for impairment between annual tests if events or circumstances warrant; however, it does revise the examples of events and circumstances that an entity should consider.
889331_14_ITEM8_P75_S5	The amendments are effective for annual and interim goodwill impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
889331_14_ITEM8_P75_S6	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012.
889331_14_ITEM8_P75_S7	There was no significant impact on its consolidated financial statements upon adoption.
889331_14_ITEM8_P75_S8	Goodwill testing was completed as of September 29, 2013 using the previous methodology, as permitted.
889331_14_ITEM8_P76_S0	In July 2012, the FASB issued authoritative guidance on testing indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment.
889331_14_ITEM8_P76_S1	Under the revised guidance, entities testing indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment will have the option first to assess qualitative factors to determine whether the existence of events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that the indefinite-lived intangible asset is impaired.
889331_14_ITEM8_P76_S2	If, after assessing the totality of events and circumstances, an entity concludes that it is not more likely than not that the indefinite-lived intangible asset is not impaired, then the entity is not required to take further action.
889331_14_ITEM8_P76_S3	The amendment is effective for annual and interim indefinite-lived asset impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after September 15, 2012.
889331_14_ITEM8_P76_S4	The company adopted the new guidance on January 1, 2012.
889331_14_ITEM8_P76_S5	There was no significant impact on its consolidated financial statements upon adoption.
889331_14_ITEM8_P77_S0	In February 2013, the FASB issued authoritative guidance on the reporting of amounts reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income into net income or the balance sheet.
889331_14_ITEM8_P77_S1	Under the new guidance, in addition to the presentation of changes in accumulated balances, an entity shall present separately for each component of other comprehensive income, current period reclassifications out of accumulated other comprehensive income and other amounts of current-period other comprehensive income.
889331_14_ITEM8_P77_S2	Both before-tax and net-of-tax presentations are permitted.
889331_14_ITEM8_P77_S3	The guidance is effective for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2013.
889331_14_ITEM8_P77_S4	The company believes the adoption of the new guidance will require additional disclosures but will have no significant effect on its consolidated financial statements.
889331_14_ITEM8_P78_S0	The company accounts for acquisitions using the purchase method in accordance with ASC 805, Business Combinations.
889331_14_ITEM8_P78_S1	The results of operations of each acquisition have been included in the accompanying consolidated financial statements as of the dates of the acquisition.
889331_14_ITEM8_P78_S2	Acquisition costs associated with acquisitions were $1.7 million, $0.9 million and $1.0 million for fiscal years 2013, 2012 and 2011, respectively and were recorded in Selling, general and administrative expenses.
889331_14_ITEM8_P79_S0	On May 31, 2013, the company acquired 100% of Hamlin, Inc. ( Hamlin ) from Key Safety Systems, for $144.4 million (net of cash acquired).
889331_14_ITEM8_P80_S0	Hamlin is a manufacturer of sensor technology providing standard products and custom solutions for leading global manufacturers in the automotive and electronic industries.
889331_14_ITEM8_P80_S1	The acquisition allows the company to expand its automotive and electronics product offerings in the global sensor market in both the Automotive and Electronics business segments.
889331_14_ITEM8_P81_S0	Hamlin is headquartered in Lake Mills, Wisconsin and has manufacturing, engineering and sales offices in the U.S., Mexico, Europe and Asia.
889331_14_ITEM8_P81_S1	The company funded the acquisition with available cash raised from borrowings on the company s new credit arrangement (See Note 7).
889331_14_ITEM8_P82_S0	The following table sets forth the preliminary purchase price allocation, as of December 28, 2013, for Hamlin acquisition-date net assets, in accordance with the purchase method of accounting with adjustments to record the acquired net assets at their estimated fair values.
889331_14_ITEM8_P82_S1	The company expects to finalize the purchase price allocation for Hamlin in the second quarter of 2014 as certain areas remain to be finalized; however, the adjustments are not anticipated to be significant.
889331_14_ITEM8_P83_S0	All Hamlin goodwill and other assets and liabilities were recorded in the Automotive and Electronics business unit segments and reflected in the Americas, Europe and Asia-Pacific geographical areas.
889331_14_ITEM8_P83_S1	The distribution network, trademarks and patents and licenses are all being amortized over 10 years.
889331_14_ITEM8_P83_S2	The goodwill resulting from this acquisition consists largely of the company s expected future product sales and synergies from combining Hamlin s products with the company s existing product offerings.
889331_14_ITEM8_P83_S3	A portion of the goodwill for the acquisition is not expected to be deductible for tax purposes.
889331_14_ITEM8_P84_S0	The company initially recorded a $2.1 million step-up of inventory to its fair value as of the acquisition date based on preliminary valuation.
889331_14_ITEM8_P84_S1	During the second and third quarters of 2013, as the remainder of this inventory was sold, cost of goods sold included $1.7 million and $0.4 million of non-cash charges for this step-up, respectively.
889331_14_ITEM8_P84_S2	During the fourth quarter of 2013, the inventory step-up valuation was finalized at $1.5 million which resulted in a $0.5 million non-cash credit to income in the fourth quarter of 2013.

889331_14_ITEM8_P110_S0	Investments in unconsolidated entities over which the company has significant influence over the investees operating and financing activities are accounted for under the equity method of accounting.
889331_14_ITEM8_P110_S1	Investments in affiliates in which the company does not have such ability are accounted for under the cost method of accounting.
889331_14_ITEM8_P111_S0	In 2011, the company invested $6.0 million in certain preferred stock of Shocking Technologies, Inc. ( Shocking ).
889331_14_ITEM8_P111_S1	Shocking is an early-stage company which is developing circuit protection products for the computer and telecommunications markets.
889331_14_ITEM8_P111_S2	At December 31, 2011, the company accounted for its investment at cost as it did not have significant influence over financing or operating activities.
889331_14_ITEM8_P111_S3	Total investment ownership in Shocking was $6.0 million or approximately 6.1% at December 31, 2011.
889331_14_ITEM8_P112_S0	In April 2012, the company invested an additional $10.0 million in certain common and preferred stock of Shocking, increasing its investment interest to $16.0 million or approximately 18.4%.
889331_14_ITEM8_P112_S1	In addition, in late-November 2012, the company provided an additional $2.0 million short-term secured loan to Shocking and determined that the company then had the ability to exert significant influence.
889331_14_ITEM8_P112_S2	As a result, the company began accounting for the investment in Shocking using the equity method.
889331_14_ITEM8_P112_S3	In accordance with ASC 323, the company retroactively recorded its proportional share of Shocking's operating losses, which amounted to approximately $4.0 million in 2012.
889331_14_ITEM8_P113_S0	The proportional amount of operating losses in 2011 was not material.
889331_14_ITEM8_P114_S0	Impairment During the fourth quarter of 2012, the company concluded that there was an other-than-temporary impairment which existed for its investment in Shocking.
889331_14_ITEM8_P114_S1	The company engaged a third-party valuation firm to assist in developing the fair value of the investment in Shocking.
889331_14_ITEM8_P114_S2	Based on the then fair value, the company determined that there was an impairment of approximately $3.3 million which was recorded as a non-operating impairment and equity loss of unconsolidated affiliate in the Consolidated Statements of Net Income.
889331_14_ITEM8_P115_S0	During the first quarter of 2013, the company fully impaired its investment in a loan receivable from Shocking owing to their filing for Chapter 7 bankruptcy on March 12, 2013.
889331_14_ITEM8_P115_S1	The impairment charge of approximately $10.7 million consisted of the remaining equity method investment of $8.7 million and a $2.0 million loan receivable, and reduced the carrying value of both the investment and loan receivable to zero at March 30, 2013.
889331_14_ITEM8_P116_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2013, the company incurred a $6.1 million charge to income tax expense related to the company s investment in Shocking which had been fully impaired and written off as described above.
889331_14_ITEM8_P116_S1	$3.3 million of this charge was pushed back to the first quarter of 2013 with the remaining $2.8 million (which related to the fourth quarter of 2012) recorded in the fourth quarter of 2013 as the correction of an immaterial error under ASC 250.
889331_14_ITEM8_P116_S2	This charge was determined to be a capital loss for tax purposes, instead of an ordinary loss as the company had previously determined in consultation with a third party expert.
889331_14_ITEM8_P117_S0	The effect of retroactively recording the company s proportional share of Shocking's operating losses (including the impact of differences in the company s equity in Shocking s net assets, which is attributable to amortizable intangible assets) for the quarterly periods in 2012 was as follows:

889331_14_ITEM8_P129_S0	Occasionally, the company uses financial instruments to manage its exposures to movements in commodity prices, foreign exchange and interest rates.
889331_14_ITEM8_P129_S1	The use of these financial instruments modifies the company s exposure to these risks with the goal of reducing the risk or cost to the company.
889331_14_ITEM8_P129_S2	The company does not use derivatives for trading purposes and is not a party to leveraged derivative contracts.
889331_14_ITEM8_P130_S0	The company recognizes all derivative instruments as either assets or liabilities at fair value in the Consolidated Balance Sheets.
889331_14_ITEM8_P130_S1	The fair value is based upon either market quotes for actively traded instruments or independent bids for non-exchange traded instruments.
889331_14_ITEM8_P130_S2	The company formally documents its hedge relationships, including identifying the hedging instruments and the hedged items, as well as its risk management objectives and strategies for undertaking the hedge transaction.
889331_14_ITEM8_P131_S0	This process includes linking derivatives that are designated as hedges of specific assets, liabilities, firm commitments or forecasted transactions to the hedged risk.
889331_14_ITEM8_P131_S1	On the date the derivative is entered into, the company designates the derivative as a fair value hedge, cash flow hedge or a net investment hedge, and accounts for the derivative in accordance with its designation.
889331_14_ITEM8_P131_S2	The company also formally assesses, both at inception and at least quarterly thereafter, whether the derivatives are highly effective in offsetting changes in either the fair value or cash flows of the hedged item.
889331_14_ITEM8_P131_S3	If it is determined that a derivative ceases to be a highly effective hedge, or if the anticipated transaction is no longer likely to occur, the company discontinues hedge accounting, and any deferred gains or losses are recorded in the respective measurement period.
889331_14_ITEM8_P131_S4	The company currently does not have any outstanding derivative instruments.
889331_14_ITEM8_P132_S0	In determining fair value, the company uses various valuation approaches within the fair value measurement framework.
889331_14_ITEM8_P132_S1	Fair value measurements are determined based on the assumptions that market participants would use in pricing an asset or liability.
889331_14_ITEM8_P133_S0	Applicable accounting literature establishes a hierarchy for inputs used in measuring fair value that maximizes the use of observable inputs and minimizes the use of unobservable inputs by requiring that the most observable inputs be used when available.
889331_14_ITEM8_P133_S1	Applicable accounting literature defines levels within the hierarchy based on the reliability of inputs as follows:
889331_14_ITEM8_P134_S0	Level 1 Valuations based on unadjusted quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets; Level 2 Valuations based on quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities or identical assets or liabilities in less active markets, such as dealer or broker markets; and Level 3 Valuations derived from valuation techniques in which one or more significant inputs or significant value drivers are unobservable, such as pricing models, discounted cash flow models and similar techniques not based on market, exchange, dealer or broker-traded transactions.
889331_14_ITEM8_P135_S0	Following is a description of the valuation methodologies used for instruments measured at fair value and their classification in the valuation hierarchy.
889331_14_ITEM8_P136_S0	Equity securities listed on a national market or exchange are valued at the last sales price.
889331_14_ITEM8_P136_S1	Such securities are further detailed in Note 5 and classified within Level 1 of the valuation hierarchy.
889331_14_ITEM8_P137_S0	and then an option pricing method to allocate the equity value to the various classes of stock in Shocking s capital structure, including Series C and common shares held by the company.
889331_14_ITEM8_P137_S1	Significant unobservable inputs used included an expected two years until liquidity event, a volatility of 35% and a risk free rate of 0.44%.
889331_14_ITEM8_P137_S2	The investment is categorized as Level 3.
889331_14_ITEM8_P138_S0	There were no changes during the year ended December 28, 2013 to the company s valuation techniques used to measure asset and liability fair values on a recurring basis.
889331_14_ITEM8_P138_S1	As of December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012, the company held no non-financial assets or liabilities that are required to be measured at fair value on a recurring basis.

889331_14_ITEM8_P140_S0	The following table presents assets measured at fair value by classification within the fair value hierarchy as of December 29, 2012 (in thousands):

889331_14_ITEM8_P141_S1	Due to their short-term maturity, the carrying amounts of cash and cash equivalents, short-term investments and accounts receivable approximate their fair values.
889331_14_ITEM8_P141_S2	The company s long-term debt fair value approximates book value at December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012.
889331_14_ITEM8_P142_S0	Included in other long-term liabilities is an accrual related to former coal mining operations at Littelfuse GmbH (formerly known as Heinrich Industries, AG) for the amounts of 2.2 million ($3.1 million) and 2.4 million ($3.1 million) at December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012, respectively.
889331_14_ITEM8_P143_S0	Management accrues for losses associated with litigation and environmental claims based on management's best estimate of future costs when such losses are probable and reasonably able to be estimated.
889331_14_ITEM8_P144_S0	Management, in conjunction with an independent third-party used to prepare an annual engineering study, performs an annual evaluation of the former coal mining operations in order to develop its estimate of their probable future obligations in regard to remediating the dangers (such as a shaft collapse) of abandoned coal mine shafts in the former coal mining operations.
889331_14_ITEM8_P144_S1	The ultimate determination can only be done after respective investigations because the concrete conditions are mostly unknown at this time.
889331_14_ITEM8_P144_S2	The accrual is not discounted as management cannot reasonably estimate when such remediation efforts will take place.
