889331_15_ITEM6_P0_S0	The information presented below provides selected financial data of the company during the past five fiscal years and should be read in conjunction with Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and the Consolidated Financial Statements and Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Item 7 and Item 8, respectively, for the respective years presented (amounts in thousands, except per share data):
889331_15_ITEM7_P0_S0	Introduction Littelfuse, Inc. and its subsidiaries (the company or Littelfuse or we or our ) is the worldwide leader in circuit protection offering the industry s broadest and deepest portfolio of circuit protection products and solutions.
889331_15_ITEM7_P0_S1	The company s devices protect products in virtually every market that uses electrical energy, from consumer electronics to automobiles to industrial equipment.
889331_15_ITEM7_P0_S2	The company conducts its business through three reportable segments, which are defined by markets and consist of Electronics, Automotive, and Electrical.
889331_15_ITEM7_P0_S3	The company s customer base includes original equipment manufacturers, tier one automotive suppliers and distributors.
889331_15_ITEM7_P1_S0	In addition to protecting and growing its core circuit protection business, Littelfuse has been investing in power control and sensing technologies.
889331_15_ITEM7_P1_S1	These newer platforms, combined with the company s strong balance sheet and operating cash flow, provide opportunities for increased organic and acquisition growth.
889331_15_ITEM7_P1_S2	In 2012, the company set a five-year strategic target plan to grow annual sales at 15% per year; 5% organically and 10% through acquisitions.
889331_15_ITEM7_P1_S3	As of December 27, 2014, two years into the five-year plan, the company has achieved an annual sales growth of 13%; 5% organically and 8% through acquisitions.
889331_15_ITEM7_P1_S4	The company remains focused on only those acquisitions that will add shareholder value.
889331_15_ITEM7_P1_S5	Overall, the company believes its strategy is sound, the fundamentals of its business have not changed, and its long-term goals are achievable.
889331_15_ITEM7_P2_S0	To maximize shareholder value, the company s primary strategic goals are to:
889331_15_ITEM7_P3_S0	The company serves markets that are directly impacted by global economic trends with significant exposures to the consumer electronics, automotive, industrial and mining end markets.
889331_15_ITEM7_P3_S1	The company s results will be impacted positively or negatively by changes in these end markets.
889331_15_ITEM7_P4_S0	Electronics Segment Overview The Electronics segment, which accounts for 48% of total sales, has produced solid revenue growth and substantial margin improvement over the last few years.
889331_15_ITEM7_P4_S1	In 2014, sales increased 12% (7% excluding acquisitions) and operating margin increased from 19.0% to 21.2% reflecting growth in all regions.
889331_15_ITEM7_P4_S2	The company believe this is the result of a stable electronics market combined with ongoing design wins and market share gains for Littelfuse.
889331_15_ITEM7_P5_S0	The electronics business is affected by seasonality.
889331_15_ITEM7_P5_S1	Sales are typically weaker in the first and fourth quarters and stronger in the second quarter and third quarters.
889331_15_ITEM7_P5_S2	This reflects the production ramp up for consumer electronics in advance of the year-end holidays and other factors.
889331_15_ITEM7_P6_S0	Fourth quarter 2014 sales for Electronics were consistent with normal seasonality as channel inventories remain at appropriate levels.
889331_15_ITEM7_P6_S1	The book-to-bill ratio of 1.06 (1.0 excluding sensors) at the end of the fourth quarter is also consistent with normal seasonal trends .
889331_15_ITEM7_P7_S0	The Automotive segment, which accounts for 38% of sales, has been the company s fastest growing business over the last few years.
889331_15_ITEM7_P8_S0	Passenger car fuse sales continue to outperform global car production due primarily to the success of the company s new high current fuses which are driving increases in content per vehicle.
889331_15_ITEM7_P8_S1	Commercial vehicle products had their best year ever with double-digit sales growth and improved operating margin driven by strength in the North American heavy duty truck market and integration-related cost savings.
889331_15_ITEM7_P8_S2	Automotive sensors also had their second consecutive year of double-digit sales growth primarily reflecting ramp-up of new solar sensor and speed and position sensor platforms.
889331_15_ITEM7_P8_S3	In summary, sales increased in all three major areas of the Automotive business, and while the company is currently experiencing headwinds from the weaker euro, it anticipates continued growth in the year ahead.
889331_15_ITEM7_P9_S0	The Electrical segment, which accounts for about 14% of total sales, has been the company s most challenging segment for the past two years.
889331_15_ITEM7_P9_S1	In 2014, Electrical sales declined 6% (22% excluding the acquisition of SymCom) reflecting the depressed global mining market, a difficult year for solar sales and continued weakness in non-residential construction.
889331_15_ITEM7_P10_S0	Toward the end of 2014, the company began seeing signs of improvement in two of its most important end markets: potash mining and non-residential construction.
889331_15_ITEM7_P10_S1	While these positive trends did not significantly impact 2014, the company expects these trends to contribute to growth in 2015.
889331_15_ITEM7_P10_S2	In addition, the company expects improved performance for SymCom in 2015 reflecting new product introductions and progress on integration activities.
889331_15_ITEM7_P11_S0	On January 3, 2014, the company acquired 100% of SymCom, Inc. ( SymCom ) for $52.8 million (net of cash acquired).
889331_15_ITEM7_P11_S1	Located in Rapid City, South Dakota, SymCom provides overload relays and pump controllers primarily to the industrial market.
889331_15_ITEM7_P11_S2	The acquisition allows the company to strengthen its position in the relay products market by adding new products and new customers within its Electrical business unit segment.
889331_15_ITEM7_P12_S0	On May 31, 2013, the company acquired 100% of Hamlin, Inc. ( Hamlin ) from Key Safety Systems, for $144.4 million (net of cash acquired).
889331_15_ITEM7_P13_S0	Hamlin is a manufacturer of sensor technology providing standard products and custom solutions for leading global manufacturers in the automotive and electronic industries.
889331_15_ITEM7_P13_S1	The acquisition allows the company to expand its automotive and electronics product offerings in the global sensor market in both the Automotive and Electronics business segments.
889331_15_ITEM7_P14_S0	U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principl e s ( GAAP ) dictates annual and interim reporting standards for an enterprise s operating segments and related disclosures about its products, services, geographic areas and major customers.
889331_15_ITEM7_P14_S1	Within U.S. GAAP, an operating segment is defined as a component of an enterprise that engages in business activities from which it may earn revenues and incur expenses, and about which separate financial information is regularly evaluated by the Chief Operating Decision Maker ( CODM ) in deciding how to allocate resources.
889331_15_ITEM7_P14_S2	The CODM is the company s President and Chief Executive Officer.
889331_15_ITEM7_P14_S3	The following table is a summary of the company s business unit segments net sales by business unit and geography (in millions):
889331_15_ITEM7_P15_S0	(a) Sales by geography represent sales to customer or distributor locations.
889331_15_ITEM7_P15_S1	(b) 2014 and 2013 includes incremental Hamlin net sales of $36.5 million and $24.1 million, respectively.
889331_15_ITEM7_P15_S2	(c) 2014 and 2013 includes incremental Hamlin net sales of $20.2 million and $26.9 million, respectively.
889331_15_ITEM7_P15_S3	(d) 2013 includes incremental Accel and Terra Power net sales of $9.2 million and $5.7 million, respectively.
889331_15_ITEM7_P15_S4	(e) 2014 and 2013 include incremental Hamlin net sales of $16.7 million and $23.0 million, respectively.
889331_15_ITEM7_P15_S5	(f) 2014 and 2013 include incremental Hamlin net sales of $9.3 million and $11.6 million, respectively.
889331_15_ITEM7_P15_S6	(g) 2014 and 2013 include incremental Hamlin net sales of $10.4 million and $16.4 million, respectively.
889331_15_ITEM7_P15_S7	(h) 2014 includes incremental SymCom net sales of $19.6 million.
889331_15_ITEM7_P16_S0	Business unit segment information is described more fully in Note 15 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_15_ITEM7_P17_S0	The following discussion provides an analysis of the information contained in the Consolidated Financial Statements and accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements at December 27, 2014 and December 28, 2013, and for the three fiscal years ended December 27, 2014, December 28, 2013 and December 29, 2012.
889331_15_ITEM7_P18_S0	The following table summarizes the company s consolidated results of operations for the periods presented.
889331_15_ITEM7_P18_S1	The results include incremental activity from the company s business acquisitions as described, where applicable, in the below analysis.
889331_15_ITEM7_P18_S2	There were also additional expenses and accounting adjustments during 2014.
889331_15_ITEM7_P18_S3	These include a $2.8 million inventory adjustment in 2014 related to the SymCom acquisition as described in Note 2, $0.4 million in acquisition-related costs, $3.2 million in severance charges related to the Lake Mills, Wisconsin and Matamoros, Mexico locations, $2.2 million in internal legal restructuring costs that will enable the up-streaming of cash to the U.S., and $0.3 million in asset impairments.
889331_15_ITEM7_P19_S0	Fiscal year 2014 also included $3.9 million in foreign currency losses primarily attributable to changes in the value of both the euro and Philippine peso against the U.S. dollar while fiscal year 2013 included $3.3 million in foreign currency gains primarily related to the value of the Philippine peso against the dollar.
889331_15_ITEM7_P20_S0	Net sales increased $94.1 million or 12% to $852.0 million for fiscal year 2014 compared to $757.9 million in fiscal year 2013 due primarily to an incremental $56.1 million from business acquisitions and growth in electronic and automotive products, offset by lower electrical sales.
889331_15_ITEM7_P20_S1	The company also experienced $0.4 million in unfavorable foreign currency effects in 2014 as compared to 2013 primarily resulting from sales denominated in Canadian dollars and Japanese yen.
889331_15_ITEM7_P20_S2	During the fourth quarter of 2014, sales were negatively impacted by the steep decline in the euro.
889331_15_ITEM7_P20_S3	Excluding acquisitions and currency effects, net sales increased $38.5 million or 5% year over year.
889331_15_ITEM7_P20_S4	The Automotive business segment sales increased $58.2 million or 22% to $325.4 million.
889331_15_ITEM7_P20_S5	The Electronics business segment sales increased $43.0 million or 12% to $410.1 million, and the Electrical business segment sales decreased $7.1 million or 6% to $116.5 million.
889331_15_ITEM7_P20_S6	automotive and electronic products partially offset by slowing demand for the company s electrical products.
889331_15_ITEM7_P21_S0	The increase in Automotive sales was primarily due to strong organic growth in all product categories and an incremental $20.2 million in sales from Hamlin.
889331_15_ITEM7_P21_S1	Currency effects increased sales by $0.6 million for the full year 2014 compared to 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P21_S2	Excluding incremental sales from Hamlin and currency effects, Automotive sales increased $37.3 million or 14% year over year due primarily to increases in content per vehicle and strength in the heavy truck market.
889331_15_ITEM7_P22_S0	The increase in Electronics sales reflected solid growth for both semiconductor and passive components and incremental sales from Hamlin of $16.3 million.
889331_15_ITEM7_P22_S1	In addition, sales were positively impacted by net favorable currency effects of $0.2 million for the full year 2014.
889331_15_ITEM7_P22_S2	Excluding acquisitions and currency effects, Electronics sales increased $26.5 million or 7% year over year.
889331_15_ITEM7_P23_S0	The decrease in Electrical sales was primarily from declines in custom and relay sales into the mining market and power fuses into the solar market.
889331_15_ITEM7_P23_S1	These declines more than offset incremental sales of $19.6 million from the SymCom acquisition in 2014.
889331_15_ITEM7_P23_S2	The Electrical segment experienced net unfavorable currency effects of $1.3 million primarily from sales denominated in Canadian dollars.
889331_15_ITEM7_P23_S3	Excluding incremental sales and currency effects, Electrical sales decreased $25.4 million or 21% year over year.
889331_15_ITEM7_P24_S0	On a geographic basis, sales in the Americas increased $35.3 million or 10% in 2014 as compared to 2013 due primarily to incremental sales from business acquisitions of $36.3 million offset by $1.4 million in unfavorable currency effects resulting from sales denominated in Canadian dollars.
889331_15_ITEM7_P24_S1	Excluding acquisitions and currency effects, Americas sales increased $0.4 million or less than 1%.
889331_15_ITEM7_P24_S2	Increases in the company s Automotive and Electronics sales were mostly offset by a decline in Electrical sales.
889331_15_ITEM7_P24_S3	Automotive sales increased $33.4 million or 26% primarily reflecting incremental sales from acquisitions of $12.5 million, strong growth in the passenger vehicle market and growth in the commercial vehicle market.
889331_15_ITEM7_P24_S4	Electronics sales increased $9.6 million or 9% primarily reflecting higher demand and incremental sales from Hamlin of $4.3 million.
889331_15_ITEM7_P24_S5	Electrical sales decreased $7.7 million or 7% resulting from decreases in demand for protection relays and custom products due to continued weakness in the mining segment.
889331_15_ITEM7_P24_S6	This decrease more than offset $19.6 million in incremental sales from SymCom in 2014.
889331_15_ITEM7_P25_S0	European sales increased $27.1 million or 20% in 2014 compared to 2013 primarily due to strong demand for electronics and automotive products, incremental sales from Hamlin of $9.4 million and $1.0 million in favorable currency effects from sales denominated in euros.
889331_15_ITEM7_P25_S1	Excluding acquisitions and currency effects, European sales increased $16.8 million or 12%.
889331_15_ITEM7_P25_S2	This resulted from increases in the company s Electronics and Automotive sales partially offset by a decrease in Electrical sales.
889331_15_ITEM7_P25_S3	Automotive sales increased $18.2 million or 21% in 2014 primarily reflecting incremental sales from Hamlin sensors of $6.2 million and higher sales in the passenger vehicle markets driven primarily by increased content.
889331_15_ITEM7_P25_S4	Excluding the impact of incremental sales from Hamlin and favorable currency effects, Automotive sales increased $11.5 million or 13%.
889331_15_ITEM7_P25_S5	Electronics sales increased $9.2 million or 22% reflecting incremental sales from Hamlin of $3.2 million and higher demand in 2014.
889331_15_ITEM7_P25_S6	Electrical sales decreased $0.3 million or 4% in 2014 primarily from decreased demand in the marine market for relays.
889331_15_ITEM7_P26_S0	Asia-Pacific sales increased $31.7 million or 11% in 2014 compared to 2013 primarily due to increased demand across all product categories and incremental sales from Hamlin of $10.4 million.
889331_15_ITEM7_P26_S1	Currency effects amounted to less than $0.1 million.
889331_15_ITEM7_P26_S2	Excluding acquisitions and currency effects, Asia-Pacific sales increased $21.3 million or 8%.
889331_15_ITEM7_P26_S3	Electronics sales increased $24.2 million or 11% reflecting incremental sales from Hamlin of $8.9 million and increased sales in China offset by weakness in the Taiwan, Japan and Korea markets.
889331_15_ITEM7_P26_S4	Automotive sales increased $6.6 million or 12% reflecting incremental sales from acquisitions of $1.5 million and continued increased demand for passenger vehicles in China as well as gains in market share.
889331_15_ITEM7_P27_S0	Gross profit was $324.4 million or 38.1% of sales in 2014, compared to $296.2 million or 39.1% of sales in 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P27_S1	Gross profit in both 2014 and 2013 were negatively impacted by purchase accounting adjustments in cost of sales of $2.8 million and $1.5 million, respectively.
889331_15_ITEM7_P27_S2	These charges were the additional cost of goods sold for SymCom and Hamlin inventories which had been stepped up to fair value at the acquisition dates as required by purchase accounting rules.
889331_15_ITEM7_P27_S3	Additionally, 2014 gross profit was negatively impacted by $2.7 million in severance charges.
889331_15_ITEM7_P27_S4	These severance charges primarily related to post-Hamlin acquisition reorganization changes.
889331_15_ITEM7_P27_S5	Excluding the impact of these charges, gross profit was $329.9 million or 38.7% of sales as compared to $297.8 million or 39.3% of sales in 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P27_S6	The decrease in gross margin was primarily attributable to higher sales of sensors in 2014 which carry lower margins than the company s core products.
889331_15_ITEM7_P28_S0	Total operating expense was $190.6 million or 22.4% of net sales for 2014 compared to $166.4 million or 22.0% of net sales for 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P28_S1	The increase in operating expenses primarily reflects incremental operating expenses of $14.2 million from business acquisitions and $3.5 million in restructuring, acquisition and impairment costs, $2.2 million of which was to effect changes in the company s legal structure to allow tax-efficient repatriation of approximately $90.0 million of cash in the fourth quarter of 2014.
889331_15_ITEM7_P29_S0	Operating income was $133.8 million or 15.7% of net sales in 2014 compared to $129.9 million or 17.1% of net sales in the prior year.
889331_15_ITEM7_P29_S1	The increase in operating income and decrease in operating margin in the current year was due primarily to the factors affecting gross profit and operating expenses discussed above.
889331_15_ITEM7_P30_S0	Interest expense was $4.9 million in 2014 as compared to $2.9 million in 2013 and is primarily related to the company s increased borrowing to fund acquisitions.
889331_15_ITEM7_P31_S0	Impairment and equity in net loss of unconsolidated affiliate was $10.7 million in 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P31_S1	During the first quarter of 2013, the company fully impaired its investment in and loan receivable from Shocking Technologies, Inc. ( Shocking ) as described in Note 6 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_15_ITEM7_P32_S0	Foreign exchange (gain) loss was $3.9 million of loss in 2014 compared to $3.3 million of gain in 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P32_S1	The fluctuation in foreign exchange was primarily attributable to changes in the value of both the euro and the Philippine peso against the U.S. dollar in 2014 and the Philippine peso against the dollar in 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P33_S0	Other expense (income), net, consisting of interest income, royalties and non-operating income was $6.6 million of income in 2014 compared to $4.6 million of income in 2013 .
889331_15_ITEM7_P33_S1	The year-over-year increase in income primarily reflects higher interest income in 2014.
889331_15_ITEM7_P34_S0	Income before income taxes was $131.6 million in 2014 compared to $124.2 million in 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P34_S1	Income tax expense was $32.2 million in 2014 compared to $35.5 million in 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P34_S2	The 2014 effective income tax rate was 24.5% compared to 28.5% in 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P34_S3	The lower effective tax rate in 2014 is primarily related to the $6.1 million Shocking tax adjustment booked in 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P34_S4	The 2014 and 2013 effective tax rates are lower than the U.S. statutory tax rate primarily the result of income earned in low-tax jurisdictions.
889331_15_ITEM7_P35_S0	The following table summarizes the company s consolidated results of operations for the periods presented.
889331_15_ITEM7_P35_S1	The results include incremental activity from the company s business acquisitions as described, where applicable, in the below analysis.
889331_15_ITEM7_P35_S2	There were also additional expenses and accounting adjustments during 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P35_S3	These include a $1.5 million inventory adjustment in 2013 as described in Note 2, and $1.7 million in acquisition related operating expenses in 2013 both related to the Hamlin acquisition.
889331_15_ITEM7_P35_S4	Fiscal year 2013 included $3.3 million in foreign currency gains while fiscal year 2012 included $3.2 million in foreign currency losses, both primarily related to U.S. dollar gains or losses against the Philippine peso.
889331_15_ITEM7_P36_S0	Net sales increased $89.9 million or 13% to $757.9 million for fiscal year 2013 compared to $667.9 million in fiscal year 2012 due primarily to an incremental $66.0 million from business acquisitions and growth in electronic and automotive products, offset by lower electrical sales.
889331_15_ITEM7_P36_S1	The company also experienced $1.4 million in favorable foreign currency effects in 2013 as compared to 2012 primarily resulting from sales denominated in euros partially offset by sales denominated in Japanese yen and Canadian dollars.
889331_15_ITEM7_P36_S2	Excluding acquisitions and currency effects, net sales increased $22.6 million or 3% year over year.
889331_15_ITEM7_P36_S3	The Automotive business segment sales increased $61.0 million or 30% to $267.2 million.
889331_15_ITEM7_P36_S4	The Electronics business segment sales increased $37.6 million or 11% to $367.1 million, and the Electrical business segment sales decreased $8.6 million or 7% to $123.6 million.
889331_15_ITEM7_P36_S5	Sales levels in 2013, excluding acquisitions and currency effects, were positively impacted by increased demand for the company s automotive and electronic products partially offset by slowing demand for the company s custom mining products.
889331_15_ITEM7_P37_S0	The increase in Automotive sales was primarily due to an incremental $41.9 million in sales related to business acquisitions in 2013, strong worldwide growth in passenger vehicle fuses, growth in commercial vehicle products and favorable currency effects.
889331_15_ITEM7_P37_S1	Currency effects increased sales by $2.6 million in 2013 compared to 2012 primarily due to the euro.
889331_15_ITEM7_P37_S2	Excluding incremental sales from acquisitions and currency effects, Automotive sales increased $16.5 million or 8% year over year.
889331_15_ITEM7_P38_S0	The increase in Electronics sales reflected incremental sales from Hamlin of $24.1 million, improving demand across all geographies and a slightly more favorable macroeconomic outlook.
889331_15_ITEM7_P38_S1	In addition, sales were negatively impacted by net unfavorable currency effects of $0.2 million, primarily from sales denominated in Japanese yen.
889331_15_ITEM7_P38_S2	Excluding incremental sales from acquisitions and currency effects, Electronics sales increased $13.7 million or 4% year over year.
889331_15_ITEM7_P39_S0	The decrease in Electrical sales was primarily due to slowing demand for protection relays and custom products as a result of reduced potash mine expansion activity as well as the global downturn in the broader mining market.
889331_15_ITEM7_P39_S1	The decline was partially offset by stronger power fuse sales which increased 13% year-over-year primarily reflecting strength in the solar and HVAC markets as well as distributor conversions.
889331_15_ITEM7_P39_S2	The Electrical segment experienced net unfavorable currency effects of $1.0 million primarily from sales denominated in Canadian dollars.
889331_15_ITEM7_P39_S3	Excluding incremental sales from currency effects, Electrical sales decreased $7.6 million or 6% year over year.
889331_15_ITEM7_P40_S0	On a geographic basis, sales in the Americas increased $38.8 million or 13% in 2013 as compared to 2012 primarily due to incremental sales from business acquisitions of $32.4 million offset by $1.2 million in unfavorable currency effects resulting from sales denominated in Canadian dollars.
889331_15_ITEM7_P40_S1	Excluding incremental sales and currency effects, Americas sales increased $7.6 million or 3%.
889331_15_ITEM7_P40_S2	This increase resulted from an increase in the company s Automotive and Electronics business segments offset by a decline in the Electrical business segment.
889331_15_ITEM7_P40_S3	Automotive sales increased $31.3 million or 33% primarily reflecting incremental sales from acquisitions of $25.9 million, strong growth in the passenger vehicle market and growth in the commercial vehicle market.
889331_15_ITEM7_P40_S4	Electronics sales increased $14.4 million or 16% primarily reflecting incremental sales from Hamlin of $6.5 million and higher demand.
889331_15_ITEM7_P40_S5	Electrical sales decreased $7.0 million or 6% resulting from decreases in demand for protection relays and custom products due to continued weakness in the mining segment.
889331_15_ITEM7_P41_S0	European sales increased $29.3 million or 27% in 2013 compared to 2012 primarily due to incremental sales from business acquisitions of $15.7 million and favorable currency effects of $3.8 million primarily from sales denominated in euros.
889331_15_ITEM7_P41_S1	Excluding incremental sales and currency effects, European sales increased $9.8 million or 9%.
889331_15_ITEM7_P41_S2	This resulted from increases in the company s Electronics and Automotive business segments offset by a decrease in the Electrical business segment.
889331_15_ITEM7_P41_S3	Automotive sales increased $20.2 million or 30% in 2013 primarily reflecting incremental sales from business acquisitions of $11.7 million and higher sales in the passenger vehicle markets driven by increased content.
889331_15_ITEM7_P41_S4	Excluding the impact of incremental sales from acquisitions and unfavorable currency effects, primarily from a weaker euro, Automotive sales increased $6.2 million or 9%.
889331_15_ITEM7_P41_S5	Electronics sales increased $10.6 million or 33% reflecting incremental sales from Hamlin of $4.0 million and higher demand in 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P41_S6	Electrical sales decreased $1.6 million or 18% in 2013 primarily from decreased demand for nautical relays.
889331_15_ITEM7_P42_S0	Asia-Pacific sales increased $21.9 million or 9% in 2013 compared to 2012 primarily due to incremental sales from business acquisitions of $17.9 million offset by unfavorable currency effects of $1.2 million primarily from sales denominated in Japanese yen.
889331_15_ITEM7_P42_S1	Excluding the impact of incremental sales and currency effects, Asia-Pacific sales increased $5.2 million or 2%.
889331_15_ITEM7_P42_S2	Electronics sales increased $12.5 million or 6% reflecting incremental sales from Hamlin of $13.4 million and increased sales in China offset by weakness in the Taiwan, Japan and Korea markets.
889331_15_ITEM7_P42_S3	Automotive sales increased $9.5 million or 22% reflecting incremental sales from acquisitions of $4.5 million and continued increased demand for passenger vehicles in China as well as gains in market share.
889331_15_ITEM7_P43_S0	Gross profit was $296.2 million or 39.1% of sales in 2013, compared to $258.5 million or 38.7% of sales in 2012.
889331_15_ITEM7_P43_S1	Gross profit in both 2013 and 2012 were negatively impacted by purchase accounting adjustments in cost of sales of $1.5 million and $0.6 million, respectively.
889331_15_ITEM7_P43_S2	These charges were the additional cost of goods sold for Hamlin, Accel and Selco inventories which had been stepped up to fair value at the acquisition dates as required by purchase accounting rules.
889331_15_ITEM7_P43_S3	Excluding the impact of these charges, gross profit was $297.7 million or 39.3% of sales as compared to $259.1 million or 38.8% of sales in 2012.
889331_15_ITEM7_P43_S4	The increase in gross margin was primarily attributable to operating leverage on higher sales.

889331_15_ITEM7_P45_S1	The increase in operating income in the current year was due primarily to the increased sales and resulting operating leverage.

889331_15_ITEM7_P54_S0	On May 31, 2013, the company entered into a new credit agreement with J.P. Morgan Securities LLC for up to $325.0 million which consists of an unsecured revolving credit facility of $225.0 million and an unsecured term loan of $100.0 million.
889331_15_ITEM7_P54_S1	The new credit agreement is for a five year period.
889331_15_ITEM7_P54_S2	At December 27, 2014, the company had available $190.9 million of borrowing capacity under the credit agreement at an interest rate of LIBOR plus 1.25% (1.42% as of December 27, 2014).
889331_15_ITEM7_P55_S0	The credit agreement replaces the company s previous credit agreement dated June 13, 2011, which was terminated on May 31, 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P56_S0	On January 30, 2014, the company increased the unsecured revolving credit facility entered into on May 31, 2013, by $50.0 million thereby increasing the total revolver borrowing capacity from $225.0 million to $275.0 million.
889331_15_ITEM7_P57_S0	This arrangement contains covenants that, among other matters, impose limitations on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, future mergers, sales of assets, payment of dividends, and changes in control, as defined in the agreement.
889331_15_ITEM7_P57_S1	In addition, the company is required to satisfy certain financial covenants and tests relating to, among other matters, interest coverage and leverage.
889331_15_ITEM7_P57_S2	At December 27, 2014, the company was in compliance with all covenants under the credit agreement.
889331_15_ITEM7_P58_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2014, the company entered into an entrusted loan arrangement ( Entrusted Loan ) of RMB 110.0 million (approximately $17.9 million) between two of its China legal entities, Littelfuse Semiconductor (Wuxi) Company (the Lender ) and Suzhou Littelfuse OVS Ltd. (the Borrower ), utilizing Bank of America, N.A., Shanghai Branch as agent.
889331_15_ITEM7_P58_S1	Direct borrowing and lending between two commonly owned commercial entities is strictly forbidden under China s regulations requiring the use of a third party agent to enable loans between Chinese legal entities.
889331_15_ITEM7_P58_S2	As a result, the Entrusted Loan is reflected as both a long-term asset and long-term debt on the company s Consolidated Balance Sheets and is reflected in the investing and financing activities in its Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.
889331_15_ITEM7_P58_S3	Interest expense and interest income will be recorded between the lender and borrower with no net impact on the company s Consolidated Statements of Income since the amounts will be offsetting.
889331_15_ITEM7_P58_S4	The loan interest rate per annum is 5.25%.
889331_15_ITEM7_P58_S5	The Entrusted Loan is used to finance the operation and working capital needs of the borrower and matures in November 2019.
889331_15_ITEM7_P59_S0	For the fiscal year ended December 27, 2014, the company had $0.8 million available in letters of credit.
889331_15_ITEM7_P59_S1	No amounts were drawn under these letters of credit at December 27, 2014.

889331_15_ITEM7_P64_S2	This left the company with a cash balance of $297.6 million at December 27, 2014 .

889331_15_ITEM7_P72_S0	As of December 27, 2014, the company did not have any off-balance sheet arrangements, as defined under SEC rules.
889331_15_ITEM7_P72_S1	Specifically, the company was not liable for guarantees of indebtedness owed by third parties, the company was not directly liable for the debt of any unconsolidated entity and the company did not have any retained or contingent interest in assets.
889331_15_ITEM7_P73_S0	The company does not participate in transactions that generate relationships with unconsolidated entities or financial partnerships, such as entities often referred to as structured finance or special purpose entities.
889331_15_ITEM7_P74_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) amended prior authoritative guidance for revenue recognition which provides a single comprehensive model for entities to use in accounting for revenue arising from contracts with customers and will supersede most current revenue recognition guidance.
889331_15_ITEM7_P74_S1	The standard is effective for public entities for annual and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
889331_15_ITEM7_P74_S2	The guidance permits two implementation approaches, one requiring retrospective application of the new standard with restatement of prior years and one requiring prospective application of the new standard with disclosure of results under old standards.
889331_15_ITEM7_P74_S3	The company is currently evaluating the impact of the adoption of this accounting standard on its consolidated financial statements.
889331_15_ITEM7_P75_S0	In February 2013, the FASB issued authoritative guidance on the reporting of amounts reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income into net income or the balance sheet.
889331_15_ITEM7_P75_S1	Under the new guidance, in addition to the presentation of changes in accumulated balances, an entity shall present separately for each component of other comprehensive income, significant current period reclassifications out of accumulated other comprehensive income and other amounts of current-period other comprehensive income.
889331_15_ITEM7_P75_S2	Both before-tax and net-of-tax presentations are permitted.
889331_15_ITEM7_P75_S3	The guidance is effective for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P75_S4	The company adopted the guidance on December 28, 2013.
889331_15_ITEM7_P75_S5	There was no significant effect on its consolidated financial statements upon adoption.
889331_15_ITEM7_P76_S0	Certain of the accounting policies as discussed below require the application of significant judgment by management in selecting the appropriate estimates and assumptions for calculating amounts to record in the financial statements.
889331_15_ITEM7_P76_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates and assumptions, impacting the reported results of operations and financial position.
889331_15_ITEM7_P76_S2	Significant accounting policies are more fully described in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report.
889331_15_ITEM7_P76_S3	Certain accounting policies, however, are considered to be critical in that they are most important to the depiction of the company s financial condition and results of operations and their application requires management s subjective judgment in making estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain.
889331_15_ITEM7_P76_S4	The company believes the following accounting policies are the most critical to aid in fully understanding and evaluating its reported financial results, as they require management s most difficult, subjective or complex judgments, resulting from the need to make estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain.
889331_15_ITEM7_P76_S5	The company has reviewed these critical accounting policies and related disclosures with the Audit Committee of its Board of Directors.
889331_15_ITEM7_P77_S0	The company recognizes revenue on product sales in the period in which the sales process is complete.
889331_15_ITEM7_P77_S1	This generally occurs when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, products are shipped (FOB origin) to the customer in accordance with the terms of the sale, the risk of loss has been transferred, collectability is reasonably assured and the pricing is fixed and determinable.
889331_15_ITEM7_P77_S2	At the end of each period, for those shipments where title to the products and the risk of loss and rewards of ownership do not transfer until the product has been received by the customer, the company adjusts revenues and cost of sales for the delay between the time that the products are shipped and when they are received by the customer.
889331_15_ITEM7_P78_S0	The company s distribution channels are primarily through direct sales and independent third party distributors.
889331_15_ITEM7_P79_S0	The company accepts orders from customers based on long term purchasing contracts and written sales agreements.
889331_15_ITEM7_P79_S1	Contract pricing and selling agreement terms are based on market factors, costs and competition.
889331_15_ITEM7_P79_S2	Pricing normally is negotiated as an adjustment (premium or discount) from the company s published price lists.
889331_15_ITEM7_P79_S3	The customer is invoiced when the company s products are shipped to them in accordance with the terms of the sales agreement.
889331_15_ITEM7_P80_S0	the ability to receive price adjustments on products previously shipped and invoiced.
889331_15_ITEM7_P80_S1	This practice is common in the industry and is referred to as a ship and debit program.
889331_15_ITEM7_P80_S2	This program allows the distributor to debit the company for the difference between the distributors contracted price and a lower price for specific transactions.
889331_15_ITEM7_P81_S0	Under certain circumstances (usually in a competitive situation or large volume opportunity), a distributor will request authorization to reduce its price to its buyer.
889331_15_ITEM7_P81_S1	If the company approves such a reduction, the distributor is authorized to debit its account for the difference between the contracted price and the lower approved price.
889331_15_ITEM7_P81_S2	The company establishes reserves for this program based on historic activity and actual authorizations for the debit and recognizes these debits as a reduction of revenue.
889331_15_ITEM7_P82_S0	The company has a return to stock policy whereby a customer with previous authorization from Littelfuse management can return previously purchased goods for full or partial credit.
889331_15_ITEM7_P82_S1	The company establishes an estimated allowance for these returns based on historic activity.
889331_15_ITEM7_P82_S2	Sales revenue and cost of sales are reduced to anticipate estimated returns.
889331_15_ITEM7_P83_S0	Volume Rebates : The company offers incentives to certain customers to achieve specific quarterly or annual sales targets.
889331_15_ITEM7_P83_S1	If customers achieve their sales targets, they are entitled to rebates.
889331_15_ITEM7_P83_S2	The company estimates the future cost of these rebates and recognizes this estimated cost as a reduction to revenue as products are sold.
889331_15_ITEM7_P84_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts: The company evaluates the collectability of its trade receivables based on a combination of factors.
889331_15_ITEM7_P84_S1	The company regularly analyzes its significant customer accounts and, when the company becomes aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the company records a specific reserve for bad debt to reduce the related receivable to the amount the company reasonably believes is collectible.
889331_15_ITEM7_P84_S2	The company also records allowances for all other customers based on a variety of factors including the length of time the receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, macroeconomic considerations and past experience.
889331_15_ITEM7_P85_S0	Historically, the allowance for doubtful accounts has been adequate to cover bad debts.
889331_15_ITEM7_P85_S1	If circumstances related to specific customers change, the estimates of the recoverability of receivables could be further adjusted.
889331_15_ITEM7_P86_S0	The company performs regular detailed assessments of inventory, which include a review of, among other factors, demand requirements, product life cycle and development plans, component cost trends, product pricing, shelf life and quality issues.
889331_15_ITEM7_P86_S1	Based on the analysis, the company records adjustments to inventory for excess quantities, obsolescence or impairment when appropriate to reflect inventory at net realizable value.
889331_15_ITEM7_P87_S0	Historically, inventory reserves have been adequate to reflect inventory at net realizable values.
889331_15_ITEM7_P87_S1	During 2014, 2013 and 2012, the company was required to step up the value of inventory acquired in business combinations to its selling prices less the cost to sell under business combination accounting.
889331_15_ITEM7_P87_S2	This was approximately $2.8 million for SymCom in 2014, $1.5 million for Hamlin in 2013 and $0.6 million in 2012 for Accel and Selco.
889331_15_ITEM7_P88_S0	The company annually tests goodwill for impairment on the first day of its fiscal fourth quarter or at an interim date if there is an event or change in circumstances that indicates the asset may be impaired.
889331_15_ITEM7_P88_S1	The company has eight reporting units for goodwill testing purposes.
889331_15_ITEM7_P88_S2	Management determines the fair value of each of its reporting units by using a discounted cash flow model (which includes forecasted five-year income statement and working capital projections, a market-based weighted average cost of capital and terminal values after five years) to estimate market value.
889331_15_ITEM7_P88_S3	In addition, the company compares its derived enterprise value on a consolidated basis to the company s market capitalization as of its test date to ensure its derived value approximates the market value of the company when taken as a whole.
889331_15_ITEM7_P89_S0	As of the most recent annual test conducted on September 27, 2014, the company concluded the fair value of each of the reporting units exceeded its carrying value of invested capital and therefore, no potential goodwill impairment existed.
889331_15_ITEM7_P89_S1	Specifically, the company noted that its headroom, defined as the excess of fair value over the carrying value of invested capital, was 114%, 128%, 128%, 190%, 26%, 6%, 82% and 83% for its electronics (non-silicon), electronics (silicon), passenger car, commercial vehicle products, sensors, relays, custom products and fuse reporting units, respectively, at September 27, 2014.
889331_15_ITEM7_P89_S2	Certain key assumptions used in the annual test included a discount rate of 11.8% and a long-term growth rate of 3.0% was used for all reporting units except for relay which had a discount rate of 12.8% as a result of a 1.0% premium factor.
889331_15_ITEM7_P90_S0	In addition, the company performed a sensitivity test at September 27, 2014 that showed either a 100 basis point increase in its discount rate or a 100 basis point decrease in the long-term growth rate for each reporting unit would not have changed the company s conclusion that no potential goodwill impairment existed at September 27, 2014.
889331_15_ITEM7_P91_S0	The company will continue to perform a goodwill impairment test as required on an annual basis and on an interim basis, if certain conditions exist.
889331_15_ITEM7_P91_S1	Factors the company considers important, which could result in changes to its estimates, include underperformance relative to historical or projected future operating results and declines in acquisitions and trading multiples.
889331_15_ITEM7_P91_S2	Due to the diverse end user base and non-discretionary product demand, the company does not believe its future operating results will vary significantly relative to its historical and projected future operating results.
889331_15_ITEM7_P92_S0	The company evaluates long-lived asset groups on an ongoing basis.
889331_15_ITEM7_P92_S1	Long-lived asset groups are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the related asset may not be recoverable.
889331_15_ITEM7_P93_S0	Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of the asset to future undiscounted cash flows expected to be generated by the asset group.
889331_15_ITEM7_P93_S1	If it is determined to be impaired, the impairment recognized is measured by the amount by which the carrying value of the asset exceeds its fair value.
889331_15_ITEM7_P93_S2	The company s estimates of future cash flows from such assets could be impacted if it underperforms relative to historical or projected future operating results.
889331_15_ITEM7_P93_S3	The company recorded asset impairment charges of $0.3 million, $0.0 million and $0.5 million for the fiscal years ended 2014, 2013 and 2012, respectively.
889331_15_ITEM7_P93_S4	Further information regarding asset impairments is provided in Note 11 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_15_ITEM7_P94_S0	The company evaluates its investments quarterly or when there is an indicator of a potential impairment.
889331_15_ITEM7_P94_S1	During the fourth quarter of 2012, company management determined that an indicator of impairment existed for the company s investment in Shocking Technologies, Inc.
889331_15_ITEM7_P94_S2	Subsequently, the company engaged a third party asset valuation firm to perform an analysis for purposes of assisting management in determining the amount of impairment.
889331_15_ITEM7_P94_S3	Further information regarding the impairment of the company s investment in Shocking Technologies, Inc. is provided in Note 6 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_15_ITEM7_P95_S0	Environmental liabilities are accrued based on estimates of the probability of potential future environmental exposure.
889331_15_ITEM7_P95_S1	Costs related to on-going maintenance of environmental sites are expensed as incurred.
889331_15_ITEM7_P95_S2	If actual or estimated probable future losses exceed the company s recorded liability for such claims, it would record additional charges as other expense during the period in which the actual loss or change in estimate occurred.
889331_15_ITEM7_P96_S0	The company evaluates its reserve for coal mine remediation annually utilizing a third party expert.
889331_15_ITEM7_P97_S0	Littelfuse has a number of company-sponsored defined benefit plans primarily in North America, Europe and the Asia-Pacific region.
889331_15_ITEM7_P97_S1	The company recognizes the full unfunded status of these plans on the balance sheet.
889331_15_ITEM7_P97_S2	Actuarial gains and losses and prior service costs and credits are recognized as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income.
889331_15_ITEM7_P98_S0	Accounting for pensions requires estimating the future benefit cost and recognizing the cost over the employee s expected period of employment with the company.
889331_15_ITEM7_P98_S1	Certain assumptions are required in the calculation of pension costs and obligations.
889331_15_ITEM7_P98_S2	These assumptions include the discount rate, salary scales and the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
889331_15_ITEM7_P99_S0	The discount rate is intended to represent the rate at which pension benefit obligations could be settled by purchase of an annuity contract.
889331_15_ITEM7_P99_S1	These assumptions are subject to change based on stock and bond market returns and other economic factors.
889331_15_ITEM7_P99_S2	Actual results that differ from the company s assumptions are accumulated and amortized over future periods and, therefore, generally affect its recognized expense and accrued liability in such future periods.
889331_15_ITEM7_P99_S3	While the company believes that its assumptions are appropriate given current economic conditions and its actual experience, significant differences in results or significant changes in the company s assumptions may materially affect its pension obligations and related future expense.
889331_15_ITEM7_P99_S4	Further information regarding these plans is provided in Note 12 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_15_ITEM7_P100_S0	Equity-based compensation expense is recorded for stock-option awards and restricted share units based upon the fair values of the awards.
889331_15_ITEM7_P101_S0	The fair value of stock-option awards is estimated at the grant date using the Black-Scholes option pricing model, which includes assumptions for volatility, expected term, risk-free interest rate and dividend yield.
889331_15_ITEM7_P101_S1	Expected volatility is based on implied volatilities from traded options on Littelfuse stock, historical volatility of Littelfuse stock and other factors.
889331_15_ITEM7_P101_S2	Historical data is used to estimate employee termination experience and the expected term of the options.
889331_15_ITEM7_P102_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect at the time of grant.
889331_15_ITEM7_P102_S1	The company initiated a quarterly cash dividend in 2010 and expects to continue making cash dividend payments in the foreseeable future.
889331_15_ITEM7_P103_S0	Total equity-based compensation expense for all equity compensation plans was $9.4 million, $8.9 million, and $7.3 million in 2014, 2013, and 2012, respectively.
889331_15_ITEM7_P103_S1	Further information regarding this expense is provided in Note 13 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_15_ITEM7_P104_S0	The company accounts for income taxes using the liability method.
889331_15_ITEM7_P105_S0	Deferred taxes are recognized for the future effects of temporary differences between financial and income tax reporting using tax rates in effect for the years in which the differences are expected to reverse.
889331_15_ITEM7_P105_S1	The company recognizes deferred taxes for temporary differences, operating loss carryforwards and tax credit carryforwards.
889331_15_ITEM7_P105_S2	Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if it is more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
889331_15_ITEM7_P106_S0	Federal and state income taxes are provided on the portion of foreign income that is expected to be remitted to the U.S. and be taxable.
889331_15_ITEM7_P107_S0	The company recognizes the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical merits of the position.
889331_15_ITEM7_P107_S1	The tax benefits recognized in the financial statements from such a position are measured based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized upon ultimate settlement.
889331_15_ITEM7_P108_S0	Further information regarding income taxes, including a detailed reconciliation of current year activity, is provided in Note 14 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report.
889331_15_ITEM7_P109_S0	Sales for the first quarter of 2015 are expected to be in the range of $202.0 to $212.0 million which represents flat revenue at the midpoint compared to the prior year after currency effects (approximately 4% growth in constant currency).
889331_15_ITEM7_P109_S1	Earnings for the first quarter of 2015 are expected to be in the range of $1.00 to $1.14 per diluted share.
889331_15_ITEM7_P109_S2	This includes negative currency effects of approximately $0.10 compared to the prior year.
889331_15_ITEM7_P110_S0	For the year 2015, the company expects to face substantial currency headwinds.
889331_15_ITEM7_P110_S1	At current exchange rates, sales would be negatively impacted by approximately $30 million and earnings by approximately $0.40 per share compared to 2014.
889331_15_ITEM7_P110_S2	The company has planned improvements in the Electrical, Automotive sensor and commercial vehicle businesses and believes it can achieve modest sales growth and earnings in 2015.
889331_15_ITEM7_P111_S0	The company expects capital expenditures in 2015 to be in the range of $35 to $40 million primarily for capacity to support volume increases, new product introductions and restructuring activities.
889331_15_ITEM7_P111_S1	The company expects to fund 2015 capital expansion from operating cash flows.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The company is exposed to market risk from changes in interest rates, foreign exchange rates and commodity prices.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The company had $177.3 million in debt outstanding at December 27, 2014 related to the unsecured revolving credit facility and term loan which are described in Item 7 under Liquidity and Capital Resources .
889331_15_ITEM7A_P1_S1	While this debt has a variable interest rate of LIBOR plus 1.25%, the company s interest expense is not materially sensitive to changes in interest rate levels since debt levels and potential interest expense increases are insignificant relative to earnings.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The majority of the company s operations consist of manufacturing and sales activities in foreign countries.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The company has manufacturing facilities in the U.S., Mexico, Canada, Denmark, China, Lithuania and the Philippines.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P2_S2	During 2014, sales to customers outside the U.S. were approximately 63% of total net sales.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P2_S3	Substantially all sales in Europe are denominated in euros and substantially all sales in the Asia-Pacific region are denominated in U.S. dollars, Japanese yen, Korean won, Chinese yuan and Taiwanese dollars.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P3_S0	The company s foreign exchange exposures result primarily from sale of products in foreign currencies, foreign currency denominated purchases, employee-related and other costs of running operations in foreign countries and translation of balance sheet accounts denominated in foreign currencies.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P3_S1	The company s most significant long exposure is to the euro, with lesser long exposures to the Canadian dollar, Japanese yen and Korean won.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P3_S2	The company s most significant short exposures are to the Mexican peso, Philippine peso and Chinese yuan.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P3_S3	Changes in foreign exchange rates could affect the company s sales, costs, balance sheet values and earnings.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P3_S4	The company uses netting and offsetting intercompany account management techniques to reduce known foreign currency exposures where possible and also, from time to time, utilizes derivative instruments to hedge certain foreign currency exposures deemed to be material.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The company uses various metals in the manufacturing of its products, including copper, zinc, tin, gold and silver.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P4_S1	Prices of these commodities can and do fluctuate significantly, which can impact the company s earnings.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P4_S2	The most significant of these exposures is to copper, zinc, gold and silver, where at current prices and volumes, a 10% price change would affect annual pre-tax profit by approximately $1.5 million for copper, $0.7 million for zinc, $0.3 million for gold and $0.9 million for silver.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The cost of oil fluctuated dramatically over the past several years.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P5_S1	Consequently, there is a risk that a return to high prices for oil and electricity in 2015 could have a significant impact on the company s transportation and utility expenses.
889331_15_ITEM7A_P6_S0	While the company is exposed to significant changes in certain commodity prices and foreign currency exchange rates, the company actively monitors these exposures and takes various actions to mitigate any negative impacts of these exposures.
889331_15_ITEM8_P0_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders of Littelfuse, Inc.
889331_15_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheet of Littelfuse, Inc. (a Delaware corporation) and subsidiaries (the Company) as of December 27, 2014, and the related consolidated statements of net income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for the year ended December 27, 2014.
889331_15_ITEM8_P1_S1	Our audit of the basic consolidated financial statements included the financial statement schedule listed in the index appearing under Item 15(a)(2).
889331_15_ITEM8_P1_S2	These financial statements and financial statement schedule are the responsibility of the Company s management.
889331_15_ITEM8_P1_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements and financial statement schedule based on our audit.
889331_15_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
889331_15_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
889331_15_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
889331_15_ITEM8_P3_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
889331_15_ITEM8_P3_S2	We believe that our audit provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
889331_15_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Littelfuse, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 27, 2014, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for the year ended December 27, 2014 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
889331_15_ITEM8_P4_S1	Also in our opinion, the related financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic consolidated financial statements taken as a whole, present fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth therein.
889331_15_ITEM8_P5_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 27, 2014, based on criteria established in the 2013 Internal Control - Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO), and our report dated February 24, 2015, expressed an unqualified opinion.
