889331_16_ITEM15_P1081_S0	Pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 (subsections (a) and (b) of Section 1350, Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code), each of the undersigned officers of Littelfuse, Inc. ( the Company ) does hereby certify that to his knowledge:
889331_16_ITEM15_P1082_S0	The Annual Report of the Company on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended January 2, 2016 ( the Report ) fully complies with the requirements of section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and the information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
889331_17_ITEM1_P0_S0	Littelfuse, Inc., was incorporated under the laws of the State of Delaware in 1991.
889331_17_ITEM1_P0_S1	References herein to the company, we, our or Littelfuse refer to Littelfuse, Inc. and its subsidiaries.
889331_17_ITEM1_P0_S2	References herein to 2016 , fiscal 2016 or fiscal year 2016 refer to the fiscal year ended December 31, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM1_P0_S3	References herein to 2015 , fiscal 2015 or fiscal year 2015 refer to the fiscal year ended January 2, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM1_P0_S4	References herein to 2014 , fiscal 2014 or fiscal year 2014 refer to the fiscal year ended December 27, 2014.
889331_17_ITEM1_P1_S0	The company operates on a 52-53 week fiscal year (4-4-5 basis) ending on the Saturday closest to December 31.
889331_17_ITEM1_P1_S1	Therefore, the financial results of certain fiscal years and the associated 14 week quarters will not be exactly comparable to the prior and subsequent 52 week fiscal years and the associated quarters having only 13 weeks.
889331_17_ITEM1_P1_S2	As a result of using this convention, each of fiscal 2016 and fiscal 2014 contained 52 weeks whereas fiscal 2015 contained 53 weeks.
889331_17_ITEM1_P2_S0	We are one of the world s leading suppliers of circuit protection products for the electronics, automotive, and industrial markets, with expanding platforms in sensors and power control components and modules.
889331_17_ITEM1_P2_S1	In addition to circuit protection products and solutions, the company offers electronic reed switches and sensors, automotive sensors for comfort and safety systems and a comprehensive line of highly reliable electromechanical and electronic switch and control devices for commercial and specialty vehicles, as well as protection relays and power distribution centers for the safe control and distribution of electricity.
889331_17_ITEM1_P2_S2	The company has a network of global engineering centers and labs that develop new products and product enhancements, provide customer application support and test products for safety, reliability, and regulatory compliance.
889331_17_ITEM1_P3_S0	The company s devices protect products in virtually every market that uses electrical energy, from consumer electronics to automobiles to industrial equipment.
889331_17_ITEM1_P4_S0	The company conducts its business through three reportable segments which are defined by markets and consist of: Electronics, Automotive, and Industrial.
889331_17_ITEM1_P4_S1	For segment and geographical information and consolidated net sales and operating income see Item 7, Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and Note 14, Segment Information , of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this Annual Report.
889331_17_ITEM1_P5_S0	Electronics Segment : Provides circuit protection components for overcurrent and overvoltage protection, as well as sensor components and modules to leading global manufacturers of a wide range of electronic products.
889331_17_ITEM1_P5_S1	The segment covers a broad range of end markets, including consumer electronics, telecommunications equipment, medical devices, lighting products, and white goods.
889331_17_ITEM1_P6_S0	The Electronics segment has one of the broadest product offering in the industry including fuses and protectors, positive temperature coefficient ( PTC ) resettable fuses, varistors, polymer electrostatic discharge ( ESD ) suppressors, discrete TVS diodes, TVS diode arrays protection and switching thyristors, gas discharge tubes, power switching components, fuseholders, reed switch and sensor assemblies, insulated gate bipolar transistors ( IGBT ) blocks, and related accessories.
889331_17_ITEM1_P6_S1	The Electronics segment supplies products to leading manufacturers such as Cisco, Celestica, Delta, Flextronics, Foxconn, Huawei, IBM, Intel, Jabil, LG, Microsoft, Nokia, Panasonic, Quanta, Samsung, Sanmina-SCI, Seagate, Siemens, and Sony, as well as to leading electronics distributors such as Arrow Electronics, Future Electronics, TTI, Mouser Electronics and Digi-Key.
889331_17_ITEM1_P7_S0	Automotive Segment: Provides circuit protection and sensor products to the worldwide automotive original equipment manufacturers ( OEM ) and parts distributors of passenger automobiles, trucks, buses, and off-road equipment.
889331_17_ITEM1_P7_S1	In addition, the company supplies heavy duty power distribution modules, switches and relays to the commercial vehicle industry.
889331_17_ITEM1_P7_S2	The company also sells its fuses, including blade fuses, high current fuses, battery cable protectors, and varistors, in the automotive replacement parts market.
889331_17_ITEM1_P8_S0	In the automotive passenger car and commercial vehicle market, the company s end customers include worldwide OEMs and Tier One suppliers such as Autoliv, BMW, Caterpillar, Chrysler, Daimler Trucks NA, Delphi, Ford Motor Company, General Motors, Hyundai Group, John Deere, Key Safety Systems, Lear, Navistar, Stabilus, and Volkswagen.
889331_17_ITEM1_P8_S1	Reilly Auto Parts, Pep Boys, Sumitomo, Valeo, and Yazaki.
889331_17_ITEM1_P9_S0	Industrial Segment: Provides circuit protection products for industrial and commercial customers.
889331_17_ITEM1_P9_S1	Products include power fuses and other circuit protection devices, including protection and time delay relays, which are used in commercial and industrial buildings and large equipment such as HVAC systems, elevators, and machine tools.
889331_17_ITEM1_P9_S2	The company also supplies industrial ground fault protection in mining and other large industrial operations.
889331_17_ITEM1_P9_S3	In the industrial market, the company supplies representative customers such as Agrium, Corning, Gamesa, LG, Mosaic, Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, Trane, as well as leading industrial distributors.
889331_17_ITEM1_P10_S0	In December 2016, we announced a new five-year strategic plan.
889331_17_ITEM1_P10_S1	Building upon our achievements from our previous five-year plan and leveraging our position in global mega trends such as safety, connectivity, and energy efficiency, we are targeting accelerated annual organic growth of 5-7% and annual growth from strategic acquisitions of 5-7%.
889331_17_ITEM1_P10_S2	Our strategic goals include the continued growth of our circuit protection business, accelerated growth in our power control business and the doubling of the sensor platform revenue over the next five years.
889331_17_ITEM1_P10_S3	We expect to do this through content and share gains, targeting underpenetrated geographies and markets, and innovation while continuing to acquire and integrate businesses that fit our strategic focus areas.
889331_17_ITEM1_P11_S0	In 2016, 2015, and 2014, we completed several acquisitions that have broadened our product offerings and contributed to our growth.
889331_17_ITEM1_P12_S0	ON Portfolio: On August 29, 2016, the company acquired certain assets of select businesses (the ON Portfolio ) of ON Semiconductor Corporation for $104.0 million.
889331_17_ITEM1_P12_S1	The acquired business, which is included in the Electronics segment, consists of a product portfolio that includes transient voltage suppression ( TVS ) diodes, switching thyristors, and IGBTs for automotive ignition applications.
889331_17_ITEM1_P12_S2	The acquisition expands the company s offerings in power semiconductor applications as well as increases its presence in the automotive electronics market.
889331_17_ITEM1_P12_S3	The ON Portfolio products have strong synergies with the company s existing circuit protection business, will strengthen its channel partnerships and customer engagement, and expand its power semiconductor portfolio.
889331_17_ITEM1_P13_S0	Menber s: On April 4, 2016, the company completed the acquisition of Menber s S.p.A.
889331_17_ITEM1_P13_S1	( Menber s ) headquartered in Legnago, Italy for $19.2 million (net of cash acquired and after settlement of a working capital adjustment).
889331_17_ITEM1_P13_S2	The acquired business is part of the company's commercial vehicle product business within the Automotive segment and specializes in the design, manufacturing, and selling of manual and electrical high current switches and trailer connectors for commercial vehicles.
889331_17_ITEM1_P13_S3	The transaction expands the company s commercial vehicle products business globally.
889331_17_ITEM1_P14_S0	PolySwitch: On March 25, 2016, the company acquired 100% of the circuit protection business ( PolySwitch ) of TE Connectivity Ltd. for $348.3 million (net of cash acquired and after settlement of certain post-closing adjustments).
889331_17_ITEM1_P14_S1	The PolySwitch business, which is split between the Automotive and Electronics segments, has a leading position in polymer based resettable circuit protection devices, with a strong global presence in the automotive, battery, industrial, communications and mobile computing markets.
889331_17_ITEM1_P14_S2	PolySwitch has manufacturing facilities in Shanghai and Kunshan, China, and Tsukuba, Japan.
889331_17_ITEM1_P14_S3	The acquisition allows the company to strengthen its global circuit protection product portfolio, as well as expands its presence in the automotive electronics and battery end markets.
889331_17_ITEM1_P14_S4	The acquisition also significantly increases the company s presence in Japan.
889331_17_ITEM1_P15_S0	Sigmar: On October 1, 2015, the company acquired 100% of Sigmar S.r.l.
889331_17_ITEM1_P15_S1	( Sigmar ) for $6.5 million (net of cash acquired and including estimated additional net payments of up to $0.9 million, a portion of which is subject to the achievement of certain milestones).
889331_17_ITEM1_P16_S0	Located in Ozegna, Italy, Sigmar is a leading global manufacturer of water-in-fuel sensors and also manufactures selective catalytic reduction ( SCR ) quality sensors and diesel fuel heaters for automotive and commercial vehicle applications.
889331_17_ITEM1_P16_S1	The acquisition further expanded the company s automotive sensor product line offerings within its Automotive segment.
889331_17_ITEM1_P17_S0	On January 3, 2014, the company acquired 100% of SymCom, Inc. ( SymCom ) for $52.8 million (net of cash acquired).
889331_17_ITEM1_P17_S1	Located in Rapid City, South Dakota, SymCom provides overload relays and pump controllers primarily to the industrial market.
889331_17_ITEM1_P17_S2	The acquisition allows the company to strengthen its position in the relay products market by adding new products and new customers within its Industrial segment.
889331_17_ITEM1_P18_S0	The company operates in three geographic regions: the Americas, Europe, and Asia-Pacific.
889331_17_ITEM1_P18_S1	The company manufactures products and sells to customers in all three regions.
889331_17_ITEM1_P19_S0	Net sales by segment for the periods indicated are as follows:
889331_17_ITEM1_P20_S0	Net sales in the company s three geographic regions, based upon the shipped-to destination, are as follows:
889331_17_ITEM1_P21_S0	The company s products are sold worldwide through distributors, a direct sales force and manufacturers representatives.
889331_17_ITEM1_P21_S1	For the fiscal year 2016, approximately 66% of the company s net sales were to customers outside the United States ( U.S. ), including approximately 25% to China.
889331_17_ITEM1_P22_S0	The company manufactures many of its products on fully integrated manufacturing and assembly equipment.
889331_17_ITEM1_P22_S1	The company maintains product quality through a Global Quality Management System with most manufacturing sites certified under ISO 9001:2000.
889331_17_ITEM1_P22_S2	In addition, several of the Littelfuse manufacturing sites are also certified under TS 16949 and ISO 14001.
889331_17_ITEM1_P23_S0	Additional information regarding the company s sales by geographic area and long-lived assets in different geographic areas is in Note 14, Segment Information , of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this Annual Report.
889331_17_ITEM1_P24_S0	Electronic circuit protection, sensing, and control products are used to protect circuits in a multitude of electronic systems.
889331_17_ITEM1_P25_S0	The company s product offering includes a complete line of overcurrent and overvoltage solutions including (i) fuses and protectors, (ii) PTC resettable fuses, (iii) varistors, (iv) polymer ESD suppressors, (v) discrete TVS diodes, TVS diode arrays, protection and switching thyristors, (vi) gas discharge tubes, (vii) power switching components, (viii) fuseholders, (ix) reed switch and sensor assemblies, (x) IGBT blocks, and (xi) related accessories.
889331_17_ITEM1_P26_S0	Electronic fuses and protectors are devices that contain an element that melts in an overcurrent condition.
889331_17_ITEM1_P26_S1	Electronic miniature and subminiature fuses are designed to provide circuit protection in the limited space requirements of electronic equipment.
889331_17_ITEM1_P26_S2	The company s fuses are used in a wide variety of electronic products, including mobile phones, flat-screen TVs, computers, and telecommunications equipment.
889331_17_ITEM1_P26_S3	The company markets these products under trademarked brand names including PICO II and NANO2 SMF.
889331_17_ITEM1_P27_S0	Resettable fuses are PTC polymer devices that limit the current when an overcurrent condition exists and then reset themselves once the overcurrent condition has cleared.
889331_17_ITEM1_P28_S0	The company s product line offers both radial leaded and surface mount products.
889331_17_ITEM1_P29_S0	Varistors are ceramic-based, high-energy absorption devices that provide transient overvoltage and surge suppression for automotive, telecommunication, consumer electronics, and industrial applications.
889331_17_ITEM1_P29_S1	The company s product line offers both radial leaded and multilayer surface mount products.
889331_17_ITEM1_P30_S0	Polymer ESD suppressors are polymer-based devices that protect an electronic system from failure due to rapid transfer of electrostatic charge to the circuit.
889331_17_ITEM1_P30_S1	The company s PULSE-GUARD line of ESD suppressors is used in PC and PC peripherals, digital consumer electronics, and wireless applications.
889331_17_ITEM1_P31_S0	Discrete diodes, diode arrays, and protection thyristors are fast switching silicon semiconductor structures.
889331_17_ITEM1_P31_S1	Discrete diodes protect a wide variety of applications from overvoltage transients such as ESD, inductive load switching or lightning, while diode arrays are used primarily as ESD suppressors.
889331_17_ITEM1_P32_S0	Protection thyristors are commonly used to protect telecommunications circuits from overvoltage transients such as those resulting from lightning.
889331_17_ITEM1_P32_S1	Applications include telephones, modems, data transmission lines, and alarm systems.
889331_17_ITEM1_P32_S2	The company markets these products under trademarked brand names including TECCOR , SIDACtor , Battrax , and SPA .
889331_17_ITEM1_P33_S0	Gas discharge tubes are very low capacitance devices designed to suppress any transient voltage event that is greater than the breakover voltage of the device.
889331_17_ITEM1_P33_S1	These devices are primarily used in telecommunication interface and conversion equipment applications as protection from overvoltage transients such as lightning.
889331_17_ITEM1_P34_S0	Power switching components, such as switching thyristors and IGBTs, are used to regulate energy to various types of loads most commonly found in industrial and home applications.
889331_17_ITEM1_P34_S1	These components are easily activated from simple control circuits or interfaced to computers for more complex load control.
889331_17_ITEM1_P34_S2	Typical applications include heating, cooling, battery chargers and lighting.
889331_17_ITEM1_P35_S0	Magnetic sensing products are used to monitor, sense, and measure magnetic fields in a number of applications.
889331_17_ITEM1_P35_S1	The company s product offerings include a line of reed switches, reed based sensors, and hall effect sensors.
889331_17_ITEM1_P36_S0	Reed switches are non-contact magnetically operated devices that provide an output based on the electrical load during the presence of magnetic field.
889331_17_ITEM1_P36_S1	They are used in a wide variety of applications including security, medical, fluid monitoring, telephones, fitness equipment, metering, toys, white goods, and consumer and industrial controls.
889331_17_ITEM1_P37_S0	Reed switch sensors utilize reed switch technology in various packaging configurations with custom enclosures, terminations, and connectors to provide an application specific product as a final assembly.
889331_17_ITEM1_P37_S1	Key applications include fluid level monitoring, position sensing, fluid flow, and proximity sensing.
889331_17_ITEM1_P38_S0	Hall effect sensors utilize hall chip technology to sense magnetic fields to provide ratio metric output based on magnetic fields.
889331_17_ITEM1_P38_S1	Key applications include motor speed sensing, directional sensing, rotation, and linear sensing.
889331_17_ITEM1_P39_S0	In addition to the above products, the company is also a supplier of fuse holders, fuse blocks (including OMNI-BLOK ), and fuse clips primarily to customers that purchase circuit protection devices from the company.
889331_17_ITEM1_P40_S0	Fuses are extensively used in automobiles, trucks, buses, and off-road equipment to protect electrical circuits and the wires that supply electrical power to operate lights, heating, air conditioning, radios, windows, and other controls.
889331_17_ITEM1_P40_S1	Currently, a typical automobile contains 30 to 100 fuses, depending upon the options installed.
889331_17_ITEM1_P40_S2	The fuse content per vehicle is expected to continue to grow as more electronic features are included in automobiles and as a result of vehicle electrification such as 48 volt, hybrid, and battery electric vehicles, for which the company also supplies.
889331_17_ITEM1_P41_S0	The company is a primary supplier of automotive fuses to worldwide automotive OEMs, through automotive fuse sales made to Tier One suppliers, main-fuse box, and wire harness manufacturers that incorporate the fuses into their products, as well as automotive component parts manufacturers, and automotive parts distributors.
889331_17_ITEM1_P41_S1	The company also sells its fuses in the replacement parts market, with its products being sold through merchandisers, discount stores, and service stations, as well as under private label by national firms.
889331_17_ITEM1_P42_S0	The company invented and owns U.S. and foreign patents related to blade-type fuses, which is the standard and most commonly used fuse in the automotive industry.
889331_17_ITEM1_P42_S1	The company s automotive fuse products are marketed under trademarked brand names, including ATO , MINI , MIDI , MEGA , Masterfuse , JCASE , and CABLE PRO .
889331_17_ITEM1_P43_S0	Products sold into the market include speed, position, and direction sensors, occupant safety sensors, solar sensors, fluid level, and quality sensors, fuel heating systems, rotary sensors for comfort applications, and water in fuel sensors.
889331_17_ITEM1_P43_S1	A majority of the company s automotive sensor sales are made to Tier One suppliers and distributors.
889331_17_ITEM1_P44_S0	The company has expanded the Automotive segment into the commercial vehicle market with various acquisitions, also expanding the company s portfolio of power control products.
889331_17_ITEM1_P44_S1	Additional products in this market include: power distribution modules, low current switches, high current switches, solenoids and relays, electronic switches, battery management products, ignition key switches, and trailer connectors.
889331_17_ITEM1_P44_S2	Custom and market products are sold directly to a mix of OEMs, Tier One suppliers, aftermarket channels, as well as through general distribution.
889331_17_ITEM1_P45_S0	The company owns U.S. and foreign patents related to high current switching, power distribution modules, and switching.
889331_17_ITEM1_P46_S0	The company manufactures and sells a broad range of low-voltage and medium-voltage circuit protection products to electrical distributors and their customers in the construction, OEM and industrial maintenance, repair and operating supplies ( MRO ) markets.
889331_17_ITEM1_P46_S1	The company also designs and manufactures portable custom electrical equipment for the mining and utility industry in Canada as well as protection relays for the global mining, oil and gas, and general industrial markets.
889331_17_ITEM1_P47_S0	Power fuses are used to protect circuits in various types of industrial equipment and in industrial and commercial buildings.
889331_17_ITEM1_P47_S1	They are rated and listed under one of many Underwriters Laboratories fuse classifications.
889331_17_ITEM1_P48_S0	Major applications for power fuses include protection from overload and short-circuit currents in solar, motor branch circuits, heating and cooling systems, control systems, lighting circuits, solar and electrical distribution networks.
889331_17_ITEM1_P49_S0	The company s POWR-GARD product line features the Indicator series power fuse used in both the OEM and MRO markets.
889331_17_ITEM1_P49_S1	The Indicator technology provides visual blown-fuse indication at a glance, reducing maintenance and downtime on production equipment.
889331_17_ITEM1_P49_S2	The Indicator product offering is widely used in motor protection and industrial control panel applications.
889331_17_ITEM1_P50_S0	Protection relays are used to protect personnel and equipment in mining, oil and gas, and industrial environments from excessive currents, over voltages, and electrical shock hazards called ground faults.
889331_17_ITEM1_P50_S1	Major applications for protection relays include protection of motor, transformer, and power-line distribution circuits.
889331_17_ITEM1_P51_S0	Ground-fault relays are used to protect personnel and equipment in wet environments such as underground mining or water treatment applications where there is a greater risk for electricity to come in contact with water and create a shock hazard.
889331_17_ITEM1_P52_S0	Littelfuse custom-engineered electrical equipment is designed and built for use in harsh or demanding environments where standard industrial electrical gear will not meet customer needs for reliability and durability.
889331_17_ITEM1_P53_S0	Portable power substations are used throughout mines to transform voltage from distribution to utilization levels and provide local protection and control for equipment such as mining machines, pumps, fans, conveyors, and other electrical machinery.
889331_17_ITEM1_P53_S1	Custom-built switchgear is used in mining, oil and gas, and power generation where rugged designs, quick turnaround, unique footprints, or arc-resistant equipment is required.
889331_17_ITEM1_P54_S0	The company employs scientific, engineering, and other personnel to continually improve its existing product lines and to develop new products at its research, product design, and development ( R D ) and engineering facilities in Champaign and Mt. Prospect, Illinois, Fremont, California, Rapid City, South Dakota, Canada, China, Japan, Italy, the Philippines, Taiwan, Lithuania, Germany, and Mexico.
889331_17_ITEM1_P54_S1	The Product Development Technology departments maintain a staff of engineers, chemists, material scientists and technicians whose primary responsibility is to design and develop new products.
889331_17_ITEM1_P55_S0	Proposals for the development of new products are initiated primarily by sales, marketing, and product management personnel with input from customers.
889331_17_ITEM1_P55_S1	The entire product development process usually ranges from a few months to 18 months based on the complexity of development, with continuous efforts to reduce the development cycle.
889331_17_ITEM1_P56_S0	During fiscal years 2016, 2015, and 2014, the company expended $42.2 million, $30.8 million, and $31.1 million, respectively, on R D.
889331_17_ITEM1_P57_S0	The company generally relies on patents, trademarks, licenses, and nondisclosure agreements to protect its intellectual property and proprietary products.
889331_17_ITEM1_P57_S1	In cases where it is deemed necessary by management, key employees are required to sign an agreement that they will maintain the confidentiality of the company s proprietary information and trade secrets.
889331_17_ITEM1_P58_S0	The company owns a large portfolio of patents worldwide and new products are continually being developed to replace older products.
889331_17_ITEM1_P58_S1	The company regularly applies for patent protection on such new products.
889331_17_ITEM1_P58_S2	Although, in the aggregate, the company s patents are important in the operation of its businesses, the company believes that the loss by expiration or otherwise of any one patent or group of patents would not materially affect its business.
889331_17_ITEM1_P59_S0	The company performs the majority of its own fabrication, stamps some of the metal components used in its fuses, holders and switches from raw metal stock and makes its own contacts and springs.
889331_17_ITEM1_P59_S1	In addition, the company fabricates silicon wafers for certain applications and performs its own plating (silver, nickel, zinc, tin, and oxides).
889331_17_ITEM1_P59_S2	Thermoplastic molded component requirements are met through the company s in-house molding capabilities.
889331_17_ITEM1_P59_S3	After components are stamped, molded, plated, and readied for assembly, final assembly is accomplished on fully automatic and semi-automatic assembly machines.
889331_17_ITEM1_P60_S0	Quality assurance and operations personnel, using techniques such as statistical process control, perform tests, checks and measurements during the production process to maintain the highest levels of product quality and customer satisfaction.
889331_17_ITEM1_P61_S0	The principal raw materials for the company s products include copper and copper alloys, heat-resistant plastics, zinc, melamine, glass, silver, gold, raw silicon, solder, and various gases.
889331_17_ITEM1_P61_S1	The company uses a single source for several heat-resistant plastics and for zinc, but believes that suitable alternative heat-resistant plastics and zinc are available from other sources at comparable prices.
889331_17_ITEM1_P61_S2	All other raw materials are purchased from a number of readily available outside sources.
889331_17_ITEM1_P62_S0	The company s sales and marketing staff maintains relationships with major OEMs and global distributors.
889331_17_ITEM1_P62_S1	The company s sales, marketing and engineering personnel also interact directly with OEM engineers to ensure appropriate sensor design, circuit protection and reliability within the OEM s parameters.
889331_17_ITEM1_P62_S2	The company also markets its products indirectly through a worldwide organization of over 60 manufacturers representatives and distributes through an extensive network of electronics, automotive and electrical distributors.
889331_17_ITEM1_P63_S0	The company sells a majority of its Electronics segment products through distribution, including global distributors such as Arrow Electronics, Future Electronics and TTI, Inc, with most of the remainder sold directly to OEMs.
889331_17_ITEM1_P63_S1	In the Americas, the company maintains a direct sales staff and utilizes manufacturers representatives to sell its electronics products in the U.S. and to call on major U.S. and international OEMs and distributors.
889331_17_ITEM1_P63_S2	In Canada, the company utilizes manufacturers representatives and distributors.
889331_17_ITEM1_P63_S3	In Europe and Asia-Pacific regions, the company also maintains a direct sales staff and utilizes distributors.
889331_17_ITEM1_P64_S0	The company maintains a direct sales force to service all the major automotive and commercial vehicle OEMs, system suppliers, and Tier One suppliers in the U.S.
889331_17_ITEM1_P64_S1	The company also has manufacturers representatives that sell the company s products to aftermarket fuse retailers and commercial vehicle product OEMs.
889331_17_ITEM1_P65_S0	In Europe, the company uses both a direct sales force and manufacturers representatives to service its OEMs, major system suppliers and aftermarket distribution customers.
889331_17_ITEM1_P65_S1	In the Asia-Pacific region, the company uses both a direct sales force and distributors to supply to major OEM system suppliers and Tier One suppliers.
889331_17_ITEM1_P66_S0	The company markets and sells its power fuses and protection relays through manufacturers representatives across North America.
889331_17_ITEM1_P66_S1	These representatives sell power fuse products through an electrical and industrial distribution network comprised of over 2,500 distributor buying locations.
889331_17_ITEM1_P66_S2	These distributors have customers that include electrical contractors, municipalities, utilities and factories (including both MRO and OEM).
889331_17_ITEM1_P67_S0	The company s field sales force (including regional sales managers and application engineers) and manufacturers representatives call on both distributors and end-users (consulting engineers, municipalities, utilities, and OEMs) in an effort to educate these customers on the capabilities and characteristics of the company s products.
889331_17_ITEM1_P68_S0	The company sells to over 6,000 customers and distributors worldwide.
889331_17_ITEM1_P68_S1	No single customer accounted for more than 10% of net sales during any of the last three years.
889331_17_ITEM1_P68_S2	During fiscal 2016, 2015, and 2014, net sales to customers outside the U.S. accounted for approximately 66%, 60%, and 63%, respectively, of the company s total net sales.
889331_17_ITEM1_P69_S0	The company s products compete with similar products of other manufacturers, some of which may have substantially greater financial resources than the company.
889331_17_ITEM1_P69_S1	In the electronics market, the company s competitors include Eaton Corporation, Bel Fuse Inc., Bourns Inc., EPCOS, ON Semiconductor Corporation, STMicroelectronics NV, Semtech Corporation, and Vishay Intertechnology Inc.
889331_17_ITEM1_P69_S2	In the automotive market, the company s competitors include Amphenol Corporation, Eaton Corporation, Pacific Engineering, MTA, CTS Corporation, Amphenol, Sensata Technologies Holding NV, and TE Connectivity Ltd.
889331_17_ITEM1_P69_S3	In the industrial market, the company s major competitors include Eaton Corporation, GE Multilin, and Mersen.
889331_17_ITEM1_P69_S4	The company believes that it competes on the basis of innovative products, the breadth of its product line, the quality and design of its products, and the responsiveness of its customer service, in addition to price.
889331_17_ITEM1_P70_S0	The backlog of unfilled orders at December 31, 2016 was approximately $110.3 million, compared to $96.4 million at January 2, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM1_P70_S1	Substantially all of the orders currently in backlog are scheduled for delivery in 2017.
889331_17_ITEM1_P71_S0	As of December 31, 2016, the company employed approximately 10,300 employees worldwide.
889331_17_ITEM1_P71_S1	Approximately 1,900 employees in Mexico are covered by collective bargaining agreements.
889331_17_ITEM1_P71_S2	In Mexico the company has two separate collective bargaining agreements, one for 1,200 employees in Piedras Negras, expiring January 31, 2018 and the second for 720 employees in Matamoros, expiring January 1, 2018.
889331_17_ITEM1_P71_S3	Approximately 18% of the company's total workforce was employed under collective bargaining agreements at December 31, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM1_P71_S4	Overall, the company has historically maintained satisfactory employee relations and considers employee relations to be good.
889331_17_ITEM1_P72_S0	The company is subject to numerous foreign, federal, state, and local regulations relating to air and water quality, the disposal of hazardous waste materials, safety and health.
889331_17_ITEM1_P72_S1	Compliance with applicable environmental regulations has not significantly changed the company s competitive position, capital spending or earnings in the past and the company does not presently anticipate that compliance with such regulations will change its competitive position, capital spending or earnings for the foreseeable future.
889331_17_ITEM1_P73_S0	The company employs a chemical engineer to monitor regulatory matters and believes that it is currently in compliance in all material respects with applicable environmental laws and regulations.
889331_17_ITEM1_P74_S0	Littelfuse GmbH, which was acquired by the company in May 2004, is responsible for maintaining closed coal mines from legacy operations.
889331_17_ITEM1_P74_S1	The company is compliant with German regulations pertaining to the maintenance of the mines and has an accrual related to certain of these coal mine shafts based on an engineering study estimating the cost of remediating the dangers (such as a shaft collapse) of certain of these closed coal mine shafts in Germany.
889331_17_ITEM1_P74_S2	The accrual is reviewed annually and calculated based upon the cost of remediating the shafts.
889331_17_ITEM1_P74_S3	Further information regarding the coal mine liability accrual is provided in Note 1, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies and Other Information, of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this Annual Report.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Our business, financial condition, and results of operations are subject to various risks and uncertainties, including the risk factors we have identified below.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Any of the following risk factors could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition, or results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P0_S2	These factors are not necessarily listed in order of importance.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Our industry is subject to intense competitive pressures.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We operate in markets that are highly competitive.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P2_S1	We compete on the basis of price, quality, service, and / or brand name across the industries and markets we serve.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Competitive pressures could affect the prices we are able to charge our customers or the demand for our products.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We may not always be able to compete on price, particularly when compared to manufacturers with lower cost structures.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Some of our competitors have substantially greater sales, financial and manufacturing resources and may have greater access to capital than Littelfuse.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P3_S2	As other companies enter our markets or develop new products, competition may further intensify.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Our failure to compete effectively could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, and results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P4_S0	We may be unable to manufacture and deliver products in a manner that is responsive to our customers needs.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P5_S0	The end markets for our products are characterized by technological change, frequent new product introductions and enhancements, changes in customer requirements and emerging industry standards.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P5_S1	The introduction of products embodying new technologies and the emergence of new industry standards could render our existing products obsolete and unmarketable before we can recover any or all of our research, development, and commercialization expenses on capital investments.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Furthermore, the life cycles of our products may change and are difficult to estimate.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our future success will depend upon our ability to manufacture and deliver products in a manner that is responsive to our customers needs.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P6_S1	We will need to develop and introduce new products and product enhancements on a timely basis that keep pace with technological developments and emerging industry standards and address increasingly sophisticated requirements of our customers.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P6_S2	We invest heavily in research and development without knowing that we will recover these costs.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Our competitors may develop products or technologies that will render our products non-competitive or obsolete.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P6_S4	If we cannot develop and market new products or product enhancements in a timely and cost-effective manner, our business, financial condition, and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Our business may be interrupted by labor disputes or other interruptions of supplies.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P8_S0	A work stoppage could occur at certain of our facilities, most likely as a result of disputes under collective bargaining agreements or in connection with negotiations of new collective bargaining agreements.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P8_S1	In addition, we may experience a shortage of supplies for various reasons, such as financial distress, work stoppages, natural disasters or production difficulties that may affect one of our suppliers.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P8_S2	A significant work stoppage, or an interruption or shortage of supplies for any reason, if protracted, could substantially adversely affect our business, financial condition, and results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P8_S3	The transfer of our manufacturing operations and changes in our distribution model could disrupt operations for a limited time.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Our revenues may vary significantly from period to period.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our revenues may vary significantly from one accounting period to another due to a variety of factors including:
889331_17_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The bankruptcy or insolvency of a major customer could adversely affect us.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P12_S0	The bankruptcy or insolvency of a major customer could result in lower sales revenue and cause a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P12_S1	In addition, the bankruptcy or insolvency of a major U.S. auto manufacturer or significant supplier likely could lead to substantial disruptions in the automotive supply base, resulting in lower demand for our products, which likely would cause a decrease in sales revenue and have a substantial adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Our ability to manage currency or commodity price fluctuations or supply shortages is limited.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P14_S0	As a resource-intensive manufacturing operation, we are exposed to a variety of market and asset risks, including the effects of changes in commodity prices, foreign currency exchange rates, and interest rates.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P14_S1	We have multiple sources of supply for the majority of our commodity requirements.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P14_S2	However, significant shortages that disrupt the supply of raw materials or result in price increases could affect prices we charge our customers, our product costs, and the competitive position of our products and services.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P14_S3	We monitor and manage these exposures as an integral part of our overall risk management program, which recognizes the unpredictability of markets and seeks to reduce the potentially adverse effects on our results.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P14_S4	Nevertheless, changes in currency exchange rates, commodity prices and interest rates cannot always be predicted.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P14_S5	In addition, because of intense price competition and our high level of fixed costs, we may not be able to address such changes even if they are foreseeable.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P14_S6	Substantial changes in these rates and prices could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P14_S7	In addition, significant portions of our revenues and earnings are exposed to changes in foreign currency rates.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P14_S8	As we operate in multiple foreign currencies, changes in those currencies relative to the U.S. dollar will impact our revenues and expenses.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P14_S9	The impact of possible currency devaluation in countries experiencing high inflation rates or significant exchange fluctuations can impact our results and financial guidance.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P14_S10	For additional discussion of interest rate, currency or commodity price risk, see Item 7A, Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks .
889331_17_ITEM1A_P15_S0	A significant fluctuation between the U.S. dollar and other currencies could adversely impact the Company's revenue and earnings.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Although the company's financial results are reported in U.S. dollars, the majority of the company s operations consist of manufacturing and sales activities in foreign countries.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P16_S1	The company s most significant net long exposure is to the euro.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P16_S2	The company s most significant net short exposures are to the Chinese renminbi, Mexican peso, and Philippine peso.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Changes in foreign exchange rates and in particular, an increase in the value of the U.S. dollar against foreign currencies, could have an adverse effect on profitability and financial condition.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P18_S0	We are exposed to pol itical, economic, and other risks that arise from operating a multinational business.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P19_S0	We have significant operating activities in numerous countries around the globe that contribute significantly to our revenues and earnings.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P19_S1	Serving a global customer base and remaining competitive in the global marketplace requires the company to place our production in countries outside the U.S., including emerging markets, to capitalize on market opportunities and maintain a cost-efficient structure.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P19_S2	In addition, we source a significant amount of raw materials and other components from third-party suppliers in low-cost countries.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Our operating activities are subject to a number of risks generally associated with multi-national operations, including risks relating to the following:
889331_17_ITEM1A_P21_S0	limitations on our ability to enforce legal rights and remedies.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Any of these factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P23_S0	We engage in strategic acquisitions and may not realize the anticipated benefits of the acquisitions and / or may encounter difficulties in integrating these businesses.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P24_S0	We are a company that seeks to grow through strategic acquisitions.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P24_S1	We have in the past acquired a number of businesses or companies and additional product lines and assets.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P24_S2	We intend to continue to expand and diversify our operations with additional future acquisitions.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P25_S0	An acquired business, technology, service or product could under-perform relative to our expectations and the price paid for it, or not perform in accordance with our anticipated timetable.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P25_S1	This could cause our financial results to differ from expectations in any given fiscal period, or over the long term.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P25_S2	The success of these transactions also depends on our ability to integrate the assets and personnel acquired in these acquisitions.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P25_S3	We may encounter difficulties in integrating acquisitions with our operations and may not realize the degree or timing of the benefits that we anticipated from an acquisition.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P26_S0	We may also discover liabilities or deficiencies associated with the companies or assets we acquire that were not identified in advance, which may result in significant unanticipated costs.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P26_S1	The effectiveness of our due diligence review and our ability to evaluate the results of such due diligence are dependent upon the accuracy and completeness of statements and disclosures made or actions taken by the companies we acquire or their representatives, as well as the limited amount of time in which acquisitions are executed.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P26_S2	In addition, we may fail to accurately forecast the financial impact of an acquisition transaction, including tax and accounting charges.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P26_S3	Acquisitions may also result in our recording of significant additional expenses to our results of operations and recording of substantial intangible assets on our balance sheet upon closing.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P26_S4	Any of these factors may adversely affect our financial condition or results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Reorganization activities may lead to additional costs and material adverse effects.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P28_S0	In the past we have taken actions to restructure and optimize our production and manufacturing capabilities and efficiencies through relocations, consolidations, plant closings or asset sales.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P28_S1	In the future we may take additional restructuring actions including the consolidating, closing or selling of additional facilities.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P28_S2	These actions could result in impairment charges and various charges for such items as idle capacity, disposition costs and severance costs, in addition to normal or attendant risks and uncertainties.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P29_S0	We may be unsuccessful in any of our current or future efforts to restructure or consolidate our business.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P29_S1	Our plans to minimize or eliminate any loss of revenues during restructuring or consolidation may not be achieved.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P29_S2	These activities may have a material adverse effect upon our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Environmental liabilities could adversely impact our financial position.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Foreign, federal, state and local laws and regulations impose various restrictions and controls on the discharge of materials, chemicals and gases used in our manufacturing processes or in our finished goods.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P31_S1	These environmental regulations have required us to expend a portion of our resources and capital on relevant compliance programs.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P31_S2	Under these laws and regulations, we could be held financially responsible for remedial measures if our current or former properties are contaminated or if we send waste to a landfill or recycling facility that becomes contaminated, even if we did not cause the contamination.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P31_S3	We may be subject to additional common law claims if we release substances that damage or harm third parties.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P31_S4	In addition, future changes in environmental laws or regulations may require additional investments in capital equipment or the implementation of additional compliance programs.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P31_S5	Any failure to comply with new or existing environmental laws or regulations could subject us to significant liabilities and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P32_S0	In the conduct of our manufacturing operations, we have handled and do handle materials that are considered hazardous, toxic or volatile under federal, state, and local laws.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P32_S1	The risk of accidental release of such materials cannot be completely eliminated.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P33_S0	In addition, we operate or own facilities located on or near real property that was formerly owned and operated by others.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P33_S1	Certain of these properties were used in ways that involved hazardous materials.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P33_S2	Contaminants may migrate from, within or through these properties.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P33_S3	These releases or migrations may give rise to claims.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Where third parties are responsible for contamination, the third parties may not have funds, or not make funds available when needed, to pay remediation costs imposed upon us under environmental laws and regulations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P35_S0	The company is responsible for the maintenance of discontinued coal mining operations in Germany.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P35_S1	The risk of environmental remediation exists and the company is in the process of remediating the mines considered to be the most at risk.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P36_S0	Disruptions in our manufacturing, supply or distribution chain could result in an adverse impact on results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P37_S0	We source materials and sell product through various international network channels.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P37_S1	A disruption could occur within our manufacturing, distribution or supply chain network.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P37_S2	This could include damage or destruction due to various causes including natural disasters or political instability which would cause one or more of these network channels to become non-operational.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P37_S3	This could adversely affect our ability to manufacture or deliver our products in a timely manner, impair our ability to meet customer demand for products and result in lost sales or damage to our reputation.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P37_S4	Such a disruption could have a material adverse effect upon our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P38_S0	We derive a substantial portion of our revenues from customers in the automotive industry and we are susceptible to trends and factors affecting this industry including industry cyclicality, and unexpected product recalls as well as the success of our customers products.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Net sales to the automotive industry represent a substantial portion of our revenues.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P39_S1	Factors negatively affecting this industry and the demand for products also negatively affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P39_S2	Any adverse occurrence, including industry slowdown, recession, political instability, costly or constraining regulations, tax policies and regulations, armed hostilities, terrorism, excessive inflation, prolonged disruptions in one or more of our customers production schedules, unexpected product recalls or labor disturbances, that results in significant decline in the volume of sales in these industries, or in an overall downturn in the business and operations of our customers in these industries, could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P39_S3	To the extent that demand for certain of our customers products declines, the demand for our products may decline.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P39_S4	Reduced demand relating to general economic conditions, consumer preferences, or interest rates may have a material adverse effect upon our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P40_S0	The inability to maintain access to capital markets may adversely affect our business and financial results.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P41_S0	Our ability to invest in our businesses, make strategic acquisitions, and refinance maturing debt obligations may require access to the capital markets and sufficient bank credit lines to support short-term borrowings.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P41_S1	If we are unable to access the capital markets or bank credit facilities, we could experience a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P42_S0	Fixed costs may reduce operating results if our sales fall below expectations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Our expense levels are based, in part, on our expectations for future sales.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P43_S1	Many of our expenses, particularly those relating to capital equipment and manufacturing overhead, are relatively fixed.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P43_S2	We might be unable to reduce spending quickly enough to compensate for reductions in sales.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P43_S3	Accordingly, shortfalls in sales could materially and adversely affect our operating results.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P44_S0	The volatility of our stock price could affect the value of an investment in our stock and our future financial position.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P45_S0	The market price of our stock can fluctuate widely.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P45_S1	Between January 2, 2016 and December 31, 2016, the closing sale price of our common stock ranged between a low of $90.61 and a high of $156.54.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P46_S0	The volatility of our stock price may be related to any number of factors, such as volatility in the financial markets, general macroeconomic conditions, industry conditions, analysts expectations concerning our results of operations, or the volatility of our revenues as discussed above under Our Revenues May Vary Significantly from Period to Period.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P46_S1	The historic market price of our common stock may not be indicative of future market prices.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P46_S2	We may not be able to sustain or increase the value of our common stock.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P46_S3	Declines in the market price of our stock could adversely affect our ability to retain personnel with stock incentives, to acquire businesses or assets in exchange for stock and/or to conduct future financing activities with or involving our common stock.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Customer demands and new regulations related to conflict-free minerals may force us to incur additional expenses.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P48_S0	The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act requires disclosure of use of conflict minerals mined from the Democratic Republic of Congo and adjoining countries and efforts to prevent the use of such minerals.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P49_S0	In the semiconductor industry, these minerals are most commonly found in metals.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P50_S0	As there may be only a limited number of suppliers offering conflict free metals, we cannot be certain that we will be able to obtain necessary metals in sufficient quantities or at competitive prices.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P50_S1	Also, we may face challenges with our customers and suppliers if we are unable to sufficiently verify that the metals used in our products are conflict free.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P51_S0	We are exposed to, and may be adversely affected by, potential security breaches or other disruptions to our information technology systems and data security.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P52_S0	We rely on our information technology systems and networks in connection with many of our business activities.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P52_S1	Some of these networks and systems are managed by third-party service providers and are not under our direct control.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P52_S2	Our operations routinely involve receiving, storing, processing and transmitting sensitive information pertaining to our business, customers, dealers, suppliers, employees, and other sensitive matters.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P52_S3	As with most companies, we have experienced cyber-attacks, attempts to breach our systems, and other similar incidents, none of which have been material.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P52_S4	Any future cyber incidents could, however, materially disrupt operational systems; result in loss of trade secrets or other proprietary or competitively sensitive information; compromise personally identifiable information regarding customers or employees; and jeopardize the security of our facilities.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P53_S0	A cyber incident could be caused by malicious outsiders using sophisticated methods to circumvent firewalls, encryption, and other security defenses.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P53_S1	Because techniques used to obtain unauthorized access or to sabotage systems change frequently and generally are not recognized until they are launched against a target, we may be unable to anticipate these techniques or to implement adequate preventative measures.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P54_S0	Information technology security threats, including security breaches, computer malware, and other cyber-attacks are increasing in both frequency and sophistication and could create financial liability, subject us to legal or regulatory sanctions or damage our reputation with customers, dealers, suppliers, and other stakeholders.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P54_S1	We continuously seek to maintain a robust program of information security and controls, but the impact of a material information technology event could have a material adverse effect on our competitive position, reputation, results of operations, financial condition, and cash flows.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P55_S0	Lapses in disclosure controls and procedures or internal control over financial reporting could materially and adversely affect our operations, profitability or reputation.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P56_S0	We are committed to maintaining high standards of internal control over financial reporting and disclosure controls and procedures.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P56_S1	Nevertheless, lapses or deficiencies in disclosure controls and procedures or in our internal control over financial reporting may occur from time to time.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P57_S0	There can be no assurance that our disclosure controls and procedures will be effective in the future or that a material weakness or significant deficiency in internal control over financial reporting will not exist.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P57_S1	Any such lapses or deficiencies may materially and adversely affect our business and results of operations or financial condition, restrict our ability to access the capital markets, require us to expend significant resources to correct the lapses or deficiencies, expose us to regulatory or legal proceedings, subject us to fines, penalties, judgments or losses not covered by insurance, harm our reputation, or otherwise cause a decline in investor confidence.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P58_S0	The c ompany s effective tax rate could materially increase as a consequence of various factors, including U.S. and/or international tax legislation, mix of the c ompany s earnings by jurisdiction, and U.S. and foreign jurisdictional tax audits.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P59_S0	The company is subject to taxes in the U.S. and numerous foreign jurisdictions.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P59_S1	Therefore, it is subject to changes in tax laws in each of these jurisdictions and such changes could have a material adverse affect on the company s effective tax rate and cash flows.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P60_S0	As a U.S. company with significant non-U.S. operations (generally taxed at rates that are lower than the U.S. statutory rate), it is particularly susceptible to changes in U.S. tax rules.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P60_S1	Various U.S. corporate tax legislative proposals are under consideration, some of which may have a material adverse effect on the company s effective tax rate and cash flows.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P60_S2	In addition, certain foreign jurisdictions are considering tax legislation based upon recommendations made by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in connection with its Base Erosion and Profit Shifting study.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P60_S3	The outcome of these legislative developments could have a material adverse effect on the company s effective tax rate and cash flows.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P61_S0	The tax rates applicable in the jurisdictions within which the company operates vary widely.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P61_S1	Therefore, the company s effective tax rate may be adversely affected by changes in the mix of its earnings by jurisdiction.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P62_S0	The company is also subject to examination of its tax returns by the U.S. Internal Revenue Service and other tax authorities and governmental bodies.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P62_S1	The company regularly assesses the likelihood of an adverse outcome resulting from these examinations to determine the adequacy of its provision for income taxes.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P62_S2	However, there can be no assurance as to the outcome of these examinations.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P63_S0	Failure to attract and retain qualified personnel could affect our business results.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P64_S0	Our success, both generally and in connection with mergers and acquisitions, depends on our ability to attract, retain, and motivate a highly-skilled and diverse management team and workforce.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P64_S1	Failure to ensure that we have the depth and breadth of personnel with the necessary skill set and experience could impede our ability to deliver our growth objectives and execute our strategy.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P64_S2	Competition for qualified employees among companies that rely heavily upon engineering and technology is at times intense, and the loss of qualified employees could hinder our ability to conduct research activities successfully and develop marketable products.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P65_S0	We may not be successful protecting our patents and trademarks.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P66_S0	We consider our intellectual property, including patents, trade names, and trademarks, to be of significant value to our business as a whole.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P66_S1	Our products are manufactured, marketed, and sold under a portfolio of patents, trademarks, licenses, and other forms of intellectual property, some of which expire or are allowed to lapse at various dates in the future.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P66_S2	We develop and acquire new intellectual property on an ongoing basis and consider all of our intellectual property to be valuable.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P66_S3	The company's policy is to file applications and obtain patents for the great majority of its novel and innovative new products including product modifications and improvements.
889331_17_ITEM1A_P67_S0	Based on the broad scope of our product lines, management believes that the loss or expiration of any single intellectual property right would not have a material adverse effect upon our business, financial condition or results of operations; however, multiple losses or expirations could have a material adverse effect upon our business, financial condition or results of operations.
889331_17_ITEM2_P0_S0	The company s operations are located in 51 owned or leased facilities worldwide, totaling approximately 2.8 million square feet.
889331_17_ITEM2_P0_S1	The company s corporate headquarters is located in the U.S. in Chicago, Illinois.
889331_17_ITEM2_P0_S2	The company has North American manufacturing facilities in Saskatoon, Canada, Piedras Negras, Mexico, Melchor Muzquiz, Mexico, Matamoros, Mexico, and Rapid City, South Dakota.
889331_17_ITEM2_P0_S3	The company has European manufacturing facilities in Kaunas, Lithuania, and Legnago and Ozegna, Italy.
889331_17_ITEM2_P0_S4	Asia-Pacific operations include sales and distribution centers located in Singapore, Taiwan, Japan, China, and Korea, with manufacturing plants located in the Philippines, Japan, and various cities in China.
889331_17_ITEM2_P1_S0	The company does not believe that it will encounter any difficulty in renewing its existing leases upon the expiration of their current terms.
889331_17_ITEM2_P1_S1	Management believes that the company s facilities are adequate to meet its requirements for the foreseeable future.
