889331_17_ITEM7_P73_S0	Changes in operating assets and liabilities (including short-term and long-term items) that negatively impacted cash flows in 2015 consisted of changes in accounts receivable ($14.4 million), inventory ($3.6 million).
889331_17_ITEM7_P73_S1	Increases in accounts receivable and inventory resulted from higher sales volumes in 2015.
889331_17_ITEM7_P73_S2	Positively impacting cash flows were changes in accrued expenses including post-retirement ($6.5 million), accounts payable ($2.6 million), accrued payroll and severance ($5.9 million), accrued taxes ($0.6 million) , and prepaid expenses and other ($5.2 million).
889331_17_ITEM7_P74_S0	Net cash used in investing activities decreased $59.8 million in 2015 compared to 2014 primarily due to less cash used for business acquisitions in 2015 compared to 2014.
889331_17_ITEM7_P74_S1	In 2014 the company acquired Symcom for $52.8 million, net of cash acquired while in 2015 the company paid $4.6 million, net of cash acquired, toward the acquisition of Sigmar.
889331_17_ITEM7_P75_S0	Net cash used in financing activities increased $24.4 million in 2015 compared to 2014 primarily due to increased use of cash for the repurchase of stock.
889331_17_ITEM7_P75_S1	The company s Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of up to 1,000,000 shares of the company s common stock under a program for the period May 1, 2015 to April 30, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM7_P75_S2	The company repurchased 350,000 shares of its common stock during 2015 under this program.
889331_17_ITEM7_P76_S0	We expend capital to support our operating and strategic plans.
889331_17_ITEM7_P76_S1	Such expenditures include strategic acquisitions, investments to maintain capital assets, develop new products or improve existing products, and to enhance capacity or productivity.
889331_17_ITEM7_P76_S2	Many of the associated projects have long lead-times and require commitments in advance of actual spending.
889331_17_ITEM7_P77_S0	The company s Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of up to 1,000,000 shares of the company s common stock under a program for the period May 1, 2016 to April 30, 2017.
889331_17_ITEM7_P77_S1	The company did not repurchase any shares of its common stock during fiscal 2016 and the full 1,000,000 shares may yet be purchased under the program as of December 31, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM7_P78_S0	The following table summarizes contractual obligations and commitments as of December 31, 2016:
889331_17_ITEM7_P79_S0	As of December 31, 2016, the company did not have any off-balance sheet arrangements, as defined under SEC rules.
889331_17_ITEM7_P79_S1	Specifically, the company was not liable for guarantees of indebtedness owed by third parties, the company was not directly liable for the debt of any unconsolidated entity and the company did not have any retained or contingent interest in assets.
889331_17_ITEM7_P80_S0	The company does not participate in transactions that generate relationships with unconsolidated entities or financial partnerships, such as entities often referred to as structured finance or special purpose entities.
889331_17_ITEM7_P81_S0	This ASU provides a single comprehensive model for entities to use in accounting for revenue arising from contracts with customers and will supersede most current revenue recognition guidance.
889331_17_ITEM7_P81_S1	The guidance permits two implementation approaches, one requiring retrospective application of the new standard with restatement of prior years and one requiring prospective application of the new standard with disclosure of results under old standards.
889331_17_ITEM7_P82_S0	In August, 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-14, which postponed the effective date of ASU No. 2014-09 to fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2017, with early adoption permitted on the original effective date of fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM7_P82_S1	The company is in the process of performing its initial assessment of the potential impact on its consolidated financial statements and has not concluded on its adoption methodology.
889331_17_ITEM7_P82_S2	While the company is currently assessing the impact of the new standards, the company s revenue is primarily generated from the sale of finished products to customers.
889331_17_ITEM7_P82_S3	Sales predominantly contain a single delivery element and revenue is recognized at a single point in time when ownership, risks, and rewards transfer.
889331_17_ITEM7_P82_S4	These are largely un-affected by the new standard.
889331_17_ITEM7_P82_S5	The company does not expect this new guidance to have a material impact on the amount of overall sales recognized; however, the timing of sales on certain projects may be affected.
889331_17_ITEM7_P82_S6	The company has not yet quantified this potential impact.
889331_17_ITEM7_P83_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-02, "Leases" (Topic 842).
889331_17_ITEM7_P83_S1	This ASU requires lessees to recognize, on the balance sheet, assets and liabilities for the rights and obligations created by leases of greater than twelve months.
889331_17_ITEM7_P83_S2	The accounting by lessors will remain largely unchanged.
889331_17_ITEM7_P84_S0	The ASU is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2018, with early adoption permitted.
889331_17_ITEM7_P84_S1	Adoption will require a modified retrospective transition.
889331_17_ITEM7_P84_S2	The company is currently evaluating the impact of this ASU on its consolidated financial statements.
889331_17_ITEM7_P85_S0	In January 2017, the FASB issued ASU No. 2017-04, Intangibles-Goodwill and Other (Topic 350).
889331_17_ITEM7_P85_S1	This ASU modifies the concept of impairment from the condition that exists when the carrying amount of goodwill exceeds its implied fair value to the condition that exists when the carrying amount of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value.
889331_17_ITEM7_P85_S2	An entity no longer will determine goodwill impairment by calculating the implied fair value of goodwill by assigning the fair value of a reporting unit to all of its assets and liabilities as if that reporting unit had been acquired in a business combination.
889331_17_ITEM7_P85_S3	Because the update will eliminate Step 2 from the goodwill impairment test, it should reduce the cost and complexity of evaluating goodwill for impairment.
889331_17_ITEM7_P85_S4	This ASU is effective for annual or any interim goodwill impairment tests in fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2020, with early adoption is permitted for interim or annual goodwill impairment tests performed on testing dates after January 1, 2017.
889331_17_ITEM7_P86_S0	Certain of the accounting policies as discussed below require the application of significant judgment by management in selecting the appropriate estimates and assumptions for calculating amounts to record in the financial statements.
889331_17_ITEM7_P86_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates and assumptions, impacting the reported results of operations and financial position.
889331_17_ITEM7_P86_S2	Significant accounting policies are more fully described in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report.
889331_17_ITEM7_P86_S3	Certain accounting policies, however, are considered to be critical in that they are most important to the depiction of the company s financial condition and results of operations and their application requires management s subjective judgment in making estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain.
889331_17_ITEM7_P86_S4	The company believes the following accounting policies are the most critical to aid in fully understanding and evaluating its reported financial results, as they require management s most difficult, subjective or complex judgments, resulting from the need to make estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain.
889331_17_ITEM7_P86_S5	The company has reviewed these critical accounting policies and related disclosures with the Audit Committee of its Board of Directors.
889331_17_ITEM7_P87_S0	The company recognizes revenue on product sales in the period in which the sales process is complete.
889331_17_ITEM7_P87_S1	This generally occurs when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, products are shipped (FOB origin) to the customer in accordance with the terms of the sale, the risk of loss has been transferred, collectability is reasonably assured and the pricing is fixed and determinable.
889331_17_ITEM7_P87_S2	At the end of each period, for those shipments where title to the products and the risk of loss and rewards of ownership do not transfer until the product has been received by the customer, the company adjusts sales and cost of sales for the delay between the time that the products are shipped and when they are received by the customer.
889331_17_ITEM7_P88_S0	The company s distribution channels are primarily through direct sales and independent third party distributors.
889331_17_ITEM7_P89_S0	The company accepts orders from customers based on long term purchasing contracts and written sales agreements.
889331_17_ITEM7_P89_S1	Contract pricing and selling agreement terms are based on market factors, costs, and competition.
889331_17_ITEM7_P89_S2	Pricing normally is negotiated as an adjustment (premium or discount) from the company s published price lists.
889331_17_ITEM7_P89_S3	The customer is invoiced when the company s products are shipped to them in accordance with the terms of the sales agreement.
889331_17_ITEM7_P90_S0	the ability to receive price adjustments on products previously shipped and invoiced.
889331_17_ITEM7_P90_S1	This practice is common in the industry and is referred to as a ship and debit program.
889331_17_ITEM7_P90_S2	This program allows the distributor to debit the company for the difference between the distributors contracted price and a lower price for specific transactions.
889331_17_ITEM7_P91_S0	Under certain circumstances (usually in a competitive situation or large volume opportunity), a distributor will request authorization to reduce its price to its buyer.
889331_17_ITEM7_P91_S1	If the company approves such a reduction, the distributor is authorized to debit its account for the difference between the contracted price and the lower approved price.
889331_17_ITEM7_P91_S2	The company establishes reserves for this program based on historic activity and actual authorizations for the debit and recognizes these debits as a reduction of revenue.
889331_17_ITEM7_P92_S0	The company has a return to stock policy whereby a customer with previous authorization from Littelfuse management can return previously purchased goods for full or partial credit.
889331_17_ITEM7_P92_S1	The company establishes an estimated allowance for these returns based on historic activity.
889331_17_ITEM7_P92_S2	Sales revenue and cost of sales are reduced to anticipate estimated returns.
889331_17_ITEM7_P93_S0	Volume Rebates: The company offers incentives to certain customers to achieve specific quarterly or annual sales targets.
889331_17_ITEM7_P93_S1	If customers achieve their sales targets, they are entitled to rebates.
889331_17_ITEM7_P93_S2	The company estimates the future cost of these rebates and recognizes this estimated cost as a reduction to revenue as products are sold.
889331_17_ITEM7_P94_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts: The company evaluates the collectability of its trade receivables based on a combination of factors.
889331_17_ITEM7_P94_S1	The company regularly analyzes its significant customer accounts and, when the company becomes aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the company records a specific reserve for bad debt to reduce the related receivable to the amount the company reasonably believes is collectible.
889331_17_ITEM7_P94_S2	The company also records allowances for all other customers based on a variety of factors including the length of time the receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, macroeconomic considerations and past experience.
889331_17_ITEM7_P95_S0	Historically, the allowance for doubtful accounts has been adequate to cover bad debts.
889331_17_ITEM7_P95_S1	If circumstances related to specific customers change, the estimates of the recoverability of receivables could be further adjusted.
889331_17_ITEM7_P96_S0	The company performs regular detailed assessments of inventory, which include a review of, among other factors, demand requirements, product life cycle and development plans, component cost trends, product pricing, shelf life, and quality issues.
889331_17_ITEM7_P96_S1	Based on the analysis, the company records adjustments to inventory for excess quantities, obsolescence or impairment when appropriate to reflect inventory at net realizable value.
889331_17_ITEM7_P97_S0	Historically, inventory reserves have been adequate to reflect inventory at net realizable values.
889331_17_ITEM7_P97_S1	During 2016, the company was required to step up the value of inventory acquired in business combinations to its selling prices less the cost to sell under business combination accounting.
889331_17_ITEM7_P97_S2	This step-up was approximately $7.8 million for the PolySwitch, ON portfolio, and Menber s acquisitions in 2016.
889331_17_ITEM7_P98_S0	The company annually tests goodwill for impairment on the first day of its fiscal fourth quarter or at an interim date if there is an event or change in circumstances that indicates the asset may be impaired.
889331_17_ITEM7_P99_S0	Management determines the fair value of each of its reporting units by using a discounted cash flow model (which includes forecasted five-year income statement and working capital projections, a market-based weighted average cost of capital and terminal values after five years) to estimate market value.
889331_17_ITEM7_P99_S1	In addition, the company compares its derived enterprise value on a consolidated basis to the company s market capitalization as of its test date to ensure its derived value approximates the market value of the company when taken as a whole.
889331_17_ITEM7_P100_S0	Due to negative events in the potash market in 2016, management revisited its long term projections and conducted a step one goodwill impairment analysis for its custom products reporting unit in the third quarter of 2016.
889331_17_ITEM7_P100_S1	The reporting unit failed the step one test and management conducted a step two analysis with the revised projections.
889331_17_ITEM7_P100_S2	The fair value of the unit was estimated using the expected present value of future cash flows over a seven year forecast period and appraisal of certain assets.
889331_17_ITEM7_P100_S3	As a result, the company recognized a charge for goodwill impairment of $8.8 million as it wrote off the entire goodwill balance.
889331_17_ITEM7_P100_S4	In addition, the company recognized intangible assets impairments aggregating $6.0 million, including a $3.8 million reduction of the custom products trade names to a $0.7 million remaining value and a $2.2 million reduction of the reporting unit s customer relationships to zero value.
889331_17_ITEM7_P101_S0	As of the most recent annual test conducted on October 2, 2016, the company had seven reporting units for goodwill testing purposes and concluded the fair value of each of the reporting units exceeded its carrying value of invested capital and therefore, no potential goodwill impairment existed.
889331_17_ITEM7_P101_S1	Specifically, the company noted that the excess of fair value over the carrying value of invested capital, was 65%, 154%, 218%, 132%, 70%, 15%, and 150% for its reporting units; electronics (non-silicon), electronics (silicon), passenger car, commercial vehicle products, sensors, relays, and power fuse, respectively, at October 2, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM7_P102_S0	Certain key assumptions used in the annual test included a discount rate of 9.8% and a long-term growth rate of 3.0% which were used for all reporting units except for relays which had a discount rate of 10.3% as a result of a 0.5% premium factor.
889331_17_ITEM7_P103_S0	In addition, the company performed a sensitivity test at October 2, 2016 that showed either a 100 basis point increase in its discount rate or a 100 basis point decrease in the long-term growth rate for each reporting unit would not have changed the company s conclusion that no potential goodwill impairment existed at October 2, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM7_P104_S0	The company will continue to perform a goodwill impairment test as required on an annual basis and on an interim basis, if certain conditions exist.
889331_17_ITEM7_P104_S1	Factors the company considers important, which could result in changes to its estimates, include underperformance relative to historical or projected future operating results and declines in acquisitions and trading multiples.
889331_17_ITEM7_P104_S2	Due to the diverse end user base and non-discretionary product demand, the company does not believe its future operating results will vary significantly relative to its historical and projected future operating results.
889331_17_ITEM7_P104_S3	However, it is possible that we could recognize impairment charges for the relays reporting unit if we have declines in profitability or projected future operating results due to changes in volume, market pricing, cost, or the business environment.
889331_17_ITEM7_P105_S0	As of the 2016 annual test date, the relays reporting unit had $41.4 million of goodwill and intangible assets.
889331_17_ITEM7_P106_S0	The company evaluates long-lived asset groups on an ongoing basis.
889331_17_ITEM7_P106_S1	Long-lived asset groups are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the related asset may not be recoverable.
889331_17_ITEM7_P107_S0	Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of the asset to future undiscounted cash flows expected to be generated by the asset group.
889331_17_ITEM7_P107_S1	If it is determined to be impaired, the impairment recognized is measured by the amount by which the carrying value of the asset exceeds its fair value.
889331_17_ITEM7_P107_S2	The company s estimates of future cash flows from such assets could be impacted if it underperforms relative to historical or projected future operating results.
889331_17_ITEM7_P107_S3	The company did not record asset impairment charges in 2016 or 2015, but did recognize asset impairment charges of $0.3 million in 2014.
889331_17_ITEM7_P108_S0	Environmental liabilities are accrued based on estimates of the probability of potential future environmental exposure.
889331_17_ITEM7_P108_S1	Costs related to on-going maintenance of environmental sites are expensed as incurred.
889331_17_ITEM7_P108_S2	If actual or estimated probable future losses exceed the company s recorded liability for such claims, it would record additional charges as other expense during the period in which the actual loss or change in estimate occurred.
889331_17_ITEM7_P109_S0	The company evaluates its reserve for coal mine remediation annually utilizing a third party expert.
889331_17_ITEM7_P110_S0	Littelfuse has a number of company-sponsored defined benefit plans primarily in Europe and the Asia-Pacific region.
889331_17_ITEM7_P110_S1	The company recognizes the full unfunded status of these plans on the balance sheet.
889331_17_ITEM7_P110_S2	Actuarial gains and losses and prior service costs and credits are recognized as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income.
889331_17_ITEM7_P111_S0	Accounting for pensions requires estimating the future benefit cost and recognizing the cost over the employee s expected period of employment with the company.
889331_17_ITEM7_P111_S1	Certain assumptions are required in the calculation of pension costs and obligations.
889331_17_ITEM7_P111_S2	These assumptions include the discount rate, salary scales and the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
889331_17_ITEM7_P112_S0	The discount rate is intended to represent the rate at which pension benefit obligations could be settled by purchase of an annuity contract.
889331_17_ITEM7_P112_S1	These assumptions are subject to change based on stock and bond market returns and other economic factors.
889331_17_ITEM7_P112_S2	Actual results that differ from the company s assumptions are accumulated and amortized over future periods and, therefore, generally affect its recognized expense and accrued liability in such future periods.
889331_17_ITEM7_P112_S3	While the company believes that its assumptions are appropriate given current economic conditions and its actual experience, significant differences in results or significant changes in the company s assumptions may materially affect its pension obligations and related future expense.
889331_17_ITEM7_P112_S4	During 2015, the company settled its U.S. defined benefit pension plan as described in Note 10, Benefit Plans , of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this Annual Report.
889331_17_ITEM7_P112_S5	Further information regarding these plans is also provided in Note 10, Benefit Plans , of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this Annual Report.
889331_17_ITEM7_P113_S0	Equity-based compensation expense is recorded for stock-option awards and restricted share units based upon the fair values of the awards.
889331_17_ITEM7_P114_S0	The fair value of stock-option awards is estimated at the grant date using the Black-Scholes option pricing model, which includes assumptions for volatility, expected term, risk-free interest rate and dividend yield.
889331_17_ITEM7_P114_S1	Expected volatility is based on implied volatilities from traded options on Littelfuse stock, historical volatility of Littelfuse stock and other factors.
889331_17_ITEM7_P114_S2	Historical data is used to estimate employee termination experience and the expected term of the options.
889331_17_ITEM7_P115_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect at the time of grant.
889331_17_ITEM7_P115_S1	The company initiated a quarterly cash dividend in 2010 and expects to continue making cash dividend payments in the foreseeable future.
889331_17_ITEM7_P116_S0	Total equity-based compensation expense for all equity compensation plans was $12.8 million, $10.7 million, and $9.4 million in 2016, 2015, and 2014, respectively.
889331_17_ITEM7_P116_S1	Further information regarding this expense is provided in Note 11, Shareholders Equity , of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this Annual Report.
889331_17_ITEM7_P117_S0	The company accounts for income taxes using the liability method.
889331_17_ITEM7_P118_S0	Deferred taxes are recognized for the future effects of temporary differences between financial and income tax reporting using tax rates in effect for the years in which the differences are expected to reverse.
889331_17_ITEM7_P118_S1	The company recognizes deferred taxes for temporary differences, operating loss carryforwards and tax credit carryforwards.
889331_17_ITEM7_P118_S2	Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if it is more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
889331_17_ITEM7_P119_S0	Federal and state income taxes are provided on the portion of foreign income that is expected to be remitted to the U.S. and be taxable (and foreign income taxes are provided on the portion of foreign income that is expected to be remitted to an upper-tier foreign entity).
889331_17_ITEM7_P120_S0	The company recognizes the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical merits of the position.
889331_17_ITEM7_P120_S1	The tax benefits recognized in the financial statements from such a position are measured based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized upon ultimate settlement.
889331_17_ITEM7_P121_S0	Further information regarding income taxes, including a detailed reconciliation of current year activity, is provided in Note 12, Income Taxes , of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in this Annual Report.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The company is exposed to market risk from changes in interest rates, foreign exchange rates and commodity prices.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The company had $232.8 million in debt outstanding at December 31, 2016 related to the unsecured revolving credit facility and term loan.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P1_S1	Because 100% of this debt has variable interest rates, the company is subject to future interest rate fluctuations in relation to these borrowings which could potentially have a negative impact on cash flows of the company.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P1_S2	A prospective increase of 100 basis points in the interest rate applicable to the company s outstanding borrowings under its credit facility would result in an increase of approximately $2.3 million in annual interest expense.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P1_S3	The company is not party to any currency exchange or interest rate protection agreements as of December 31, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The majority of the company s operations consist of manufacturing and sales activities in foreign countries.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The company has manufacturing facilities in the U.S., Mexico, Canada, China, Italy, Lithuania, Japan and the Philippines.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P2_S2	During 2016, sales to customers outside the U.S. were approximately 66% of total net sales.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P2_S3	During 2015, sales to customers outside the U.S. were approximately 60% of total net sales.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P2_S4	Substantially all sales in Europe are denominated in euros and substantially all sales in the Asia-Pacific region are denominated in U.S. dollars, Japanese yen, Korean won, Chinese renminbi or Taiwanese dollars.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P3_S0	The company s foreign exchange exposures result primarily from sale of products in foreign currencies, foreign currency denominated purchases, external borrowings, inter-company loans, employee-related and other costs of running operations in foreign countries and translation of balance sheet accounts denominated in foreign currencies.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P3_S1	The company s most significant net long exposure is to the euro.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P3_S2	The company s most significant net short exposures are to the Chinese renminbi, Mexican peso, and Philippine peso.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P3_S3	Changes in foreign exchange rates could affect the company s sales, costs, balance sheet values and earnings.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P3_S4	The company uses netting and offsetting intercompany account management techniques to reduce known foreign currency exposures where possible.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The company uses various metals in the manufacturing of its products, including copper, zinc, tin, gold, and silver.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P4_S1	Prices of these commodities can and do fluctuate significantly, which can impact the company s earnings.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P4_S2	The most significant of these exposures is to copper, zinc, gold, and silver, where at current prices and volumes, a 10% price change would affect annual pre-tax profit by approximately $2.4 million for copper, $0.9 million for zinc, $0.2 million for gold, $0.5 million for silver, and $0.3 million for tin.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The cost of oil has fluctuated dramatically over the past several years.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P5_S1	Consequently, there is a risk that a return to high prices for oil and electricity in 2017 could have a significant impact on the company s transportation and utility expenses.
889331_17_ITEM7A_P6_S0	While the company is exposed to significant changes in certain commodity prices and foreign currency exchange rates, the company actively monitors these exposures and takes various actions to mitigate any negative impacts of these exposures.
889331_17_ITEM8_P0_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders of Littelfuse, Inc.
889331_17_ITEM8_P1_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Littelfuse, Inc. (a Delaware corporation) and subsidiaries (the Company ) as of December 31, 2016 and January 2, 2016, and the related consolidated statements of net income, comprehensive income, equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM8_P1_S1	Our audits of the basic consolidated financial statements included the financial statement schedule listed in the index appearing under Item 15(a)(2).
889331_17_ITEM8_P1_S2	These financial statements and financial statement schedule are the responsibility of the Company s management.
889331_17_ITEM8_P1_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements and financial statement schedule based on our audits.
889331_17_ITEM8_P2_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
889331_17_ITEM8_P2_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
889331_17_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
889331_17_ITEM8_P3_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
889331_17_ITEM8_P3_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
889331_17_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Littelfuse, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2016 and January 2, 2016, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2016 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
889331_17_ITEM8_P4_S1	Also in our opinion, the related financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic consolidated financial statements taken as a whole, present fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth therein.
889331_17_ITEM8_P5_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders of Littelfuse, Inc.
889331_17_ITEM8_P6_S0	We have audited the internal control over financial reporting of Littelfuse, Inc. (a Delaware corporation) and subsidiaries (the Company ) as of December 31, 2016, based on criteria established in the 2013 Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
889331_17_ITEM8_P6_S1	The Company s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting ( Management s Report ).
889331_17_ITEM8_P6_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
889331_17_ITEM8_P6_S3	Our audit of, and opinion on, the Company s internal control over financial reporting does not include the internal control over financial reporting of PolySwitch, Menber s and the ON Portfolio businesses, wholly-owned subsidiaries, whose financial statements reflect total assets and revenues constituting 36 percent and 16 percent, respectively, in aggregate, of the related consolidated financial statement amounts as of and for the year ended December 31, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM8_P6_S4	As indicated in Management s Report, PolySwitch, Menber s and the ON Portfolio businesses were acquired during 2016.
889331_17_ITEM8_P6_S5	Management s assertion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting excluded internal control over financial reporting of PolySwitch, Menber s and the ON Portfolio businesses.
889331_17_ITEM8_P7_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
889331_17_ITEM8_P7_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
889331_17_ITEM8_P7_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
889331_17_ITEM8_P7_S3	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
889331_17_ITEM8_P8_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
889331_17_ITEM8_P8_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
889331_17_ITEM8_P9_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
889331_17_ITEM8_P9_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
889331_17_ITEM8_P10_S0	In our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2016, based on criteria established in the 2013 Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by COSO.
889331_17_ITEM8_P11_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the year ended December 31, 2016, and our report dated February 27, 2017 expressed an unqualified opinion on those financial statements.
889331_17_ITEM8_P12_S0	See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_17_ITEM8_P13_S0	See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_17_ITEM8_P14_S0	See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_17_ITEM8_P15_S0	See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
889331_17_ITEM8_P16_S0	Littelfuse, Inc. and subsidiaries (the company ) design, manufacture, and sell circuit protection devices for use in the automotive, electronics, and industrial markets throughout the world.
889331_17_ITEM8_P16_S1	The company is one of the world s leading suppliers of circuit protection products for the electronics, automotive, and industrial markets, with expanding platforms in sensors and power control components and modules.
889331_17_ITEM8_P16_S2	In addition to circuit protection products and solutions, the company offers electronic reed switches and sensors, automotive sensors for comfort and safety systems and a comprehensive line of highly reliable electromechanical and electronic switch and control devices for commercial and specialty vehicles, as well as protection relays and power distribution centers for the safe control and distribution of electricity.
889331_17_ITEM8_P16_S3	The company has a network of global engineering centers and labs that develop new products and product enhancements, provides customer application support and test products for safety, reliability, and regulatory compliance.
889331_17_ITEM8_P17_S0	The company s devices protect products in virtually every market that uses electrical energy, from consumer electronics to automobiles to industrial equipment.
889331_17_ITEM8_P18_S0	References herein to 2016 , fiscal 2016 or fiscal year 2016 refer to the fiscal year ended December 31, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM8_P18_S1	References herein to 2015 , fiscal 2015 or fiscal year 2015 refer to the fiscal year ended January 2, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM8_P18_S2	References herein to 2014 , fiscal 2014 or fiscal year 2014 refer to the fiscal year ended December 27, 2014.
889331_17_ITEM8_P19_S0	The company operates on a 52-53 week fiscal year (4-4-5 basis) ending on the Saturday closest to December 31.
889331_17_ITEM8_P19_S1	Therefore, the financial results of certain fiscal years and the associated 14 week quarters will not be exactly comparable to the prior and subsequent 52 week fiscal years and the associated quarters having only 13 weeks.
889331_17_ITEM8_P19_S2	As a result of using this convention, each of fiscal 2016 and fiscal 2014 contained 52 weeks whereas fiscal 2015 contained 53 weeks.
889331_17_ITEM8_P20_S0	The Consolidated Financial Statements include the accounts of Littelfuse, Inc. and its subsidiaries.
889331_17_ITEM8_P20_S1	All significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
889331_17_ITEM8_P21_S0	The company s Consolidated Financial Statements were prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America and include the assets, liabilities, sales and expenses of all wholly-owned subsidiaries and majority-owned subsidiaries over which the company exercises control.
889331_17_ITEM8_P22_S0	The process of preparing financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the Consolidated Financial Statements, and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses and the accompanying notes.
889331_17_ITEM8_P22_S1	The company evaluates and updates its assumptions and estimates on an ongoing basis and may employ outside experts to assist in its evaluation, as considered necessary.
889331_17_ITEM8_P22_S2	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
889331_17_ITEM8_P23_S0	All highly liquid investments, with an original maturity of three months or less when purchased, are considered to be cash equivalents.
889331_17_ITEM8_P24_S0	The company has determined that certain of its investment securities are to be classified as available-for-sale.
889331_17_ITEM8_P24_S1	Available-for-sale securities are carried at fair value with the unrealized gains and losses reported as a component of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income (Loss).
889331_17_ITEM8_P25_S0	Realized gains and losses and declines in unrealized value judged to be other-than-temporary on available-for-sale securities are included in other expense (income), net.
889331_17_ITEM8_P26_S0	The cost of securities sold is based on the specific identification method.
889331_17_ITEM8_P26_S1	Interest and dividends on securities classified as available-for-sale are included in interest income.
889331_17_ITEM8_P27_S0	Short-term investments, which are primarily certificates of deposits, are carried at cost which approximates fair value.
889331_17_ITEM8_P28_S0	The company performs credit evaluations of customers financial condition and generally does not require collateral.
889331_17_ITEM8_P28_S1	Credit losses are provided for in the financial statements based upon specific knowledge of a customer s inability to meet its financial obligations to the company.
889331_17_ITEM8_P29_S0	Historically, credit losses have consistently been within management s expectations and have not been a material amount.
889331_17_ITEM8_P29_S1	A receivable is considered past due if payments have not been received within agreed upon invoice terms.
889331_17_ITEM8_P29_S2	Write-offs are recorded at the time a customer receivable is deemed uncollectible.
889331_17_ITEM8_P30_S0	The company also maintains allowances against accounts receivable for the settlement of rebates and sales discounts to customers.
889331_17_ITEM8_P30_S1	These allowances are based upon specific customer sales and sales discounts as well as actual historical experience.
889331_17_ITEM8_P31_S0	Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market (first in, first out method), which approximates current replacement cost.
889331_17_ITEM8_P32_S0	The company maintains excess and obsolete allowances against inventory to reduce the carrying value to the expected net realizable value.
889331_17_ITEM8_P32_S1	These allowances are based upon a combination of factors including historical sales volume, market conditions, lower of cost or market analysis and expected realizable value of the inventory.
889331_17_ITEM8_P33_S0	As of December 31, 2016 the company had investments in Polytronics Technology Corporation Ltd. ( Polytronics ), a Taiwanese publicly traded company and Monolith Semiconductor, Inc. ( Monolith ), a Texas-based startup company.
889331_17_ITEM8_P34_S0	The company s Polytronics shares held at the end of fiscal 2016 and 2015 represent approximately 7.2% of total Polytronics shares outstanding.
889331_17_ITEM8_P34_S1	The Polytronics investment is classified as available-for-sale and is carried at fair value with the unrealized gains and losses reported as a component of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income (Loss).
889331_17_ITEM8_P34_S2	The fair value of the Polytronics investment was 10.0 million (approximately $10.4 million) at December 31, 2016 and 10.7 million (approximately $11.7 million) at January 2, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM8_P34_S3	Included in 2016 and 2015, other comprehensive income is an unrealized loss of $0.8 million and an unrealized gain of $0.9 million, respectively, due to changes in fair market value of the Polytronics investment.
889331_17_ITEM8_P34_S4	The remaining movement year over year was due to the impact of changes in exchange rates.
889331_17_ITEM8_P35_S0	In December 2015, the company invested $3.5 million in the preferred stock of Monolith, a U.S. start-up company developing silicon carbide technology, which represents approximately 12% of the common stock of Monolith on an as-converted basis.
889331_17_ITEM8_P35_S1	The company accounts for its investment in Monolith under the cost method with any changes in value recorded in other comprehensive income.
889331_17_ITEM8_P35_S2	The value of the Monolith investment was $3.5 million at December 31, 2016 and January 2, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM8_P36_S0	Land, buildings, and equipment are carried at cost.
889331_17_ITEM8_P36_S1	Depreciation is calculated using the straight-line method with useful lives of 21 years for buildings, seven to nine years for equipment, seven years for furniture and fixtures, five years for tooling and three years for computer equipment.
889331_17_ITEM8_P37_S0	The company annually tests goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment on the first day of its fiscal fourth quarter or at other dates if there is an event or change in circumstances that indicates the asset may be impaired.
889331_17_ITEM8_P38_S0	Management determines the fair value of each of its reporting units by using a discounted cash flow model (which includes forecasted five-year income statement and working capital projections, a market-based weighted average cost of capital and terminal values after five years) to estimate market value.
889331_17_ITEM8_P38_S1	In addition, the company compares its derived enterprise value on a consolidated basis to the company s market capitalization as of its test date to ensure its derived value approximates the market value of the company when taken as a whole.
889331_17_ITEM8_P39_S0	Due to negative events in the potash market in 2016, management revisited its long term projections and conducted a step one goodwill impairment analysis for its custom products reporting unit in the third quarter of 2016.
889331_17_ITEM8_P39_S1	The reporting unit failed the step one test and management conducted a step two analysis with the revised projections.
889331_17_ITEM8_P39_S2	The fair value of the unit was estimated using the expected present value of future cash flows over a seven year forecast period and appraisal of certain assets.
889331_17_ITEM8_P39_S3	As a result, the company recognized a charge for goodwill impairment of $8.8 million as it wrote off the entire goodwill balance.
889331_17_ITEM8_P39_S4	In addition, the company recognized intangible assets impairments aggregating $6.0 million, including a $3.8 million reduction of the custom products trade names to a $0.7 million remaining value and a $2.2 million reduction of the reporting unit s customer relationships to zero value.
889331_17_ITEM8_P40_S0	As of the most recent annual test conducted on October 2, 2016, the company had seven reporting units for goodwill testing purposes and concluded the fair value of each of the reporting units exceeded its carrying value of invested capital and therefore, no potential goodwill impairment existed.
889331_17_ITEM8_P40_S1	Specifically, the company noted that the excess of fair value over the carrying value of invested capital, was 65%, 154%, 218%, 132%, 70%, 15%, and 150% for its reporting units; electronics (non-silicon), electronics (silicon), passenger car, commercial vehicle products, sensors, relays, and power fuse, respectively, at October 2, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM8_P41_S0	Certain key assumptions used in the annual test included a discount rate of 9.8% and a long-term growth rate of 3.0% which were used for all reporting units except for relays which had a discount rate of 10.3% as a result of a 0.5% premium factor.
889331_17_ITEM8_P42_S0	The company will continue to perform a goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible asset impairment test as required on an annual basis and on an interim basis, if certain impairment conditions exist.
889331_17_ITEM8_P42_S1	Factors the company considers important, which could result in changes to its estimates, include underperformance relative to historical or projected future operating results and declines in acquisitions and trading multiples.
889331_17_ITEM8_P42_S2	Due to the diverse end user base and non-discretionary product demand, the company does not believe its future operating results will vary significantly relative to its historical and projected future operating results.
889331_17_ITEM8_P42_S3	However, it is possible that we could recognize impairment charges for the relays reporting unit if we have declines in profitability or projected future operating results due to changes in volume, market pricing, cost, or the business environment.
889331_17_ITEM8_P43_S0	As of the 2016 annual test date, the relays reporting unit had $41.4 million of goodwill and intangible assets.
889331_17_ITEM8_P44_S0	Customer relationships, trademarks and tradenames are amortized using the straight-line method over estimated useful lives that have a range of five to 20 years.
889331_17_ITEM8_P44_S1	Patents, licenses and software are amortized using the straight-line method or an accelerated method over estimated useful lives that have a range of five to 17 years.
889331_17_ITEM8_P44_S2	The distribution networks are amortized on either a straight-line or accelerated basis over estimated useful lives that have a range of three to 20 years.
889331_17_ITEM8_P44_S3	Other intangible assets are also tested for impairment when there is a significant event that may cause the asset to be impaired.
889331_17_ITEM8_P44_S4	As described above, in 2016 the company recognized an impairment charge of $2.2 million to reduce the custom products reporting unit s customer relationships to zero value.
889331_17_ITEM8_P45_S0	Environmental liabilities are accrued based on engineering studies estimating the cost of remediating sites.
889331_17_ITEM8_P45_S1	Expenses related to on-going maintenance of environmental sites are expensed as incurred.
889331_17_ITEM8_P45_S2	If actual or estimated probable future losses exceed the company s recorded liability for such claims, the company would record additional charges during the period in which the actual loss or change in estimate occurred.
889331_17_ITEM8_P46_S0	Accounting for pensions requires estimating the future benefit cost and recognizing the cost over the employee s expected period of employment with the company.
889331_17_ITEM8_P46_S1	Certain assumptions are required in the calculation of pension costs and obligations.
889331_17_ITEM8_P46_S2	These assumptions include the discount rate, salary scales and the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
889331_17_ITEM8_P47_S0	The discount rate is intended to represent the rate at which pension benefit obligations could be settled by purchase of an annuity contract.
889331_17_ITEM8_P47_S1	These assumptions are subject to change based on stock and bond market returns and other economic factors.
889331_17_ITEM8_P47_S2	Actual results that differ from the company s assumptions are accumulated and amortized over future periods and therefore generally affect its recognized expense and accrued liability in such future periods.
889331_17_ITEM8_P47_S3	While the company believes that its assumptions are appropriate given current economic conditions and its actual experience, significant differences in results or significant changes in the company s assumptions may materially affect its pension obligations and related future expense.
889331_17_ITEM8_P47_S4	During 2015, the company terminated the U.S. defined benefit pension plan which resulted in a settlement of the plan s liabilities resulting in a pre-tax charge of $29.9 million.
889331_17_ITEM8_P47_S5	See Note 10, Benefit Plans , for additional information.
889331_17_ITEM8_P48_S0	The company recognizes revenue on product sales in the period in which the sales process is complete.
889331_17_ITEM8_P48_S1	This generally occurs when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, products are shipped (FOB origin) to the customer in accordance with the terms of the sale, the risk of loss has been transferred, collectability is reasonably assured, and the pricing is fixed and determinable.
889331_17_ITEM8_P49_S0	At the end of each period, for those shipments where title to the products and the risk of loss and rewards of ownership do not transfer until the product has been received by the customer, the company adjusts revenues and cost of sales for the delay between the time that the products are shipped and when they are received by the customer.
889331_17_ITEM8_P50_S0	The company s distribution channels are primarily through direct sales and independent third party distributors.
889331_17_ITEM8_P51_S0	The company accepts orders from customers based on long term purchasing contracts and written sales agreements.
889331_17_ITEM8_P51_S1	Contract pricing and selling agreement terms are based on market factors, costs, and competition.
889331_17_ITEM8_P51_S2	Pricing normally is negotiated as an adjustment (premium or discount) from the company s published price lists.
889331_17_ITEM8_P51_S3	The customer is invoiced when the company s products are shipped to them in accordance with the terms of the sales agreement.
889331_17_ITEM8_P52_S0	the ability to receive price adjustments on products previously shipped and invoiced.
889331_17_ITEM8_P52_S1	This practice is common in the industry and is referred to as a ship and debit program.
889331_17_ITEM8_P52_S2	This program allows the distributor to debit the company for the difference between the distributors contracted price and a lower price for specific transactions.
889331_17_ITEM8_P53_S0	Under certain circumstances (usually in a competitive situation or large volume opportunity), a distributor will request authorization to reduce its price to its buyer.
889331_17_ITEM8_P53_S1	If the company approves such a reduction, the distributor is authorized to debit its account for the difference between the contracted price and the lower approved price.
889331_17_ITEM8_P53_S2	The company establishes reserves for this program based on historic activity and actual authorizations for the debit and recognizes these debits as a reduction of revenue.
889331_17_ITEM8_P54_S0	The company has a return to stock policy whereby a customer with prior authorization from Littelfuse management can return previously purchased goods for full or partial credit.
889331_17_ITEM8_P54_S1	The company establishes an estimated allowance for these returns based on historic activity.
889331_17_ITEM8_P54_S2	Sales revenue and cost of sales are reduced to anticipate estimated returns.
889331_17_ITEM8_P55_S0	The company offers incentives to certain customers to achieve specific quarterly or annual sales targets.
889331_17_ITEM8_P55_S1	If customers achieve their sales targets, they are entitled to rebates.
889331_17_ITEM8_P55_S2	The company estimates the future cost of these rebates and recognizes this estimated cost as a reduction to revenue as products are sold.
889331_17_ITEM8_P56_S0	The company evaluates the collectability of its trade receivables based on a combination of factors.
889331_17_ITEM8_P56_S1	The company regularly analyzes its significant customer accounts and, when the company becomes aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the company records a specific reserve for bad debt to reduce the related receivable to the amount the company reasonably believes is collectible.
889331_17_ITEM8_P56_S2	The company also records allowances for all other customers based on a variety of factors including the length of time the receivables are past due, the financial health of the customer, macroeconomic considerations and past experience.
889331_17_ITEM8_P56_S3	Accounts receivable balances that are deemed to be uncollectible, are written off against the reserve on a case-by-case basis.
889331_17_ITEM8_P57_S0	Historically, the allowance for doubtful accounts has been adequate to cover bad debts.
889331_17_ITEM8_P57_S1	If circumstances related to specific customers change, the estimates of the recoverability of receivables could be further adjusted.
889331_17_ITEM8_P57_S2	However, due to the company s diverse customer base and lack of credit concentration, the company does not believe its estimates would be materially impacted by changes in its assumptions.
889331_17_ITEM8_P58_S0	The company expenses advertising costs as incurred, which amounted to $2.9 million, $2.3 million, and $2.8 million in 2016, 2015, and 2014, respectively, and are included as a component of selling, general, and administrative expenses.
889331_17_ITEM8_P59_S0	Amounts billed to customers related to shipping and handling is classified as revenue.
889331_17_ITEM8_P59_S1	Costs incurred for shipping and handling of $9.1 million $7.0 million, and $6.7 million in 2016, 2015, and 2014, respectively, are classified in selling, general, and administrative expenses.
889331_17_ITEM8_P60_S0	The company s foreign subsidiaries use the local currency or the U.S. dollar as their functional currency, as appropriate.
889331_17_ITEM8_P60_S1	Assets and liabilities are translated using exchange rates at the balance sheet date, and revenues and expenses are translated at weighted average rates.
889331_17_ITEM8_P60_S2	The amount of foreign currency gain or loss from remeasurement recognized in the income statement was a loss of $0.5 million in 2016, a gain of $1.5 million in 2015, and a loss of $3.9 million in 2014.
889331_17_ITEM8_P60_S3	Adjustments from the translation process are recognized in Shareholders equity as a component of Accumulated other comprehensive income.
889331_17_ITEM8_P61_S0	The company recognizes compensation expense for the cost of awards of equity compensation using a fair value method.
889331_17_ITEM8_P61_S1	Benefits of tax deductions in excess of recognized compensation expense are reported as both operating and financing cash flows.
889331_17_ITEM8_P61_S2	See Note 11, Shareholders Equity , for additional information on stock-based compensation.
889331_17_ITEM8_P62_S0	Included in other long-term liabilities is an accrual related to former coal mining operations at Littelfuse GmbH (formerly known as Heinrich Industries, AG) for the amounts of 1.4 million ($1.5 million) and 1.8 million ($2.0 million) at December 31, 2016 and January 2, 2016, respectively.
889331_17_ITEM8_P63_S0	Management, in conjunction with an independent third-party, performs an annual evaluation of the former coal mining operations in order to develop an estimate of the probable future obligations in regard to remediating the dangers (such as a shaft collapse) of abandoned coal mine shafts in the former coal mining operations.
889331_17_ITEM8_P63_S1	Management accrues for costs associated with such remediation efforts based on management's best estimate when such costs are probable and reasonably able to be estimated.
889331_17_ITEM8_P63_S2	The ultimate determination can only be done after respective investigations because the concrete conditions are mostly unknown at this time.
889331_17_ITEM8_P63_S3	The accrual is not discounted as management cannot reasonably estimate when such remediation efforts will take place.
889331_17_ITEM8_P64_S0	Other expense (income), net generally consists of interest income, royalties, and non-operating income.
889331_17_ITEM8_P65_S0	The company accounts for income taxes using the liability method.
889331_17_ITEM8_P66_S0	Deferred taxes are recognized for the future effects of temporary differences between financial and income tax reporting using enacted tax rates in effect for the years in which the differences are expected to reverse.
889331_17_ITEM8_P66_S1	The company recognizes deferred taxes for temporary differences, operating loss carryforwards and tax credit carryforwards.
889331_17_ITEM8_P66_S2	Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if it is more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
889331_17_ITEM8_P67_S0	Federal and state income taxes are provided on the portion of foreign income that is expected to be remitted to the U.S. and be taxable.
889331_17_ITEM8_P68_S0	Certain amounts presented in the 2015 financial statements have been reclassified to conform to the 2016 presentation.
889331_17_ITEM8_P69_S0	No. 2015-03, Interest - Imputation of Interest (Subtopic 835-30): Simplifying the Presentation of Debt Issuance Costs.
889331_17_ITEM8_P69_S1	The amendments in this ASU require that debt issuance costs related to a recognized debt liability be presented in the balance sheet as a direct deduction from the carrying amount of that debt liability, consistent with debt discounts.
889331_17_ITEM8_P69_S2	The amended guidance is effective for financial statements issued for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2015, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
889331_17_ITEM8_P69_S3	The amended guidance is to be applied on a retrospective basis.
889331_17_ITEM8_P69_S4	The company adopted the new guidance on January 3, 2016 and has made the corresponding reclassification on its balance sheet for the fiscal year ended January 2, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM8_P69_S5	The adoption of the new guidance had no effect on the company s net income, cash flows or shareholders equity.
889331_17_ITEM8_P69_S6	Additionally, the company has reclassified a portion of its current tax position at January 2, 2016 to more accurately reflect its prepaid/liability position at a jurisdictional level.
889331_17_ITEM8_P70_S0	This ASU provides a single comprehensive model for entities to use in accounting for revenue arising from contracts with customers and will supersede most current revenue recognition guidance.
889331_17_ITEM8_P70_S1	The guidance permits two implementation approaches, one requiring retrospective application of the new standard with restatement of prior years and one requiring prospective application of the new standard with disclosure of results under old standards.
889331_17_ITEM8_P71_S0	In August, 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-14, which postponed the effective date of ASU No. 2014-09 to fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2017, with early adoption permitted on the original effective date of fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2016.
889331_17_ITEM8_P71_S1	The company is in the process of performing its initial assessment of the potential impact on its consolidated financial statements and has not concluded on its adoption methodology.
889331_17_ITEM8_P71_S2	While the company is currently assessing the impact of the new standards, the company s revenue is primarily generated from the sale of finished products to customers.
889331_17_ITEM8_P71_S3	Those sales predominantly contain a single delivery element and revenue is recognized at a single point in time when ownership, risks, and rewards transfer.
889331_17_ITEM8_P71_S4	These are largely un-affected by the new standard.
889331_17_ITEM8_P71_S5	The company does not expect this new guidance to have a material impact on the amount of overall sales recognized; however, the timing of sales on certain projects may be affected.
889331_17_ITEM8_P71_S6	The company has not yet quantified this potential impact.
889331_17_ITEM8_P72_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-02, "Leases" (Topic 842).
889331_17_ITEM8_P72_S1	This ASU requires lessees to recognize, on the balance sheet, assets and liabilities for the rights and obligations created by leases of greater than twelve months.
889331_17_ITEM8_P72_S2	The accounting by lessors will remain largely unchanged.
889331_17_ITEM8_P73_S0	The ASU is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2018, with early adoption permitted.
889331_17_ITEM8_P73_S1	Adoption will require a modified retrospective transition.
889331_17_ITEM8_P73_S2	The company is currently evaluating the impact of this ASU on its consolidated financial statements.
889331_17_ITEM8_P74_S0	In January 2017, the FASB issued ASU No. 2017-04, Intangibles-Goodwill and Other (Topic 350).
889331_17_ITEM8_P74_S1	This ASU modifies the concept of impairment from the condition that exists when the carrying amount of goodwill exceeds its implied fair value to the condition that exists when the carrying amount of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value.
889331_17_ITEM8_P74_S2	An entity no longer will determine goodwill impairment by calculating the implied fair value of goodwill by assigning the fair value of a reporting unit to all of its assets and liabilities as if that reporting unit had been acquired in a business combination.
889331_17_ITEM8_P74_S3	Because the update will eliminate Step 2 from the goodwill impairment test, it should reduce the cost and complexity of evaluating goodwill for impairment.
889331_17_ITEM8_P74_S4	This ASU is effective for annual or any interim goodwill impairment tests in fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2020, with early adoption is permitted for interim or annual goodwill impairment tests performed on testing dates after January 1, 2017.
889331_17_ITEM8_P75_S0	In the second quarter of 2016, management determined that the company may incur additional income taxes and interest in a foreign jurisdiction with respect to the 2011 through 2015 fiscal years.
889331_17_ITEM8_P75_S1	The cumulative adjustment for this income tax (including interest of $1.5 million) as of January 2, 2016, is approximately $4.9 million.
889331_17_ITEM8_P75_S2	The adjustment applicable to 2015, 2014, 2013, 2012, and 2011 was $1.6 million, $1.3 million, $1.0 million, $0.9 million, and $0.1 million, respectively.
889331_17_ITEM8_P76_S0	Pursuant to the guidance of Staff Accounting Bulletin ("SAB") No. 99, Materiality, the company concluded that the errors were not material to any of its applicable prior period annual and quarterly financial statements.
889331_17_ITEM8_P77_S0	Considering the Effects of Prior Year Misstatements when Quantifying Misstatements in Current Year Financial Statements, due to the significance of the out-of-period correction.
889331_17_ITEM8_P77_S1	The adjustment for each year has been treated as applicable to the fourth quarter of each year.
889331_17_ITEM8_P78_S0	The following is a reconciliation of the effects of the adjustments to the previously reported balance sheet at January 2, 2016 follows:

889331_17_ITEM8_P83_S0	The company accounts for acquisitions using the acquisition method in accordance with ASC 805, Business Combinations, in which assets acquired and liabilities assumed are recorded at fair value as of the date of acquisition.
889331_17_ITEM8_P83_S1	The operating results of the acquired business are included in the company s consolidated financial statements from the date of the acquisition.
889331_17_ITEM8_P84_S0	On August 29, 2016, the company acquired certain assets of select businesses (the ON Portfolio ) of ON Semiconductor Corporation for $104.0 million.
889331_17_ITEM8_P84_S1	The company funded the acquisition with available cash and proceeds from its credit facility .
889331_17_ITEM8_P84_S2	The acquired business, which is included in the Electronics segment, consists of a product portfolio that includes transient voltage suppression ( TVS ) diodes, switching thyristors and insulated gate bipolar transistors ( IGBTs ) for automotive ignition applications.
889331_17_ITEM8_P84_S3	The acquisition expands the company s offerings in power semiconductor applications as well as increases its presence in the automotive electronics market.
889331_17_ITEM8_P84_S4	The ON Portfolio products have strong synergies with the company s existing circuit protection business and will strengthen its channel partnerships and customer engagement.
889331_17_ITEM8_P85_S0	The following table summarizes the purchase price allocation of the fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed in the ON Portfolio acquisition:
889331_17_ITEM8_P86_S0	All the ON Portfolio business goodwill and other assets were recorded in the Electronics segment and are reflected in the Americas and Europe geographic areas.
889331_17_ITEM8_P86_S1	The customer relationships are being amortized over 13.5 years.
889331_17_ITEM8_P86_S2	The patented and unpatented technologies are being amortized over 6-8.5 years.
889331_17_ITEM8_P86_S3	The non-compete agreement is being amortized over 4 years.
889331_17_ITEM8_P86_S4	The goodwill resulting from this acquisition consists largely of the company s expected future product sales and synergies from combining the ON Portfolio products with the company s existing power semiconductor product portfolio.
889331_17_ITEM8_P86_S5	$7.3 million of goodwill for the above acquisition is expected to be deductible for tax purposes.
889331_17_ITEM8_P87_S0	As required by purchase accounting rules, the company recorded a $0.7 million step-up of inventory to its fair value as of the acquisition date based on the preliminary valuation.
889331_17_ITEM8_P87_S1	All of the step-up was amortized as a non-cash charge to cost of goods sold during 2016, as the acquired inventory was sold, and reflected as other non-segment costs.
889331_17_ITEM8_P88_S0	Included in the company s consolidated statement of net income for the year ended December 31, 2016 are net sales of approximately $21.8 million since the August 29, 2016 acquisition of the ON Portfolio business.
889331_17_ITEM8_P89_S0	On April 4, 2016, the company completed the acquisition of Menber s S.p.A.
889331_17_ITEM8_P89_S1	( Menber s ) headquartered in Legnago, Italy for $19.2 million, net of acquired cash and after settlement of a working capital adjustment.
889331_17_ITEM8_P89_S2	The company funded the acquisition with cash on hand and borrowings under the company s revolving credit facility.
889331_17_ITEM8_P89_S3	The acquired business is part of the company's commercial vehicle product business within the Automotive segment and specializes in the design, manufacturing, and selling of manual and electrical high current switches and trailer connectors for commercial vehicles.
889331_17_ITEM8_P89_S4	The acquisition expands the company s commercial vehicle products business globally.

889331_17_ITEM8_P91_S2	The patented and unpatented technologies are being amortized over 5 years.
889331_17_ITEM8_P91_S3	The trademarks and tradenames are being amortized over 10 years.
889331_17_ITEM8_P91_S4	The goodwill resulting from this acquisition consists largely of the company s expected future product sales and synergies from combining Menber s products with the company s existing automotive product portfolio.
889331_17_ITEM8_P91_S5	Goodwill for the above acquisition is not expected to be deductible for tax purposes.

889331_17_ITEM8_P93_S0	Included in the company s consolidated statements of net income for the year ended December 31, 2016 are net sales of approximately $17.3 million since the April 4, 2016 acquisition of Menber s.
889331_17_ITEM8_P94_S0	On March 25, 2016, the company acquired 100% of the circuit protection business ( PolySwitch ) of TE Connectivity Ltd. for $348.3 million, net of acquired cash and after settlement of certain post-closing adjustments.
889331_17_ITEM8_P94_S1	At December 31, 2016, $344.5 million of the $348.3 million purchase price has been paid with the remaining consideration expected to be paid by the second quarter of 2017.
889331_17_ITEM8_P94_S2	The company funded the acquisition with available cash on hand and borrowings under the company s revolving credit facility.
889331_17_ITEM8_P95_S0	The PolySwitch business, which is split between the Automotive and Electronics segments, has a leading position in polymer based resettable circuit protection devices, with a strong global presence in the automotive, battery, industrial, communications and mobile computing markets.
889331_17_ITEM8_P95_S1	PolySwitch has manufacturing facilities in Shanghai and Kunshan, China and Tsukuba, Japan.
889331_17_ITEM8_P95_S2	The acquisition allows the company to strengthen its global circuit protection product portfolio, as well as strengthen its presence in the automotive electronics and battery end markets.
889331_17_ITEM8_P95_S3	The acquisition also significantly increases the company s presence in Japan.
889331_17_ITEM8_P96_S0	The following table summarizes the purchase price allocation of the fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed in the PolySwitch acquisition:

889331_17_ITEM8_P97_S1	The customer relationships are being amortized over 15 years.
889331_17_ITEM8_P97_S2	The patented and unpatented technologies are being amortized over 10 years.
889331_17_ITEM8_P97_S3	The goodwill resulting from this acquisition consists largely of the company s expected future product sales and synergies from combining PolySwitch products with the company s existing automotive and electronics product portfolio.
889331_17_ITEM8_P97_S4	$103.8 million and $61.3 million of the goodwill for the above acquisition has been assigned to the Electronics and Automotive segments, respectively, with $64.9 million expected to be deductible for tax purposes.
889331_17_ITEM8_P98_S0	As required by purchase accounting rules, the company recorded a $6.9 million step-up of inventory to its fair value as of the acquisition date based on the preliminary valuation.
889331_17_ITEM8_P98_S1	The step-up was amortized as a non-cash charge to cost of goods sold during the second quarter of 2016, as the acquired inventory was sold, and reflected as other non-segment costs.
889331_17_ITEM8_P99_S0	Included in the company s consolidated statements of net income for the year ended December 31, 2016 are net sales of approximately $126.5 million since the March 25, 2016 acquisition of PolySwitch.
889331_17_ITEM8_P100_S0	On October 1, 2015, the company acquired 100% of Sigmar S.r.l.
889331_17_ITEM8_P100_S1	The total purchase price for Sigmar was $6.5 million, net of cash acquired and including estimated additional net payments of up to $0.9 million, a portion of which is subject to the achievement of certain milestones.
889331_17_ITEM8_P101_S0	Located in Ozegna, Italy, Sigmar is a leading global manufacturer of water-in-fuel sensors and also manufactures selective catalytic reduction ( SCR ) quality sensors and diesel fuel heaters for automotive and commercial vehicle applications.
889331_17_ITEM8_P101_S1	The acquisition further expanded the company s automotive sensor product line offerings within its Automotive segment.
